Further, a board resolution has been passed and shareholder?s approval has been sought for promoters to additionally infuse INR 250 crore to support the operations and timely pay off its liabilities. The group will to continue to benefit from the resourceful promoters which is expected to provide a certain degree of comfort on the financial flexibility of the group.

The Company has an operational track record of more than three decades and has survived economic and business cycles. The Company is currently led by Mr. Parag Vinod Jhaveri, Managing Director, who has chemical industry experience of more than two decades and has done his master?s degree in science. Other director?s viz. Mr Nilesh V Jhaveri & Mr Yayesh V Jhaveri and managerial team of the Company too have extensive chemical industry experiences and has sound educational background.

Furthermore, the management?s knowledge on the industry dynamics with extensive experience of three decades has helped the Company to develop strong business relations with its customers and suppliers enabling it to bag repeat orders and ease in sourcing of materials from customers and suppliers respectively. The Company registered a strong growth in topline in FY 2018 and FY 2019.
Thus, long standing experience of the Company and extensive management experience is expected to support the Company?s business growth.
Reputed customer base and wide product range catering to diverse industries

The Company is engaged in manufacturing of wide range of specialty and fine chemicals. These chemicals find application in different industries and the Company caters to a clientele of diverse industries like food industry, fast-moving consumer goods industry (FMCG industry), flavors and fragrances industry, rubber industry and petroleum industry, etc. Aroma Chemicals are mainly relating to Personal Care Products, Cosmetics & Toiletries segment. Food Antioxidants are used in a wide range of Food Blends and also in order to prevent Rancidity in Edible Oil and other Food Preparations and increase shelf life. Lube Chemicals are generally meant for Petroleum and Synthetic Lubricants industry. Specialty Chemicals are used in different segment of industry such as Electroplating chemicals, Intermediates for API/Bulk Drugs etc.

Further, being in the industry for more than 3 decade, the Company has been able to garner large customer portfolio and distribution network in both domestic as well as international market. The customers of the Company includes reputed companies like Madras Rubber Factory Limited (India), H. Reynaud & Fils (France), Akrochem Corporation (USA), Covestro Deutschland AG (Germany) and Kemin Food Technologies Inc. (USA), etc. Reputed clientele coupled with diversified industry base provides sustained revenue visibility to the Company along with prompt debtor?s realization. This also partially mitigates concentration risk as a slowdown in demand from any one of these industries / customers may be offset by growth in other industries, thus maintaining the overall topline and profitability of the Company.
Improving returns year on year on back of healthy revenue growth

The Company grew at a high CAGR of 31% in the last three year review period. The net cash accruals improved from INR 8.8 crores in FY 2017 to INR 19 crores in FY 2019 on back of its high revenue growth. High accretion to reserves resulted in the increase in the net worth of the Company (increased from INR 17.30 crore in FY 2017 to INR 45.80 crore in FY 2019). This has improved returns indicating optimal utilization of the funds employed in the business. Company?s ROTNW (Return on Tangible Net Worth) and ROCE (Return on Capital Employed) increased from 24% in FY 2017 to 38% in FY 2019 and from 13% in FY 2017 to 18% in FY 2019 respectively.

Financial profile of the Zycus group remained healthy as marked by a virtually debt free capital structure, adequate liquidity position and increasing scale of operations. Revenue of the Group showed an increasing trend and grew at a CAGR of 52.47% during the five years ending FY 2019. Sustained increase in scale of operations reflects ability of the group to grow through continuous product innovation and strong customer support. In the last two years ending FY 2019, group has undertaken aggressive marketing and added 30 sales personnel to reach out to newer markets, mainly Europe. Its active client base stood at 175 for FY 2019 with new customer additions of 50+ every year. As informed, the group has a contract renewal rate of about 90% on an average. In addition, contracts entered by the Group carry a lock-in of three to five years. Thus, revenue from renewal contracts further supplemented by new software deployments led to a y-o-y increase in revenue.

The Group has negligible reliance on debt funds. The operating cash flows remained positive throughout the review period. The current ratio stood moderate due to high unearned revenues (current liability). Positive cash flows indicate the ability of the Group to manage its working capital requirements, fund investments and organic & inorganic growth opportunities. The Group has liquid assets of INR 33.65 crores including marketable investments of INR 16.51 crores as on 31st March 2019 which further exhibits ready funds availability. Below is the snapshot on the movement of its year end cash balances:

Cash and bank balance declined in FY 2019 and stood the lowest as a percentage of total assets in the last five years as net cash accruals declined on back of decrease in margins and continued high dividend outflow for the year. Also, the group made current advances to the group company to the tune of around INR 5 crore, excluding which current ratio would decline to 1 for FY 2019. The advances and investment made in group companies had affected the year end cash/bank balances/liquid investment as depicted in the above table, however the same has remained at comfortable level.

However, the Group is debt free from last four years ending FY 2019. Also, in FY 2020, as informed, on a provisional basis, the group has achieved a high EBITDA of 22% which would lead to high cash flows for the year. This gives it the necessary financial flexibility in terms of its ability to raise funds from alternate sources in times of further financial requirement like for investing in new technologies, capital expenditure and entry in new markets.
Diversified customer base of reputed companies with high renewal rate

The Group?s active clientele base stood at 175 from diverse industries including manufacturing, automotive, banking and finance, consumer packaged goods, oil and gas, food processing, electronics, telecommunications, chemicals, health, pharma, energy and utilities, retail, insurance and education, etc. Such diversified customer base across industries insures the business from industry specific downturns. Some of the clients of the Group from various industries are reflected in the below table -

Further, the Group primarily caters to large MNCs with billion dollar plus revenues (Largely Fortune 500 companies). Some of the reputed clients of the Group includes Modelez Global LLC, General Electric Company, Tate and Lyle Americas LLC, Linde AG Europe and Sprint. Reputed clientele of large MNCs enables the group to receive recurring orders y-o-y and mitigate debtor?s realization risk. This is evident from the fact that the Group derived close to 90% of the total business through repeat orders. It also indicates that users find significant value in use of these software modules. Moreover, none of the customers contribute more than 20% of the revenue signifying absence of customer concentrated operations. Further, with the Group foraying into newer markets (Europe, Middle East, Asia, etc.), it will enable the group to garner a wide prospective customer base in other segments.

The Group is founded and managed by Mr. Aatish Dedhia ? Chief Executive Officer. He has a bachelor?s degree in technology (B. Tech.) with specialization in electrical engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology, Mumbai (India) and a Master?s degree in Science (M.S.) in electrical engineering from Cornell University, USA. He has more than two decades of relevant experience of IT industry. Prior to founding Zycus, Mr. Aatish worked with Intel Corporation in USA and was part of the core design team for the Pentium-II processor.

Under his leadership, Zycus has turned into a global provider of comprehensive service offerings for the procurement community of large corporates. Continuous focus on product development has enabled the Group to expand its product offerings to cover the entire procurement workflow right from expense analysis to sourcing, supplier management and payment. As informed, around 50% of the customers prefer the entire suite over individual software. This results in customer stickiness and provides a competitive advantage to the Group as it can leverage on its larger gamut of offerings as compared to multiple vendors offering specialized services.

Such extensive experience of the management coupled with technical expertise would facilitate in driving the business of the Group and help it mitigate business risks. This is evident from the reputed clientele the Group has garnered and its y-o-y growth in scale of operations.

The Company?s profitability remained uneven during the review period. Gross profit margins declined in FY 2019 mainly due to increase in raw material and finished goods prices. As informed, the primary raw material of the Company is metals in the form of aluminum, stainless steel and iron, part of which is imported from international market. Given the volatility in the foreign exchange fluctuations due to various macro-economic factors, the Company faces low bargaining power with its customers. However, the raw material cost is linked to global London metal exchange for which the prices are revised quarterly. Also, contracts have an escalation clause for pass through of increase in raw material prices to the customers. Decline in gross margin had an impact on operating and net margins as well. However, this was partly offset by decline in depreciation and tax provision. Along with profit margins, returns of the Company also remained uneven during the review period. Hence, ability of the Company to sustain its margins and returns while increasing its revenue remains critical.

Also, the high net margin as depicted above was supported by the non-operating income mainly in the form of interest income; excluding the same, the net margins would be 4.36% in FY 2019. Therefore, any change in the dividend policy of subsidiaries or reduced investments due to capex/increased working capital requirement could affect the net margins going forward and sustainability of this income remains important.
Note: The tax incidence on profit has not been considered

The Company derives around 75% of the revenue from Turbo Energy Private Limited, TRW Automotive Group and BorgWarner Turbo Systems Group. This exposes the Company to customer concentration risk. Though the group is amongst the auto industry leaders and has a wide reach which partially mitigates the risk, however, any significant decline in demand for the products of these component manufacturers can significantly affect the revenues of the Company. This can be seen from the nearly stagnant growth in FY 2017 and FY 2018, which was because of subdued demand of turbocharger components.
Moderate scale of operations with degrowth in last 2 financial years leading to declining returns on funds employed by the Company

The Company had modest scale of operations marked by topline of INR 550,462 thousand in FY 2019 and reported a degrowth of around 36.28% in FY 2018 and degrowth of around 9.14% in FY 2019. As informed by the management, degrowth in last 2 financial year was owing to strategy adopted by the Company to bid selectively for projects with high priority given to ability to execute the project successfully and profitably. Further, profitability declined at absolute level in FY 2018 and FY 2019, but still remain at healthy level. But in relative terms the same showed an improvement at all levels owing to drastic decline in operating expenses (as the major projects executed were post implementation support) and increase in non-operating income.

Selective bidding and moderation in the order book position have resulted in decline in revenue and profitability in last 2 financial year which further lead to lowering of the return ratios during the period under study.
Also, provisional financials for 3 months ended 30th June 2019 shows a Y-O-Y degrowth of 20.85% in revenue and 53.39% in net profit after tax of the Company.

Further, as informed by the management, company is expecting subdued performance in FY 2020 also, because of state election in Maharashtra which will impact the business of the Company for 2-3 months of the current fiscal.

However, as informed, during the current fiscal, Company has plans to build orderbook of upto INR 500 crore, which will be executed in next 3-5 years. As on September 2019, Company has pending confirmed order book of INR 215 crore and orders worth INR 15 crore for which Company has won the tender, but contracts terms are not finalized yet.
Thus, ability of the Company to improve its topline, while sustaining its margins remains critical.
Large working capital requirements on account of high and fluctuating collection cycle

The operations of the Company have remained working capital intensive driven by its high & fluctuating collection period which ranges from 57 days to 316 days. As informed, collection period depends on the project stage. If majority of revenue in a year is related to projects which are in implementation stage, then collection period is high for that year and if revenue consists majorly of maintenance revenue, then cash inflows are fast and receivables are low. Also, since the Company?s customers are state government, municipality and other government organizations, receivables are high owing to delay in internal approvals. Further, during last 2 financial years, Company has recognized provision for bad debts of around INR 1.13 crore against pending payment from 2 of its customers.
However, as the Company has cash surplus in the system, it manages its working capital requirement through internal funds and does not avail any debt.
Nevertheless, prudent management of working capital remains critical.
High dependency on few service offerings leading to intense competition and shrinking revenues

Although the Company has diversified solution catering capabilities, the revenue is highly dependent on E-municipality solution & SAP implementation solutions. E-municipality solution & SAP implementation solution for government contributed around 40% & 50% respectively to the total revenues in FY 2019. Although, the Company has increased its focus on various other offerings like smart city solutions, smart water management solutions, cyber security solutions, tax reforms solutions etc., it has not contributed significantly to the revenue of the Company. Company has 4 smart city projects order in its orderbook, successful execution of the same in coming years might result in reduction in concentration on few service offerings

As informed by the management, lately the competition in this sector has increased significantly with several small and mid-size players bidding for the projects at competitive prices. Entry barriers operating in the sector are considerably weak, primarily due to the easy availability of skilled employees and low amount of investment required for set up. Tender based nature of operations further puts constant pricing pressure on the Company. The Companies with higher topline become favorable choice with their capability to quote lower bids on account of benefits from economies of scale. Specifically, in e-governance domain companies like Tata Consultancy Services Limited, HCL Technologies Limited, Deloitte Consulting India Private Limited, PricewaterhouseCoopers Private Limited, Wipro Limited are competitors of the Company.

As informed, being the cost centric company with greater focus on quality and successful implementation of the project, the management had preferred selective bidding which resulted in decline in scale of operations during last 2 financial years. Also, Company depicted y-o-y degrowth in revenue in Q1 of current fiscal as well. Moreover, management indicated that the scale of operations for current fiscal is expected to remain subdued having an impact on the profitability levels.

The business model of the Company has inherent risk of being entirely dependent on Indian government projects at state/ municipality level with large exposure in state of Maharashtra. Though e-governance is one of the key visions of the government, , the inherent challenges and shortcomings related to infrastructure, bureaucracy, frequent changes in leadership, legal, partial automation and budget driven approach slows down the implementation and completion of the project. This leads to risk like time and cost overruns, delay in payments, disruptions / cancellation of the project, and others.

The Company had witnessed operational as well as financial challenges during the project execution phases like delay in project clearance, poor infrastructure and reluctance from the beneficiaries to adopt the new infrastructure, delay in receivables, change in government policies and government officials. The working capital cycle of the Company was stretched during FY 2015 and FY 2018 owing to significant increase in receivable days. As informed by the management, the stretched receivables were on account of change in billing system of one of its customers from centralized to decentralized accounting and billing which led to extensive paper work and delayed the receivables. Also, the Company had reported a decline in topline by 5.95% in FY 2016 on account of delay in implementation of projects. The above mentioned challenges may have implications on topline growth as well as financial strength of the Company.
Uneven and low profitability during the review period

Revenue de-grew in FY 2015 and remained stagnant till FY 2017 while showcasing growth only in FY 2018. The profitability of the Company exhibited uneven trend and remained low during the review period. In FY 2014, the Company incurred net losses on account of prior period expenditure being more than the profits earned during the year. Further, the increase in revenue coupled with the decline in cost of operations had augmented the profitability of the Company in FY 2016 as compared to previous year FY 2015 as shown in table below. Further, though gross profitability continued to decline in FY 2017 and FY 2018, the net profit margin improved to stand above 1% during these years due to the absence of prior period expenditure in these years. However, despite the improvement, the net profitability has remained low resulting in low returns as depicted in the table below:
Networth erosion owing to land being gifted to its fellow subsidiaries

The networth base of the Company eroded as on 31st March 2017. This erosion is owing to land parcel being gifted to its fellow subsidiaries costing worth INR 2,044,644 thousand. As stated, to align with the group operating structure of having companies engaged in logistics and warehousing business, it decided to gift the land parcels to its fellow subsidiary. Post the above transaction, networth of the Company declined but remained strong at around INR 2,138,707 thousand. A strong networth base is the inherent strength of any company which supplement the business growth. Also, in case of any adverse event companies with strong networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain.
Presence in the generics market characterized by intense competition

The Company is primarily a generic player with no patented drugs. Its research & development efforts also are not targeted towards innovation of new drugs that could give exclusivity rights and thereby provide a stable stream of revenues for a very long period of time. Since the domestic pharmaceutical industry is dominated by generic players, competitive intensity remains very high for a generic version of drugs.

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment with more than 5,600 pharma companies in the country. As informed, the major competitors of the Company are Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Limited for ophthalmic segment; Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Limited for dermatology segment; and Zydus Cadila Limited and Ranbaxy Laboratories Limited for cardiology segment. With even global pharmaceutical companies now increasing their focus on the generic version of drugs, via the acquisition of leading Indian generic companies, the competition gets fueled. The impact could get magnified owing to the Company deriving a large portion of its revenue from therapeutic segments like anti-malarial, ophthalmology, ENT, cardiology, etc. which relatively have higher competition. High competitive intensity could restrict the ability of the Company to scale up its revenues and improve its profitability especially when the Company derives a major portion of its exports from price sensitive market of Africa, Asia, and the domestic market.

Institution sales contributes around 9% to the total revenue in FY 2019. As informed, volumes in institutional business were reduced to half due to cut down of funding by the donor- Global Fund, as a result of which revenue from emerging markets is expected to be impacted by INR 250 crores.

The Group manufactures generic fixed dosage combinations which cater lower margins than patented drugs and/or contract research due to the lesser complexity involved in manufacture and process development of the same. Further, as informed, the segment is highly competitive market and the implementation of GST has further hindered the pricing advantage of the Group over its competitors. Further, there was increase in revenue from trading of raw material in FY 2019. The same has resulted in lower profitability margins during the year.

Also, the Group offers more than 4,000 SKUs. The high number of products require consistent upgrade and review leading to under-utilization of capacity. As a result, the Group?s capacity utilization remains very low at about 10-12%. In addition, with 30.35% growth in revenue in FY 2019, the working capital requirement of the Group has increased substantially through increased receivables. Also, the Group has invested heavily in capital expenditure during the review period as its plant in Guwahati was setup and began commercial operations during this period. This has led to increased investments in the form of both debt as well as equity by the Group.

The moderate profitability and the low utilization has led to moderate return of tangible networth and return on capital employed. Also, with benefits from the Group?s Uttarakhand plants expiring in FY 2020, the Group faces additional challenges in terms of maintaining its profitability. As informed, the Group has already commenced operations in its new facility setup in Guwahati which has similar tax benefits.
Thus, going forward, ability of the Group to improve scale of operations while improving profitability and return indicators remains crucial.

The Company operates as a contract manufacturer in the Indian pharmaceutical industry which encompasses generic formulation manufacturers, API manufacturers and companies providing CRAMS. The industry is fragmented in nature with generic manufacturers enjoying a dominant position. Despite the stringent regulatory environment, which poses an entry barrier, the sector has a large concentration of small and medium sized manufacturing units. Global pharmaceutical companies are beginning to focus on generic versions of drugs by acquiring leading Indian generic companies, which further has increased the competition. Moreover, Indian pharmaceutical companies face a cost disadvantage as compared to China, Korea and Taiwan, which offer low cost manufacturing base. Going forward, increased competition will continue to pose a challenge for growth in both revenue as well as profitability for the Group.
Working capital intensive nature of operations coupled with moderate liquidity

The operations of the Company are working capital intensive in nature as reflected in high inventory days (between 130-155 days) and high receivable days (90 - 96 days). As informed by the management, AEPL is required to hold ~150-days of inventory (including raw material and finished goods inventory) as per tentative schedule provided by customer who requires JIT delivery on actual placement of orders. Further, the Company offers credit period of 60-90 days to its customers. Moreover, the Company, due to ongoing credit issues with suppliers, has had to make prompt payment to suppliers leading to reduced payable days leading to further increase in working capital cycle. While the high working capital requirement is mainly managed through internal cash accruals, supplier credit and working capital borrowings, the incremental requirements as on 31st March 2019 were managed largely through working capital borrowings leading to working capital limit utilization of ~89% as on 31st March 2019.

Furthermore, the current ratio stood moderate supported by high debtors and inventory, collectively amounting to ~88.41% of the current assets on an average during the review period (84.16% in FY 2019). Quick ratio remained subdued throughout the review period on account of high inventory holding. Nevertheless, liquidity to certain extent remained supported by adequate net cash accruals as against the current debt obligations due in FY 2020 (CPLTD). Any further increase in working capital requirements may exert further stress on liquidity position and could constrain Company from scaling up its operations.

As informed, additional working capital requirement arising from increase in scale of operations will be funded through cash accruals obtained from business on a going basis in the absence of any capex requirements in the near future.
Moderate scale of operations in a highly competitive industry

Despite its recent diversification into production of capacitors catering to various new segment, AEPL primarily derived majority of its revenue during the review period through manufacturing aluminum electrolytic capacitors and film capacitors for the power electronics sector. As informed by the management, the Company faces competition from both local and international players. The electronics manufacturing industry is characterized by high cost of raw materials along with low product differentiation and requirement of additional investment based on changes in technology. Thus, efficiencies in this business are obtained from economies of the scale which spread out the fixed costs over a larger base of operations, leading to improvement in profitability. Although, revenue of the Company grew at a CAGR of 17.08% during the review period, its scale of operation remained moderate levels and the revenue grew only by 4.20% in FY 2019 despite having a track record of more than 4 decades. The Company?s moderate scale of operations may act as a constraining factor which may restrict the Company?s ability to secure big orders and thus, in realizing the benefits of economies of scale. Further, The Company also has moderate tangible networth of INR 356,860 thousand as on 31st March 2019. The networth of company indicates its inherent strength. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain. Moderate size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks.

However, as informed by management, the Company is able to compete effectively despite its low scale of operations in a highly competitive industry, due to its focus on customized products which require a high technical ability thus effectively reducing competition from other players.
Intense competition in the industry leading to early commoditization of generic products

The Indian pharmaceutical industry is fragmented with more than 10,000 companies manufacturing drugs catering to a wide range of therapeutic segments. Companies operating in the sector ranges from Indian subsidiaries of multinational drug manufacturers, large and medium sized domestic companies active in generic formulation space and numerous bulk drug manufacturers. In addition, multinational companies have started acquiring / picking up stake / entering into agreement with domestic generic manufacturers to establish presence in fledging generic drug business. The relaxation in FDI cap, which allow upto 100 % FDI into existing pharmaceutical company has eased entry of foreign pharmaceutical firms into Indian market, which has further intensified the industry competitiveness. Moreover, Indian pharma player may face strong competition from China, where the government has been particularly proactive in encouraging foreign investments in pharmaceuticals and biotechnology.

The cut throat competition in the industry has led to price wars, impacting the market share and profitability. With existing and newer companies increasing their expenditure on R&D has led to increase in filing of ANDAs, thus significantly reducing the scope of exclusivity of generics. As seen in FY 2017- FY 2018, the export revenue of the Company has declined on account of price revisions undertaken by the Company on ?day-one? drug which was launched a year earlier. This has resulted in moderation of profitability. However, the Company witnessed healthy y-o-y growth of 23.94% in FY 2019 as the Company was able to capitalize on the shortage of hypertension drug, Valsartan in the USA coupled with 48% increase in international generics segment, 18% increase in API segment, and 9% increase in domestic branded segment.

As informed by the management, though the competition in the market intensifies, however, its strategies to diverse into geographies like Algeria, MENA region and increase its presence in Australia, Canada and Europe will augment its business while easing out the pressure on margins. Also, the Company has forayed in dermatology and oncology segments where it foresees tremendous growth. For domestic market, the Company has strategically shifted its product base from acute to chronic therapeutic segment where margins are better. Also, the disciplinary and compliance driven approach of the Company has assisted in quicker approvals of ANDAs and the facilities of the Company are approved by various regulatory bodies which helps in commercialization of its products without any regulatory hurdles. With robust product pipeline and strong networth base, the Company is planning to file 20 to 25 ANDAs each year in next few years (starting from FY 2018). Thus, the diversification and growth plans of the Company together with strong product pipeline would augment the business of the Company as well as assist in generating sustainable margins.
Government policies having a bearing on the domestic pharmaceutical industry
The Indian pharmaceutical industry has been impacted by an unprecedented series of policy changes during the previous financial years.

The Government introduced the new Pricing Policy with the notification of the Drugs (Prices Control) Order, 2013 (DPCO 2013) which brought 728 formulations in the National List of Essential Medicines (NLEM) under price control. However, the issues with trade over demand for trade margins and wider interpretation of the DPCO by the NPPA, bringing additional medicines under price control, meant an unexpected interruption in business and an adverse revenue and profit impact on the Industry. Also based on Niti Aayog observations the government is planning to launch a benchmark price index for drugs that will decide the prices of all medicines in India. This index will also replace the existing WPI index that is currently used to regulate drug prices. Moreover, the new pricing regime, once in effect, will also dictate the prices of those drugs that are currently outside the ambit of the present regulations. This pricing mandate will thus affect the pharmaceutical sector margins and revenues from the domestic market.

During November 2016, the Government of India had declared demonetization of high valued currencies which left the industry in loads of hazels. Though this move was taken to eliminate corruption, it led to a trail of effect on the medicine supplying domain. This has disrupted pharma market temporarily as distributors resorted to de-stocking inventory. As informed, the last quarter of FY 2017 was marginally impacted on account of demonetization.

Further, the domestic growth of the Company had significant bearing of these events and the expected topline growth rate of 15% for FY 2017 was almost halved to around 7% recorded by the Company in the similar period.

Drugstores in the United States typically generate revenues by selling prescription drugs, over-the-counter medications, health and beauty products, and general merchandise. However, recently there is a trend of retail pharmacies acquiring medical clinics and pharmacy benefit management (PBM) companies (which process prescriptions for corporations and insurance companies, and negotiate prices with drug manufacturers and retailers). The generic pharmaceutical manufacturers from India typically count a major of these players as their customers.
Low and uneven profitability albeit strong revenue growth

Although the Company experienced strong revenue during the review period the profit margins of the Company have depicted stagnancy and staggering trend as can be seen in the table below. The net margins of the Company remained low (below 1%) during the review period owing to trading nature of business with a large part of the product portfolio being commoditized in nature. Commodity chemicals or bulk chemicals are less complex than value added chemicals and generate lower profitability compared to specialty chemicals. Further, the dip in margins at gross levels despite revenue growth were primarily on account of increase of purchases cost as a percentage of revenue, indicating that the Company is not effectively been able to pass on the incremental cost to its customers, primarily on account of nature of products traded and the stiff competition. However, the limited dip in operating margin in FY 2018 and subsequent improvement in FY 2019 is an indicator that the Company is deriving benefits of scale with the topline growth. Moreover, net profitability on excluding non-operating income would be further constrained as interest income and tax refund accounted for ~0.30% of revenue during the review period.

However, the Company has added wood based premium products such as veneer to its trading portfolio to support its bottom line. It already has a showroom in Mumbai for the same and plans to set-up another one in the medium term. However, currently, the share of wood based premium products to its total revenue is minimal.
Working capital intensive operations putting pressure on liquidity coupled with moderate tangible networth

Major part of working capital of the Company was funded by payables which resulted in high outside liabilities to tangible networth. Its payables on an average during the review period stood at 96.47% of the current liabilities coupled with a moderate tangible networth of INR 136,692 thousand in FY 2019. This resulted in significantly high total current liabilities to tangible networth at over 5.22 times in FY 2019 indicating that the Company has used significant portion of its net worth as a lever to raise outside funds and relies heavily on creditors to fund the working capital operations. As the Company demonstrated revenue growth of over 30% during the review period, the inventory of traded goods and receivables also increased resulting in negative cash flow from operations in FY 2018 and FY 2017. However, the Company has unutilized working capital limits as average cash credit utilization stands below 30-40% per annum which provides a cushion to the overall liquidity position.

Further, the moderate tangible networth has also impacted the capital structure which stood at 2.27 times as on 31st March 2019. However, the majority of the Company?s debt is skewed towards unsecured loans from related parties and directors. Accordingly, the adjusted gearing stands adequate at 0.56 times as on 31st March 2019. The unsecured loans carry an interest rate of 9.00% per annum. Therefore, with low-interest cost on unsecured loans and low cash credit utilization, the interest coverage of the Company depicted an increasing trend and stood moderate at 2.55 times in FY 2018. However, with the contraction in profits at EBIT level resulted in a deteriorating interest coverage ratio and stood lowest at 1.95% indicating further restraints on debt serviceability. Further, if the credit terms undergo a revision the short term solvency of the Company will be highly constrained. Hence it remains vital for the Company to continue managing its working capital requirement prudently.

The Company derives its entire revenue from the domestic market, while 25% of procurement of goods for trading is done from various overseas counties. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, inflow/outflow of foreign investment in/out from the domestic markets, domestic inflation, and deterioration in the financial condition of other economies, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Therefore, adverse movement in exchange rates could adversely affect the profitability and liquidity position of the Company. As informed, the Company takes up hedging of outstanding positions on a regular basis. As informed, the purchase cost of all foreign exchange purchase is scaled up by 6% per annum as per their payment date. Any positive or negative balance is transferred to rate difference account. This is a part of the Company?s purchase cost. This is no income or loss as such there is very limited foreign exchange risk. Also, the Company maintains a very limited inventory. These factors mitigate foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk to a significant extent.
Despite improvement in scale of operations profit margins have remained limited

Despite recovering from the revenue growth deterioration in FY 2016 and FY 2017 and registering ~20% in FY 2018 and FY 2019, the profit margins of the Company went for a tailspin during the same period. The gross profit margin dipped y-o-y from 19.09% in FY 2016 to 6.97% in FY 2019. The operating profit margin of the Company exhibited a similar trend and dipped sharply from FY 2016 to FY 2019. Further, despite improvement in the revenue of the Company in FY 2018 and FY 2019 profit margin at the operating level continued to deteriorate and the dip in margin was higher than the dip in gross margin indicating that the Company is yet to completely achieve operational efficiency. Also, the net profit margin of the Company to an extent was supported by income from non-operating sources and positive previous year tax adjustment (FY 2019), without these income and adjustments the Company would exhibited lower net profits margins and the net profit margins would have remained lower than operating profits; as seen in the table below. Going forward with the Company achieving better revenue growth will enable it to fully and better utilize its operational capacity, thereby improving its margin at operating and net levels with the benefit of the economies of scale. As informed, profitability of the Company remained low owing to market condition not being conducive and also, pricing pressure from the customers along with increased competition. The Company intends to improve the profitability going ahead as the market conditions have improved and it can revise its price in the upward trend.

Further, limited profitability has resulted in modest returns indicating lesser income for the investment made, as depicted in the table below. Going forward, with improvement in the scale of operations coupled with improved margins will improve the return indicators. However, addressing the needs for future investment while scaling up operations will dictate the overall return indicators for the Company.

The working capital cycle of the Company was intensive on account of stretched collection days and high inventory holding, it fluctuated in a range of 102 to 142 days. The Collection days albeit showing improvement in FY 2019 has exhibited a cyclical trend and went high as 103 days in FY 2018. The inventory holding of the Company continued to increase during the review period and increased from 57 days in FY 2016 to 84 days in FY 2019. Further ~67% of the current assets of the company comprised of debtors and inventory indicating a fairly high blockage of funds in these assets stressing the smooth fund flow in working capital management. Further, this trend has increased from FY 2017 onwards and stood high at 76.39% in FY 2019. Although, the Company has largely been able to manage its working capital requirement through internal accruals and with working capital facilities from bank. However, any further increase in working capital requirements would result in an increase in borrowings and may affect the gearing of the Company. Hence going forward, it would remain crucial for the Company to prudently manage its working capital requirement to avoid contingencies in the short term.

Majority of the Company?s revenue (more than 75% of revenue in FY 2019) is derived from oil & gas industry. Indications of a slowdown in global economy and oil supply glut have led to a slump in oil prices. Oil exploration expenditures had dropped 60% from 2014 to 2017. This coupled with dip in oil prices led to a de-growth in exploration sector, further impacting the Company?s top line (depicted by a decline of 9.05% in FY 2016 and further decline of 11.92% in FY 2017). Although, the oil prices have picked up since FY 2017, the uncertainty towards future trend still remains as seen in the continued volatility in oil prices. The Company?s high dependency on oil & gas sector creates a risk of low offtake if the industry going forward witnesses downshifts in demand. Considering the slowdown in the oil & gas exploration industry and the Company?s major reliance on it, the Company?s revenue will be under stress until it diversifies its end user industrial base.

As of FY 2019 Company derived around ~53% of its revenue from its top 5 customer namely Samson AG. Mess Und Regeltechnik (21.62%), Xomox International Gmbh & Co. OHG, Phonix Armaturen-werke Bregel GmbH, Leser Gmbh & Co. Kg and Braunschweiger Flammenfilter Gmbh; exposing itself to customer concentration risk. Any significant downturn in the demand for products of these customers can significantly affect the revenue of this Company. However, the Company has established business relationship with these customers for more than 17 years which partly mitigates the risk. Nevertheless, diversification of clientele base remains critical. Further all its top customers are based in Germany and cumulatively earning 60% of its revenue from Germany exposing it to geographical concentration risk, which makes the Company highly susceptible to any economic slowdown or adverse event in the country. Also, the Company has taken initiatives to diversify into countries such as Russia, Middle East and China.
Low profitability and returns given the limited pricing flexibility due to high competition

The Company operates in a highly competitive market resulting in pricing pressure. The industry is highly fragmented with presence of large number of unorganised players and few organised players. Some of the other players operating in the menthol industry are Sharp Mint Limited, KV Aromatics Private Limited, Swati Menthol and Allied Chemicals Limited and others. Also, there is high competition from the Chinese companies in international market and to compete on the pricing front, many end users are now resorting to Chinese products. Low value addition in processing activities and its limited ability to pass on the price rise to customers has resulted in low margins for the period under study. Further, the Company also trades in essential oils which inherently has lower margins.

Despite y-o-y growth in the revenue, its profitability has remained low till FY 2018. The Company enters into contracts with customers from six months to three years and given the volatile raw material prices and limited pass through contracts with customers, the margins have remained low. However, improvement in gross margins is reflected during FY 2019 primarily due to substantial growth in revenue which almost doubled. The operating margins of the Company were further supported through increase in duty drawback and other incentives during the same period which led to improvement in net margins as well as return indicators. Returns on capital employed was in the range of 5% to 29% over the five-year period ending FY 2019.
Further given the intense competition in the industry, it remains critical for the Company to improve its profit margins and returns while maintaining its revenue growth over the medium term.

The Company is into trading of aromatic ingredients and operates on a stock and sell method. It maintains an inventory equivalent to 2-2.5 months at any given point of time. Further, the Company offers credit period of 45-60 days to its customers. As against these, receivable days fluctuated between 84-93 days leading to high working capital requirements. Together, these lead to large working capital requirement. Till FY 2019, the working capital requirement was managed through short term working capital facility from bank, unsecured loans from promoters and payables to creditors which ranged between 40-71 days during the three year period ending 31st March 2019. However, as informed, the Company has repaid most of the availed short term loans and as on date manages its working capital requirements mainly through internal accruals and payables to creditors. Going forward, prudent working capital management will continue to be a priority for the Company.
Limited bargaining power with the principals/suppliers and customers owing to trading nature of operations

The Company is associated with around 90 suppliers and has a large customer base of over 800 customers. Being a trader, the Company?s core strength lies in making the products available in desired quantity and timeline as required by the customer. This requires the Company to maintain traded goods inventory at all times. Further, the product prices are largely market driven and the Company thus has limited bargaining power with both its suppliers and customers. In case of market volatility, the Company?s revenues and margins are both expected to get impacted.
Moderate scale of operations vs players in domestic market

Though, the Company?s is in the process of rapidly establishing its presence in the market recording good revenue growth rate (CAGR of ~155% during the period from FY 2016 to FY 2019), the scale of operations and tangible networth remained moderate. Moderate size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. Company?s moderate scale of operations acts as a constraining factor in realizing the benefits of economies of scale. The networth of the Company indicates the inherent strength of the concerned Company. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain.
Modest liquidity profile on the back of moderate solvency ratio

Since Besten is in the business of engineering and architectural related services, the operations are not highly working capital intensive in nature unlike the manufacturing operations and are thus largely linked to changes in collection period. However, the Company?s major short-term obligations comprise creditor for expenses and statutory obligations (together accounted for 82% of total current liabilities on an average). The Company?s core current asset comprised receivables and cash when compared with its core current liabilities has constrained liquidity as witnessed in low current ratio during the review period. Current ratio improved during FY 2019 mainly driven by increase in receivables and cash with no significant increase in current liabilities. However, increase in receivables have also led to higher collection days/working capital days which stood at 80 days during FY 2019. Hence any stretch in collection cycle could constrain liquidity position and result into delays in servicing the current liabilities as well as funding day-to-day operations.

Modest liquidity position can pose a serious risk in the short-term liquidity management and reduce its financial flexibility in short term. Also, the ability of the Company to maintain adequate liquidity in coming years remains crucial as increase in projects will warrant for increased working capital requirement and serviceability of the same if debt is relied for the same. However, this risk is partly mitigated by adequate profitability resulting into healthy cash accruals and low reliance on the external debt which provides cushion to liquidity profile in terms of scaling up the operations.

The Company?s liquidity is stretched as seen in low current ratio and higher payable days. The Company has a sanctioned cash credit facility of INR 6 crores which remains fully utilized. Also, there have been instances of minor EPFO delays both on account of operational issues and cash flow mismatches. Thus, increasing scale along with the improved margin and efficient working capital management will remain important. Further, continuance of need based promoter funding is to be seen. As indicated, amidst the slowdown and debt funded capex, Company plans to infuse INR 2 crore of unsecured loans (INR 1 crore already infused) in the current year.
Moderate scale of operations vs global players in the domestic market

Although the revenue of the Company has improved sharply in FY 2018 with a moderation in FY 2019, the scale of operations and tangible networth remained moderate throughout the review period. Moderate size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. Company?s moderate scale of operations acts as a constraining factor in realizing the benefits of economies of scale. Large companies have the strangth to weather the demand fluctuations in the industry in which they undertake business. In contrast, small and mid sized companies are more vulnerable to market shocks given the scale of their business and balance sheet. The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from several other injection moulding players in the domestic market and also manufacturers in the international market. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limits the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise to its customers who mostly comprise of the reputed OEM?s.
Low and uneven profitability, leading to limited return indicators

Despite a modest gross margin of ~20% (on an average during the review period; 18.83% in FY 2019), the Company?s operating profitability margins moved from moderate level of 8.45% in FY 2017 and continued declining y-o-y to 2.64% in FY 2019. Despite the improvement in the gross margin of the Company in FY 2019, profit margin at the operating level further dipped due to higher fixed cost expenses coupled with increase in bank charges, bad debt write off and depreciation cost. The declining operating profit margins resulted in weaker net profit margins as seen in the table below. Increasing scale with better utilization of capacities needs to be seen.
Further, limited profitability has resulted in modest returns indicating lesser income for the investment made, as depicted in the table below.
Leveraged capital structure coupled with declining interest coverage

The Company?s total debt-to-equity ratio is skewed almost entirely towards long term loans and deteriorated to 4.58 times as of FY 2019 vs. 4.27 times as of FY 2018. Leveraged capital structure was on account of increase in debt exposure towards the capex undertaken (expended about INR 34 crore in the last thee year review period) as against marginal improvement in tangible networth. Leveraged capital structure would restrict the financial flexibility of the Company while procuring funds for any of its expansion plans and/or for funding its incremental working capital requirements. Company has also received high unsecured loans from promoters/directors to the tune of INR 7-8 crores. Considering the same as neither debt nor equity, gearing level reduces to 1.92 times as on 31st March 2019. As indicated, The Company is undertaking a debt funded capex in CY towards expansion of facility at Sanand, Gujarat. The current economic slowdown could further pressurize the Company?s revenues and margin which might increase the gearing of the Company.

Low profit margins have adversely impacted the Company?s financial flexibility as reflected in declining interest coverage ratio throughout the review period (except in FY 2018 wherein there is a marginal improvement). Interest coverage ratio declined from 3.42 times in FY 2018 to 1.45 times in FY 2019. Incremental debt would also result in higher interest costs which could limit the ability of the Company to service its interest obligations.

Company has high working capital requirements. The collection days and inventory holding period was high at 100 and 124 days in FY 2017. However, the same underwent a substantial improvement in FY 2018 and FY 2019. The payable days remained high throughout the review period and the same was utilized towards meeting its high working capital needs. High collection and inventory holding has led to modest liquidity position during the review period which has also impacted the net cash flow from operating activities during the review period. Current and quick ratio stood low at 0.95 times and 0.57 times respectively as on 31st March 2019. Any further elongation in the working capital cycle may have an impact on the cash flows of the Company and hence prudent management of the same remains critical.
Leveraged capital structure owing to largely debt funded operations

Given the nascent stage of operations (~6 years), the Company has been undertaking capex on continual basis to enhance its manufacturing capacities. The capex is majorly funded through external debt and the balance from unsecured loans from promoters (accounting for ~25% of the total debt). With nascent stage of operations, the Company?s profitability has also remained moderate resulting in low accretions to reserves and thereby leading to modest tangible networth which stood at INR 272,255 thousand as on 31st March 2019.

Though reduced, the gearing of the Company still remains high at 2.17 times as on 31st March 2019, despite the increase in tangible networth, due to continued dependence on external debt to fund its capex and working capital requirements leading to a leveraged capital structure. Even after exclusion of funds infused in by promoters (in the form of unsecured loans carrying an interest rate of 9%), BPPL?s capital structure remained high at more than unity as on 31st March 2019.

As informed, the working capital limits of the Company remain ~80% utilised on an average though peak utilization has reached 100%. Further, going forward, Company has a capex of ~INR 250,000 crore planned over the span of next two financial years. The project will encompass additional term loan borrowings of up to INR 170,000 thousand. This may further impact the capital structure of the Company. Leveraged capital structure limits the ability of the Company to borrow funds in case of any business exigencies, or to fund its incremental working capital requirements and capex plans.
Limited pricing flexibility leading to uneven profit margins

Although the Company?s scale of operations has showcased a significant improvement with y-o-y increase in revenue, its profitability levels have been uneven over the review period ended FY 2019. BPPL operates in a highly competitive industry with volatile prices of raw materials (as polyester and polyurethane are the derivatives of crude oil). Over the years, its cost of materials has varied between ~70-77%. With volatile raw material prices and limited ability to pass on the price change because of low bargaining power, the gross margins of the Company have depicted an uneven trend as well. Moreover, the Company has undertaken substantial capex y-o-y basis to enhance its capacities leading to high depreciation cost and it plans to further leverage its capital structure through additional term loan borrowing for new project in the next few years. Interest costs resulting from high borrowing will also impact its profitability.

On the other hand, given the improved profitability and moderate capital base, return indicators in FY 2019 have strengthened considerably. Going forward, the ability of the Company to sustain its profitability and return indicators remains crucial.
Project execution risk arising from perceived large scale capex in the next two years

The Company plans on undertaking construction of a new building for expansion of its production capacity. The building will be designed to encompass future requirement of capacity expansion as well and therefore would require large investment of ~INR 250,000 thousand within the next two years. The Company plans to initially install machinery for limited capacity expansion in the building during the next two years. The capacity will be then enhanced y-o-y based on perceived demand in the market. The later expansion will require minimum expenditure as all the provisions for installation of machinery in the later phases will be planned while undertaking civil construction of the new building.

The Company plans to avail a term loan of up to INR 170,000 thousand for the plant while the rest of the funding will be met by internal accruals. Though the Company will get a moratorium period before repayments for the term loan would begin, the interest expenditure on the loan is expected to bring down the profitability margins to some extent. Further, any delay in commencement of operations of the plant or lower utilization during initial phase will lead to time and therefore cost overrun which will impact the liquidity position and therefore the overall financial profile of the Company.

The gearing of the Group has mostly increased during the review period as a result of increase in debt being more than increase in tangible net worth of the Group. Hence, the total loans to tangible networth ratio, has remained elevated throughout the review period. The total loans of the Group have increased significantly (almost by 46%) in FY 2019 on account of enhanced short and long term debt coupled with decline in tangible net worth of the Group. High total debt to equity ratio indicates high reliance on debt funds, thus limiting the financial flexibility for expansion through additional leverage.
Debtors and inventory as a percentage of total current assets, stood at around 78% indicating a significant amount being blocked thereby putting pressure on liquidity of the Group.
FDA observation on two plants during the review period

The increasing number of regulatory actions from the US Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) is emerging as a key risk for Indian pharmaceutical companies. The Group received FDA observations (Form 483) for its formulations plant at Moraiya, Ahmedabad plant in May 2019 which was later updated to Official Action Indicated in August 2019. There was a minor regulatory hiccup when its Ankaleshwar, Gujarat API facility received and Establishment Inspection Report from US FDA in September 2019 with VAI classification. As per the USFDA, VAI means that though "objectionable conditions or practices were found, but the agency is not prepared to take or recommend any administrative or regulatory action?. Ability of the group to address regulatory aspects remains critical.
Geographical concentration risk with USA accounting for significant portion of the total revenue

The group derived more than 84% of its revenue from the North American market, depicting geographical concentration risk. The group, however, has been steadily expanding across geographies such as Europe and Asia Pacific. Though US economy has shown signs of economic recovery post 2008 financial crisis, high accumulated debt of these nations (resulting in high fiscal deficit), and euro-zone crisis such as Brexit, US trade wars etc. which could result in contagion across other euro zone countries and could deteriorate the short-term economic environment. In such an environment, the clients start cutting on discretionary IT spending resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiation of the contract value resulting in pressure on margins.

Existing customers start commanding pricing power or cut costs by means of vendor consolidation, in-sourcing or captive set ups. Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it difficult for the IT companies to bag new contracts. IT budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing IT spending and postponing investments. Therefore, the ability of the group to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets remains critical. However, in the backdrop of this macro-economic environment, the group has been able to acquire new customers and win new large deals and expand its capabilities.

The Group operates in an intensely competitive environment. Some of the major competitors of the group are SQS Software Quality System AG, Germany, Thinksoft Global Services, Maveric Systems Limited, QA Infotech, and large domestic IT companies like Infosys Limited, Capgemini S.A., Wipro Limited, Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp, etc. Also, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is also becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture PLC, Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp, International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destination nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware, but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Moreover, there exists a threat of insourcing or captive set up by the clients to reduce the dependence on IT vendors for core processes which might affect revenue from existing clients (indirect competition). Therefore, the ability of the group to retain its existing clients and add new clients amidst high competitive environment remains critical.

Further, as informed, there is an increasing trend by the end user to avail the services of independent software testing services like Cigniti Group to enhance the verification and validation process in software development and maintenance services as IT systems related risks are increasingly threatening the operations of the customers. Through a mix of global marketing initiatives, sound industry analyst relations, and other brand building initiatives, the Group has been consistently strengthening its brand.
Large working capital requirements resulting in moderate financial profile and liquidity position

The Company?s operations have remained working capital intensive primarily emanating from its large inventory holding. The inventory days remained in the range of 226 days to 246 days over the three year period ending FY 2019 on account of stocking up of natural marble lumps in anticipation of demand. Further, as majority of CMC?s clientele base is retail segment and it has a large and wide product portfolio, the inventory levels are expected to remain high going forward as well.

These large working capital requirements have been funded through advances from customers, unsecured loans and external borrowings. As informed by management, the unsecured loans carry an interest rate of 12% and average utilization of bank lines has been around 85%. Its current and quick ratios also remained low at 1.03 times and 0.43 times, respectively, as on 31st March 2019.

Along with large working capital requirements, capex plans for enhancing its facilities has also led to increase in debt levels. As informed, the Company had undertaken capex for enhancing its quartz manufacturing capacity during FY 2019 for which the total cost outlay was around INR 25 crore funded through a mix of debt and internal funds which has led to increase in long term borrowings. Furthermore, even during the current fiscal, the Company has undertaken capex of similar amount to increase its quartz capacity which is funded through debt and internal funds.

Of the total debt availed by the Company, around 52% is from director and relative (unsecured loans). Further, it also included redeemable preference shares to the tune of INR 11.5 crore and as informed, the same have been redeemed during the current fiscal through internal accruals. Despite leverage capital structure, the interest coverage ratio remained adequate at 3.74 times for FY 2019 on the back of improving profitability levels. Nonetheless, it remains critical for the Company to efficiently manage its large working capital requirements and improve its capital structure while undertaking capital expansion plans.
Risk associated with the Indian real estate industry

The Indian real estate market has undergone a tumultuous period for the last couple of years, especially the residential segment. The residential market has been in the midst of slowdown over the past two-three years on account of the prices, launches based on an over-estimation of the size of the luxury market, unsold inventory, slowdown in rentals and the overall slowdown in the sentiments of home buyers. Further, demonitisation, introduction of RERA and GST also had an impact on the overall industry.

With real estate segment (builders/ contractors, dealers, large corporate) being the revenue driver of the Company, any change in the policies by the government/ or slowdown in the industry will have an impact on its business profile. This is reflected in the expected moderation in the revenue during FY 2020 and increase in bad debts and provisions during FY 2019. Hence it remains critical for Company to sustain its business profile over the near to medium term.
Decline in demand from US market resulting in moderation of revenue and uneven profitability during the review period

India?s gems and jewellery exports contracted by around 5.3% to USD 30.96 billion in 2018-19 against USD 32.7 billion in the preceding year. This has been primarily on account of slowdown in the demand from major developed markets which includes USA. As majority (around 80%) of the revenue of the Company is derived from US market, the slowdown in the demand subsequently impacted the Company?s revenue. Its topline shrunk by around 18% in FY 2018 and remained almost stagnated during FY 2019 with just 1% growth. Even on consolidated basis, the revenue growth remained at around 6% during FY 2019.

Decline in revenue impacted the operating profitability of the Company which dipped from 7% to 4.9% at operating level during FY 2018 because of under absorption of costs along with decline in gross margins. This, along with volatile dollar rates and inventory valuation losses (owing to the sizeable inventory being held by the Company) resulted in a decline in profits on an absolute level. However, the management?s focus was to improve its bottom line during FY 2019 and with cost rationalization, the Company was able to improve its profitability levels. As a result, operating margins stood moderate at 7.12% during FY 2019. This further led to modest return indicators marked by return on capital employed of 10.48% and return on tangible networth which stood at 8.19% during FY 2019.

Even during the first half of the current fiscal (FY 2020), as per Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council, the exports of gems and jewellery marked a decline of around 7.5%. This has been primarily on account of high custom duty on cut and polished diamonds and 12.5% import duty on gold. Amidst these pressures and declining demand, improving scale and maintaining profitability levels remains critical. As indicated by management, on consolidated basis, the revenue is expected to be in the range of INR 210 crore to INR 225 crore for FY 2020; however, with increase in business from Walmart Inc. (volume driven business), sustenance of profitability remains critical.
Elongated working capital cycle marked by high collection and inventory holding

The Company?s working capital requirements have remained large primarily emanating from its high collection cycle and inventory holding. Entire of its revenue is derived from export market of which 41% is from its wholly owned subsidiary, Cynergy Trading Corporation. The wholly owned subsidiary further sells to departmental stores and e-commerce companies. The credit period extended to customers ranges from 30 to 120 days resulting in stretched collection. Nonetheless, of the debtors outstanding as on 31st March 2019, 75% were due from Cynergy Trading Corporation. On consolidated basis, collection cycle has depicted an improvement and stood at 43 days in FY 2019. Further, in order to cater to the requirement of its customers and with large product basket, the Company needs to maintain high inventory of around three months. As indicated, the Company receives cash discount from its suppliers on short payment cycle. Hence, these large working capital requirements are managed mostly through internal accruals, thus having lower reliance on borrowings.
However, on consolidated basis, the working capital requirements were primarily driven by large inventory holding. As indicated by management, the focus is on improvement in collection cycle.

Although at consolidated level, there has been improvement in working capital management, working capital cycle still remained high and therefore, efficient management of same would remain critical as any material incremental requirements may have an impact on the cash flows of the Company.

Presently, the Company derives around 80% of the total revenue from USA market exposing it to geographic concentration risk. Slowdown in the demand for exports in USA had adversely impacted the topline of the Company in FY 2018 which remained stagnant during FY 2019. Further, factors such as partial shutdown of the US government, US-China trade war, drop in shipments due to negative growth in the export of silver jewellery; with a sharp rise in the return of consignments over past two years amplify the risks of generating a large portion of the total revenue from a single market, despite the fact that USA, UAE and Hongkong are the largest markets for export of Indian jewellery.

As apprised by the management, to mitigate this risk, the Company is focusing on generating higher revenues from other regions and has penetrated in Canada and Australia. It has been participating in exhibitions and trades at Las Vegas and Hongkong etc. to diversify its regional base. Nonetheless, amidst the declining exports because of lull demand from key markets, it remains critical for the Company to more diversify its geographical base.
Government initiatives with global trade war to benefit companies

The gems and jewellery sector play a significant role in the Indian economy which contributes around 7% of the country?s GDP. The gems and jewellery?s market size was around USD 75 billion in FY 2017 and is expected to reach around USD 100 billion by FY 2025. The Government of India has taken various policy initiatives to improve the performance of the sector. 100% FDI is allowed through automatic route.

Recently, the Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC) to build India?s largest jewellery park at Ghansoli (Navi Mumbai) on 25 acre land with more than 5,000 jewellery units of various sizes. The overall investment expected is around INR 13,500 crore. Further, policy measures taken by Government with respect to exemption of Goods and Service Tax (GST) on silver and platinum by specified nominated agencies, GST rate cut from 3% to 0.25% on cut and polished semi-precious stones, along with reduction of corporate tax rate to 25% is expected to benefit the SME/MSME players in the country.

Apart from government initiatives, current trade war between US and China is expected to spur India?s gold jewellery export. In 2018-19, India?s total export of gold jewellery to US was around USD1.9 billion. With fresh tariffs announced by US government on commodities imported by China, the gold jewellery export to US from China will remain under pressure, which would benefit the Indian exporters.

The Group derived around 53% of its total revenue from the Americas thereby indicating geographic concentration risk, though the same improved over the previous year. USA and Europe being the major markets for the Group, any adverse event occurring in these geographies could adversely affect the topline of the Group. The Indian IT industry is facing challenges owing to uncertain global economic environment and the existing Euro Zone crisis. Political policies towards visa issuance remains a sticking point in near future. These reforms could limit the number of Indian technology professional?s IT companies can put in U.S.A. and increases the cost of business. Therefore, the ability of the group to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets remains critical. As informed, the Group is focused on hiring local talent within each of its global regions, including North America. It is also expecting revenue growth from APAC (Asia Pacific) majorly from markets like Africa, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Korea and Taiwan.

High attrition rate has always remained a major concern in Indian IT industry. It results in loss of skill sets and the cost of recruitment and training. The Group also remained challenged with high rates of attrition. During the review period, personnel costs of the Group as a percentage of revenue saw a decline but remained high. This has been due to local hiring due to unemployment concerns in the key markets. Further, services of the Group being focused on aerospace and defense engineering, it needs to retain high skilled manpower. Upward movement in its personnel cost, if any, may adversely affect the margins. As informed by the management, several measures have been taken to reduce the attrition while maintaining the personnel cost like employee pyramid resizing, employee engagement programmes etc. which helped in better employee utilization.

The revenue of the Company depicted an improvement y-o-y basis; however, the growth remained modest at 1.38% during FY 2019 on the back of deferment of some orders. Overall the profit margins at gross levels remained stable backed by the integrated operations it undertakes from designing till manufacturing resulting in operational efficiencies. However, being an integrated player, the Company has high asset base. With moderate margins at net levels, the Company?s returns have remained low, despite an improvement over the review period. Return on capital employed stood at 10% during FY 2019 whereas return on tangible networth stood at around 7% during the same period.
Hence it remains critical for the Company to improve its margins thereby resulting in improvement in return indicators over the medium term.

The Company?s operations remained working capital intensive as reflected in its working capital cycle ranging from 195 to 351 days over the past three years through FY 2019. The large working capital requirements primarily emanated from high inventory holding and collection cycle. The inventory cycle was around 240 days as on 31st March 2019 which has been on account of imports and higher lead time for execution of projects. Around 70% of the raw material requirements are imported resulting in high inventory holding. The increase in the inventory levels during FY 2018 against the preceding year was on account of procurement of key materials for execution of project. Further, collection cycle is high because of the milestone based payments, although around 10% of the payment is received in advance. The collection period increased from 151 days in FY 2017 to 203 days in FY 2018 because of delays in payments from its customers. Further, the management indicated that majority of the billing happens during the last two quarters of the fiscal resulting in high collection cycle.

These large working capital requirements are met through extended credit from suppliers, advances from customers and bank borrowings. As indicated, the working capital limits are utilized at an average of 85%. Although the working capital cycle improved in FY 2019 on the back of reduction in collection days, any further incremental requirements may have an impact on the cash flows and hence prudent management of same remains critical.

The Company derived around 40% of its revenues from Mitsubishi Hitachi Power Systems Limited and Dangote Oil Refining Company Limited during FY 2019 exposing itself to customer concentration risk. Further, around 60% of the revenue is derived from power sector and around 30% from oil and gas and other process industries. Any significant downturn in the demand for products of this customers or any adverse event at the customer?s end or any decision taken by the customer to alter its supplier will adversely affect the topline and bottom line of the Company. However, established relationship coupled with repeat orders mitigates the risk to an extent.
Large working capital requirements emanating from high inventory levels

The Company?s operations remained working capital intensive on the back of its large inventory holding and high collection cycle. As India has negligible explored reserves of gold and rough diamonds, the domestic players largely rely on imports. DDPL being an importer, stocks up large inventory of different categories of diamond with respect to sizes, shape, color and clarity. Also, DDPL being a sight holder has access to direct supply from De Beers through auctions which are held by De Beers only 10 times a year. Therefore, as informed, the Company maintains a minimum inventory of around 2.5 to 3 months (around INR 1,600 to 1,700 crores of inventory) at a given point in time due to the large processing time required. The inventory days fluctuated from 99-136 days during the review period.
