The increase in the inventory levels during FY 2019 was on the back of purchase of rough diamonds to cater to the future demands.

In line with high inventory, the receivables remained high between 90-104 days during the review period as the credit extended is around 90 to 120 days, given the long-standing relationship with customers coupled with polished diamonds being sold through its subsidiaries. However, it makes an advance payment for its purchases from the mines. Payment days had ranged between 56-82 days during the review period which it avails from wholesale suppliers.

This phenomenon increases the working capital requirements of the Company, which is mainly funded through creditors and short term borrowings. With lower incremental working capital requirements and increasing y-o-y accruals, the short term borrowings reduced during FY 2019. As indicated, the average utilization of the working capital limits is around 80% to 85%.

However, considering the working capital intensive operations and seasonality of operations in export market, any further incremental working capital requirements might have an impact on the cash flows of the Company and hence prudent management of the same remains critical.
Modest return indicators resulting from moderate profitability and subdued revenue growth

The weak market sentiments in the last quarter of FY 2018 on the back of PNB scam, resulted in stagnant revenue during the same fiscal which is reflected in around 4% growth in the Company?s topline. Furthermore, the growth in the export of cut and polished diamonds during 2017-18 was less than 1% (in value terms) against the preceding year as per GJEPC (Gem Jewellery Export Promotion Council). Following the scam, the growth momentum in exports was cut down during FY 2019, as overall exports of gems and jewellery from India increased by a marginal 0.39% against FY 2018. Further, exports of cut and polished diamonds declined by 15.12% to USD 1.88 billion in May 2019 as compared to USD 2.21 billion in May 2018, depicting overall gloomy scenario in the industry. Further, the lending to the diamond sector was controlled and several instruments offering ease of working capital management to the diamond companies were suspended under scrutiny. The resulting weak sentiments in the industry are visible in the muted growth in FY 2019. The building working capital requirement and slowdown in revenue growth has impacted the overall return indicators of the Company.

Operating margins remained in the range of 3.83% to 4.24% during the three-year period ending FY 2019. Nevertheless, moderate margins and large working capital requirements have resulted in modest return indicators as reflected in its return on tangible networth of 10.82% and return on capital employed (RoCE) of 9.45% as on 31st March 2019. With increasing prices of rough diamonds and weak market sentiments, it remains critical for the Company to further improve its margins resulting in improvement in its return indicators.
Moderate gearing owing to expansion of capacity and acquisitions

DTPL expanded its capacity for existing products and is also developing capacity for new products and some of the key input products (backward integration). The Company expanded its facilities partly through long term debts and also availed short term debts to fund its incremental working capital which resulted in almost doubling its total borrowings and increase its total debt equity ratio from 1.26 times as on 31st March 2017 to 1.46 times as on 31st March 2019. Also with significant debt funded capex for capacity enhancement at different locations, it may strain the gearing ratio of the Company in the near term.

Moreover, the Company acquired three companies in two years -FY 2018-2019 and the acquisitions were funded through term debt and internal accruals. DTPL has a high tangible networth backed by improved accretion to reserves owing to which despite of the high reliance on debt, its gearing remained at moderate levels.

Due to a moderate gearing, any time and cost overrun in the ongoing capex of the manufacturing facilities or lower than expected benefit from the acquisition can impact the profitability and capital structure of the Company.

Liquidity ratios of the Company remained at moderate levels during the review period with current ratio depicting a declining trend which stood at 0.93 times as on 31st March 2019. Low liquidity ratio was on account of increase in working capital loans to support the incremental revenue growth and increase in CPLTD due to loans contracted in the last three year period. Working capital cycle was moderate at around 47 days for FY 2019 and though the cash flow from operations remained positive, the same fluctuated due to higher incremental working capital requirement.
However, the Company generated sufficient net cash accruals of around INR 48 crores which was more than adequate to meet the maturing term loan obligations of INR 12 crores.
Efficient management of working capital would continue to remain crucial for improvement in current ratio going forward.

The Company derived around 85% to 90% of its revenues from wiring harnesses during the period under review. While wiring harnesses can be used across multiple industries like consumer durables, construction machinery, etc., the Company derived a bulk of its revenue from automobile industry, depicting segment/vertical concentration risk. Any slowdown in the automobile sector as currently witnessed could adversely affect the demand of wiring harnesses and consequently, DTPL?s revenue. However, as informed, though the Company expects revenue growth to moderate in FY 2020 on back of decline in auto industry volumes, it is expecting increased scale in FY 2021 onwards as the Company has received huge orders for BS VI compliant vehicles. As informed, it has bagged around 35-40% of the orders for BS VI compliant two wheeler segment. DTPL believes wiring harness business is likely to have significant growth prospects going forward, given the BS-VI emission norms which would be applicable from 2020 and the shift towards EFI systems. Furthermore, the Company has expanded its product portfolio to include products like actuators, controllers, sensors, tooling, switches, etc.

DTPL derives a significant portion (~40%) of its FY 2019 revenues from Bajaj Auto Limited (BAL), exposing it to customer concentration risk. While decade and a half old relationship of the Company with BAL, diversifications initiated by the Company and leading position of BAL in the two-wheeler market provides comfort, the competitive intensity in the domestic two-wheeler market has increased post the split of Hero Honda (now Hero MotoCorp) with now both the erstwhile partners independently operating in the domestic market. Further, a significant portion of the incremental demand for two-wheelers comes from rural areas where the purchasing power of the people depends upon good monsoons (with majority of the people dependent on agriculture and allied activities for their livelihood), thereby, making the demand patterns erratic. The aforesaid could therefore, adversely impact the volumes of BAL and, consequently, the revenues of the Company. Nevertheless, as informed, the Company has been diversifying its customer base since 2009, and currently caters to other OEMs as well, such as Honda Motor Company, Royal Enfield, Eicher Motors Limited, Mahindra& Mahindra Limited and Force Motors Limited. As informed, going forward the Company expects the concentration to reduce further for BAL largely driven by increased business from newly acquired companies as well as increased revenue from BSVI requirement by other customers. Despite decline in contribution to the total revenue, the Company expects to continue to remain the largest supplier of wiring harnesses set to its top customer.

Given the nature of the industry in which the Group operates, the working capital cycle was elongated (fluctuated between 103-148 days in the last five-year review period) primarily emanating from the high inventory period. As informed, the inventory days of the Group remained high since it is required to maintain 4 months? inventory. The Group managed its working capital requirements through extended credit availed from suppliers, advance received from the customers which ranges between 30-60% of the total development cost, and partly through working capital loans. Since, the entire development of the molecule is an elongated cycle, the Group receives payment on milestone basis, thus the working capital of the Group gets stretched for a longer period. As informed the bank line utilization is between 75-80% on an average in the last one year period.

The return indicators remained low primarily due to lower net profits. The profitability at net levels declined in FY 2017 owing to high depreciation and amortization cost (at approximately 13% of revenue in the last three years ending FY 2019) because of the goodwill and revaluation of assets. Further, revaluation of assets led to an increase in tangible networth of the Group in FY 2017. OPBITDA margins though high has shown a fluctuating trend due to the product mix. As indicated, Group earns higher margins on the commercialization of the product as compared to contract research services. Carbogen Amcis has lower margins as the Company undertakes development work at early stages of the molecule and thereafter revenues depend on the successful commercialization of the product by the innovator. Supply of Vitamin D is at a higher margin of 65% OPBITDA and forms about 60% of the total revenues of marketable molecules. Going ahead, commercialized products would drive the high margins.

In FY 2019, OPBDITA declined to about 22% (excluding the forex gain impact on sales) visa vis 26% in FY 2018. As indicated, Group exited the low profit contracts. However, it expects the margins to improve with commercial launch of Niraparib and other oncology drugs.

The operations at most of its facilities are running at optimal levels except for Bavla and China which as indicated is running at 65% and 25% respectively. Netherland facility is at 60% utilization. Other facilities are operating at nearly 90% capacity utilization.

With fluctuating profitability, returns of the Group had remain uneven during the review period. ROCE and ROTNW has marginally declined in the last three year period, the same stood at 8.6% and 5.56% respectively for FY 2019 (excluding the forex gain impact on sales). An increase in the proportion of high-margin oncology APIs and other niche APIs in the overall revenue mix is likely to improve capacity utilization and improve return ratios.
Moderate scale of operations and profits amidst competitive landscape

The Company operates in an intensely competitive environment marked by pricing pressure. Given the moderate scale of operations and the industry competition, the Company is not able to fully pass on the rise in prices of raw materials to its consumers, which was evident from the drop in gross margins in FY 2016. Although the scale of operations has depicted an improvement y-o-y basis, it remains moderate at INR 89 crore as on FY 2019. Further, the profitability has remained uneven during the review period. It depicted an improvement from FY 2016 to FY 2019 primarily on account of increase in its scale of operations. As indicated by management, addition of capacities and addition of products in its portfolio coupled with lowering of subcontract cost resulted in improvement in margins during FY 2019. Furthermore, as informed backward integration for some of its API?s has helped the Company to improve its profitability. Net margins of the Company also depicted a substantial improvement on the back of higher non-operating income (profit on sale of asset) and lower tax provisioning. Subsequently returns remains adequate during FY 2019.

Despite improvement in topline and profitability, the ability of the Company to remain competitive and gain pricing flexibility resulting into further improvement and sustenance of margins remains critical.

The Company is engaged in manufacturing speciality chemicals and intermediates well as Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs). It has a product basket of more than 70 products in API?s and intermediates segment whereas it has filed 5 US DMF?s (Drug Master File), 1 Taiwanese DMF, 1 Japanese DMF, 1 Chinese DMF & 2 EDMF?s (European Drug Master File). During FY 2020, it has filed 3 DMF?s in the European market. As informed, the Company derives major revenue from Trimethobenzamide, Probenecide, Vitamin D3, Lasamide, Fenofibric acid, PTS refined products etc. with top three products Trimethobenzamide, Probenecide, Vitamin D3 contributing around 65% to total revenue.

Though, the Company registered healthy growth over the past five years, any decline in the revenue from any of the top three products owing to regulatory changes, competition, etc. can significantly impact the revenue of the Company.
Subdued revenue growth and limited pricing flexibility leading to moderation in profitability and returns

The group?s revenue growth largely remained muted during the review period. The management indicated that the slow growth since FY 2015 was on account of pressure in USA led by price erosions and customer consolidation. Further, stoppage in sale to Europe for four months due to regulatory action that got resolved in January 2018, led to lesser revenues. On the profitability front, the Group faces headwinds from increasing competitive intensity and channel consolidation in the USA market which resulted in price erosion in its generic business. Furthermore, its front-end investment for setting-up team for its specialty business increased in the past two years resulting in further pressure on profitability.

The aforementioned factors resulted in tepid revenue growth throughout the review period marked by muted growth in FY 2018 over a sharp decline in FY 2017, and volatile margins with sharp decline in FY 2017 and FY 2018. Also, the return indicators saw similar magnitude of decline in FY 2017 and FY 2018.

However, the management expects to end FY 2019 with relatively higher revenues and better profitability owing to increase in drug prices, and commercialization of few specialty products. This is supported by FY 2019 results, which saw a revenue growth of approximately8% and operating and net margin improvement of approximately 600 basis points over same period last year.
High regulatory risk given increasing scrutiny and stricter controls by regulatory authorities of developed countries

The increasing number of regulatory actions from the US Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) is emerging as a key risk for Indian pharmaceutical companies. As far as DRL is concerned, its regulatory track record has been blemished by adverse observations for its plants. The Group received a warning letter dated 5 November 2015 from the U.S. FDA relating to current Good Manufacturing Practice (?cGMP?) deviations at its active pharmaceutical ingredient (?API?) manufacturing facilities at Srikakulam, Andhra Pradesh and Miryalaguda, Telangana, as well as violations at its oncology formulation manufacturing facility at Duvvada, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh. The contents of the warning letter emanated from Form 483 observations that followed inspections of these sites by the U.S. FDA in November 2014, January 2015 and February-March 2015, respectively.

There was also a regulatory hiccup when the Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices (BfArM) of Germany audited Group?s formulation unit 2 (FTO-2) at Bachupally, Hyderabad (Telangana). This resulted in the good manufacturing practices (GMP) compliance certi?cate not being renewed in August 2017. Corrective work was immediately undertaken. After a follow-up audit, the GMP non-compliance status was withdrawn in January 2018. However, stoppage in sale to Europe for four months led to lesser revenues. Ability of the group to address regulatory aspects remains critical.
Moderate scale of operation amidst high competitive industry

The Indian IT industry is highly fragmented with more than 16,000 players and comprises of large multi-billion-dollar companies as well as small domestic and global MNCs. e-Zest?s immediate competitors comprise of Mindtree, Zensar, Calsoft, Bitwise, Persistent, Cognizant, Xoriant amongst others. Apart from these, the Company also faces competition from large size players like Infosys Limited, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Wipro Limited, Tech Mahindra Limited, etc. Further, with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its competitive cost of operations, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is also becoming less relevant. Large IT players have already built strong digital practices and have started investing in IoT. They have full service offerings, strong customer relationships, domain expertise, low-cost delivery capabilities that make them a preferred partner for many enterprise customers. In comparison, the Company is a mid-size player in the highly competitive ITes industry as reflected in its turnover size of INR 1,123,345 thousand in FY 2019. Therefore, the ability of the Company to retain its existing clients and add new clients to increase its revenue rapidly, amidst high competitive environment, remains important.
Moderation in profitability and return indicators in FY 2019

The profitability of the Company has remained uneven during the review period. As informed, FY 2018 was an exceptional year for the Company where it derived nearly 30% of its revenue from a high margin contract. Profitability has since moderated to standard levels and is expected to remain more or less at FY 2019 levels going ahead. Profitability at the gross level was majorly influenced by expenses towards salaries and wages and towards technical consultancy fees. Profitability of the Company at the operating and net level principally followed suit to the gross margin with further influence from the increasing travelling and conveyance expenses. Profitability at net level stood further supported by non-operating income (comprising dividend income, forex gain, interest income, profit on sale of investments) coupled with y-o-y declining interest expenses.

Given the presence in IT industry, the Company?s profitability as well as scale of operations remains moderate when compared to other competitors. Ability of the Company to improve scale of operations and profitability therefore remains critical.
Geographic concentration risk with majority revenue contribution from the USA and UK
The Company derived on an average about 80% of its revenue from the USA and UK during the review period.

The economic growth of USA is tempered by continuing concerns over determination of a long-term solution to inherent issues like government spending, increasing national debt, and their negative impact on the country?s economy. In addition, concerns over potential increases in cost of borrowing and reduction in availability of credit also raise head as the US Federal Reserve begins raising interest rates. The protectionist policies that may be pursued by the presidential administration have added further uncertainty to the global economy. Further, there is uncertainty regarding the impact of the escalating ?trade war? between USA and other major powers on the global economy. Globally, weaker GDP growth in both developing and advanced countries point towards a global slowdown. Further, uncertainty regarding the terms of Brexit, and its eventual effects once implemented, have had and may continue to have a material adverse effect on global economic conditions and the stability of global financial markets, and may significantly reduce global market liquidity and restrict the ability of key market participants to operate in certain financial markets.

In such an environment, the clients start cutting on discretionary IT spending resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiation of the contract value resulting in pressure on margins. Existing customers start commanding pricing power or cut costs by means of vendor consolidation, in-sourcing or captive set ups. Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it difficult for the IT companies to bag new contracts. IT budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing IT spending and postponing investments. Therefore, the ability of the Company to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets
Declining and moderate profitability owing to trading nature of operations

The Company?s profitability levels have remained moderate during the review period largely driven by the trading nature of operations which has low value additions. Decline in profitability was mainly driven by high competition resulting in pricing pressure thereby limiting the Company?s ability to command better prices in the market. Gross profit margin fluctuated during the review period owing to movement in purchase cost, salary cost and other direct expenses (comprising of freight, transport and clearance charges). Operating and net profit margin depicted a declining trend and remained moderate throughout the review period. Intense competition in the industry has impacted the profitability of the Company. Declining profit margins have resulted in declining returns as depicted in table below:

The high competitive intensity coupled with price volatility of traded goods may result in pricing pressure and thereby constrain the profitability of the Company in future. Ability of the Company to improve the margins while increasing the scale of operations remain critical going ahead.
Low scale of operations and moderate tangible networth

Although the revenue of the Company grew at a CAGR of 16.12% during the review period; its overall scale of operations has remained at low levels as compared to other player in auto-component industry. The Company?s low scale of operations may act as a constraining factor which may restrict the Company?s ability to secure big orders and thus, in realizing the benefits of economies of scale making its cost structure uncompetitive.

The Company also has moderate tangible networth of INR 82,930 thousand as on 31st March 2019. The networth of Company indicates its inherent strength. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain. Moderate size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. Hence, ability of the Company to increase its scale of operations and networth remains critical.

In FY 2019, the Company derived around 50% of its revenue from one customer exposing itself to customer concentration risk. Any significant downturn in the demand for products of this customers or any adverse event at the customer?s end or any decision taken by the customer to alter its supplier will adversely affect the topline and bottom line of the Company. However, as informed, the Company is negotiating order contracts with a number of additional customers during FY 2020 and expects orders from these customers in the near future. Nevertheless, diversification of clientele base remains critical.

The management has consciously embarked on a single product policy as paracetamol is the safest and the cheapest API for analgesic and antipyretic usage with the largest volumes in the API segment. The Company derived a major portion i.e. more than 95% of its revenue from sale of paracetamol throughout the review period depicting high product concentration risk. Production cost has long been a critical factor for success in the paracemetol business, because it is a price-intensive, commodity type of market. Any decline in the demand from paracetamol could adversely impact the topline of the Company. Considering the competition in pharmaceutical industry from both large number of unorganized players as well as global players who have advantage of large market share and scale of operations, the revenue and profitability of the Company is at risk of depletion in case of losing orders to competitors.

Indian pharmaceutical sector, though organized, is highly fragmented in nature. Indian pharmaceutical market is characterized by generic formulation manufacturers, API manufacturers, and companies providing Contract Research and Manufacturing services. The industry is organized in nature with generic manufacturers enjoying a dominant position. Despite the stringent regulatory environment which poses an entry barrier, the sector has a large concentration of small and medium-sized manufacturing units. Also, the global pharmaceutical companies are beginning to focus on generic versions of drugs by acquiring leading Indian generic companies which further has increased the competition in the industry. Indian pharmaceutical companies face cost disadvantages as compared to China, Korea and Taiwan, which offer low cost manufacturing base. Some of the large global players include Mallinckrodt, Anqiu Lu?an and in domestic market, key players include Granules India, Meghmani Chemicals, Sri Krishna Pharma amongst others. Company?s long standing presence, its established relations with the large formulators ensures repeat orders year on year. Also, it benefits from the backward integrated operations as entire requirement of key intermediate is met by the group Company visa vvis other manaufactures who are majorly dependent on the import of the ingredient, improving on the operating efficiency. This competition could drive down prices for the Company?s products, thereby impacting its margins.
Weak return indicators driven by high capital intensity

Although the revenue of the Company has shown an upward trend during the review period, the profitability margins (at operating and net level) have remained limited. Further, despite the moderate scale of operation, due to capital intensive nature of business and due to the additional incentives provided by Government for upgradation of existing facilities, the Company has made heavy investment in fixed assets over the years. Limited profitability and high capital investments have resulted in modest returns indicating lesser income for investment made, as depicted in table below. Going forward, with improvement in the scale of operations the return indicators are expected to improve. However, addressing the needs for future investment while scaling up operations will dictate the overall return indicators for the Company.
Highly intensive working capital cycle emanating from high inventory holding and change in procurement policy

The Company?s working capital cycle remained elongated primarily emanating from its high inventory days. As informed, FTL has a long lead time for manufacturing that requires holding high levels of inventory of raw materials as well as work in progress. Further, inventory holding days also remain high on account of high finished goods held as a part of an order under execution or due to delay in shipment on account of external factors. However, some comfort can be derived from the fact that with adoption of non-credit payment terms thereby resulting into a wider supplier base has ensured faster procurement and thus enabled the Company to reduce inventory holding of raw materials y-o-y with lower lead time which would continue to benefit in coming years.

Increased working capital requirements has resulted in a moderate liquidity position as reflected in negative cash flow from operations in prior period before the improvement in FY 2019. Additionally, change to cash payment terms with suppliers and expected scaling of operations could exert stress on the liquidity profile in the near to medium term. Thus, ability of the Company to ensure prudent management of working capital requirements and thereby ensure adequate liquidity remains to be seen.

However, as informed, the Company has receivables from the Government of up to INR 8 crore which when received will help with its liquidity position. Further, the Company has pending MAT credit entitlement of ~INR 9 crore which will help reduce tax payables in the near future.

The Company has generated revenue of INR 2,464,200 thousand in FY 2019. Further, the Company estimates the scale of operations to improve during FY 2019 and achieve a turnover of ~INR 3,000,000 thousand in FY 2020. The Company?s moderate scale of operations acts as a constraining factor which may restrict the Company from realizing the benefits of economies of scale. Thus, the ability of the Company to increase its scale of operations remains crucial.

The Company derives ~75% of its total revenue from USA (~50% of exports in FY 2019) and UK (~35% of exports in FY 2019) collectively, thus making its operations vulnerable to geographic concentration risks. Although, USA is the key market for home textile exports, there have been significant revamping of operations at retailer?s end in the country. Concerns like increasing consumer preference for online channels leading to destocking by brick-and-mortar retailers may significantly impact physical retailers in the country. Further the growth in exports remained subdued when compared to the growth in domestic revenue during the review period.

However, the management indicated that its established relation with reputed clients is not likely to adversely impact demand from its customers in these geographies. It has also set-up a subsidiary in the USA to cater to business which require presence in USA, further it helps the Company to have a physical contact with customers to strengthen business relationships.
Limited pricing power and susceptibility to commodity prices resulting in moderate profitability

The Company operates in a fairly competitive market and caters to large reputed customers such as Daikin, Voltas, Bluestar amongst others having higher bargaining power resulting in limited pricing flexibility. The gross margins of the Company have remained low at 9-11% during the review period primarily owing to high raw material costs which formed approx. 85% of the total topline in FY 2018. The Company imports approx. 20-25% of the raw material requirement and the depreciating rupee has not augured well for the profitability. As informed by the management, the Company is able to pass on the price rise to its customers with a time lag of a quarter. Further, significant debt levels till FY 2017 resulted in high interest outgo resulting in subdued net margins. However, equity infusion through IPO in FY 2018 resulted in repayment of debt and in turn lower interest outgo on the recued debt leading to an improvement in net margins

H1FY19 was hit by unseasonal rains which hampered the secondary sales and lead to inventory buildup across the dealers, distributors and brands resulting in de-growth in sales of RAC. This, resulted in a decline in revenue by around 4% despite a growth in revenue by 12% and 19% in the Company?s AC components and non-AC components segment over the same period previous year. However, decline in finance costs for the period ended 31st March 2019 over 31st March 2018 resulted in higher profits at net levels. H2FY19 saw an uptick in sales and the Company achieved its target of 2.1 million volumes for FY 2019. The revenue grew by over 12% in FY 2019 over FY 2018.
Seasonal nature of business along with customer concentration risk

RAC segment of the Company accounted for approx. 74% of the total revenue in H1FY19 (71% in FY 2018). Growth in this segment is exposed to seasonality marked by lower sales during the winters. The revenue concentration of the Company has been observed in the Q1 and Q4 of the financial year. Q1FY18 and Q4FY18 cumulatively contributed to approx. 34% and 43% the total topline indicating the dependence on climatic changes for sales uptick. Further, energy efficiency norms are revised every two years and become applicable from the first day of a calendar year. By virtue of these regulations, classification of star ratings of ACs undergo a change.ÿThus, AC companies? clear stocks (by offering high discounts on models that will be subject to a downgrade in ratings) prior to implementation of the new norms which also impacts the topline. However, there has been no change in the star rating since 2014.

The Company?s top 5 customers contributed to 78% of the total revenue in FY 2018 indicating customer concentration risk. Although the risk is mitigated by the long business relationship enjoyed by the Company with these customers along with their dominant market share (over 75% cumulatively); any fall in offtake or backward integration by the customers can impact the Company?s topline adversely. As indicated, the Company plans to add new key customers across geographies over the medium term.

Inherent seasonality in the RAC business, inventory pileup in the distribution resulted in large working capital of the Company marked by inventory days between 65-90 days during the review period. The gross current asset days stood high at 150 in FY 2018 but the working capital requirement was primarily managed through extended credit from suppliers, customer advances and working capital loans. The short term debt equity ratio of the Company stood high till FY 2017 ranging from 1.2 to 0.7 times during the period. However, infusion of funds which was used to repay debt obligations resulted in lower working capital loans in FY 2018.
Thus, with growing scale of operations, the ability of the Company to prudently manage its incremental working capital requirements remains crucial.
Deterioration in financial risk profile in FY 2019

The Company?s revenue, profitability, and credit protection saw significant improvement between FY 2015-18. However, in FY 2019, due to decline in orders from its key customer, lower capacity utilization, and debt laden capex, its overall financial risk profile deteriorated significantly. This was evident from a sharp fall in profitability at all levels (deferred tax liability aggravating the decline resulting in net loss in FY 2019), significant increase in gearing (debt-equity ratio stood at 2.50 times in FY 2019), and sharp decline interest coverage (incremental interest cost on both long-term and short-term debt resulting in interest coverage of 1.44 times).

Between FY 2015-18, the Company?s credit protection measures improved y-o-y marked by improving capital structure and interest coverage during this period. However, the capital structure of the Company increased sharply in FY 2019 on account of lower accretion to reserves to due sharp fall in profits coupled with incremental debt availed from banks towards setting up the new plant in Zaroli. This along with high working capital intensity requiring incremental working capital debt deteriorated the capital structure as well as the interest coverage ratio. Accordingly, the debt-equity ratio stood high at 2.03 times with interest coverage of 1.44 times in FY 2019.

Moreover, as per the seven month provisional financials from April-October 2019, the debt-equity continues to remain high. The Company also has further plans for capex in the near to medium term which are partially to be financed through debt, however, the plan is at nascent stage.

A leveraged capital structure may restrict its financial flexibility thereby making it difficult to leverage further in case of any business exigencies or to fund the incremental working capital requirements. Also, a higher interest outflow would limit the ability of the Company to service its interest obligations.
However, as informed, the capacity utilization at the Zaroli plant stands high at around 70% in FY 2020 and the Company projects healthy topline growth of around 40% for the year ending FY 2020.
Moderate liquidity profile marked by working capital intensive nature of operations

Operations of the Company remained working capital intensive owing to high collection cycle and inventory holding. Collection velocity stood high owing to extended credit period provided to key customer Decon along with a time lag of 10 to 15 days for transporting goods. Inventory holding of the Company was further elongated as majority of customers are based out of Pune and Chennai which elongates the transportation time. The working capital operations of the Company are met through extended credit availed from suppliers and working capital loans availed from banks. With rise in working capital requirements, the payment velocity along with incremental working capital loans witnessed an increasing trend during FY 2019. Moreover, the Company?s inventory days increased sharply from 56 days to 119 days driven by increase in finished goods inventory as well. The Company had piled up huge inventory in anticipation of orders from Decon (major customer), however, due to decline regular order inflows, the inventory days significantly increased. As provided by the management, the inventory days stood at around 138 days while the receivable days around 205 days by the end of October 2019, indicating continual pressure on working capital management in the near-term as well.

Driven by working capital intensive operations, liquidity of the Company stood moderate as witnessed in moderate liquidity ratios marked by quick ratio below unity throughout the review period. Inventories and receivables constituted ~76% of the total current assets in FY 2019 indicating blockage of funds. Further, cash flow from operating activities which stood positive through FY 2015 ? FY 2018 turned negative in FY 2019 due to significant rise in inventory holding. Continued trend of incremental borrowings or increase in the working capital requirement would put further stress on the overall liquidity position of the Company.

The revenue growth of the Company has been uneven though it witnessed a steady growth in FY 2016 and FY 2017 of ~45 % and ~32% respectively, revenue growth was subdued at ~11% in FY 2018 and degrowth of ~18% was observed in FY 2019. Hence, despite a track record of over a decade, revenue of the Company stood moderate at INR 804,444 thousand in FY 2019. The Company?s moderate scale of operations, in comparison with its domestic and global competitors, could act as a constraining factor by restricting its ability to secure big orders and exploit the benefits of economies of scale. Hence, the ability of the Company to further scale up its operations remains crucial. Further, backed by equity infusion, the networth of the Company witnessed an increasing trend during the review period however stood moderate at INR 408,881 thousand in FY 2019. The networth of theÿCompany indicates the inherent strength of the Company. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain itself. Smaller size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. The ability of the Company to improve its networth size remains critical.

The Company derived a large portion of its total revenue from a single customer namely Decon India Plastics Private Limited which contributed to approx. 41% of the total revenue in FY 2018. With decline in orders from this customer the Company was impacted by sharp decline in revenues and margins in FY 2019. Customer concentration could be detrimental to the Company?s growth prospects as any change in procurement policy of its customers or better pricing from the Company?s competitor may adversely impact the topline of the Company. However, the Company enjoys long business relationship with some of its customers mitigating this risk to some extent. Moreover, it has added around 4-5 new customers and significantly diversified its customer base. Decon now accounts for around 30% of the revenue and the concentration is likely to reduce further from further addition of new customers and penetration in new markets which will be catered through its new facility in Zaroli.
Modest profitability margins due to highly competitive intensity in the industry

Over the years, GHV has established itself as a prominent player in EPC segment and has scaled up to a topline of INR 12,581,313 thousand in FY 2019. However, the profitability margins of the Company have remained moderate throughout the review period due to high competitive intensity in both domestic as well as international markets. Moreover, the Company?s business is tender based leading to pricing pressures arising for competitive bidding which has kept the profitability margins low during the review period.

Gross margins of the Company were majorly influenced by the increase in contract execution expenses. Net margins of the Company showed an uneven trend during the review period mainly due to other non-operating income and increasing interest expenses.
Non operating income comprised interest income and in FY 2018 it also included liabilities written back. On removing non operating income, the margins are as follows:

Being into EPC segment, the payable cycle of the Company has remained high, as payments to suppliers have been linked to milestone basis receivables from end customer. The Company?s working capital requirements were aided to an extent by large payables cycle, which stood at 223 days in FY 2019. These large working capital requirements are primarily funded through extended payable days to suppliers. This resulted in moderately low dependence on the working capital limits.
Any incremental working capital requirements over the near to medium term with decline in extended credit from suppliers hence prudent management of the same remains critical.
High contingent liabilities largely in the form of bank guarantees

The Company carries high off balance sheet liabilities largely in the form of guarantees. The total contingent liabilities the Company as on 31st March 2019 amounted to INR 27 crores and as informed, the Company had total off balance sheet liabilities in form of bank guarantees of approx. INR 620 crores. Combined together the liabilities are more than the Company?s tangible networth at INR 216 crores. Any slowdown in business or any other event resulting in invocation of the bank or corporate guarantee, may lead substantial stress on the cash flows and financial position of the Company.
High gearing on the back of the hotel construction being largely financed through loans from group companies as well as external institutions

The cost of the project was funded through intercorporate loan from IL&FS Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited to the tune of INR 100 crore, while the balance was in the form on unsecured loans from promoter and family and other entities of GHV group. Although all the loans availed carry interest of around 12%, for some of the debt being availed from family and GHV group, there is no structured repayment. As indicated by management, the intercorporate loan availed from IL & FS is also repayable on demand.

Since the hotel has just initiated operations, the cash flows generated by the hotel are minimal and inadequate from the view of financing the repayments. The tangible networth of the Company remained modest at around INR 4 crore given the losses incurred. Going forward infusion of funds in the business, with repayment of loans and improvement in the cash flows would remain critical.
Low liquidity with losses incurred given the high interest costs

The hotel commenced its operations in July 2018 and being the first year of operations, it incurred losses on the back of high interest costs. Although the operating margins were adequate backed by healthy occupancy levels, it incurred losses at net level because of high interest costs which accounted for around 25% of the topline resulting in interest coverage of less than 1 during FY 2019. Further, it incurred losses of around INR 0.94 crore. This led to low cash accruals of INR 1.3 crore against which it had substantially large quantum of debt. Although as indicated by management, debt of around INR 10 crore from Cosmos Bank has been repaid, significant amount of loan remains outstanding which majorly includes intercorporate deposit availed from IL & FS Infrastructure Development Limited. Any demand from IL&FS for repayment of the said amount would put further pressure on the Company?s liquidity position given its low liquidity marked by modest cash flows generated from operations and significant amount blocked in loans and advances to extended to SSTL Limited (which is one of the SPV?s of IL &FS). Hence it remains critical for the Company to generate adequate cash flow from its business over the medium term.

GHV Hotel has had a negative networth since inception. Moreover, it has piled up significant debt largely from related parties, directors, and friends to the tune of INR 1,581,723 thousand outstanding as on 31st March 2019. Two major parties who have extended loans include DB Realty Group?s hotel under the name Hotel Balwas International and GHV India (group company). Both these lenders account for approx. 60% and 21% of the total debt respectively as on 31st March 2019. These loans appear to be evergreen in nature and as informed they are payable on demand.
Moreover, the Company?s solvency position is also under pressure as evident from a low current and quick ratio which stood below unity throughout the review period.

Additionally, the Company has advanced loans to SSTL Limited - an SPV of ITNL (an IL&FS group company) in FY 2018. The total loans receivable stood at INR 765,265 thousand as on 31st March 2019 out of which INR 702,979 thousand (or 92% of the total loans receivable) was from SSTL Limited. There has not been any repayment as on 30th September 2019 as well and the Company may carry a recovery risk of the same.
With the networth of the Company being negative coupled with high debt obligations and recovery risk of loans advanced, there is a concern over the stretched liquidity position of the Company.
Profitability witnessed pressure at net level due to abnormal interest cost and high depreciation; however, witnessed improvement at EBITDA level

The Company commenced operations of its hotel based out of Hinjewadi, Pune in January 2015 with FY 2016 being the first full year of operations. The occupancy rates since then improved significantly until FY 2018. Since FY 2018, occupancy rates stood rangebound at around 75-77% coupled with gradual increase in average room rate. These factors coupled with operating leverage kicking in has resulted in the Company steadily achieving economies of scale. Accordingly, the EBITDA margins stood at 23.95% in FY 2019 marked by y-o-y improvement.

However, on the net level, the profits were severely constrained by interest cost on debt (stood abnormally high at around 90% of total revenue in FY 2018) coupled with high depreciation cost (around 13-16% of revenue) during the review period. As a result, the Company incurred losses in FY 2017 which intensified in FY 2018 and, however, moderated in FY 2019. Ability of the Company to continue improve and sustain its margins at all levels remains critical.
Large working capital requirements largely funded from stretch in payables

The Company?s operations are working capital intensive. The receivable days have been increasing y-o-y as evident from collection period of 81 days in FY 2016 to 106 days in FY 2018. The increase in FY 2018 was on account of extended credit to few key customers on account of higher volume sales. Inventory days which majorly includes inventory for raw materials and packaging materials was range bound between 50-65 days. However, in order to meet its working capital requirements the payable days remained elongated between 195-200 days throughout the review. The Company does not avail any working capital facility and hence has to partially rely on extended credit from suppliers apart from internal accruals to fund its working capital. As informed by the management, some of the purchases were backed by L/C with payment terms of 180 days. Further, as notified, long standing relationship with its suppliers provides it with additional cushion of extended payable terms.
Accordingly, the working capital cycle was negative throughout the review period

Although the Company is not dependent on working capital debt, however, its working capital requirements remain high as seen in stretched receivable and payable days. This also had led to decline in cash flow from operations. Thus ability of the Company to improve its working capital management amidst growing scale of operations remains critical.

The Company derived around 40% of its revenue from Exphar S.A and the top 3 customers contributed around 60% to the topline. High revenue concentration towards few customers may have an impact on the topline of the Company in case of any adverse events or decline in orders from them. Long relationship spanning over three decades with the key customer - Exphar S.A coupled with their minor stake in the shareholding helps to mitigate the risk of concentration to some extent. Also, the Company is trying to address customer concentration risk by penetration in new regions like Philippines, Thailand, Ukraine, Ghana, Zimbabwe, Uzbekistan etc.

Further, in the past two years the Company has been highly reliant on its new product addition ? Paracetemol 665 MG which accounted for 44% of the total revenue in FY 2018. Although it has visibility of orders from its customers, ability to reduce product concentration to ensure stable revenue streams remains critical. Also, as informed, the Company plans to launch female sex hormones in international markets such as Europe and Australia which would aid in diversification of product profile.

The Company had a working capital-intensive nature of operations during the review period. Working capital cycle of the Company declined during the review period and remained high at 145 days in FY 2018. The working capital cycle remained high due to increased collection days which has increased twice as compared to previous year and also due to reduced payment days. Above that the inventory days is also on a higher side. The working capital cycle of the company will recover if all the account receivables are converted to cash in the next financial year or else the company will have to rely more on external borrowing for working capital requirement.

Debtors and inventory as a percentage of total current assets, on an average stood at around 65% and 25% respectively; indicating a significant amount being blocked thereby putting pressure on liquidity of the Company. The realisation of both the parameters required in the coming years so that the liquidity of the company can revive to a comfortable level.

However, the liquidity profile remained supported by a consistent improvement in cash flow generation and proceeds received from the private equity infusions which will aid HFL in prepaying some of its high-cost debt.

The Company predominantly caters to domestic market (90% of revenue) and to major OEMs, with about 15% of revenue coming from top customer and about 40% of revenue coming from top 3 customers. This leads to risk of concertation of revenue to key customers, which is somewhat mitigated by long standing relationships and the fact that these are top players in commercial vehicle segment with strong business risk profile.
High working capital intensity putting pressure on liquidity and net profitability coupled with high off-balance sheet liabilities

The Company predominantly caters to the Indian Railways and undertakes turnkey projects for its various bodies where the gestation period is long and payment receipt terms are elongated. Hence, the average receivable days stood over 200 days during the review period. Moreover, the receivable days increased y-o-y from 174 days in FY 2017 to 243 days in FY 2019, as the Company increased its scale of operations. As a result, the Company has high dependency on working capital debt apart from credit from suppliers to manage its working capital. As informed, the working capital debt utilization stands at almost 100%. Moreover, the Company undertakes its EPC business through its JVs who have also availed banking limits independently depending on the project the JV is floated for. The entire corporate guarantee for projects undertaken by the JVs is given by HYT. Bank guarantee on behalf of JVs stood high at INR 2,098,910 thousand (almost 171% of the tangible networth) which increases the total indebtedness of the Company.
Accordingly, the Company?s liquidity position stood moderate marked by current ratio of 1.39 times as on 31st March 2019 coupled with low unencumbered cash & bank balance 10,435 thousand.

Moreover, the Company?s net profit margins are weighed by high incidence of interest cost driven by high working capital debt utilization and incremental long-term debt for purchase of machinery. Interest cost including bank charges & bank guarantee commission as a percentage of revenue increased from 7.45% in FY 2017 to 9.28% in FY 2019. Ability of the Company to continue on the growth trajectory while further improving net margins remains critical.

However, as informed, the Company has minimal debtors realization risk as it caters to Indian Railways. Its working capital facilities sanctioned by the banker have factored in the high receivable days when catering to Indian railways. Hence, the Company is able to elongate its working capital cycle.
Moderately leveraged capital structure coupled with debt laden capex plans impacting coverage indicators

The Company?s financial risk profile remained moderately leveraged with a gearing of 1.29 times as on 31st March 2019. Also, there is working capital debt outstanding in the books of its JVs to the tune of INR 286,763 thousand as on 31st March 2019 which would further increase the overall leverage in the Company.

The Company?s borrowings increased y-o-y throughout the review period as significant additions to long term loans were made during FY 2019 to back its expansion plans coupled with increasing working capital debt during review period. With increasing revenue its working capital requirements increased which were largely funded through working capital debt apart from internal accruals. This is evident from sharp increase in short-term borrowings with utilization levels at around 95-100%. Higher utilization of working capital resulted increasing outflow of interest coupled with increasing bank guarantee commission expense from the non-fund based limit which are entirely utilized as well. Accordingly, the interest coverage ratio declined y-o-y from 3.40 times in FY 2017 to 2.89 times in FY 2019.
Ability of the Company to reduce dependency on debt and withstand from further decline in interest coverage remains critical.

The Company derives almost entire revenue from the Indian Railways and its associated organizations such COFMOW, ICF, and all other zonal railways. Although the Company has along standing relationship with the Indian Railways, its entire business is dependent on tenders floated by the government orgasnisation. Also, the terms of payment with the government organization are elongated which requires it to continuously depend on banking facilities as and when order inflows increase. Customer concentration could be detrimental to the Company?s growth prospects as any change in procurement policy of its customers or better pricing from the Company?s competitor may adversely impact the topline of the Company.

Although an integrated player, the Company derives a significant portion of its revenue from commoditized services such as business application services, global infrastructure services, application development and maintenance and others which have high competitive intensity. The traditional services provided by the Company accounted for approximately two third of its total revenue for FY 2019. The marginal decline in the profitability levels (operating) can also be attributed to the pricing pressure from the clients following the economic slowdown in the Company?s key markets and increase in the compensation costs.

The Company has earmarked USD 100 million for investments in startups in innovative technologies (which is expected to augment revenue from new technologies), to renew existing offerings and achieve growth through in-organic route. Furthermore, the Company expects that its investments in domains like SMAC (Social, Mobile, Analytics and Cloud) and new technologies like internet of things, sensor-based technology will enable it drive revenue from these new services which will balance the revenue mix and will also benefit in increasing margins as new technologies command pricing premium based on capability to deliver those services. Revenue from digital services increased to 31% in FY 2019 compared to 25.2% in FY 2018. Further, the Company is implementing industrialization (automation of processes) of a few processes for rendering services like infrastructure management services, independent validation services which will improve productivity and maintain/improve margins of traditional services.
Challenging economic environment in the developed markets of Americas and Europe

The Company, on a standalone basis derived around 85% of its FY 2019 revenue from developed markets of Americas & Europe, exposing it to geographical concentration risk. These markets witnessed a deep economic slowdown during the financial crisis that started in FY 2008. Though, both the economies have shown signs of economic recovery, high accumulated debt of these nations (resulting in high fiscal deficit) and risk of a euro-zone crisis due to Brexit, which could result in contagion across other euro zone countries, could deteriorate the short term economic environment. In such an environment, the clients start cutting down discretionary IT spends resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiate the contract value resulting in pressure on margins. Existing customers start commanding pricing power by lowering costs and increasing volumes. Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it very difficult for the IT companies to bag new contracts. IT budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing IT spend and postponing investments. Therefore, the ability of the group to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets remains extremely critical.
Leveraged capital structure albeit improvement backed by acquisitions

The capital structure of the Group deteriorated substantially during FY 2019 which, however, has depicted an improvement over the past two years ended FY 2019. The Group during FY 2017 acquired Actavis Ireland Limited (generics division) in UK and Ireland from Teva Pharmaceuticals Limited for an enterprise value of GBP 603 million. Intas India and its subsidiary Accord Healthcare Limited had availed bank borrowings amounting to INR 4,842 crore in FY 2017 to fund this acquisition. The goodwill created on account of acquisition for around INR 4,422 crore led to substantial deterioration in the capital structure of the Group. Further, it acquired Essential Pharmaceuticals in FY 2018 resulting in increase in the goodwill as well as debt as it was funded through borrowings of USD 50 million. On adding back goodwill, the debt equity ratio has been below 1 time over the past two years.

Despite additional debt, the Group?s capital structure depicted an improvement y-o-y basis on the back of healthy profitability and accretions to reserves. Nonetheless, the capital structure remained leveraged at 1.93 times as on 31st March 2019. As informed by management, the capital structure is expected to remain at around 1.5 times during the current fiscal (FY 2020). Any further debt funded acquisition may have an impact on the capital structure of the Group and hence it remains critical to improve profitability and increase its accretions to reserves to lower down its gearing levels over the near to medium term.

The operations of the Group remained working capital intensive primarily emanating from its large inventory holding and moderate collection cycle. As majority of the sales are through its subsidiaries, Accord group of companies, and it needs to cater to regular demand from customers, inventory holding is high especially in the European market. Further, large product portfolio also results in large inventory levels. Collection cycle has remained moderate in the range of 80 to 100 days over a period of five years. This has led to large working capital requirements with working capital cycle ranging between 123 to 262 days through five year period ending FY 2019.

These requirements are met through creditors, advances from customers and bank borrowings. As indicated by management, the average utilization of the bank lines is around 55% to 60%. The cash flow from operations also declined, although remained positive during FY 2019. Thus it remains critical for the Group to efficiently manage its working capital requirements amidst increasing scale of operations.
Subdued performance of Integreon Group albeit improvement since investment from new PE

Integreon Group is engaged in providing LPO/BPO services and the Company is one of the offshore delivery centre of the Group. During CY 2016, the Group recorded losses on account of Brexit resulting in slow growth and depreciation of Pound against USD. In addition, during the year ended 31st December 2016, a new PE investor NewQuest Capital acquired the entire stake in the Group from erstwhile PE holders namely Actis and LiveIt. Hence, the losses incurred in FY 2016 were majorly on account of some exceptional expenses like onetime bonus, restructuring and consultancy expenses, severance fees paid to a few key management personnel, etc. coupled with high selling, general and administrative expenses and heavy project-based expenses.

With the new PE investment coming in CY 2016, there have been increased measures towards improving internal efficiencies. This resulted in the group recording profits at EBITDA level in CY 2017 and turning profitable in CY 2018. Also, the competition in LPO market is increasing, thereby putting pricing pressure on the Group and impacting the profitability.

As informed, the business development units of the Group established in USA and UK, offshores around 40% of total Group?s operations to Integreon India and Integreon India has around 40% of total employee base of the Group. Although, since the Integreon India is captive business centre and revenue is booked at cost plus mark up, nevertheless the operations of the Company are entirely dependent on the order book of the business development units. Also, as informed, the group companies (customers of Integreon India) outsource the contracts among different delivery centers based on skill sets and hence ability of the Company to continue to secure contracts from its group companies remains critical.

Accordingly, although the growth rate was healthy in FY 2017, the growth rate of revenue and profit was relatively muted in FY 2018. However, the same is expected to increase in FY 2019 and going forward.
Thus, the ability of the Group to increase its scale of operations and improve profitability remains crucial for the Company to scale up and improve profitability.
Stretched receivables of Integreon India to support group?s cash flow

Entire of the Company?s revenue is derived by undertaking the outsourced services for its group entities. Although the billing for the services rendered is done on monthly basis, there are delays in receipt from its group entities. The Company?s collection cycle stood at an average of 309 days over the three years ended FY 2018. However, the receivables outstanding for more than six months reduced to 15% of the outstanding debtors in FY 2018 as against 41% o in FY 2017. Although the Company has not availed any external debt to manage these working capital requirements, its cash & bank balance remained low. Albeit entire of its receivables are from its group entities, any stretch in receipts by those entities from end customers may further result in delays in payments to IMSIPL which is likely to have an impact on the cash flows.
As informed, the credit policy of the Group to its external customers is around 3-4 months, with receivable days at 50-60 days in the past three years ended CY 2018.
De-growth in revenue and modest profitability supported by non-operating income

The revenue of the Company observed a decline of approx. 18% in FY 2018 and 13% in FY 2017, as informed, owing to reduction in trading business. Further, the profitability of the Company stood at modest levels marked by declining gross margins owing to high material costs. Modest profitability resulted in low return indicators as highlighted in the below table ?

The Company had sizeable liquid investments (lien marked) during the review period which resulted in substantial non-operating income in the form of interest income which supported the net margins. At consolidated levels, the revenue observed a de-growth mainly due to headwinds in the oil and gas sector with drop in prices globally. Further, the group incurred extraordinary loss in FY 2018 due to impairment of assets in the associate Company I.e. Dynamic Offshore Drilling Limited - Cyprus resulting in losses at net levels. As informed, the Group would be focusing on the EPC segment going ahead and the revenue from oil and drilling has dropped to INR 200 crores in FY 2019 with only 2 active rigs with ONGC. As apprised, the revenue at standalone has increased to INR 160 crores in FY 2019 with EBITDA margin of 10-12%.
Subcontracting risk coupled with fixed price contracts may lead to increased time and cost overruns

The construction projects of the Company face the risk of time and cost overruns. With inflationary pressures plaguing the domestic economy, time delays could lead to cost escalations. Given the fixed price nature of few contracts, the ability of the Company to pass on the increase in raw material prices is restricted. The Company sub contracts many of its activities. General risks associated with subcontracting such as lack of control, quality etc. may further fuel the time and cost overruns. As informed, there is an escalation clause in most of the contracts of the Company which mitigates the risk of cost overruns to certain extent.
Low profitability at consolidated level due to loss making subsidiary and limited pricing flexibility

The Company has a subsidiary in the USA, Jash USA Inc. which has been incurring losses over the past few years on account of sub optimal capacity utilization and high employee related expenses. Accordingly, the operating and net profitability of the group remained low as it was weighed by losses of the subsidiary at a consolidated level.

Further, JEL is exposed to volatility in prices of raw materials (steel and castings) as against fixed price orders from its clientele. The duration of contracts range between 2-7 months depending on the size of the project. Any significant volatility in the material costs might impact the profitability of the Company. Also, the bargaining power of the Company remains limited as it deals with reputed clientele in a competitive industry. Thus, the profitability of the Company was fluctuating during the review period.

However, as indicated, with increased contribution from export revenue and US subsidiary; operating leverage is slowly kicking in. Accordingly, margins improved in FY 2019 and are to further increase as the US subsidiary is expected to breakeven on the back of healthy order book in FY 2020. However, ability of the group to demonstrate this improvement remains critical.
Working capital intensive nature of operation leading along with moderate liquidity position

JEL?s operation are working capital intensive. This large requirement emanates from its elongated inventory days and collection days. Inventory and collection period stood high at 123 and 173 days respectively as on 31st March 2019. The Company usually maintains high inventory for non-routine items resulting in high inventory holding. Furthermore, some inventory is lying with the Company as the customers are not taking delivery due to financial constraint at client?s end and projects delays. Also, there have been instances of delay in receipt of payment from customers, as a consequence of which the Company had written off bad debts over the review period.

The Company manages its high working capital intensity through extended credit from suppliers, advance from customers, and working capital debt from banks. The working capital limit utilization has been increasing y-o-y during the review period and currently the average utilization stands at 90%. It is in process of enhancing its limits to support increasing export business.

The aforementioned factors have resulted into low liquidity position during the review period wherein the current and quick ratio stood at 1.28 times and 0.86 times respectively as on 31st March 2019. Lower quick ratio was on account of high inventory forming part of total current assets. Moreover, inventory and account receivables stood on an average at above 85% of the total current assets during the entire review period.

As informed, to overcome the same the Company is penetrating to overseas markets as seen in increased order flow from regulated markets such as Singapore and UK. It expects timely receipt of payment from overseas customers which is likely to help the Company manage its high working capital intensity.

Although the Company was able to grow its topline during FY 2018 and FY 2019, the profitability of the Company witnessed uneven trend and stood moderate across all levels. Uneven trend across the gross level was primarily driven by the cost of raw materials and finished good consumed (which on average stood at ~70% of the total revenue during the review period). The key raw material required by the Company is stainless steel scrap which is mainly imported and the prices for which are governed by London Metal Exchange (LME) prices. Over a period of March 2017 to March 2019, the prices have fluctuated heavily in the range of USD 270 to USD 384 per MT. Gross profitability stood further strained with y-o-y increasing freight expenses and job work charges. Profit margins at the net level witnessed a declining trend throughout the review period driven by a y-o-y increase in interest expenses due to the high short term working capital borrowing from banks. Return indicators of the Company witnessed a declining trend following the reducing profitability and the increasing tangible networth and capital employed.
Going forward, the ability of the Company to sustain and improve its margins while improving its scale of operations amidst volatile raw material prices remains crucial.
Leveraged capital structure skewed towards short term working capital borrowings

The capital structure of the Company stood leveraged with a gearing of 2.02 times as on 31st March 2019. The Company?s reliance on external borrowings has remained high primarily to fund its capital expenditure plans and working capital requirements. ~72% of the total debt as on 31st March 2019 comprised working capital borrowings. Leveraged capital structure would restrict the financial flexibility of the Company while procuring funds for any of its capacity expansion plans. Furthermore, with y-o-y increase with interest expenses coupled with moderate EBIT, the interest coverage ratio of the Company stood moderate at 2.32 times for FY 2019. Any further reliance on the external debt would deteriorate the leverage metrics and restrict the financial flexibility of the Company. Incremental debt would also result in higher interest costs which could limit the ability of the Company to service its interest obligations.
Working capital intensive nature of operations resulting in modest liquidity position

The nature of operations of the Company is working capital intensive as reflected in the stretched working capital cycle of 181 days as on 31st March 2019. Working capital intensive operations are primarily driven by high collection and inventory days. Inventory days stood in the range of 117 to 151 days during the review period. The collection velocity of the Company stood high during the review period driven by high credit period commanded by customers (mainly overseas customers). These working capital requirements are primarily funded through working capital borrowings and extended credit to suppliers thereby constraining the liquidity position of the Company.

Solvency ratios of the Company stood moderate during the review period as witnessed in current and quick ratios of 1.12 times and 0.50 times during FY 2019. Incremental working capital requirements required to fund the rapid growth in scale of operations resulted in negative cash flow from operations during FY 2017 and FY 2018. However, the liquidity position as on 31st March 2019 showcased an improvement as the collection period of the Company improved drastically providing some relief on the liquidity end. Further, liquidity stood supported in y-o-y increase in net cash accruals which was sufficient against the near term debt obligations.

As informed, the Company is currently functioning only at 70-75% of its manufacturing capacity. However, for further scaleup in operations, the Company has applied for additional short term working capital loan limiting its current ability to expand in the absence of additional liquidity support. Ability of the Company to scale up operations while avoiding dependence on external working capital requirement to improve, net profitability, return indicators, leverage as well as liquidity position therefore remains crucial.
Transfer of business to group company resulting to decline in revenue and profit levels

In FY 2018, the Company has recorded high revenue growth which resulted in increased economies of scale and thereby led to strong profitability margins. However, as informed, in FY 2019, the Company has seen a reduction in revenue recorded as the Company lost the advantage in rice trading derived from reduced import duty on rice and transferred some of its trading business to its group company in Bangladesh. These have resulted in decline in operating and net margin as shown in the table below.

The decline in revenue has led to higher fixed cost per revenue unit leading to reduced operating and net profitability during FY 2019. Further, reduced profitability ratios have also impacted the return indicators which have reduced during the year.
Need for steady revenue visibility despite diversified business operations across segments with revision in revenue in FY 2019

Since inception in October 2016, the Company has recognised revenue through different business segments which included trading of various unrelated commodities like rice & other agro products, stone chips & boulders and coal. Further, the Company also has licenses for mining at three sand ghats with operating leases up to FY 2021 and has diversified by setting up a rice mill, which was commissioned in January 2019. The Company?s revenue showed a lot of variations with trading in onions and fabric being major contributor to revenue in FY 2017, trading in rice contributing to majority revenue in FY 2018 and the subsequent decline in revenue from trading of rice leading to substantial decline in overall revenue in FY 2019. The same was visible during FY 2019 when the Company recorded net revenue of INR 820,094 thousand due to a number of reasons. Stability in revenue from business segments over the near to medium term remains critical from the view of continuity and improvement in its scale of operations.
Low profitability on the back of significant portion of revenue from traditional services and high operating costs

Although an integrated service provider, the Group derives a significant portion of its revenue from commoditized services such as application development and maintenance which have high competitive intensity. These traditional services accounted for over 75% of its total revenue in FY 2018 and have remained in similar lines since the past few years. High portion of revenue derived from these services results in pricing pressure from the clients following the economic slowdown in the Group?s key markets.

Moreover, although the revenue and profits, both grew at a healthy rate since the past three years ended FY 2018, the overall profitability was pulled down by high operating costs pertaining to professional fees, travelling expense (given majority of the revenue is from subsidiaries in the USA and UK) and management charges (pertained to incremental expense of hiring top management). These operating expenses cumulatively stood high at 20-23% of the total revenue resulting in weak operating profitability. As a result, the operating and net profitability stood low at 6.20% and 3.58% respectively in FY 2018.

However, the management indicated the topline has been increasing since FY 2017. Its growth rate was over 12% in FY 2017 and FY 2018. As informed, it recorded even higher growth of over 26% in FY 2019 and projects healthier growth in FY 2020 as well on the back of increased wallet share from existing customers, continuous addition to customer base, and increase in average deal value. Also, as informed, the management has also been investing in next generation technology such as robotics, artificial intelligence, and analytics and expects to see more traction in revenue streams in the medium term. However, its ability to further increase profitability amidst growth in topline remains critical.
Geographical concentration risk with the USA and UK accounting for significant portion of the total revenue

As informed, the group derived over 87% of its revenue from the USA and UK markets with 72% of the revenue being generated from the USA, depicting geographical concentration risk. This trend remained over the past few years. Also, these markets have witnessed an economic slowdown during the financial crisis that started in FY 2008 and are still under recovery. Though both the economies have shown signs of economic recovery, high accumulated debt of these nations (resulting in high fiscal deficit), and euro-zone crisis such as Brexit etc. which could result in contagion across other euro zone countries could deteriorate the short term economic environment. In such an environment, the clients start cutting on discretionary IT spending resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiation of the contract value resulting in pressure on margins.

Existing customers start commanding pricing power or cut costs by means of vendor consolidation, in-sourcing or captive set ups.
