Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it difficult for the IT companies to bag new contracts. IT budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing IT spending and postponing investments. Therefore, the ability of the group to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets remains critical. However, in the backdrop of this macro-economic environment, the Group has been able to acquire new customers and win larger deals and expand its capabilities in digital services.
Weak liquidity profile resulting from high finance costs despite reducing borrowings

While the operations of the Company remain working capital intensive requiring high working capital borrowing, the Company has also availed long term loans which have been passed on to is subsidiary in France (Jyoti, SAS) to fund the operations of its step-down subsidiary, Huron which has been incurring operational losses and erosion of networth. As a result of the same, while the Company is unable to receive interest income from Huron, the financial liabilities arising out of its loans have to be borne by the Company. As a result, the Company?s financial costs have increased leading to increase in monthly outgo for servicing of interest obligations. The Company has faced several challenges in servicing these obligations in FY 2019 which is apparent in the delayed payments to banks ranging from 1 to 13 days for payments which ranged from INR 2,084 thousand to INR 7,500 thousand indicating weak liquidity. Further, the Company has also delayed in payment of EPFO dues for its employees on several occasions. Though, the Company has been slowly reducing its external debt obligations to ensure y-o-y reduction in finance cost and repayment obligations and improve liquidity, the ability of the Company to ensure profitable operations of its subsidiary to reduce its financial burden remains crucial.

The Company manufactures complex machinery which require several spares and parts made from a gamut of raw materials. This requires the Company to maintain a huge raw material inventory. In addition to this, the Company is required to maintain work in progress inventory as long as the product is kept in its premises. This results in large work in progress inventory at the Company?s end thereby leading to a huge inventory holding period for the Company. This inventory is recorded as sales only when the product is installed at the customer premise after which the customer takes nearly 60 days on commissioning of the machinery to make payment. Further, the Company has receivables from related parties amounting to INR 747,501 thousand. This has resulted in high receivables for the Company. Overall, the working capital requirement of the Company is drawn out due to the complex nature of the product and its implementation at the customers end. This requirement is funded mainly through working capital borrowings, trade payables, advances from customers as well as through internal cash accruals. The working capital cycle of the Company is shown in the table below.
Going forward, the ability of the Company to prudently manage its working capital operations will remain crucial to improving the overall financial profile of the Company as well as the Group.
Moderate profitability margins leading to modest return indicators

The Company provides specialized machinery to its customers. This machinery involves large number of complex parts which are designed and assembled in a complex pattern to serve specific applications for the customers. While some of this machinery sold to customers is low end and is manufactured by a number of players leading to restriction on pricing and margins, certain amount of the revenue is obtained from complex machinery which provides scope for better realizations and margins. However, over the years, the increasing cost of materials has led to reduction in gross and operating margins of the Company. Further, the high external borrowings to fund operations of the Company as well as that of its subsidiaries has led to increased interest costs which have further moderated the net margins leading to moderate overall profitability of the Company as shown in the table below.

Moderate margins have further led to modest return indicators as the Company has invested INR 288,291 thousand in the form of equity and has lent INR 1,261,562 thousand to its subsidiaries to fund their operations. The net margin is further moderate (as shown in the table below) on adjustment of non-operating income which comprised mainly of interest income from subsidiaries and other non-operating income during FY 2019.
Going forward, the ability of the Company to improve its profitability and its return indicators will remain crucial.
Kay Jay?s financial risk profile has remained moderate on back of leveraged gearing, moderate profitability, returns and liquidity

Company has expended nearly INR 100 crores in the five year review period for enhancing capacities to cater to new orders for TVS group. The capex was majorly funded through debt. Kay Jay?s gearing increased from 1.20 times in FY 2014 to about 1.50 times in FY 2018. Increased gearing resulted in the rise in interest expenditure. Though, improved realizations and revenue scale supported the margins at OPBDITA level (7-8%) which remained moderate and has shown minor fluctuations in the five year review period, however, high interest expenditure has impacted the net level margin which ranged between 1.6%-2.6%. For FY 2019, increased debt and high interest expenditure is estimated to further lower the net margin for the year. Returns too has shown fluctuations with increasing capital employed. Revenue growth has shown an erratic trend with strong growth in FY 2015, FY 2018 and estimated FY 2019. Increasing scale, optimum capacity utilization of the expanded capacities would remain important for generation of efficient returns. For FY 2018, ROTNW (Return on Tangible Net Worth) and ROCE (Return on Capital Employed) stood at 15% and 14% respectively.

Liquidity remained moderate with decline in current ratios for FY 2017, FY 2018 on account of increase in creditors, maturing term loan obligations and the short term borrowings. Company generated sufficient cash accruals of INR 216,319 thousand in FY 2018 against CPLTD of INR 171,317 thousand in FY 2017. Also, the promoters have bought in additional unsecured loans in FY 2019 of about 4 crores to support the high revenue growth thus providing financial flexibility.

Kay Jay has high dependence on TVS group with the customer forming over 50% of its total revenue in FY 2018. This also makes Company more susceptible to industry segment concentration risk as its major revenues are from the two-wheeler segment. The risk is to some extent mitigated by the Company?s strong relations with the key client and TVS group is amongst the market leaders in two-wheeler segment, however, any cyclicality seen in the key customer?s business could directly impact the Company?s topline. Further, Kay Jay has low exposure in export market which forms around 5% of the total revenues. As informed, the Company is focusing to grow its export market and has received enquiries from the export players. Kay Jay in FY 2018 has commenced its supplies to Royal Enfield. Diversification of customers and industry segment would remain critical in the long run.

The Company derived around 85% of its revenue from overseas market which mainly includes North America, Europe and Rest of World (RoW). Approximately, 55% of the revenue was from North America and around 18% from European region, indicating risk of geographical concentration. The Indian technology and outsourcing industry is facing challenges owing to uncertain global economic environment and the existing Brexit uncertainty. Reforms to the way H-1B and L-1 visas are granted also remains a sticking point in near future. These reforms could limit the number of Indian technology professionals, the technology companies can ship to USA and increase the cost of business.

Further, these markets witnessed a economic slowdown during the financial crisis that started in FY 2008 and continued to be somewhat impacted by the economic recession. During tough times, the clients start cutting on R&D spends resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiate the contract value resulting in pressure on margins. Existing customers start commanding pricing power or cut costs by means of vendor consolidation, in-sourcing or captive set ups. This can be witnessed in CY (FY 2020) as one of the key customer had resorted to in-sourcing which is expected to effect the LTTS revenues. Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it very difficult for the technology companies to bag new contracts. R&D budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing spend and postponing investments. Also, there is uncertainty around the impact of China-USA trade war which might affect some industries like semiconductors. Therefore, the ability of the Company to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets (as witnessed currently in India) remains critical.
As informed, North America being the largest market for ER&D companies across the globe, LTTS?s focus would continue to remain North America for generation of revenue.
Large working capital requirements resulting in modest liquidity

The Company?s working capital requirements have remained large which primarily emanated from its high collection cycle. The contracts executed by the Company are for a duration of 24 to 36 months and has milestone-based payments. As indicated, around 10% of the contract value is received on advance basis while the balance is on milestone basis. 10% of the money is submitted as retention amount which is received after the completion of contract. Further as informed by management, during the first six months of the contracts which generally includes the designing work, the Company does not receive any payments resulting in large working capital requirements.

Although collection cycle has improved during the review period, the same remained high at 296 days as on 31st March 2019 with 14% of the debtors outstanding for more than a year (same came down from 25% during previous year). Further retention amount stood high at INR 152 crore as on 31st March 2019. In case retention money is added to receivables, the collection cycle goes upto 400 days. These large working capital requirements are funded through customer advances, extended credit from suppliers and bank borrowings.

High reliance on short term borrowings coupled with large payables and advances from customers led to modest liquidity ratios. The current ratio remained below 1.5 times throughout the review period. Furthermore, the cash flow from operations also declined during FY 2019. With increase in scale of operations, the working capital requirements may increase, and hence prudent management of working capital requirement remains critical over near to medium term.
Subdued financial profile with large dependence on borrowings

The financial profile of the Company remained subdued marked by its leveraged capital structure and low interest coverage ratio. Large working capital requirements led to large dependence on borrowings resulting in high debt equity ratio. The borrowings of the Company have been skewed towards short term debt and its capital structure stood at 1.64 times as on 31st March 2019. With modest profitability and large interest outflow due to high borrowings led to low interest coverage ratio and which stood at 1.35 times during FY 2019.
Leveraged capital structure restricts the financial flexibility of the Company to avail additional debt to fund its incremental working requirements or capital expenditure plans if any.
Low profitability and return indicators resulting from limited pricing flexibility

The Company?s revenue depicted an uneven trend during the review period. It declined in FY 2018 on the back of weak industry sentiments; however, improved during FY 2019 with increased execution of orders. The profitability of the Company remained low throughout the review period. The contracts executed by the Company are fixed price in nature resulting in limited pricing flexibility and hence ability to pass on raw material price rise to the end users. Furthermore, the operating margins have remained low on account of high freight cost and write off of bad debts. The bad debts substantially increased during FY 2019 which accounted for around 6% of the topline. The management expects additional write offs of around INR 60 crore to INR 70 crore over the next 2 years which is likely to have an impact on the Company?s profitability levels.

The net profits of the Company remained low given the high interest costs with large dependence on borrowings. However, non-operating income in the form of liabilities and provisions written back, interest income, profit on foreign exchange gain and others which accounted for around 2.5% of the topline. Exclusion of same, the Company has incurred losses at net level during FY 2018 and FY 2019.

Low profitability with high dependence on debt has led to low returns throughout the review period. As informed by management, the revenue for current fiscal is expected to remain stagnant. Hence it remains critical for the Company to improve its profitability and returns over the near to medium term.

Although MBPL undertakes contracts for various industries such as power, steel, cement, sugar, alumina and others, around 80% of the revenue is derived from contracts executed in the power sector. This sector witnessed sluggish growth owing to cancellation of coal mining licenses, issues of coal linkage for power plants, environmental clearances, land acquisitions, and inefficient infrastructure. Its clientele base includes companies such as NTPC, BHEL, Adani Power Limited, Tata Projects Limited and others. However, around 47% of the revenue during FY 2019 was derived from BHEL. Further, of the order book of INR 1,400 crore as well, majority is from contracts of BHEL resulting in the risk of customer as well as sector concentration.

Further, the engineering sector in India attracts immense interest from foreign players as it enjoys a comparative advantage in terms of manufacturing costs, technology and innovation. Due to the increasing demand in various sectors such as housing, commercial construction and industrial construction, cement industry is expected to reach 550-600 Million Tonnes Per Annum (MTPA) by the year 2025. Moreover, the increased budgetary allocation for the infrastructure sector, which includes roads, railways, metro, irrigation and housing, during 2018-19 will directly and indirectly support cement demand.

Thus, with anticipated growth in infrastructure, and thrust on power sector with schemes such as UDAY, Deendayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) and Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS) etc. and an expected demand in cement, the Company would be able to augment its revenues going ahead.
Stretch in working capital leading to reliance of external borrowings

The Company has working capital-intensive nature of operations. Working capital cycle of the Company was uneven during the review period. It declined during FY 2018 but stood high at 151 days as on FY 2018. It remained high due to increased collection days. As informed, the Company deals with state electricity boards hence, collections from them are usually delayed.. The inventory days have been in a comfortable range mostly due to low inventory maintained by the Company.

Even though the working capital cycle has declined in FY 2018, the dependency on the working capital loans from banks has increased as credit extended by suppliers is lower. As informed, account receivables from state electricity boards, after realization, will improve the actual liquidity position in the future and reduce the reliance of the Company on external borrowings.

The debt to equity ratio has improved during the review period as a result of increase in the equity of the Company (contributed by issue of equity shares at premium and retained profit for the year). The long-term debt to equity has improved due to increase in the equity coupled with decline in the long-term loan from the banks. However, the total debt to equity ratio even though improved, has remained elevated throughout the review period. The total loans of the Company have declined in FY 2018 on the account of enhanced equity position but has been partially set off by an increase the short-term borrowings from the banks to support the working capital cycle of the Company.

The liquidity of the Company has declined in the review period but managed to stay in a comfortable level throughout. The current ratio has remained above 1.5 times mainly contributed by high account receivables. The inventory maintained by the Company has been on a lower side, so the quick ratio also remained in a comfortable position. As informed, account receivables from state electricity boards, after realization will improve the actual liquidity position in the future and reduce the reliance of the Company on external borrowings.
With the increase in the scale of operations, prudent management of working capital cycle thereby reducing its reliance on external borrowings remains a crucial aspect.

High competition in the sector limits the pricing flexibility of the Company resulting in low margins. In addition, most of the suppliers and customers of the Company are leading in their respective domain, which results in its limited pricing bargaining power. The profitability indicators have shown an improvement in FY 2018 as compared to previous year but still remained low. The revenue has shown a two-fold increase but the same is not reflected in the profits generated by the Company due to a proportionate increase in the expenses. Also, an increase in interest outflow on loans has also restricted the growth of net profit of the Company. Further, low margins led to low return as depicted in the table below:
Thus, the ability of the Company to improve margins and returns amidst competition and while scaling its operations remains critical.

The group operates in a highly competitive industry dominated by large players. Mphasis, being a mid-sized IT player, its profitability, although improved, remained moderate with operating profits of around 16% during FY 2019. Return on tangible networth (RoTN) and return on capital employed (RoCE) remained moderate and stood at 22% and 19.6%, respectively, during FY 2018. However, with buyback of equity shares undertaken by the group, the tangible networth declined as on FY 2019. This along with improvement in profitability in FY 2019 lead to adequate RoTN and RoCE.

The group?s key focus areas are digital, GRC, AI and others. During the first quarter of FY 2020, the group won a deal of USD 151 million which was in the direct international business and of these deals around 80% were of NextGen services. The profitability depicted an improvement during H1 FY 2019 and stood at 14% at net levels with RoCE of around 18% during the same period. The group?s ability to improve its profitability and sustain growth while exploring these newer service areas remains critical.
Steady payout to the promoter group through dividends

Marble II Pte (Singapore) holds around 52.23% stake in the group. It had during 2016-17 availed senior notes which are due in 2022 and are structurally subordinated to the creditors and cash flows of the group. With obligations due in 2022, its reliance on dividend outflow from Mphasis group remains critical.

Although the group has a strong financial and liquidity profile with large unencumbered liquid investments and increasing cash accruals, the quantum of dividend outflow has remained large during the review period. During FY 2018 and FY 2019, there was a cash outflow in the form of dividend payments to the tune of 47% and 51% of the net profits earned. Further the Company bought back equity shares in FY 2018 of 17,370,078 equity shares of the group, representing 8.26% of the total paid up equity share capital of the group, at a price of INR 635 per share, for an aggregate amount of INR 11,030 million and in FY 2019 of 7,320,555 fully paid-up equity shares, representing 3.79% of the total paid-up equity share capital of the Company, at a price of INR 1,350 per equity share for an aggregate consideration of INR 9,882.75 million. This steady cash outflow of dividend from Mphasis is expected to continue for the medium to long term and therefore reduces financial flexibility for the Company.

Although the group provides information technology services, business and knowledge outsourcing solutions, majority of its revenue is derived from application maintenance, application development, customer services and others which accounts for around 60% of the topline. However, the group is focusing on NextGen services which is expected to diversify its service offerings. The group has won the highest quarterly deal of USD 210 million of which 77% are of NextGen services.

Further, the group?s top five clients contributed 47% to its FY 2019 consolidated revenues, indicating revenue concentration across some key clients. As informed, the group has strong relations with its existing customers and is able to maintain key large accounts and get renewal contracts from them. Also, given the time (about 12-18 months) taken to win a new deal in an ITeS industry, the client concentration amongst existing clients remains high.

However, client concentration among some key clients may entail a risk in case of business slowdown of the customer. The same is evident from the fact that the group?s revenue growth was impacted in FY 2017 on account of continuous ramp down by HP customers which still contributes largely to the consolidated revenues. Though MSA has been signed with HP which provides revenue visibility, increase in the volume from existing key clients and new client wins in the direct business would aid diversification, going forward.
Modest and uneven profitability given the trading nature of operations

The Group reported a robust revenue growth in FY 2019 with a healthy CAGR 34% during the review period driven by pig iron sales. The profitability level though improving, remained modest at about 3.35% (at operating profit level) for FY 2019. The modest profitability was owing to trading nature of operations. However, substantial non-operating income generated by dividend and interest income resulted in relatively higher net profit margin during the review period.

Modest profitability ratios have resulted in low return indicators during the review period as reflected in its return on tangible networth and return on capital employed of 11.97% and 8.14%, respectively during FY 2017. However, supported by robust revenue growth coupled with improved profitability in FY 2019, the return on tangible networth and return on capital employed increased to 18.53% and 13.52% respectively. Sustenance of the improved margins leading to higher return remains a key rating sensitivity factor. After exclusion of non-operating income (interest and liabilities and provisions written back), the Group?s net profit level would decline to1% and below throughout the review period. Hence improvement in profitability and returns while scaling up of operations remains critical over the near to medium term.
High reliance on external debt to fund working capital requirements

The Group?s working capital requirements have remained high driven by its moderate inventory holding and high collection cycle. Its collection cycle has been around 2 months whereas inventory holding has been around 30 days. The working capital cycle of the Group remained in the range of 68 to 70 days during the review period owing to swift payments made by creditors.

These working capital requirements of the Group have been managed largely through external borrowings, as it needs to make immediate or advance payment to its suppliers. Large reliance of external debt has resulted in leveraged capital structure of the Group. It increased substantially for FY 2018 and FY 2019, remained at 3.10 times in FY 2019 vis-a-vis 2.46 times in FY 2017, due to high Inter-Group long term loans and increased incremental debt funded working capital requirements. Outstanding short term loans nearly doubled to support the increase in scale. Although the leverage ratio has remained high throughout the review period, the coverage indicator, remained modest at around 1.79 times during FY 2019. High dependency on borrowings limits the financial flexibility of the Group to leverage further to fund any incremental working capital requirements or any business exigencies.
Risk of susceptibility to volatility in exchange rates

Majority of MTC?s revenue is derived from the domestic market whereas it sources around 40% of its products from international market. This exposes the Group?s profitability to volatility in foreign exchange rates. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. As informed, the Group completely hedges the forex exposure at the time of selling the material. MTC hedges 100% of its foreign exchange exposure with the banks but in case of higher forward premiums in banks, or requirement of hedging after banking hours the Group hedges the same on NSE. Although the Group completely hedges this risk via derivatives, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected by the Group and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with absence of any natural hedge, exposes the Group to the risk of incurring losses on foreign exchange transactions, especially when the exchange rates are volatile. This is reflected in the foreign exchange losses incurred by the Group in FY 2019.
Working capital intensive nature of operations leading to moderate liquidity position

The Company has working capital intensive nature of operations. The working capital cycle is mainly driven by high collection period and inventory holding. The average collection period is about 110 days. In order to cater to day-to-day working capital requirements of the Company, it relies on short-term borrowings as well as stretched payment to suppliers. This is evident from high payables of 186 days (average) and average working capital utilization of 95%. Further, inventory days remained high throughout the review period, with an average inventory holding of 228 days. Raw material inventory contributed about 53% of the total inventory outstanding as on 31st March 2019. As indicated, the Company needs to maintain raw material inventory of 4.5 months in advance, specifically in case of chrome steel, which is imported from South Korea, Japan and France. This, in turn, leads to increase in inventory days. Thus, the working capital requirements have remained high.

High collection and inventory holding has led to moderate liquidity position during the review period which has also impacted the net cash flow from operating activities during the review period. Current and quick ratio stood at 1.38 times and 0.67 times respectively as on 31st March 2018. Any further stretch in the working capital cycle may have an impact on the cash flows of the Company and hence prudent management of the same remains critical.
Leveraged capital structure leading to high interest costs and impacting the net margins of the Company and consequently the returns

The Company had a leveraged capital structure during the review period, driven by both long term and short- term borrowings. The Company has high working capital requirement which is primarily funded through working capital loans availed from banks. As a result of high working capital utilization and debt funded year on year capex (funded through FI?s and unsecured loans), its gearing ratio increased from 1.45 times as on 31st March 2017 to 1.71 times as on 31st March 2019. As indicated, fresh long-term debt from Tata Capital was contracted towards the year end which inflated the gearing. The Company has acquired 300 machineries from South Korea Company (on a slump sale basis). The capacity is expected to increase to 4 to 5 times from the existing level once the newly installed machineries become fully operational. The benefits on the capex will accrue over time in terms of increased realizations which in turn is expected to reduce gearing over the medium to long run.

The Company also witnessed high incidence of interest pay-outs which formed 6.73% of the revenue in FY 2019. This also impacted the net margin level. Though at gross and operating level, the margins improved to 24% and 14% respectively on back of productivity improvement, the net margin remained low at 4.78% in FY 2019 due to high interest pay-outs. The interest expenditure saw an increasing trend (both in absolute terms and as a percentage of total revenue) in the last three-year period ending FY 2019. However, as indicated, the Company has taken an FCTL facility from Axis bank at a reduced interest rate, which might help save on interest expenditure. The new term loan contracted will have a 1 year moratorium period which will help improve liquidity. Modest net margin in turn translated to moderate returns. ROTNW (Return on Tangible Net Worth) remained at around 12% for FY 2019 as depicted in the below table.

Further, the Company intends to undertake debt funded capex plans over the medium term. NHB completed the acquisition of assets of a South Korean Company in FY 2019 for which a new term loan of INR 24 crores was contracted from Tata Capital Limited. Further, it is building up a new factory at Bilimora and also expanding the existing facility which is expected to double the capacity utilization levels. The expansion undertaken is to cater to new orders from SKF India Limited and Schaeffler India Limited. As indicated, around INR 10 crores of fresh loans will be contracted in FY 2020 on the aforementioned capex. The current recessionary trend has also led to a decline in the top line of the Company and any increase in gearing would further impact the net margin on account of increase in the interest cost.
Moderate scale of operations in a fairly competitive market

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition majorly from the big organized players in the international market. As informed, the Company has limited competition in the domestic market in the high precision ball category. In the international market, the Company faces competition from companies like Tsubaki Nakashima Co. Ltd., Jiangsu Lixing General Steel Ball Co., Ltd (JGBR), China and Amatsuji Steel Ball Mfg. Co., Ltd. ?AKS, Japan. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity.

The Company?s established presence and over seven-decade long market experience has helped it build strong relations with the customers. It enjoys over three decades of long relationship with the key customers like SKF group and Schaeffler group which places repeat orders year on year. As apprised, the Company is a critical component supplier and the rejection rate has remained minimal. Domestically, as indicated, the Company enjoys a good market position in the high precision ball category and is amongst the large players (in terms of capacity). It is also the recipient of Best Supplier award from its customer every year.
Nevertheless, presence of large global players limits the Company?s pricing flexibility to an extent and thus its revenues and margins remain susceptible to the industry competition.

The Company derives around 54% of the total revenues from the top two customers exposing the Company to customer concentration risk. Any significant decline in the demand for products of these OEMs can significantly affect the revenue of the Company. Further, high dependency on key customers might also exert pressure on the product pricing. This might impact the revenue and margins of the Company.
Sector concentration coupled with cyclical nature of automotive industry

The Company majorly caters to the automotive segment indicating sector concentration. The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend, is highly cyclical. Therefore, weak economic environment characterized by decline in per-capita income, high domestic inflation, increasing interest rates, weak industrial production, etc. (a scenario witnessed in FY 2013 and in current year), could adversely affect the revenues of the Company. Indian economy is currently witnessing a slowdown. India?s economic growth fell to 5.8 per cent in the January-March period of FY 2019, the lowest in 20 quarters, due to a sharp slowdown in investment andÿmanufacturing growthÿas well as a contraction in agricultural production. Thus, automobile sector too has got impacted from the slowing growth in the economy. Higher cost of vehicles, weak consumer sentiments coupled with liquidity crisis stemming from NBFC defaults are the other factors effecting the auto sales. As informed, in view of current recessionary trends, the management expects the revenue growth to remain stagnant in FY 2020.
Moderate profitability trend driven by price volatility of traded products

The business model of the Company is trading oriented where in the Company outsources the manufacturing activity which limits its bargaining power with the customers to an extent. During the review period, fluctuations across the gross profit margin was primarily driven by volatility in the cost of traded goods purchased which on an average constituted ~77% of the total revenue during the review period. The Company operates in a high competitive industry which limits the bargaining power of the Company and its ability to pass on the price rise. Profitability at the operating level stood strained driven by high proportion of directors renumeration costs that on an average constituted more than 5% of the total revenue. Moderate operating profit resulted in moderate net margins which further stood supported by non-operating income comprising interest income, forex gain and profit on sale of investments. Ability of the Company to command better price and pass on price volatility remains critical.
High competitive intensity amidst moderate scale of operations

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment, it is primarily engaged in providing CRAMS to the chemical and pharmaceutical companies with a predominant focus on the trading side of operations. It trades in various products like APIs, Bulk Drug Intermediates, veterinary products, specialty chemicals, pellets, formulations, impurities, DC granules, and herbal products. The industry is organized in nature with generic manufacturers enjoying a dominant position. Despite the stringent regulatory environment which poses an entry barrier, the sector has a large concentration of small and medium sized manufacturing units. Furthermore, the trading oriented business does not involve any major value addition which affects the pricing ability and poses risk of competition from new entrants. Moreover, the scale of operations stood moderate witnessing an uneven revenue trend during the review period. The Company?s moderate scale of operations, in comparison with its domestic and global competitors, coupled with absence of owned manufacturing facilities could act as a constraining factor by restricting its ability to secure big orders and exploit the benefits of economies of scale. Thus, the ability of the Company to scale its operations by acquiring new clients, and setting up its own manufacturing facilities remains critical.
Moderate profitability level as majority of the revenue is derived from trading

The Company?s operating profitability though increased, remained moderate at about 8% in FY 2019 due to high trading proportion (66%) in total sale. The primary raw material for some of the chemicals sold by the Company is crude oil, prices of which are determined by macro factors like global demand for fuel, quantum of production by the OPEC nations, speculative built up of the prices through forwards, political scenario in the Middle East countries, opening and closing inventories, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict which leads to volatility in the prices of crude oil and thereby of the chemicals manufactured from it. To remain competitive, the Company has to pass on the benefit of raw material price decline to its customers, but may not be always able to increase the price in times of tightening of raw material prices, which limits its bargaining power. Hence, the profitability remains susceptible to the volatile input prices during the review period.

Currently the majority of revenue is derived from the trading operations. As informed, the Company commands a better margin on trading products vis-a-vis peers due to sole distributorship of some of the chemicals. It plans to cease low margin trading operations and trade in high margin products. Currently, the manufacturing business is lower as the products are at different stages of development; however expects huge orders once the products are commercially launched by the innovator. With further increase in the scale of manufacturing operations, the margins are also expected to improve.
Sectoral concentration risk coupled with cyclical nature of agrochemical industry

Agrochemical sector accounts for about 60-70% of the total revenue of OCSPL indicating sectoral concentration risk. In an event of uncertainty in the end user industry, the revenue of the Company will have a negative impact leading to a drop in the bottom line as well. In case of agro chemicals, demand is dependent on a good sowing season which is usually linked to monsoons. Therefore, any short term deterioration in the economic environment and bad monsoons could have an impact on the Company?s business. As informed, the Company has taken steps to reduce dependency on agrochemical sector by increasing supplier base as well its existing product lines.ÿÿIn FY 2017, it has added new supplier-Domsjo Fabriker (leading Swedish speciality pulp and bio-refinery Company) for their SLS (Sodium Lauryl Sulfate) chemical range for which it expects an annual turnover of around INR 15 crores. The chemicals have multi applications such as in construction, dyes, ceramics as well as agrochemicals thus benefitting in diversifying end user industries.

The Company has moderate working capital requirements on back of high collection cycle. Debtors have ranged between 92-109 days. High collection days are to some extent offset by the payable cycle of 66-86 days. Inventory days have remained low between 28-36 days during the review period. In FY 2018, the Company saw a good revenue growth along with the improved margin, however, the incremental working capital requirements too increased which led to negative cash flow from operations. Nevertheless, the increase in working capital requirement was offset by high payable days in FY 2019. Apart from payables, the increased working capital requirement was met through a short term borrowing from bank. Promoters too have supported the Company by providing inter-party Company loans. The outstanding related party loans as on 31st March 2019 were about INR 14 crores. Significant increase in working capital requirement may lead to pressure on cash flows of the Company which in turn may increase its leverage.
Limited pricing flexibility leading to thin profitability and low returns albeit improvement

The Company has entered into a VSM agreement with Tata Steel Limited where the Company will cater to reputed OEMs through their Tier-1 suppliers. Prices are fixed according to the agreement which is at a negotiated price between TSL and OEM. Though this limits the Company?s pricing flexibility, it?s margins are protected against any adverse fluctuations in the raw material prices to an extent.
The higher interest cost further lowered the net margin level which remained below unity. This led to low return indicators, in spite of modest networth size. Below table depicts margins and returns-

The debt equity ratio of the Company stood high throughout the review period. The financial profile of the Company stood highly leveraged on the back of significant capital expenditure incurred by the Company for expansion of facilities, loans to subsidiaries and largely to fund working capital requirements. The total investment in subsidiaries the last two years cumulated to around INR 8 crore, of which major portions of the funding has been through borrowings. The Company?s investment in subsidiaries and loans advanced stood at INR 4 crore and INR 8 crore respectively as on 31st March 2018. Also, total debt is more skewed towards short term debt with working capital loans accounting for almost 80% of the total borrowings. On the back of its low margins, working capital requirement is managed by short term borrowings. Also, the net worth size stood modest at INR 18 crores as on 31st March 2018. Interest coverage increased with improved profitability (in absolute terms) due to revenue growth in FY 2018, however, the same has remained moderate at 1.48 times. Significantly leveraged capital structure would restrict the financial flexibility of the Company and make it difficult to procure debt for any of its expansion plans and higher interest cost would adversely affect the profitability of the Company.

The liquidity profile of the Company stood modest with current and quick ratio of 1.06 times and 0.85 times in FY 2018. It was even lower in FY 2016 and FY 2017. Significant working capital loans and increase in trade payables has led to modest current ratio. Further, cash accruals of the Company were moderate at around INR 7 crores as against CPLTD of INR 4 crores in FY 2018. As informed, promoters have infused funds to ensure timely repayments which provides short term flexibility (director?s loans stood at INR 4.9 crores as on March 31, 2018). Thus, the promoter?s continued support to Company in order to ensure timely servicing of repayment obligations remains critical.

The Company operates a VSM with TSL which makes it highly dependent on the TSL business. The Company derives 80% of its total revenue from Bajaj Auto Limited through its Tier-1 suppliers i.e. Yeshshree Press Comps Private Limited, Rucha Engineers Private Limited, Neel Auto Private Limited and Badve Engineering Limited thereby indicating customer concentration risk. Any change in order from Bajaj to TSL or change in business terms could adversely affect the top line and bottom line of the Company.
Moderate scale of operation in a highly competitive business environment

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Apart from small and mid-size players, the Company also faces competition from large size players like Infosys Limited, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Wipro Limited, Tech Mahindra Limited, etc. Large IT players have already built strong digital practices and have started investing in IOT. They have full service offerings, strong customer relationships, domain expertise, low-cost delivery capabilities that make them a preferred partner for many enterprise customers. Also, large companies have the strength to weather demand fluctuations in the industry in which they undertake business. In contrast, small and mid-size Companies are more vulnerable to market shocks given the scale of their business and balance sheet.

The Company is a mid-size player in the highly competitive ITes industry as reflected in its turnover size of about INR 70 crores (on standalone) and INR 83 crores (on consolidated) in FY 2019. The net cash accruals (PAT + depreciation) were low at about INR 4.8 crores in FY 2019. Company is at the growing stage and is more susceptible when compared to larger player to any increase in cost or business event which might have a negative impact on its margins as witnessed in FY 2018.
Therefore, the ability of the Company to scale up its operations amidst high competitive environment remains important.
Profitability and returns effected by high investments made in personals during the review period

Company?s profitability remained high in FY 2017. However, despite the revenue growth, the margin got impacted in FY 2018 over FY 2017. In FY 2018, to support the revenue growth and build in capacities for increasing scale of operations and bring in operating efficiencies, Company invested in personals and hired advisors, top executives which raised the salary cost (increased from 65% in FY 2017 to 75% in FY 2018). The aforesaid cost hit the gross margin level. Further, higher provisioning on bad debts (which the Company is hopeful of recovering) effected the operating margin for the year (declined from 17% in FY 2017 to about 3% in FY 2018).

In FY 2019, the Company continued to grow in double digits and though the salary cost increased, it was able to maintain the gross margin at similar level as FY 2018. Operating and net margin rose over FY 2018 and stood at 7% and 5% respectively. On a consolidated basis, operating and net margin stood at 8% and 7% respectively. Thus, continued growth and management of high personal cost will remain important. The returns fluctuated in the same tandem as the profitability. Increasing profits in FY 2019 resulted in rise in returns with ROTNW and ROCE at 15% and 21% respectively. However, on consolidated basis, the returns were higher (with ROTNW and ROCE at 23% and 31% respectively) with higher profits.
Profitability and return ratios (standalone) has been depicted in the below table:

The credit terms with customer is between 30-60 days. The year-end receivables in the last three years stood high and the same has increased with rise in scale of operations. As indicated by management, the increase seen is in receivables is on account of procedural delays and established customers are making the payment timely. In FY 2018, Company had made provisioning for bad debts which formed about 5% of the total revenue. This impacted the year?s profitability and the accretion to reserves. Currently, Company is able to manage the high receivables through internal accruals. However, with increasing scale of operations, management of high receivables will remain important as any substantial increase can exert pressure on the Company?s cash flows.
Uneven profitability trend albeit with improvement in FY 2019

Due to low scale of operations in FY 2017, the Company incurred losses across all levels as it was not able to abosrb its semi variable and fixed cost. Pursuant to significant rise in revenue, profitability of the Company at gross level witnessed improvement in FY 2018, however this rise was not translated in the operating margins owing to significant rise in depreciation expenses. Profitability of the Company at net level further stood supported non operating income majorly comprising forex gain and interest income. With improvement in profit margins, the Company witnessed improved returns as below:
Ability of the Company to sustain and improve its scale of operations and maintain its profitability remains crucial.

The Company derived around 73% of its revenue and procures almost 94% raw material requirement from domestic market, exposing it to foreign exchange risk with limited natural hedge. Considering its exposure in international market, limited natural hedge and volatility experienced in foreign exchange market, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk becomes critical for the Company. Any adverse movement in currency rates may have a significant impact on the bottom line of the Company. The Company incurred forex losses to the tune of INR 208 thousand and INR 526 thousand in FY 2017 and FY 2018 respectively.

The liquidity profile of the Company was modest with a current ratio at 1.20 times and a low quick ratio at 0.34 times respectively in FY 2019. The high inventory holding of the Company has resulted in a weak quick ratio and high working capital requirement thereby leading to modest liquidity position. The working capital requirements are high primarily emanating from the inventory days (especially high work in progress stocks) which were in the range of 116 to 135 days during the review period. The high inventory is driven mainly by the large lead time for manufacture of GLRs as also the lead time required for manufacture of certain bought out items. The bought-out items and the steel requirement are therefore procured in advance to facilitate quicker end delivery on placement of orders by customers. The stocking of steel also helps the Company to de-risk the steel price volatility to some extent. As a result, despite an improving collection velocity and sourcing advances from customers backed with comfortable credit terms from suppliers the Company continued to utilize new working capital facilities (new LT w/cap facility and ST w/cap facility).
Modest liquidity position can pose a serious risk in the short-term liquidity management and reduce its financial flexibility in short term especially given the y-o-y increase in revenue.
Moderate scale of operations vs global players in domestic market.

Though, the Company?s has rapidly established its presence in the GLR market recording good revenue growth rate (CAGR of 31.48%) during the review period, the scale of operations and tangible networth remained moderate. Moderate size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. Company?s moderate scale of operations acts as a constraining factor in realizing the benefits of economies of scale. The networth of the Company indicates the inherent strength of the concerned Company. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain.

At present, SIL faces stiff competition in glass lined equipment segment in domestic market from players like GMM Pfaudler Limited, Swiss Glass Coat Equipments Ltd, etc. Further, Glass Lined Equipment industry in India is very small as compared to the Global market which remains an untapped avenue for the Company given its lower exports as compared to its peers.
Modest profitability and return indicators albeit improvement in FY 2019

Despite headwinds in Turkey and supply chain challenges in Eurozone on the back of Brexit, the revenue of the Group improved in FY 2019 owing to incremental penetration with existing customers and the strategic investments over the years. Though the gross margins hovered in the range of 21-23% during the review period, the operation and net margins observed an improvement due to a decline in general and selling costs. Despite this improvement, the same remained modest at 7.74% and 5.57% respectively in FY 2019. The Group generated profits at EBIT level during the period under review, though the same were insufficient to meet interest costs of the Group in FY 2017. Modest profitability resulted in low return indicators during the review period. As informed, low returns and margins were due to various acquisitions done by the Group which were loss making entities and the business was yet to be streamlined coupled with depreciation of Turkish Lira in FY 2017. In FY 2018, the returns and margins were low due to the inorganic growth undertaken through aggressive acquisitions which led to higher costs. Further, the Group heavily depended on non-operating income to support the net margins till FY 2018 which majorly comprised of interest income, dividend income, and miscellaneous income.
Hence, ability of the group to further improve and sustain its margins and returns while increasing its operations remains crucial.

The Group derived around 90% of its revenue during FY 2019 from the international market, exposing it to foreign exchange fluctuation risk. Though, procurement of raw materials from overseas market could serve as a partial natural hedge, any volatility in exchange rates, as witnessed recently, can have a significant impact on the margins. Since, movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the United States of America, Brexit, etc. and most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates.

As informed, risk gets slightly amplified from the fact that, going forward, it is expected to derive a larger share of its revenue from the overseas markets. Losses due to foreign exchange transactions stood at INR 148,850 thousand, INR 41,200 thousand and INR 77,400 thousand in FY 2017, FY 2018 and FY 2019 respectively. Therefore, the ability to hedge its foreign exchange exposure through derivatives remains critical.
As informed, its business has local currency exposures only and hence, no or minimum inter- currency forex fluctuations. Loss is majorly a translational impact.
Stretched working capital cycle on account of high receivable and inventory holding period

As informed by the management, the Company?s major revenue is derived from the agricultural sector (more than 70% of revenue). Further, ~43% of the Company?s revenue is derived from Government projects which are tender based. Moreover, while billing is done on dispatch of pumps from factory, payment is received only after installation of pumps is completed leading to high receivables from these orders. Also, the Company obtains ~21% of its revenue from exports. This has resulted in stretched receivables throughout the review period. Further, as informed, the Company typically maintains an inventory of close to 3.5 months as the products of different specifications are often assembled using the similar components which are maintained in stock by the Company. Accordingly, it?s inventory has remained typically high throughout the review period against payables which have remained relatively lower. This has led to a stretched working capital cycle throughout the review period as shown in the table below.

The high working capital cycle is currently funded mainly through internal accruals and external borrowings. Going forward, any incremental working capital requirement may lead to additional funding requirement affecting the financial profile of the Company.

The Company derives a significant portion of revenue from the agriculture segment. As informed, in FY 2019, the Company derived more than 70% of its revenue from sale of products for agricultural consumption. Agriculture sector is cyclical with high dependence on monsoon patterns and largely driven by government regulations as well. Any downturn in the agriculture industry could have a significant impact on the topline of the Company.

However, the current impetus on the sector by the Government of India indicates a positive outlook for the sector. The management informed that their focus has always been on the agriculture segment and perceives huge untapped potential in the agriculture markets.

The Company derived more than 60% of its FY 2019 revenues from two customers, namely, Mahindra and Mahindra Limited, and Hyundai Motor India Limited, thereby exposing it to customer concentration risk. Earlier, around 80% of the revenue was contributed from the top three customers, however, with reduction in seating business and increasing in customer base across segments has resulted in relatively lower customer concentration. Though long term relationship, closer proximity to customers, continued efforts on research and development, process automation, value engineering, and technological upgradation, helps in creating lock-in with these OEMs and builds entry level barrier of any new player, there may be an impact on the revenue stream in a scenario of change in procurement policies of the OEM?s, product recall, etc.

As informed, the Company has already begun commercial activities for some of the additional OEMs and Tier I suppliers for its products as well as has received SOPs for its several products. The Company is increasing focus on the commercial vehicles and is in the process of initiating SOPs for few OEMs. It has already entered into a JV in this regard. Further, to diversify its customer and automotive segment base it has started supplying to new business segments such as tractors and three wheelers. As informed, the contribution from commercial vehicle segment and tractor segment is expected to increase driven by incremental orders from these new customers. As informed, supplies to these customers have already started from Q4 FY 2019.
De-growth in revenue along with modest profitability and return indicators

The revenue of the Company observed de-growth in FY 2018 on the back (post MD) despite significant improvement in the topline in FY 2017. As apprised, the improvement in the revenue in FY 2017 was owing to (post md). High raw material and personnel costs resulted in modest margins which hovered between 10-11.5% at operating levels during FY 2017 and FY 2018. Net cash accruals also declined from INR 50,462 thousand in FY 2017 to INR 27,538 thousand in FY 2018. Modest profitability resulted in low return on capital employed (RoCE) and return on tangible networth (RoTNW) which stood at 10.36% and 8.04% in FY 2018.
Large working capital requirement impacting the liquidity position

The working capital cycle of the Company stood elongated marked by high collection and inventory cycle. The collection period increased significantly in FY 2018 (reason post MD) and stood at 167 days. As informed, the Company (reason for high inventory in FY 2018 especially). Despite large working capital cycle, the Company?s short term debt equity ratio stood low at 0.13 times in FY 2018 as it was majorly funded through customer advances and extended credit from suppliers. Of the total receivables, around 56% were due for more than 6 months thus raising the risk of bad debts.

With more than 80% of the current assets being tied in inventory and debtors, the liquidity position of the Company was impacted. The current and quick ratio of the Company stood low at 1.18 times and 0.77 times in FY 2018. Further, net cash accruals also declined from INR 50,462 thousand in FY 2017 to INR 27,538 thousand in FY 2018 and were just sufficient to cover its maturing debt obligations. Moreover, cash flows from operations also declined in FY 2018 corroborating the modest liquidity position.

The Company?s scale of operations has remained at modest levels despite having a track record of around 3 decades. Further, the tangible networth of the Company has remained low at INR 251,297 thousand in FY 2018. The networth of a Company indicates its inherent strength. In case of any adverse conditions, businesses with greater networth are in a position to diversify faster and sustain longer. Smaller size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic shocks. The Company?s moderate scale of operations, in comparison with its domestic and global competitors, could act as a constraining factor by restricting its ability to secure big orders and exploit the benefits of economies of scale. Further, intense competition in the industry would also limit the pricing flexibility as the Company deals with reputed customers.
Moderate scale of operations while revenue growth remained modest during the review period

Although the Company witnessed year-on-year growth in revenue, however its revenue growth was modest with a CAGR of 8.04% during the last three years. Its topline remained moderate at INR 525,725 thousand in FY 2019 given the high competitive intensity in the industry. Further, the Company?s tangible networth remained moderate at INR 307,015 thousand as on 31st March 2019 due to writing of impairment loss for the investment in subsidiaries. The Company?s moderate scale of operations, in comparison with its established large-scale domestic and global competitors, may act as a constraining factor to achieve benefits of economic of scale. Furthermore, tangible networth of the Company indicates its inherent strength. Business with greater networth are in a better position to diversify faster and sustain in case of any adverse conditions. Smaller size implies greater susceptibility to unsystematic risks. As informed, Company is projecting to achieve revenue of INR 540,000 thousand in FY 2020.

Profitability margins of the Company remained moderate during the review period with a declining trend at operating and net levels. Employee expenses and clinical trial expenses are the major expenses impacting the margins. As informed, gross profit margins were dependent on the services mix (i.e. clinical operations or data management or medical writing). Further, as informed, operating profit margins and net margins were impacted because of additional expenses (mainly legal & professional expenses) incurred for establishing operations in USA in last 2 financial years. Also, decline in other operating income (mainly export entitlements) in last two financial years. Coupled with increase in lease rental expenses (due to increase in rents and also due to shifting of warehousing facility in FY 2019 to Thane, Maharashtra from earlier facility in Bhandup, Maharashtra, which resulted in two facility for few months till the time renovation was in progress in the new facility), further impacted the margins. However, net profit margins were supported by decline in interest expenses (owing to repayment of majority of loans) and decline in tax expenses. Further, net profit margins were impacted in FY 2018 owing to provision of INR 18,548 thousand made by Company for impairment loss of investment in Malaysia subsidiary. As indicated, Company is expecting improvement in OPBIDT margins to more than 30% in FY 2020 due to higher margins contract in pipeline from US market.
Decline in profitability margins led to decline in return indicators with return on tangible networth and return on capital employed standing at 14.00% and 22.06% in FY 2019.
Going forward, ability of the Company to improve its profitability and return indicators, while scaling up its operations remains critical
High collection cycle due to pending payment from US subsidiary

The operations of the Company have remained working capital intensive driven by its high collection period throughout the review period. Company manages its working capital requirements through internal accruals and advance from customers. Although, it has improved from 187 days in FY 2017 to 129 days in FY 2019, it is still remains at high level.

As informed, collection period is high due to pending payments (INR 132,513 thousand as on 31st March 2019) from its US subsidiary. After excluding intercompany debtors, collection period is 67days as on 31st March 2019.

Blockage of funds in debtors resulted in an increase in working capital requirements of the Company, thereby exerting a stress on its liquidity profile. It also increases the risk of bad debts for the Company.
Thus, prudent management of working capital remains critical.

Liquidity position of the Group remained moderate marked by adequate current and quick ratio throughout the review period. Further, substantial increase (104.59%) in the receivables in FY 2019 has resulted into negative cash flow from operating activities thereby constraining the liquidity profile of the Group. However, liquidity is somewhat supported with adequate cash and bank balance of INR 660,000 thousand and short term investments in form of fixed deposit of INR 1,189,200 thousand in FY 2019.

Stress on the liquidity position may limit the Group from scaling up its operations and thereby adversely impacting its financial profile. Hence, ability of the Group to turnaround and improve its liquidity position remains crucial.
High dependence on packaged software products business may put pressure on margins

In FY 2019, the Group derived around 62% of its total revenue from distribution and implementation of packaged software products. It derives majority (60% in FY 2019) of this revenue from the domestic market. Owing to limited value addition (except for pre and post implementation services) in this segment, its margins remained low at a Group level as compared to other IT companies which are pure play IT service providers. Considering the competition and presence of open source software products and increasing adoption of SAAS (Software as a Service), it may face pressure on its margins.

International IT services contributed 38% of total revenues and 81% of PAT while Domestic products and services contributed to 62% of the total revenues and 19% of PAT in FY 2019. For the International IT services, the Group derived around 57% of its total revenue from the USA and 31% of its total revenue from Europe; thereby indicating geographic concentration risk. USA and Europe being the major markets for the Group, any adverse event occurring in these geographies could adversely affect the topline of the Group. The Indian IT industry is facing challenges owing to uncertain global economic environment. Political policies towards visa issuance remains a sticking point in near future. These reforms could limit the number of Indian technology professional?s IT companies can put in USA and increase the cost of business.

High attrition rate has always remained a major concern in Indian IT industry. It results in loss of skill sets and the cost of recruitment and training. The Group also remained challenged with high rates of attrition. Also, the employee expenses have stood on an average of 20% of the total revenue despite various automation methodologies undertaken by the Group. The same has been due to increase in pay scales following the improvement in the domestic economic environment and local hiring due to unemployment concerns in the key markets. This may increase its personnel cost and may adversely affect the margins.

As informed by the management, the attrition rate of the Group has stood at 17.5% for in FY 2019. Several measures have been taken to reduce the attrition while maintaining the personnel cost like employee pyramid resizing, employee engagement programmes etc. which helped in better employee utilization which stood at 86% in FY 2019.
Low profitability margins driven by limited pricing flexibility

Despite improvement in the scale of operations, the profitability of the Company exhibited a declining trend. The profitability of the Company has remained low during the review period mainly due to high competition resulting in pricing pressure thereby limiting the ability of the Company to command better prices in the market. Decline in profitability across the gross level can be mainly attributed to y-o-y increase in cost of raw materials and traded goods and increased revenue from traded goods in FY 2019. Thus upward fluctuations in the prices of raw material may affect the margins and profitability, resulting in material adverse effect on its business and margins. Cascading the effect of profitability at gross level, margins at the operating level exhibited a declining trend. Profit across the net levels are further impacted on account of fluctuation in the interest expenses due to increased borrowing.

As informed, the Company plans to improve the profitability by increasing the volume sales of processed food products in its product portfolio. Further, the Company plans to increase penetration in the overseas market through their soya meal product.
Leveraged capital structure coupled with modest liquidity position reduces financial flexibility

The Company?s reliance on external borrowings has remained high primarily to fund its working capital requirements. On an average the working capital limits are almost 95% utilized. This has resulted in a leveraged capital structure as reflected in total debt equity ratio of 1.31 times as on 31st March 2019. Additionally, the interest coverage ratio also stood moderate at 2.34 times during FY 2019. As informed, the Company has capital expansion plans of ~INR 100,000 thousand for setting up new subsidiary in Malawi which will also require working capital of up to ~INR 400,000 thousand. Further reliance on the external debt would deteriorate the leverage metrics and restrict the financial flexibility of the Company. Incremental debt would also result in higher interest costs which could limit the ability of the Company to service its interest obligations.

Though, the quick ratio and current ratio of the Company stood at 0.75 times and 1.34 times respectively in FY 2019, cash flow through operating activities exhibited an uneven trend and stood negative in FY 2017 and FY 2019 which has led to a strain in liquidity position and resulted in the Company availing external short term borrowings.
Intense competition from organized and unorganized sector coupled with low value addition

The Company is engaged in processing and trading of organic and non-GMO agricultural products. It operates in a highly competitive environment. The industry is fragmented and dominated by small regional traders with large number of organized and unorganized players. This fragmented nature and absence of product differentiation has resulted in intense competition, with product pricing playing a major role in shaping the competition. High competitive intensity could restrict the pricing ability of the Company, putting pressure on its margins, especially in a rising prices scenario
Weak and declining operating profit and net profit margins resulting in modest returns

The profitability of the Company at operating and net level has remained low during the review period. Gross profit margin has depicted an uneven trend and remained moderate throughout the review period. Operating profit margin depicted declining trend and stood low at 2.73% in FY 2019. It declined during the review period mainly due to decline in gross profit margins coupled with increase in general & administration expenses and selling & distribution expenses. Operating profit margins were also impacted due to significant increase in depreciation expenses on account of commissioning of new plant. The net margins of the Company deteriorated with cascading impact from operating margin and increased interest burdens.

As informed, the Company undertook capital expenditure plan to enter into premium tile segment, but the benefits in terms of increase in the scale of operation remains to be seen. Low and declining profit margins have resulted in modest and declining returns as depicted in table below:
Hence, in view of weak profit margins, ability of Company to scale up its operations and ensure improvement in its cost structure remains critical.

The current ratio and quick ratio stood moderate at 1.30 times and 1.01 times as on 31st March 2019. The moderate liquidity was mainly due to working capital intensive nature of operations marked with high inventory and receivable days which were almost entirely funded through payables and short term borrowings thereby constraining the liquidity position of the Company. Continued trend of funding the working capital requirements through incremental borrowings might further deteriorate the liquidity position of the Company and could constrain the Company?s ability to meet its immediate obligations. Further, working capital cycle has increased during the review period due to increase in collection cycle and inventory days, which was partly offset by increase in payment period.

Moreover, the capex incurred during the year has further contributed to the moderate liquidity position. The Company has also utilized FCNR loans to the extent INR 33 crores towards capex funding. Additionally, the Company has modest cash and cash equivalents of INR 59,910 thousand as of 31st March 2019 which declined from INR 151,857 thousand as of 31st March 2018. However, cash flow from operating activities increased to INR 274,397 thousand in FY 2019 from INR 105,873 thousand in FY 2018.

Nevertheless, Company generated net cash accruals of INR 227,473 thousand in FY 2018 and INR 204,858 thousand in FY 2019 which were adequate to pay off the current portion of long term debt (CPLTD) of INR 61,344 thousand and INR 173,494 thousand as on 31st March 2017 and 31st March 2018 respectively.
Any significant increase in working capital requirement on account of increase in its scale of operations may put further stress on its liquidity position in the short to medium term.
Modest financial profile characterized by leveraged capital structure and declining interest coverage ratio

Total debt equity ratio of the Company exhibited uneven trend during the review period. It deteriorated in FY 2018 mainly due to increase in total debt on account of long term funds availed to fund capital expenditure for new plant and short term working capital availed to meet increased working capital requirements. It improved slightly in FY 2019 owing to scheduled repayment of long term loan and lower utilization of working capital limit at year end.

Owing to the working capital-intensive nature of operations, the reliance on short term external borrowings has remained high. Further, setup of the new plant for large tiles has led to increased long term borrowings. Increased reliance on debt has led to increase in interest expenses for the Company, which resulted in to significant decline in the interest coverage ratio which stood moderate while reducing to 1.53 times in FY 2019 from 4.35 times in FY 2017.

Company?s leveraged capital structure may restrict its financial flexibility thereby making it difficult to leverage further in case of any business exigencies or to fund the incremental working capital requirements. Furthermore, declining and moderate interest coverage ratio strains the Company?s ability to service its financial obligations.

The Company has low working capital requirements emanating from a low inventory cycle and high payable days. However, collection cycle has increased in the last two year review period (from 40 days in FY 2017 to 78 days in FY 2018 and 74 days in FY 2019). Civil construction business to an extent remains working capital intensive owing to the fact that while expenditure has to be incurred continuously (for paying employees, for procuring resources, etc.) for the execution of ongoing projects, the client is billed on a milestone basis (in accordance with the contract entered into with them) and thereafter the payment is received from them. As informed, in a civil contract, 10% is collected as mobilization advance, 70-80% is against supplies and 5-10% is performance guarantee/cash retention ratio.

The Company has largely funded its collection cycle through a long credit from the suppliers. It has also received mobilization advances from the customers which has limited the Company?s reliance on outside debt (the same has ranged between INR 8 - INR 21 crore in the three year review period). Company has a sanctioned cash credit line of INR 10 crores which as informed, doesn?t remain fully utilized.

The liquidity profile of the Company, although improved, stood moderate in FY 2019 with a current ratio of around 1.5 times. The net cash accruals improved year on year and were sufficient vis a vis the maturing term loan obligations in FY 2019. Net cash flow from operation stood positive and increased during the review period. While SBPL has been able to manage its collection cycle currently and report increasing revenues and profitability, its ability to generate sustainable cash flows by timely execution of order book remains critical from credit perspective.

Despite a high gross margin between 16-20%, the Company?s operating profitability remained moderate at an average of 8.52% during the review period. Profitability remains susceptible to the tender based nature of operations and sub-contracting cost. Though with increasing revenues, sub-contracting costs have shown an increase, the cost of materials as a percentage of revenue declined during the review period leading to an improved gross margin in FY 2019. The decline in material cost is due to the product mix. As informed, margins vary as per the customer and the nature of works. High director remuneration cost (formed between 5%- 6% of the total revenues) has led to moderate operating profitability level. As informed, the Company expects OPBDITA to remain between 8-10% in the near term. For FY 2020, the Company is estimating a PAT margin of 7% (around INR 45-50 crores).

The Company has low working capital requirements emanating from a low inventory cycle and high payable days. However, collection cycle has increased in the three year review period (from 32 days in FY 2016 to 78 days in FY 2018). Civil construction business to an extent remains working capital intensive owing to the fact that while expenditure has to be incurred continuously (for paying employees, for procuring resources, etc.) for the execution of ongoing projects, the client is billed on a milestone basis (in accordance with the contract entered into with them) and thereafter the payment is received from them. As informed, in a civil contract, 10% is collected as mobilization advance, 70-80% is against supplies and 5-10% is performance guarantee/cash retention ratio.

The Company has largely funded its collection cycle through a long credit from the suppliers. It has also received mobilization advances from the customers which has limited the Company?s reliance on outside debt (the same has ranged between INR 8 - INR 21 crore in the three year review period). Company has a sanctioned cash credit line of INR 5 crores which as informed, doesn?t remain fully utilized. However, with incremental orders, the Company is expected to seek enhancement in the cash credit lines by INR 10 crores.

Despite a high gross margin between 15-20%, the Company?s operating profitability remained moderate at about 8.45% in FY 2018. Profitability remains susceptible to the tender based nature of operations and sub-contracting cost. Though with increasing revenues, sub-contracting costs has shown an increase, the cost of materials as a percentage of revenue declined in FY 2017 and FY 2018 over FY 2016 leading to an improved gross margin in FY 2018. Decline in material cost is due to the product mix. As informed, margins vary as per the customer and nature of works. High director remuneration cost in FY 2017 and FY 2018 (formed 5% and 6% of the revenues respectively) has led to moderate operating profitability level. As informed, the Company expects OPBDITA to remain between 8-10% in the near term. For FY 2019, the Company is estimating a OPBDITA margin of 8% (around INR 37.20 crore on revenue of INR 457.89 crore).
