The government has taken several measures to improve operational efficiency through mechanization, deepening the draft and speedy evacuations.

Recognizing theÿimportance of infrastructure for doing business, the federal government is invested in critical initiatives to help companies leverage their economies of scale and provide integrated logistics networks that are cost effective. ÿ

Dedicated freight corridors:ÿThe government has notified five major industrial corridors ?ÿDelhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor (DMIC),ÿAmritsar-Kolkata Industrial Corridor (AKIC), Chennai-Bengaluru Industrial Corridor (CBIC),ÿVisakhapatnam-Chennai Industrial Corridor (VCIC)ÿand Bengaluru- Mumbai Economic Corridor (BMEC), for the faster movement of freight. These corridors are spread across 15 states in India.

Logistics parks:ÿThese parks serve as centers for freight aggregation and distribution hubs, storage, warehousing, and multi-modal transportation. The government has announced the development of 35 such parks to cut transportation cost and enable swifter freight movement on higher sized trucks and rails between hubs.ÿ

Technology upgrades:ÿNew technology such as the internet of things or IoT, mobile applications, cloud storage, big data analytics, and computing are increasingly being used by startups and logistics companies to improve the existing business operations, transact with new customers and expand their network. Startups like Rivigo are using IoT for real time data collection of truck?s fuel, engine oil temperature, brake oil pressure and more, to improve services and increase transparency in India?s truck industry.

The federal government has also adopted new systems to overcome long-standing logistics challenges. These include: Geographical Information Systems (GIS) based National Highways Information System to overcome the traffic and transportation problems on road; Rake Management System (RMS) for handling commercial transactions on Indian railways; Implementation of Radio Frequency Identification (RFI) for identifying the movement of ships wirelessly using radio waves; andÿthe GST Networkÿ? a technology platform at the heart of the GST?s administration ? to simplify the taxation system of the logistics companies.ÿ
Government initiative would bring growth momentum in the industry

The Government of India has taken up trade reforms to become export competitive and invested towards infrastructure and logistics improvement, which have greatly helped in the turnaround of India?s exports, inspite, of adverse global economic situation. The World Bank in its recent Logistics Performance Index (LPI) for 2018 has ranked India at 44 amongst 160 countries compared to the rank of 54 in 2014, thus showcasing the jump of 10 places. This is the outcome of various measures taken by the Government to boost exports. Some additional measures taken in recent times are given below:

In the Mid-Term Review of the Foreign Trade Policy (FTP) 2015-20 the Ministry of Commerce and Industry has enhanced the scope of Merchandise Exports from India Scheme (MEIS) and Service Exports from India Scheme (SEIS), increased MEIS incentive raised for ready-made garments and made- ups by 2%, raised SEIS incentive by 2% and increased the validity of Duty Credit Scrips from 18 months to 24 months.
In August 2019, Ministry of Commerce plans to introduce new foreign trade policy aimed at providing incentives and guidelines for increasing export in next five financial years 2020-25.
As of December 2018, Government of India is planning to set up trade promotion bodies in 15 countries to boost exports from Small and Medium Enterprises (SME) in India.

All export and import-related activities are governed by the Foreign Trade Policy (FTP), which is aimed at enhancing the country's exports and use trade expansion as an effective instrument of economic growth and employment generation.

The Department of Commerce has announced increased support for export of various products and included some additional items under the Merchandise Exports from India Scheme (MEIS) in order to help exporters to overcome the challenges faced by them.

The Central Board of Excise and Customs (CBEC) has developed an 'integrated declaration' process leading to the creation of a single window which will provide the importers and exporters a single point interface for customs clearance of import and export goods.

RBI has simplified the rules for credit to exporters, through which they can now get long-term advance from banks for up to 10 years to service their contracts. This measure will help exporters get into long-term contracts while aiding the overall export performance.
The Government of India is expected to announce an interest subsidy scheme for exporters in order to boost exports and explore new markets.
Bilateral / regional cooperation agreements with other nations.
Under the Sagarmala Programme, the government has envisioned a total of 189 projects for modernization of ports involving an investment of INR 1.42 trillion (USD 22 billion) by the year 2035.

Going ahead, Increasing investments and cargo traffic point towards a healthy outlook for the Indian logistics sector. Providers of services such as operation and maintenance (O&M), pilotage and harbouring and marine assets such as barges and dredgers will greatly benefit from these initiatives.
Upcoming manufacturing facility to help boost the topline of the Company

Till FY 2017, the Company had four manufacturing units to cater to the demand of Indian, USA and other emerging markets. In FY 2017, it has commenced commercial production at its new manufacturing facility in Dahej and it has completed US FDA inspection at Dahej and Paithan plant during the year.

Earlier, the Company derived 40-45% of revenue from sub-contracting through loan licensing arrangement. Now it plans to reduce the same to about 15% by FY 2021 end through in house manufacturing. So, it set-up new plant in Dahej and is in the process of setting up new plants Guwahati and another relatively smaller unit in Pitampur. Operating leverage will kick in from FY 2021. Dahej plant, which will help Ajanta to expand its generic business in the US and emerging markets, is already complete and is undergoing product registration processes. Ramp up is expected by FY 2021. The new Guwahati plant will focus on its key branded generic therapeutic segments of dermatology (commissioned in March 2018), ophthalmology (commission planned by end of Q3 FY 2020), and a set up for manufacturing larger dosages for oral dosages (by Q1 FY 2021). Current capacity utilisation at Dahej and Guwahati facilities are in the range of 15-20% and these capacities will start operating at optimal capacity in 2019-20. Negative impact is higher opex cost but at the same time it will give access to emerging markets for few drugs as it will allow direct inspection of its facilities.

Furthermore, Ajanta is also setting up another R&D center, where it will be shifting its entire R&D team divided into regions, this will help the Company to launch new products customized according to the requirements/regulations of each region. As informed, the Company introduces around 30-40 products every year with 60-65% of its products having first to market advantage.

With upcoming new manufacturing facilities along with R&D center, the Company is expected to increase its market share in the existing products coupled with the launch of new products; which is expected to boost the topline of the Company over the near to medium term.

The pharmaceutical sector was valued at US$ 33 billion in 2017. The country?s pharmaceutical industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 22.4 per cent over 2015?20 to reach US$ 55 billion. India?s pharmaceutical exports stood at US$ 17.27 billion in FY18 and have reached US$ 15.52 billion in FY19 (up to January 2019). Pharmaceutical exports include bulk drugs, intermediates, drug formulations, biologicals, Ayush & herbal products and surgicals. India?s domestic pharmaceutical market turnover reached Rs 129,015 crore (US$ 18.12 billion) in 2018, growing 9.4 per cent year-on-year (in Rs) from Rs 116,389 crore (US$ 17.87 billion) in 2017. Medicine spending in India is projected to grow 9-12 per cent over the next five years, leading India to become one of the top 10 countries in terms of medicine spending.

Going forward, better growth in domestic sales would also depend on the ability of companies to align their product portfolio towards chronic therapies for diseases such as such as cardiovascular, anti-diabetes, anti-depressants and anti-cancers that are on the rise. The Indian government has taken many steps to reduce costs and bring down healthcare expenses. Speedy introduction of generic drugs into the market has remained in focus and is expected to benefit the Indian pharmaceutical companies. In addition, the thrust on rural health programs, lifesaving drugs and preventive vaccines also augurs well for the pharmaceutical companies.

There has been a rise in demand for formulations in the semi regulated markets of South East Asia & Africa due to a rise in population, increasing health consciousness, increase in lifestyle related diseases, increase in government spending towards health development programs, and improving health infrastructure. The Company can take advantage of this rising demand to boost its top line as well as the bottom line.
Government initiatives to boost health and pharmaceuticals industry

The Government has taken several measures at both central and state levels to promote the pharmaceutical sector in India. In October 2018, the Uttar Pradesh Government announced its plans to set up six pharma parks in the state and has received investment commitments of more than INR 50,000,000 ? 60,000,000 thousand for the same. The National Health Protection Scheme is largest government funded healthcare programme in the world, which is expected to benefit 100 million poor families in the country by providing a cover of up to INR 500 thousand per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. The programme was announced in Union Budget 2018-19. In March 2018, the DCGI announced its plans to start a single-window facility to provide consents, approvals and other information. The move is aimed at giving a push to the Make in India initiative which is expected to facilitate easy setup for infrastructure in the sector. Further, the Government of India is planning to set up an electronic platform to regulate online pharmacies under a new policy, in order to stop any misuse due to easy availability. Also, the Government of India unveiled 'Pharma Vision 2020' aimed at making India a global leader in end-to-end drug manufacture. Approval time for new facilities has been reduced to boost investments. The government introduced mechanisms such as the Drug Price Control Order and the National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority to deal with the issue of affordability and availability of medicines. Moreover, the Government?s initiatives to promote generics in the market are aimed at further promoting volume sales and facilitating better penetration of medicines in the market.

These initiatives represent the Government?s will to ensure better healthcare facilities throughout the country. The impetus is a boon to all the companies within the pharmaceutical value chain which can expect growing market demand in the future.
Increasing per capita income leading to increase in lifestyle diseases and better affordability

With the incremental economic development in recent times, the per capita income within the country is on the rise. The rising per capita income is accompanied with rising life style diseases and growing affordability which both serve as a demand driver for the health care and pharmaceutical sector. Further, better penetration of the insurance sector and growing awareness about healthcare also contribute to increasing demand in the healthcare sector. Other problems like pollution and easy accessibility to healthcare professionals and medicines are also factors contributing to further demand for the pharmaceutical sector.
Government support through M-SIPS (modified special incentive package scheme)ÿto support Company?s operations

The electronic market in India is one of the largest in the world and is anticipated to reach USD 400 billion by 2020. The overall production of consumer electronics was INR 647.52 Bn in FY 2017 as compared to INR 557.65 Bn in FY 2016, showcasing an annual growth of 16.1%. In recent years, the sector has experienced a progression from being principally a consumption-driven market to the one with industrial competency and capacity to gratify domestic as well as foreign demand. Around 65% of the current demand for electronics products being met through imports provides an opportunity for import substitution. With government initiative such as Make in India drive, there is a shift from being a buyer to a manufacturer. Several government initiatives and incentives such as Electronics Development Fund (EDF), Electronic Manufacturing Clusters (EMCs) scheme coupled with 100% allowance of FDI through automatic route is expected to help the companies to scale up their operations. Also through the M- SIPS package, the Company will be benefitted due to its investment proposal being approved by the government along with its reimbursement of central taxes and duties for high-technology.

The use of capacitors is long been accepted as the most practical solution to improve power factor in any electrical power system. The application of capacitors has multiple benefits like reduction in current losses, reduction in demand, better asset management, deferred capital expenditure, enhanced voltage profile, higher quality of power, release of blocked capacity, reduced T&D losses etc. Estimated size of capacitor industry in India, is INR 6400,000 thousand including LV +MV+AHF capacitors according to IEEMA (Indian Electrical & Electronics Manufacturers? Association).

India has witnessed rapid electrification, buildings & industrial growth, thus a need for process automation to improve efficiency and drive for energy efficiency. Electricity production has increased from 771 Billion Units (Year 2010) to 1160 Billion Units (Year 2017) with CAGR of 7%. India has turned from power deficit nation to power surplus nation. With advent of Solar rooftops consumers are turning into prosumers. Government of India through EESL distributed more than 280 Million LED bulbs under UJALA scheme at affordable price by Dec 2017. All of these have now increase and changed the expectations from quantity of power supply to quality of power supply. Also increasing growth of HVDC transmission technology, renewable energy source like wind/ solar, evolution of charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, microgrids are expected to drive the future need for capacitors & advance solution.

The international generics business of the Company is largely concentrated in USA market. However, due to the recent regulatory trends and protectionist policies the Company is cautiously endeavoring to increase its presence in other geographies. The Company has entered into a Joint Venture Agreement with SPH SINE Pharmaceutical Laboratories Co Ltd, China & Adia (Shanghai) Pharma Co Ltd, China to promote and sell pharmaceutical products for the Chinese market. Initially this Joint Venture will commercialize products manufactured by Alembic. Subsequently the Joint Venture plans to set up a manufacturing facility in China. It will initially launch with a portfolio of oral solids and is expected to widen to other areas like injectable, ophthalmology, dermatology & oncology which are being currently developed and manufactured by Alembic.

The strength of the Company lies in its ability to manufacture cheaper generic versions of critical drugs, to seek approvals of ANDAs and then to launch its products in international regulated market once the drugs goes off patent. Its cumulative Abbreviated New Drug Application (ANDA) filing stood at 161 and has received 89 approvals till 31st March 2019 including 12 in tentative stage.

The R&D initiatives of the Company are synchronized with the setting up of new manufacturing facilities for oncology and dermatology formulations and these facilities are expected to be equipped for commissioning of commercial operations by FY 2019. The Company plans to incur capital expenditure of around INR 6,500,000 thousand majority linked to the injectable facility and rest for the general maintenance expenditure
The Company?s revenue is expected to scale up once these products under pipeline are converted into marketable products.
Healthy demand prospects for drugs in domestic as well as international market

There has been rise in demand for bulk drugs as well as formulations in the domestic as well as international market due to rise in population, increasing health consciousness, increase in lifestyle diseases and improving health infrastructure. The Company can take advantage of this increasing demand in domestic as well as international market to increase its revenue.

General growth in per capita income among urban and rural population has increased the pool of consumer class in the economy. This development along with growing healthcare awareness has increased the pool of patients who are able to afford healthcare services and pharmaceutical products.

Non-communicable, lifestyle related diseases like diabetes, cardio ailments, renal failure, hypertension and cancer is on the rise, partly as a result of changes in lifestyle and consumption pattern. India is all set to become the diabetes capital of the world while cases of cardio ailments, cancer cases are on the rise. This has given way to higher spending on healthcare services and consumables including drugs
Government initiatives to facilitate manufacturing of APIs/Bulk drugs

China has emerged as a dominant player in the global API industry. This is largely on account of large-scale manufacturing capabilities of APIs and intermediates enabling the companies to enjoy benefits of economies of scale coupled with export benefits and subsidies granted by the China government. Currently, India is dependent on imports of bulk drugs/ APIs from China for producing certain essential medicines. However, the Indian Government is taking variousÿinitiatives to discourageÿimportÿof bulkÿdrugsÿandÿactive pharmaceutical ingredientsÿ(APIs) into the country.ÿRecently the government has withdrawn exemption of custom duty on certain categories of bulk drugs/APIs to provide level playing field to the domestic manufacturers. Further, the government is clearing bottlenecks like environment clearance, which the manufacturers are facing in order to give boost to domestic manufacturing of bulk drugs. Government of India?s ?Pharma Vision 2020? aims to make India a global leader in end to end drug manufacturing. These initiatives would act as an opportunity for domestic manufacturers, who were earlier facing stiff competition from China due to cheap products.
Growth of the domestic and global petrochemical sector to drive Company?s topline

India?s petrochemical sector is a key pillar of the economy and one of the fastest growing, with demand growing at a CAGR of over 8% in the last five years ending FY 2018. The sector is a key input for an array of vital substances, including plastics, solvents, fertilizers and pharmaceuticals. The key factors that have driven the industry forward include strong GDP growth, changing consumer behaviors and government initiatives.ÿThe current domestic market size stands at $20 billion market, and has the potential to grow to $70 billion by 2030.ÿ

Furthermore, on the global scale, petrochemicals are set to account for more than a third of the growth in world oil demand to 2030, and almost half the growth to 2050, adding nearly seven million barrels of oil a day by (according to report by the International Energy Agency). This indicates oil demand growth is shifting to petrochemicals from motor oil. The report further enunciated, as of 2017, petrochemicals accounted for 12 percent of global oil demand, while passenger vehicles accounted for 27 percent. However, the two sectors are likely to converge over time, with petrochemicals accounting for 16 percent in 2050 and passenger vehicles accounting for 22 percent. Against a backdrop of slower gasoline demand growth, robust growth prospects for chemical products, and attractive margins, oil companies are further strengthening their links with petrochemical markets.

The Company derives approx. 90% its revenues through trade of petrochemicals. Although, it currently only supplies in the domestic market; the management has medium term plans in the international market as well once it further increases its volumes in India and is able to build a strong networth to withstand unsystematic industry risks. Hence, the aforementioned factors set a strong footing on macro-economic front for the Company?s topline growth.
Positive growth prospects for chemical industry to drive Company?s topline

Chemicals industry in India is highly diversified, covering more than 80,000 commercial products. Chemicals industry in India has been de-licensed except for few hazardous chemicals. Upcoming Petroleum, Chemicals and Petrochemicals Investment Regions (PCPIRs) and Plastic parks will provide state-of-the-art infrastructure for Chemicals and Petrochemicals sector. India?s proximity to the Middle East, the world?s source of petrochemicals feedstock, makes for economies of scale. Strong economic growth, world?s second largest population, accelerating urbanization and heavy increase in industrial demand are the major drivers of such dynamic growth for Indian Chemical & Petrochemical Industry which is currently undergoing rapid expansion. The industry is expected to grow at a healthy CAGR of 9.3% from 163 Billion to USD 304 Billion market by 2025. Demand of chemical products is expected to grow at approximately 9% p.a. over the next 5 years. Total production of major chemicals and petrochemicals stood at 27,847 MT during 2018-19, a growth of 4.15% over 2017-18. Production of polymers account for around 61% of total production of basic major petrochemicals. The current domestic market size for petrochemicals stands at $20 billion market, and has the potential to grow to $70 billion by 2030. The petrochemical demand is expected to grow at 7.5% CAGR from FY 2019-23, with polymer demand growing at 8%. Further initiatives like downstream processing industry were tabled in the recently concluded Global Chemicals & Petrochemicals Manufacturing Hubs in India on 11th & 12th November 2019 at Mumbai. Owing to growing demand, the downstream processing capacity in petrochemicals had been growing at a CAGR of 8.8% in the last 4 years. During the next 5 years, it is expected that the downstream processing industry is likely to invest $10 billion to enhance the capacity to 62.4 MMT and 86 MMT by 2027-28. Therefore, a forum dedicated to downstream industry has been envisioned to promote and highlight the future prospects in various PCPIRs.
Multiple end-uses of petrochemicals with increasing applicability as an alternative

Petrochemicals have seemingly limitless number of end-uses as they are used in plastics, fertilizers, packaging, clothing, dyes, cleaning products, cosmetics, medicines, tires. Moreover, as hundreds of millions of people in emerging markets move into the middle class, the demand is expected to further soar in the long run. In growing industries such as automotive, agriculture, medicine, infrastructure and electronics, petrochemicals can create better quality products, better efficiency, reduce costs and reduce waste. For example, the Indian automotive sector uses 5kg of engineering plastic per car, compared with 19kg in developed countries. With initiatives like Make-in-India driving up automotive manufacturing, there is an opportunity to replace metal in cars with engineering plastics produced by the domestic petrochemicals industry.
New projects in oil and gas sector to surge the demand for valves

Stabilization of the oil & gas sector, increase in investment in offshore oil and gas exploration, new refineries and modernization of existing facilities by oil & gas companies is expected to generate demand for industry valves in the overseas markets like Middle East, Africa and Latin America. Also, recent uptick in prices of crude oil is likely to increase the demand for industrial valves from oil & gas sector. Further, boom in hydraulic fracturing, shale development in the oil and gas industry in US and greater process automation by end users is expected to spur the demand for control valves in US and European markets.

Industrial valves are widely being used in diverse sectors including oil & gas; petrochemicals, chemicals & fertilizers; power; etc. Over the years, the Indian Government has been continuously focusing on the expansion of pipeline network for the distribution of natural gas across the country. With increasing demand for natural gas coupled with continuous expansion of natural gas distribution network, the country?s industrial valves market is expected to grow at a robust pace over the next five years.ÿFrom operational, safety and reliability point of view, industrial valve is one of the crucial components used in oil & gas industry. Oil & gas is expected to remain the largest source of fuel in India in the next five years as well, consequently aiding India industrial valves market. The Company can tap the opportunities emerging from these sectors to increase its topline.

According toÿ?India Industrial Valves Market Forecast & Opportunities, 2020?, industrial valves market is expected to register substantial growth at a CAGR of 13% during 2015-2020. Growing demand for industrial valves in power and oil & gas processing sector have been driving the sales of industrial valves in the country. Indian government is also investing significantly in the country?s oil and gas pipeline infrastructure development, which is expected to drive the installation of valves over the forecast period.

Indian Pumps & Valves sector has uniquely positioned itself to cater global quality solutions emerging from installations, upgradation or replacement needs. The Company can capitalize on the initiatives by the government which in turn will help in revenue growth of the Company.
Revival in global oil prices and growing energy needs to support demand for industrial valves

The global industrial valves market is expected to record a CAGR of 5.33% during the forecast period of 2019?2024. The major factor driving the market studied is the growing demand from the power and chemical industries. Stagnant industrial growth in developed countries is expected to hinder the growth of the market. The oil and gas industry dominated the market in 2017, and it is expected to experience growth during the forecast period, owing to the increasing oil and gas activities across the world.

Among all applications, the oil & gas industry is expected to account for the largest size of the industrial valve market. Recent uptrend in the oil & gas industry has boosted the demand for and increased the production of oil & gas in theÿMiddle EastÿandÿNorth America. Growing production of oil sands and shale gas fuels the demand for industrial valves inÿNorth America, and the increased investments in natural gas exploration and refineries are likely to boost the demand for these valves. Additionally, technological advancements and the adoption of more innovative valves for oil and gas transportation are the major factors that are likely to have a positive impact on the industrial valve market growth.

Further, as informed, going ahead, the ultimate parent company through its V20 transformation plan involves targeting MRO (maintenance, repair and overhaul) and after-market of North America. Further, few of the products manufacturing like pressure seal valve and, Y Pattern Globe Valves etc. will be shifted from Montreal, ultimate parents manufacturing unit to Indian Unit -as India being a low cost destination. Thus, North American plants to completely focus on complex, difficult to manufacture valves and high margins parts. Whereas , Asian plants (India and Korea) to focus on Commodity Valves. Accordingly, it can likely benefit from an anticipated recovery in crude oil prices coupled with positive outlook in demand for industrial valves.
Government support for development of technologies and common facilities

With over 9% Compounded Annual Growth Rate (CAGR), the Indian industrial valves market is expected to touch USD 3 billion by 2023.ÿThe government has taken cognizance through various industrial meets organized by bodies such as Engineering Export Promotion Council (EEPC) that the Indian Valve Industry needs investment in R & D and technology to meet the future demand, expected from the substantial investment proposed in power generation, petrochemicals, gas and fertilizer plants and to compete globally.ÿThe government has allocated INR 581 crore to take up pilot projects under the Enhancement of Global Competitiveness of Indian Capital Goods Sector scheme. So far, 30 projects had been approved for ?579 crore and the amount disbursed was INR 200 crore. In Coimbatore, a smart pump is under development under the scheme and the prototype is expected to be produced in the near-term. For the valve sector, the department is in talks with units in Hubli and Coimbatore. Coimbatore has 15-20 valve manufacturers and about 100 vendors. Further, the Southern India Engineering Manufacturers? Association (SIEMA) is undertaking a study to submit a proposal to the Government for a common facility centre for valve industries.
The Company has its operational base in Coimbatore. Any policy related benefits are likely to have direct positive impact in the Company?s business going forward.
Healthy growth prospects in the fragrance and flavour industry

The global flavour and fragrance market size was valued at USD 20.75 bn in 2018 and is expected to growth at a CAGR of 4.7% during 2019- 2025. The key factors driving the market are the growing demand for natural flavour and fragrance and consumer shift to high quality, as well as high value products across the world. Around 70% of the revenue of the Company is derived from flavour and fragrance industry. The Company?s high year on year revenue growth is attributed to the increasing demand from the end user industries. Growing awareness, easier access and changing lifestyles have been the key growth drivers for the sector.

Aromatic chemicals have multiple uses. Consumer?s fascination of fragrances has only increased with time as the manufacture of fragranced personal care, laundry care and household care products is ever growing. In addition, fragrances are present in a number of other commercial products such as tissues, candles, baby diapers, etc. Fragrances have also made their way into scented stationeries, and trash bags that now come in fragranced versions. Nowadays marketers sell products with fragrances as their main selling point with entire advertising campaigns centering on the fragrance of a product. The consumer trend too has been towards more powerful and long-lasting fragrances. Thus, the growing use of fragrances resulting in healthy growth prospects in the industry would provide fillip to Company?s revenues.
Healthy growth prospect of end user industry in the medium to long term

Though, industry is currently effected by a slowing economy, theÿgrowthÿof F&F marketÿis expected to be significant in the medium to long term. Some of the key factors driving the market are the growing demand for natural flavor and fragrance and consumer shift to high quality, as well as high value products across the world. The growing popularity of nutritionally supplemented functional foods, low-sodium foods, and low-sugar beverages, etc., is driving the demand for flavor and fragrance to improve the taste of these food & beverages.ÿThe Company?s high year on year revenue growth is attributed to the increasing demand from the end user industries. Growing awareness, easier access and changing lifestyles have been the key growth drivers for the sector. Thus, the Company is expected to benefit from the healthy growth prospect of the end user industry, which is expected to scale up its revenues going forward.

Aromatic chemicals have multiple uses. Consumer?s fascination of fragrances has only increased with time as the manufacture of fragranced personal care, laundry care and household care products is ever growing. In addition, fragrances are present in a number of other commercial products such as tissues, candles, baby diapers, etc. Fragrances have also made their way into scented stationeries and trash bags that now come in fragranced versions. Nowadays marketers sell products with fragrances as their main selling point with entire advertising campaigns centering on the fragrance of a product. The consumer trend too has been towards more powerful and long lasting fragrances. Thus the growing use of fragrances would provide fillip to Company?s revenues.
Foray into food chemicals could further enhance revenue growth

The Company may enter into food chemicals and increase range of essential oils, which are the high value products. Rapidly rising incomes and urbanization is spurring interest in convenient packaged foods and fast food. This will boost growth in the food and beverage market, as packaged goods require high flavoring loadings to preserve taste lost during large-scale manufacturing. The flourishing food industry and increasing demand for processed foods, the F&F industry in India will witness strong growth. This growth will drive the widespread use of flavors in processed food, snacks, soft drinks, candy and confectioneries, meat and seafood products, sauces and condiments, etc. Expansion of fortified food, as well as beverages, will provide opportunities, since flavors are required to cover up the off-tastes of vitamins, minerals, antioxidants and other added ingredients.ÿ

Increasing global interest in products that promote health benefits will also drive demand in both the food and beverage sector, as masking flavors are necessary to use in conjunction with antioxidants and vitamins to reduce off-tastes and off-odor. Furthermore, efforts to reduce calories, salt, and fat in foods will increase demand for flavors to improve the taste of those products. There has been a rising global interest in natural and organic products across a number of consumer markets, including food and beverages. The increasing demand augurs well for the Company, which plans to enter into the space.ÿ
Positive outlook for construction augurs well for the Company

Real estate sector in India is expected to reach USD 1 trillion by 2030, it will contribute 13 percent of the country?s Gross domestic product (GDP) by 2025. Increasing share of real estate in the GDP would be supported by increasing industrial activity, improving income level and urbanization. Construction is the fourth largest sector in terms of Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows, it stood at USD 38.92 billion from April 2000 to December 2018. Significant increase in real estate activity in cities like Indore, Raipur, Ahmedabad, Jaipur and other 2-tier cities has opened new avenues of growth for the sector. Relaxation in the FDI norms for real estate sector has boosted the real estate sector. Commercial office stock in India is estimated to be around 600 million square feet as of December 2018. New completion of office space is expected to increase by 15 percent and cross 43.6 million square feet by December 2019. Office space leasing in the top eight cities is expected to cross 100 million square feet between 2018-20. Growing impetus in co-working space with change in operating model from sales to a lease and maintenance structure. The increased demand for commercial spaces is driven by rapid growth in services sectors like Information Technology / Information Technology Enabled Services, Banking Financial Services & Insurance and Telecom coupled with rising demand from multinational corporations (MNCs) for office spaces in Tier 2 cities. Further warehousing space in top eight Indian cities increased 22 percent y-o-y in 2018 to 169 million square feet; further, investments of INR 50,000 crore (US$ 7.76 billion) are expected in India?s warehousing between 2018-20. The overall growth prospect for the real estate is expected to augment the revenue of the Company going forward.

The government?s thrust on pushing infrastructure development continues by ensuring increasing funds for core schemes such as ?Smart Cities?. It has also brought down (GST rate to 5 per cent in the sector. Stock Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has approved Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) which has led to greater transparency. With REITs institutional investors are now looking at Indian real estate with renewed interest for both commercial and industrial infrastructure sector. In March 2019, Embassy Office Parks India?s first REIT, went public. Further, the benefits from the ordinance passed for the amendment of Land Acquisition Bill is reaping benefits for improved development in the industrial corridor. All these initiatives have made the growth prospect in the real estate segment positive in the medium and long term.
Government initiatives to arrest the recent slowdown and support the positive long-term growth prospects

Although the short-term outlook remains a concern given the slowdown in the automotive sector in the last two quarters, the government of India has taken certain steps to stimulate demand for automobiles. One of the major steps announced included reduction of corporate tax rate from 30% to 22% with the effective tax rate to be 25.17% in Sep 2019.ÿ The government?s move will also help companies to spend more in research and development (R&D) of products and other aspects of the business. Automobile companies exploring opportunities to manufacture in India will have to pay an even lower tax rate of 15%, provided they start their production by 31st March 2023. To boost research and development activities in India, the minimum alternate tax rate was also reduced from 18.5% to 15% for companies who want to continue availing incentives. These set of major tax reforms are a clear indicator of the government of India?s commitment to improving the business environment to give a definite boost to economic growth. The current reduction of tax rates to globally competitive levels will incentivize OEMs and their vendors to increase localization, which augurs well for the Company and the industry as a whole. Further, given the increasing US-China trade tensions, revision in corporate tax, will attract FDI (foreign direct investment) in Indian manufacturing sector, as the revised tax structure is now in line with other emerging markets.
Favorable government policies like? Make in India? to give a boost to the auto-component industry

The Indian automotive industry has deep forward and backward linkages with several key segments of the economy. Likewise, global automobile manufacturers see India as a manufacturing hub for auto components and are rapidly increasing the value of components they source from India due to India's cost competitiveness in terms of labor and raw material and its established manufacturing base. Also, the ?Make in India? programme which was introduced in September 2014 could also help establish a global brand of auto components as many of the OEM?s have already started setting up production units in attractive international markets. For auto components manufacturers, this creates an opportunity to globalize either through exports or by setting up greenfield production units in the target markets. The 100% Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) allowed under automatic route has boosted the fund flow in the industry and boosted the technology upgradation. The government has come out with Automotive Mission Plan (AMP) 2016-26 which will help the automotive industry to grow and benefit the Indian economy.
Increasing demand and high opportunities in the flexible packaging industry in the domestic market

The Company?s products largely cater to the flexible packaging industry. The development of new substrates in this industry has led to several innovations and product developments in the laminating adhesives manufacturing industry. While the Company mainly caters to the domestic market, Indian market for flexible packaging products has been increasing by a compounded growth rate of approximately 35% during the past five years. The annual turnover in the industry is estimated to be USD 12 billion. Flexible packaging products are commonly used in the packaging of ready to consume food & beverage, personal care products (like low volume SKU, stock keeping unit, shampoo sachet) and detergents. Additionally, flexible packaging products are also finding application in pharmaceutical packaging as well as for bulk packaging.

The higher demand for consumer food & non-food products has been a major factor behind the growth of flexible packaging products. Consumption pattern among Indian consumer class has undergone a transformation. The demand for consumer essentials (food and non-food products) is increasing at a fast pace, both from rural and urban markets. This growth is fuelled by multiple factors, including increase in disposable income, changes in demographic profile, and aspirational attributes. This shift in consumption pattern is expected to be irreversible, and is closely associated with the economic growth, as witnessed in developed markets. Consequently, demand for flexible packaging products that are used in consumer packaging would continue to remains strong, which augurs well for the manufacturers of laminating adhesives.

The Company derives only ~15% of its total revenue from exports to countries like UAE, Nigeria, Nepal, Kenya, Singapore, Egypt, People?s Republic of China, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Yemen, Zambia, Indonesia, Pakistan etc. Even in these countries, the Company caters mainly to the flexible packaging industry which mainly serves the FMCG food segment. Flexible packaging has been one of the fastest growing sectors in the packaging industry over the past 10 years. Food sector within the FMCG is the biggest consumer of flexible packaging with a major share of over 70%. According to Smithers Pira, globally, the industry is expected to grow at an annual average rate of 3.4% during 2015- 2020 to reach USD 248 Billion. Asia is expected to lead the demand with its market share progressing from 42% in 2015 to nearly 45% by 2020. Changing consumer lifestyle, growth of DINK (Double Income No Kids) population, propensity to spend more on the back of increasing disposable income has enhanced dependence on processed, pre-cooked and packed foods, which has augured well for the overall growth of the flexible packaging industry throughout the world. With increasing focus on exports, the Company plans to tap this market and increase share of exports in its total revenue in the coming years.
Long term growth potential in global and domestic healthcare market
The factors that affect the pharmaceutical market size include disease prevalence, drug affordability, consumer attitudes, government policies, technology and some supply-side factors.

The global pharmaceuticals market was worth $934.8 billion in 2017 and expected to reach $1,170 billion in 2021, growing at 5.8%. The factors bolstering the growth include lower drug prices & taxes in the USA, GDP growth of over 6% in China & India, widespread population aging and sedentary lifestyles leading to increased chronic disease prevalence, lowered regulatory barriers for new drugs in the USA, and high urban pollution levels increasing the incidence of conditions like asthma. Also, the entry of consumer health wearables in the global market will facilitate access to accurate, real-world data. Subsequently, the quality of diagnostic services will improve thus leading to increased pharmaceutical consumption.

As a result, healthcare expenditure per capita is set to rise from its 2017 level of $1137 to $1427 by 2021. Most pharmaceutical industry growth now is coming from the increased size of the global aging population, which boosts demand for long-term treatments for chronic diseases, and better access to healthcare in emerging economies. In these markets, the pharmaceutical industry will also benefit from higher income level of consumers.

As far as the domestic market is concerned, India?s pharmaceutical market offers good long-term potential, driven by increasing per capita income, rising healthcare awareness, higher incidence of chronic ailments and gradually increasing insurance coverage. Cadila with its wide geographic reach and presence in multiple therapeutic areas is likely to demonstrate higher market access and topline growth in the long-run.

Drugs worth $150 billion are estimated to go off-patent by 2020 and will lead to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for Companies. This will push up the demand for low cost generics which in turn will lead to an increase in the demand for the Group?s products as it has a dominant position in the market as a manufacturer of generic formulations. Also with the number of dosages going off patent, the Indian Pharmaceutical Companies have a good opportunity to file the generics (ANDA?s) which would enable the Group a six month exclusivity right to market the drugs, giving Group a competitive edge over its peers.
Consumer and animal wellness product could augment revenues

In the previous decade, new medications have witnessed a gradual and continuous shift towards specialty medicines (defined as those that treat chronic, complex or rare conditions). Cadila has identified this transition and in order to create sustainable revenue streams, its next growth engine is to enhance share of specialty business globally. The Group is present in the niche consumer wellness space through its subsidiary, Zydus Wellness Limited which has three established brands, ?Sugar Free?, a low calorie sugar substitute, ?EverYuth?, a range of skincare products and ?Nutralite?, a cholesterol free table spread. The Group launched 8 new products in animal wellness segment in India and received 25 new marketing authorizations for the export business during the year.

Various services, across complete product lifecycle, ranging from new product development and product advancement to product migration, re-engineering, sustenance and support will be offered by vendors. The services provided will include enterprise transformation services, Independent Testing Services, Enterprise Content Management (ECM) and Business Intelligence and Analytics. Independent Testing Services comprises of testing of new technologies like Social platforms, Mobile, Analytics and Cloud (SMAC). Thus, continued focus on SMAC testing services along with technological tie-ups in the segment would help the Group augment its revenues.

Functional testing continues to be the larger portion of QA (Quality Assurance) business but digital services and non- functional testing are growing at a much faster pace. The need for Non-functional testing services such as security and performance testing are increasing manifold. In recent years? security testing in specific has become critical to ensure that any threats are identified, and vulnerabilities plugged before a system becomes available to users. The large amount of confidential data stored in these systems and the fact that monetary transactions can be carried out using this data makes it essential to protect these systems from hackers. As mentioned below are some of the industries where increased testing requirements are seen:

The Insurance industry has traditionally been the most conservative of all the financial domains. However, regulatory changes and customer demands are resulting in Insurance organizations investing in new technology and transformation initiatives. In India, significant changes are taking place and 15 life insurers have come together to build a blockchain to store and share customer detail.

Banking across the globe has been going through a major transformation over the last few years. With high focus on digitization, the financial institutions of today are more oriented towards the customer to make their experience as seamless as possible. This evolution looks set to continue well into 2018 and see developments across banking industry including a more mature application of FinTech solutions, greater use of digital payments, the opening up of banking thanks to API built architectures and the harnessing of AI and RPA solutions. It is used to get insights on customer behavior and transaction nature such as buyer propensity, suspicious transactions, subrogation opportunities etc., These insights are primarily used for developing new products, managing risk in real-time and improving profitability by way of targeted sales. Big data and Advanced Analytics technologies are being widely used by Banking & Financial Services organizations as part of their digital transformation initiatives

The Cards and Payments industry is fast shifting, driven by various factors like higher customer expectations/ changed behavior patterns & preferences, technological advancements introducing newer payment methods, increased competition due to the emergence of FinTechs and constantly changing regulations in the ecosystem. Payments landscape will find an array of new technologies to liberate the way payments are being done today. One such major disruptive technology is card-less / cash-less mobile payments using technologies such as NFC (Near Field Communication). Across the globe, there are many changes like the PSD2, Payments Systems Modernization which is gaining momentum.

Due to these changes across the BFSI landscape, there is an increased requirement for software testing services to gauge to the strength, security and other operational aspects thus increasing the scope of opportunities for the Group.
Growth in the commercial real estate space in tier 2 cities likely to boost the Company?s scale of operations

Initially, the commercial real estate used to be concentrated in the seven major cities of Mumbai, Bengaluru, Delhi, Chennai, Hyderabad, Kolkata and Pune. However, now-a-days, the markets for Tier 2 cities such as Jaipur, Indore, Kochi have seen a rise in demand primarily on account of availability of good and affordable office spaces and lower land price costs in those cities. The retail real estate sector in tier 2 and tier 3 cities has witnessed a higher investment between 2006 and 2017 which stood at around USD 6,192 million. Furthermore, factors such as international airport connectivity across these cities and rising levels of disposable income have promoted various global as well as local brands to plan their expansion in these cities.

As Company?s clientele base includes the residential and commercial real estate players and contracts across Mumbai, Chennai, Delhi and Ahmedabad, growth in the real estate space is likely to boost its scale of operations over the medium to long term.
Capacity expansion plans is expected to support the growth over the medium term

The Company during FY 2019 undertook capex for expansion of its quartz manufacturing capacity by around 30 lakh sq. feet. The cost of the project was around INR 25 crore funded through a mix of debt and internal funds. On the back of capacity addition, the Company was able to increase its revenue which grew by around 20% during FY 2019 with share of quartz in the revenue growing to 27% against 17% in FY 2018.

It further has plans to add quartz capacity by 30 lakh sq. feet during the current fiscal and the expected cash outlay is around INR 25 crore. The funding pattern would be a mix of debt and equity and this is further expected to support the growth of the Company given the increase in demand for quartz.
Revenue growth expected on the back of acquisitions

The Group has identified potential growth in four business units namely Aerospace & Defense, Medical Technology, Transportation and Communication. Increase in budget on security and defense of key nations coupled with increase in civil aircraft deliveries are key drivers for Aerospace & Defense. Similarly, increase in infrastructure investments in railways, improvement in safety & capacity of existing signaling systems would drive transportation business. Medical and health care are expecting boom in emerging markets with increased focus on smart devices, remote monitoring, telemedicine and robotics in medical surgery. Communication sector will be benefitted from demand for increased bandwidth in wireless and increased focus on IoT (internet of things).

The Group is focusing on double digit growth in the core business and 50% growth in design?led management segment. To increase its margins, it is working on operational improvements in areas like optimum utilization of resources, higher offshoring and better SG&A management. It has made new investments for growth like establishing four new subsidiaries in Beijing, Singapore, Israel and Czech Republic, developed an IoT lab internally, setup the Bogies Technical Centre at Cyient for better collaboration and value-added services in transportation. Moreover, acquisitions of Rangons and Pratt & Whitney GSE division in Singapore was in line with foraying into manufacturing and maintenance & support services of defense and medical equipment, a forward integration to the service & solutions portfolio of the Group. During FY 2018, the Group acquired Ansem N.V and B&F Design Inc. B&F Design Inc. is a Connecticut based tooling and precision engineering company that focuses on the aerospace and defense industry. Their expertise in design and manufacturing of engine assembly equipment, repair and tooling, engine factory modernization and automation equipment will aid Cyient create a differentiated value proposition centered on tooling and precision engineering. AnSem N.V. specializes in advanced analog, radio frequency, and mixed-signal integrated circuit design. Their capability allows Cyient to offer turnkey ICs?from concept circuit to final production. With this acquisition, Cyient can help clients develop smart analog sensors to capture data while leveraging IOT and analytic capabilities. Thus, the above acquisitions augur well for the topline of the group going ahead.
Growth in end user industries and Government spending on infrastructural development likely to help Company to improve its scale of operations

The overall growth and development in the infrastructure sector such as cement, airports, construction and investment in power and oil & gas (exploration/ refinery) will increase the demand for capital goods. These industries are called the core industries because their growth is critical for a country to achieve a higher economic growth rate.

With the help of the Make in India drive, India is on the path of becoming the hub for hi-tech manufacturing as global giants such as General Electric (GE), Siemens, HTC Corporation, Toshiba Corporation, and Boeing Company having either set up or are in process of setting up manufacturing plants in India. The Indian power sector is undergoing a significant change that has redefined the industry outlook. Sustained economic growth continues to drive electricity demand in India. The Government of India?s focus on attaining ?Power for all? has accelerated capacity addition in the country. Between April 2000 and March 2019, the industry attracted US$ 14.32 billion in Foreign Direct Investment (FDI), accounting for 3.41 per cent of total FDI inflows in India.

Further, the engineering sector in India attracts immense interest from foreign players as it enjoys a comparative advantage in terms of manufacturing costs, technology and innovation. Due to the increasing demand in various sectors such as housing, commercial construction and industrial construction, cement industry is expected to reach 550-600 Million Tonnes Per Annum (MTPA) by the year 2025. Thus, with anticipated growth in infrastructure, and thrust on power sector with schemes such as UDAY, Deendayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) and Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS) etc. and an expected demand in the oil and gas and other process industries, the Company would be able to augment its revenues going ahead.

The Government of India has taken many initiatives to boost the gems and jewellery industry as it is the major foreign exchange earner for the country. It has established a number of government bodies in order to facilitate trade and promote exports which include Gem & Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) and the Gems and Jewellery Trade Council of India (GJTCI). The Government has also allowed 100% FDI, in this sector through automatic route. Government of India is planning to set up gems and jewellery park in Navi Mumbai at a cost of around INR 13,500 crore. For the same, the State and GJPEC has entered into MoU. Further, the jewellery park will be developed on the line of the Shenzhen model in China which is expected to boost exports along with providing employment to around 1 lakh people.

GJEPC's thrust areas in alignment with the 'Make in India' campaign mainly include implementation of Special Notified Zone in Bharat Diamond Bourse to facilitate smooth movement of rough diamonds on consignment basis by RBI approved overseas diamond miners. GJEPC also intends to promote skill and talent development through tie-up with the existing training institutes including Gemmological Institute of America (GIA) and Indian Gemmological Institute (IGI), along with setting up of new institutes in major diamond cutting and processing centres, working with the GOI to commission exploration programmes and surveys to ascertain availability of rough diamonds and coloured gemstones in India.
Export potential likely to benefit the Company?s scale of operations

India is the world?s largest cutting and polishing centre for diamonds. As per Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) India exports 75% of the world?s polished diamonds. The low cost of labor and availability of large pool of skilled artisans has made India an attractive destination for diamond processing. Furthermore, India is famous for processing very small diamonds that requires immense skill, which the Indian artisans have developed over the years.

Though the exports from India have currently slowed down, the demand in the long term is expected to pick up on strong fundamentals in the USA and the continued growth of middle class in India and China. CPD accounted for 58.7% of the gross gems & jewellery exports in FY 2019. Thus, owing to DDPL?s large presence in the overseas market, it is expected to benefit from the huge export potential of the sector.
The global automotive industry is at the cusp of revolution, led by megatrends in the form of:

Increasing fuel costs and stringent government regulations regarding CO2 emissions are boosting demand for electric vehicles in regions such as North America, Western Europe, Eastern Europe and Asia Pacific.

Demand for electric vehicles (EVs) is expected to increase globally, led by government push. Various estimates by OEMs, experts and the government indicate that EVs would constitute 15-30% of total PV volumes by 2025. The Indian government is pushing for 100% EVs by 2030. The emergence of EVs would substantially increase the value of wiring harness per car due to the need for high voltage wiring harness systems.

Rise in technological developments is expected to create favourable growth opportunities in the market in the near future. Growing demand for connectivity and car digitisation, which not only helps establish connectivity within the integral parts of a vehicle but also enables communication with other vehicles through improved and intelligent roadway infrastructure, is an emerging trend in the market.

New car technologies are now focusing on connecting the car with its external environment, with the objective of optimizing operation, maintenance, comfort and convenience of passengers. This would result in significant increase in the number of sensors used in a car. Thus, increased use of sensors would benefit both the wiring harness as well as the polymer business.

As announced by the Indian government, vehicles will have to adhere to Bharat Stage (BS) VI norms by 2020 (currently following BS IV emission norms). The Bharat norms are emission control standards put in place by the government to keep a check on air pollution. New vehicles sold from 2020 will have to be equipped with engines compliant with the new standards BS VI. As informed, the enforcement of the new norms will boost demand for DTPL?s products, which are being manufactured with the latest technology. Furthermore, rise in demand for high-end electronics and safety features in vehicles, particularly passenger cars, along with cost reduction and enhanced reliability is leading to increase in global demand for automotive wiring harnesses.

The Company made four acquisitions in the last three year review period- Parkinson Harness Technology (UK), TFC Cable Assemblies (Scotland) and a JV into automotive switches & controllers with Carling Technologies of the USA along with the most recent acquisition of San Electromec, Bengaluru based Company which is engaged in manufacturing wire harness and control panel in highway and railway sector. Acquisitions made is to expand its product portfolio to cater to different segments and get access to wider clientele base.

TFC Cable (Scotland) was acquired by Dhoot Transmission (UK) Limited (DTPL (UK)) in June 2017 for total fund of around INR 24 crores wherein DTPL infused around INR 21 crores whereas DTPL (UK) infused the remaining INR 3 crores. This acquisition will help the Company to strengthen its presence in Europe. TFC Cable, set up in 1971, is regarded as a premier electronics manufacturer serving ATMS, analytical instruments, work access platforms, scientific equipment, gaming & vending, commercial catering & food service equipment and heating ventilation & controls, among other segments. TFC will have a dual impact on the business with the opening of a manufacturing base in Eastern Europe as well as adding new customers for its existing products.

Further, DTPL also acquired UK based Parkinson Harness Technology in March 2018. PHT is a leading manufacturer of electrical solutions including wiring harnesses, control panels, battery and power leads and control systems for manufacturers of construction equipment, municipal vehicle and industrial product. Post the said acquisition, DTPL is expecting an increase in market share in Europe along with addition of new products under its basket.

Founded in 2001, San Electromec Industries, manufactures cabling systems, wiring harnesses and control panels. It has a large clientele base that includes Wirtgen, Volvo, Terex, Faiveley, BEML, Tata Motors amongst others.

As informed, in FY 2020, the Company has entered into a JV with a China Company which is a testing facility for wiring harness products. DTPL anticipates huge opportunity for testing services ahead of BS VI and electrical vehicle norms. It is also in process to enter into a JV for electrical battery management.
The Company is expected to benefit from these acquisitions made.
Healthy growth prospects of oncology therapeutic segment could enhance Group?s revenues

Oncology is expected to be the most critical therapeutic segment driving the global spend on medicine in future. Global Spend on Medicine by Developed Markets is estimated to be $915-945bn by 2022, growing at 2-5% CAGR. The 2022 estimate for Pharmerging Markets is $345-375bn, growing at 6-9% CAGR. Oncology as a therapeutic segment is a key focus area for Dishman Group. Currently, around 50% of Dishman?s annual revenues come from Oncology therapeutic segment. Thus, Group can benefit from the good prospects of the aforesaid therapeutic segment.

China has emerged as the dominant player in the global API industry. This is largely on account of large-scale manufacturing capabilities of APIs and intermediates enabling the Chinese companies to enjoy benefits of economies of scale coupled with export benefits and subsidies granted by the China government. Currently, India is dependent on imports of bulk drugs/ APIs from China for producing certain essential medicines. However, the Indian Government is taking variousÿinitiatives to discourageÿimportÿof bulkÿdrugsÿandÿactive pharmaceutical ingredientsÿ(APIs) into the country.

The cost of technology and investment is expected to reduce on account of tax credit which can be availed now on the duties levied on import of costly machinery and equipment. Further, the government is clearing bottlenecks like environment clearance, which the manufacturers are facing in order to give boost to domestic manufacturing of bulk drugs. Government of India unveiled 'Pharma Vision 2020' aimed at making India a global leader in end-to-end drug manufacture. Favorable Central Government Policy towards the API manufacturing units by imposing anti-dumping import duty will help in retaining the profit margin & market share.

On the back of government initiatives, increased consumer spending, rapid urbanization, and improving healthcare facilities and insurance, the India pharmaceutical sector is expected to grow to US$ 100 billion by 2025.
Immense opportunities with expiry of some leading patents by 2020

The global market for generics is expected to experience robust growth in the coming years due to patent expiries of blockbuster drugs. Patent drugs are estimated to go off-patent leading to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for companies. The IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics points that patents on brands greater than USD 170 Billion are set to expire in developed markets till 2020. This will push up the demand for low cost generics. The group can capitalize on the opportunity of other companies launching the generic versions of those drugs at the earliest. Further, increased pressure on big MNCs to cut down cost offers added opportunities for CRAMS sector in India due to its cost and technical advantage. This provides great opportunity for Indian players like Dishman to increase their market share in the CRAMS segment.
Focus on high margin products to drive the profitability

The Group is engaged in CRAMS as well as manufacturing of MM like bulk drugs, intermediates, quaternary ammonium compounds (Quats), antiseptic and disinfectant formulations and specialty chemicals. The Group foresees HiPo API, niche generic API and disinfectant business to be their future growth drivers. The Group has robust pipeline of around 450 molecules across different stages of development and, of which about 15 innovative molecules are currently in late phase III trials and are expected to go into commercial manufacturing in the next 2-3 years. The Group reduced its exposure in low margin MM segment to utilize the capacities in CRAMS. About 70% of Dishman? s portfolio is geared towards higher-end API supplies with vitamin D3, bulk drugs, generic APIs and disinfectants accounting for balance 30%. In Vitamin D3, the key focus will be on quality (Vitamin D Analogues instead of Vitamin D3 500) rather than volumes, which will protect the margin. As indicated, Group is entering B2C segment and is setting up a facility for Vitamin D in the near term.

The pharmaceutical sector was valued at US$ 33 billion in 2017. The country?s pharmaceutical industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 22.4 per cent over 2015?20 to reach US$ 55 billion. India?s pharmaceutical exports stood at US$ 17.27 billion in FY18 and have reached US$ 15.52 billion in FY19 (up to January 2019). Pharmaceutical exports include bulk drugs, intermediates, drug formulations, biologicals, Ayush & herbal products and surgical. India?s domestic pharmaceutical market turnover reached Rs 129,015 crore (US$ 18.12 billion) in 2018, growing 9.4 per cent year-on-year (in Rs) from Rs 116,389 crore (US$ 17.87 billion) in 2017. Medicine spending in India is projected to grow 9-12 per cent over the next five years, leading India to become one of the top 10 countries in terms of medicine spending.

As far as the domestic market is concerned, India?s pharmaceutical market offers good long-term potential, driven by increasing per capita income, rising healthcare awareness, higher incidence of chronic ailments and gradually increasing insurance coverage.

DRL has a presence in many countries across the globe, the key geographies being the US, Europe, India, Russia, Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) countries, China and other emerging markets. With such a wide geographic reach and presence in multiple therapeutic areas viz. gastrointestinal, oncology, cardiovascular, pain management, Central Nervous System (CNS), anti-infective, respiratory and dermatology is likely to demonstrate higher market access and topline growth in the long-run.

The drugs worth $150 billion are estimated to go off-patent by 2020 will lead to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for Companies. This will push up the demand for low cost generics. This in turn will lead to an increase in the demand for the Group?s products as it has a dominant position in the market as a manufacturer of generic formulations. Also with the number of dosages going off patent, the Indian Pharmaceutical Companies have a good opportunity to file the generics (ANDA?s) which would enable the Group a six month exclusivity right to market the drugs, giving Group a competitive edge over its peers. As for instance, the group has over 170 ANDAs, over 500 DMFs and 86 patents filed in the last five years.
Ramp up of specialty product line could scale up revenues

In the previous decade, new medications have witnessed a gradual and continuous shift towards specialty medicines (defined as those that treat chronic, complex or rare conditions). DRL has identified this transition and in order to create sustainable revenue streams, its next growth engine is to enhance share of specialty business globally. Its future investments are towards differentiated products in specialty segment. In FY 2018, it derived about 3% of consolidated revenues from proprietary products segment which mainly comprises of the differentiated formulations business, focused on dermatology and neurology. It undertook R&D expenditure of approx. INR 14.44 billion in FY 2018, targeted mainly at developing complex generics and specialty products. The Group will continue to simultaneously invest in developing a global specialty portfolio. It is also investing in enhancing its product pipeline for emerging markets and other non-US developed markets. The specialty business offers an additional growth engine and helps the Group to move up the pharmaceutical value chain through development and commercialization of branded patented products.
Scope to expand in domestic and overseas IT market

India is the leading sourcing destination across the world, accounting for ~55% market share of the USD 185-190 billion global services sourcing business in 2017-18. Indian IT & ITeS companies have set up over 1,000 global delivery centres in about 80 countries across the world. The country has become the digital capabilities hub of the world with around 75% of global digital talent present in the country. India?s IT & ITeS industry grew to USD 181 billion in 2018-19. Exports from the industry increased to USD 137 billion in FY19 while domestic revenues (including hardware) advanced to USD 44 billion. Revenue from digital segment is expected to comprise 38% of the forecasted USD 350 billion industry revenue by 2025. India is the topmost offshoring destination for IT companies across the world. Having proven its capabilities in delivering both on-shore and off-shore services to global clients, emerging technologies now offer an entire new gamut of opportunities for top IT firms in India.
Increasing traction for analytics, artificial intelligence and cloud

Various services, across complete product lifecycle, ranging from new product development and product advancement to product migration, re-engineering, sustenance and support will be offered by vendors. The services provided will include enterprise transformation services, Independent Testing Services, Enterprise Content Management (ECM) and business intelligence and analytics. Independent Testing Services comprises of testing of new technologies like Social platforms, Mobile, Analytics and Cloud (SMAC). In addition to this, there is an ongoing progressive shift in the operational model where increasing focus is seen on software and platform as a service (SaaS and PaaS) resulting in a shift from the conventional billing and operational structure of an IT service provider.

India is in the midst one of the biggest technological change in the last 15 years. As per NASSCOM, Indian IT vendors would derive about USD 50 billion of their revenues from digital, 23% of the total IT-BPM industry then by 2020. Digitalization is viewed as a route to business model transformation and innovation for building sustainable competitive advantage. Businesses see a need for front-to-back, end-to-end process alignment, which would help them build their digital platforms and their digital operation environments of the future.
The higher adoption of digital technologies will enhance its pricing power and will also provide scalability to its business.
Growth prospects in the auto-components industry to help

Over the last decade, the automotive components industry has registered a CAGR of 14 percent and has scaled to IUS$ 51.2 billion in 2017-18 while exports have grown at a CAGR of 14 percent. The Indian auto-components industry is expected to register a turnover of US$ 100 billion by 2020 backed by strong exports ranging between US$ 80-100 billion by 2026. The auto-components industry accounts for almost seven percent of India?s Gross Domestic Product (GDP). India is expected to become the 4th largest automobiles producer globally by 2020 after China, US & Japan. The auto components industry is also expected to become the 3rd largest in the world by 2025. Relative to competitors, India is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East & Europe. As per Automobile Component Manufacturers Association (ACMA) forecasts, automobile component exports from India are expected to reach US$ 70-billion by 2026 from US$ 10.9 billion in FY17. The Indian auto component industry aims to achieve US$ 200 billion in revenues by 2026. India is seen as an investment hub for foreign automobile manufacturers. The Indian automobile sector has seen huge investments from both domestic and foreign manufacturers.

The country?s pharmaceutical industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 22.4% over 2015?20 to reach US$ 55 billion. India?s pharmaceutical exports stood at US$ 17.27 billion in FY18 and have reached US$ 15.52 billion in FY19 (up to January 2019). Pharmaceutical exports include bulk drugs, intermediates, drug formulations, biologicals, Ayush & herbal products and surgicals. India?s domestic pharmaceutical market turnover reached Rs 129,015 crore (US$ 18.12 billion) in 2018, growing 9.4% year-on-year (in Rs) from Rs 116,389 crore (US$ 17.87 billion) in 2017. Medicine spending in India is projected to grow 9-12% over the next five years, leading India to become one of the top 10 countries in terms of medicine spending.

The market of Asia-Pacific leads in the market of Paracetamol driven by the high growth markets of India and China. The high population and availability of cheap drugs has made Paracetamol highly popular in the market. It is also widely used and prescribed in North America and European markets. Company being a single product manufacturing Company is expected to continue to benefit from the growing demand of paracetamol.
Government initiatives to facilitate the manufacturing of APIs/Bulk drugs

China has emerged as a dominant player in the global API industry. This is largely on account of large-scale manufacturing capabilities of APIs and intermediates enabling the companies to enjoy benefits of economies of scale coupled with export benefits and subsidies granted by the China government. Currently, India is dependent on imports of bulk drugs/ APIs from China for producing certain essential medicines. However, the Indian Government is taking variousÿinitiatives to discourageÿthe importÿof bulkÿdrugsÿandÿactive pharmaceutical ingredientsÿ(APIs) into the country.ÿRecently the government has withdrawn exemption of customs duty on certain categories of bulk drugs/APIs to provide level playing field to the domestic manufacturers. Further, the government is clearing bottlenecks like environment clearance, which the manufacturers are facing in order to give a boost to the domestic manufacturing of bulk drugs. Government of India?s ?Pharma Vision 2020? aims to make India a global leader in end to end drug manufacturing. These initiatives would act as an opportunity for domestic manufacturers, who were earlier facing stiff competition from China due to cheap products.
Favourable global trends coupled with strong position of India in global home textile industry

Global home textile market was valued at USD 49 billion (2017) and is expected to increase to USD 57 billion by 2025. India?s home textile industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 8.3 % during 2014-21 to USD 8.2 billion in 2021 from USD 4.7 billion in 2014. In 2018-19, Indian home textile industry reached USD 4.95 billion. Being a cotton surplus and net cotton exporter nation, India provides the cotton home textile manufacturers an edge over manufacturers in other countries in terms of quick and continuous cotton supply at a much competitive price.

According to the Office of Textiles and Apparels (OTEXA) USA, in 2018, India supplied about 39% of the imports of cotton towels to the US, which has grown significantly from the levels of 30% in 2009. Even in the cotton sheets segment, the Country supplied about 50% (2018) of the total import to the US, increasing from 27% (2009).

India is in discussion with the European Union for a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) which would reduce the duties, currently Indian exporters pay 9-10% duty on the home textile products exported to the EU, whereas some of the key competing countries have zero duty access to the market. The above factors may lead to incremental demand for textile products manufactured by the Company thereby improving its topline. However, the global trends shifting towards e-commerce may require steps on part of Indian players to capitalize on the opportunity presented and change business model as per the need of the hour.
Favourable government initiatives to boost investment in textile industry.

The Government of India through many of its policy reforms has provided a boost for investment growth in the textile industry. Government of India has allowed 100% foreign direct investment and the industries remains one of the key focus areas under its ?Make in India? initiatives.
