Manufacturing hubs have been established to provide the ecosystem for sustainable growth in the industry.

With the aim to promote investments in the textile sector, since 2014, 19 Textile Park projects have been sanctioned under Scheme for Integrated Textile Park (SITP) under Public Private Partnership mode (PPP) with 40% government assistance of up to INR 40 crore.

Investment was made to promote modernization and up-gradation of the textile industry by providing credit at reduced rates under the Technology Up-gradation Fund Scheme (TUFS). A subsidy of INR 1,400 crore was released under this scheme in 2017. The scheme has been continuously amended since to suit the need for the hour for the industry where currently it offers capital subsidy for technology upgradation in the sector. Further, under the Union Budget 2019-20, INR 700 crore have been allocated for this scheme.

AEIL has entered into definitive agreement to acquire 80% equity in Sidwal Refrigeration Industries Private Limited (Sidwal) which also includes business of Sidwal Technologies, a sole proprietorship firm of the promoters of Sidwal. By virtue of the aforesaid acquisition of equity shares of Sidwal, the Sidwal has become a subsidiary of Amber Enterprises India Limited with effect from 2nd May 2019.

Sidwal has a diversified portfolio in the heating ventilation air-conditioning solution domain and caters to six major verticals - Indian Railways, Metros, Bus Air-conditioning, Defence, Telecom and Commercial Refrigeration. Sidwal is a market leader in Indian Railways and Metro segment with a track record of supplying more than 15,000 heating & ventilation air-conditioning units for mainline coaches and more than 2,000 such units for metro projects. Revenue split for FY?18 for Sidwal was 72% from Indian railways and metros, 9% each from defense and bus air-conditioning and the balance from telecom and commercial segment. Of the 72% between Indian railways and metros, 40% is from Railways and 30% is from metros which is the direct B2B business. In metros, it supplies air-condition to the coach manufacturers like CAF in Spain, CRRC from China, etc, which are complete B2B businesses. In the Indian Railways, the customers include Rail Coach Factory Kapurthala, Integrated Coach Factory, Chennai, and MCF, Rai Bareilly. The entire acquisition is funded majorly through internal accruals and partly through debt.

Through this acquisition, the Company is expected to gain synergies in terms of foraying into product segments having high approval cycles along with increased customer base. The acquisition is poised to help the Company to add a new business vertical in the form of mobile application and commercial application of air-conditioners that is mobile and commercial segment within the heating ventilation air-conditioning segment. With successful integration, AEIL believes it would emerge as the market leader in mobile and commercial segment of HVAC industry in addition to its leadership position in the RAC, room air-conditioners outsourcing segment. Further, as informed, EBITDA margins of Sidwal for FY 2018 are over 20% with the PAT margins of almost 13-14% and revenue of around INR 165 crores. Sidwal has no long-term debt on its books and debt in the form of short-term working capital requirements is to the tune of only INR 7-10 crores. The impact of the acquisition and its translation to the revenue and profitability of the Company however remains to be seen.
Government support, low penetration base along with foray into the international market

Indian Government raised import duty on a range of items including air-conditioners, refrigerators, washing machines, footwear, jewellery, furniture fittings and tableware besides imposing it on aviation turbine fuel (ATF) as the government seeks to rein in the current account deficit and shore up the rupee.ÿIn its notification on 27th September 2018, the government has increased the custom duty from 10% to 20% on air conditioners. This will add up to AEIL?s benefit in catering new demands of ACs which were previously being imported.

Indian room air conditioner (AC) volumes are expected to grow driven by rising penetration of ACs (4-5% currently v/s 30% global average), higher disposable income, growing urbanization and the year-round AC usage trend. Moreover, in the past few years, demand has been continually shifting toward energy-efficient ACs (5-star/inverter), which contributes ~30-35% of overall industry volumes. According to the Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE), all ACs that operate on invertor technology have to be compulsorily rated from 2018. Consequently, the rating for fixed and variable compressors is merged. The split AC market is expected to transition to inverter technology over next few years, with inverter ACs projected to account for 50% by 2020.

Presently, invertor AC accounts for only 12% of the total revenue of AEIL while split and window contribute to around 72% and 16% respectively. Thus, the shift to invertor AC, hike in custom duty on export and expected growth in the RAC market would augment the topline of the Company. Further, addition of new products and foray into the international markets mainly Middle East, South-East Asia and Europe would also augur well for the Company.

India is emerging as global hub for auto component sourcing. A cost-effective manufacturing base keeps costs lower by 10-25 per cent relative to operations in Europe and Latin America. Relative to competitors, India is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East and Europe. Indian automotive industry has deep forward and backward linkages with several key segments of the economy. Likewise, global automobile manufacturers see India as a manufacturing hub for auto components and are rapidly increasing the value of components they source from India due to India's cost competitiveness in terms of labor and raw material and its established manufacturing base.

Favorable government policies such as Auto Policy 2002, Automotive Mission Plan 2016-2026, National Automotive Testing and R&D Infrastructure Projects (NATRiPs), have helped the Indian auto components industry achieve considerable growth. However, with the introduction of BS VI norms from April 2020, the sector seems some uncertainty in the short term.

The Company operates in the plating industry, the global plating on plastic market is estimated to grow at CAGR above 7.1 % over the forecast time frame 2019-2026 and reach the market value around USD 1 billion by 2026. The growth in market size will be driven by growth prospects in light weight and high-performance plastic owing to flexibility of design, increase in efficiency along with increasing disposable income and rise in living standards. Growing demand for light weight, fuel efficient automotive would propel plating on plastic market demand owing to its wide application in grilles, light bezel, trims, dashboards, arm rest and emblems as it is easily fabricated and durable.ÿRising demand for light weight metal substitutes in electronics owing to improved performance efficiency will further drive the industry size. Further, Asia Pacific region is a rapidly expanding market for plating on plastics. Shift of automotive manufacturing activities toward developing economies, such as China and India, will fuel the plating on plastics market in Asia Pacific and provide the Company with growth opportunities.ÿ
New facilities and backward integration to boost growth opportunities

The Company undertakes backward integration through its sister concern and has set up a new facility with electroplating capabilities at Zaroli, Gujarat to cater to injection moulding of large auto component parts. As indicated, the new facility is adhering to European process standard having larger capacities and modernized machinery. This would augur well for the export markets and the Company expects increase in business from the exports to upto 50% of the total revenue going ahead.

The Company with its expertise in executing large projects in the complex industrial space is focusing on the new opportunities in the urban infra space which includes metro rail projects, water management, roads, airways, ports and bridges. Also, increased support from the Government, multilateral institutions along with lower competition reduces the risk in these projects. Smart city mission launched by the Government of India to develop 100 cities with smart solutions like E-governance and citizen services, energy management, waste management, urban mobility, water management etc., provides immense opportunity to Companies like GHV in urban infrastructure segment.

The Company is in the EPC segment which caters to road, airways, railways, dams, canals, bridges and other segments. Over the years, the revenue from railway segment has increased. Furthermore, the Government plans for 5,000 Km of gauge conversion and 4,000 Km of electrification along railway network in FY 2019. The total capital and development expenditure of railways is pegged at INR 1,48,528 crore which is expected to provide an opportunity for GHV which is reflected in present order book position of the group in this segment. Moreover, the Government is planning to invest around INR 330,000 crore for setting up of three new arms of Dedicated Railway Freight Corridor, over the next eight years for decongesting the existing network. These measures taken by the Government will help the group in bagging new orders and enable it to scale up operations.

In 2018, MICE tourism in India was pegged at Rs 25,000 crore with 8 per cent growth year-on-year. Consistently among the fastest growing economies in recent years, India has price competitive offerings in addition to 31 international airports, besides one of the largest rail and road network worldwide. The global MICE tourism is estimated to be growing at a compound annual growth rate of 7.5 per cent and reach 1.2 trillion dollars (about Rs 70 lakh crore) by 2023. Asia Pacific region is expected to lead this with 8.6 per cent growth. India ranks fifth in the Asia Pacific region behind Japan, China, South Korea and Australia. However, it has a variety of destinations which can be clubbed with diverse tourism offerings to enhance MICE. Moreover, continual economic growth coupled with rapid emergence of India on the global horizon is poised to drive the growth of MICE tourism at a much faster rate. Also, there is significant scope of penetration in this sub-segment as India is a late entrant in the segment with a little share on the global scale. Of the total 12,563 international meetings in a year, it hosts only 175 - or just 1.4 per cent to rank 24th worldwide providing it with huge growth prospects when looked in conjunction with related infrastructure development support, ability to host more world-class convention and exhibition centres and government thrust to adopt a holistic approach to promote MICE tourism.

Corporate travelers opt for MICE tours so as to promote their businesses among their peers and do networking, etc. These activities are combinations of business and sight-seeing at the destination for relaxation. GHV Group?s hospitality business largely caters to corporate clients, hence, the Company is likely to benefit from any positive thrust in the segment.
Changing landscape of the industry to give a push to the sector

The hospitality sector has advances significantly over the years. Factors such as oversupply of hotel rooms, competition from shared economy models, a blind spot in events based tourism, and experiential hospitality to appeal to a new generation has changed the landscape of the Indian hospitality sector today. On the upside, the sector will see a further rise in investment. According to a report released by Meraqi, a real estate advisory firm, the hospitality sector is likely to witness an annual investment of $0.5-0.6 billion during 2018-2022 and a total investment of up to $2.8 billion by 2022.

Event based tourism is also on the rise as domestic travel category is seeing steady growth as the burgeoning middle class continues to travel for religious and festive reasons. Ticket booking sites often report that there is month-on-month, double-digit growth in hotel bookings for cities with religious connections. Wedding tourism also still remains a largely untapped market. There is strong demand in this sector and has the potential to grow exponentially in the next few years. There is a large opportunity for India to perform better with its many diverse offerings. To sum it up, the Indian travel and tourism industry is expected significantly grow in the coming years. India?s increasing popularity as a medical tourism destination, steadily growing Meetings, Incentives, Conferences and Exhibitions (MICE) segment and an increasing fondness among millennials and Gen Z generations to travel, will result in overall growth in room tariffs and may offset the current imbalance of supply and demand.

The demand outlook for hotels has brightened due to several government initiatives. The Government has been actively working towards tapping plethora of opportunities available in the sector to actualize its true potential. Several initiatives such as rapid implementation of Swadesh Darshan and PRASHAD schemes, E-Visa for citizens from 166 countries for visit to India through 28 international airports and 5 sea airports and Adventure Tourism Guidelines, among others coupled with promotional activities such as Incredible India 2.0 campaign and India Tourism Mart 2018 have immensely benefited the sector. More recently the drastic cut in e-visa fees andÿgoods and services taxÿ(from 28% to 18% for tariff aboveÿINR 7,500 per room, and from 18% to 12% for tariff belowÿINR 7,500 per room) are likely to make India more attractive compared to its South-East Asian peers. India has seen significant jump in the Travel & Tourism Competitiveness ranking by the World Economic Forum, rising from 65th position in 2013 to 40th in 2017 making India one the most improved nations. These developments and continual government support are likely to help grow the hospitality industry and in turn benefit the hotel chain of the GHV group.

The global pharmaceutical market is expected to reach USD1.5 trillion by 2023 growing at a 3?6% compound annual growth rate over the next five years (2018-23).ÿThe factors bolstering the growth include lower drug prices & taxes in the USA, GDP growth of over 6% in China & India, widespread population aging and sedentary lifestyles. These have also resulted in chronic disease prevalence, lowered regulatory barriers for new drugs in the USA, and high urban pollution levels increasing the incidence of conditions like asthma. As a result, the global healthcare expenditures are projected to rise 3.7% annually in real (inflation-adjusted) US dollars through 2023, according toÿGlobal Healthcare. Spending will be driven by increasing access to a myriad of healthcare services in low and middle income countries and population growth, particularly in the cohort 65 years of age and older. In 2023, theÿAsia/Pacific region is projected to become the largest user of healthcare products and services, surpassingÿNorth America.

Also, the entry of consumer health wearables in the global market will facilitate access to accurate, real-world data. Subsequently, the quality of diagnostic services will improve thus leading to increased pharmaceutical consumption. As far as the domestic market is concerned, India?s pharmaceutical market offers good long-term potential, driven by increasing per capita income, rising healthcare awareness, higher incidence of chronic ailments and gradually increasing insurance coverage.
Growth in contract manufacturing and research services in India

The rising costs and regulatory pressure in developed markets are forcing many global pharmaceutical companies to reduce their internal capacities in research and development (R&D), and manufacturing, and turn to contract manufacturing and research services (CRAMS), and outsourcing of research and clinical trials to developing countries. These strategies help multinational companies reduce costs, increase development capacity, and focus on their core profit makings activities, such as drug discoveries and marketing, rather than on manufacturing. India, with a large patient population and genetic pool, is fast emerging as a preferred destination for such multinationals seeking efficiencies of cost and time. The country?s CRAM industry offers a significant cost-quality proposition, with potential savings of about 30-40 % compared to western markets such as the USA and Europe. Since the amendment to Patents Act in 2005, many Indian pharmaceutical companies have gradually moved away from generic production to the development of new drugs, exports to regulated markets and cooperative agreements with global pharma companies. A USD 33 billion opportunity, the pharmaceutical industry in India presents considerable potential for collaborative and outsourced R&D in drug development, biotechnology, chemicals, and manufacturing of medicinal products. India?s CRAM sector is globally recognized for its high-end research services and is one of the fastest growing segments of the country?s pharmaceutical industry.

The Company undertakes contract manufacturing of formulations as well as contract research (although the revenue share is low currently), hence is likely to benefit from the positive trend of the industry.

India?s generic drug producers hold a strong position in the global supply chain and play an integral role in developing the pharmaceutical industry. Drugs worth $212 billion are estimated to go off-patent by 2024 which will lead to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for companies. This will push up the demand for low cost generics. This in turn will lead to an increase in the demand for the Company?s products in the global market.
Resilient African economy provides opportunity for Indian pharmaceutical companies

With a growing population and an increase in the number of senior citizens over the next 30 years, Africa is likely to witness a greater number of age-related illnesses, far more than in previous years. In addition, the growing middle class has more disposable income than earlier, leading to changing lifestyle patterns. In turn, there is increased danger of heart-related diseases, high obesity rates and other lifestyle-related illnesses. In this respect, Africa is fast catching up with the West. Yet, its tropical climate makes it host to a large number of infectious diseases such as malaria,ÿtuberculosis, polio,ÿmeningitis, cholera, yellow fever and hepatitis to name a few. And there is always the scourge of the dreaded HIV.

As pharmaceutical markets in developed economies stagnate, Africa's growth story comes as an opportunity for pharmaceutical manufacturers across the world. Hence in the coming years there will be significant demand for generic drugs and medicines in Africa. Indian pharmaceutical companies can hope to take advantage of this demand, despite the uncertainty and volatility in the political environment of some African nations. Ethiopia has a population of over 100 million people, which is growing annually by of 2.3%. It has a vision to be Africa's leading pharmaceutical manufacturing hub. The Ethiopian pharmaceutical market is expected to grow at 15% per year and almost reach USD 1 billion by 2020.

The Company has been increasing its presence in countries such as Ethiopia, Zimbabwe, Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania, Ivory Coast, and Ghana. Also, its key customer (Exphar SA in Belgium) is a re-exporter who also exports to African countries.

Driven by the Government of India?s emphasis on the substitution of imported goods to reduce import bills, sectors such as mining, railways, etc. are expected to rely on Indian companies and domestic expertise for procurement, thus providing opportunity to the Company to grow in non-automotive business.
Focus on operational efficiency and technological upgrade is expected to assist topline growth

The Company has manufacturing facility in Ludhiana which comprises of 3D simulation (Deform ? 3D and Forge ? 2009), pneumatic and drop hammers, 8000 and 4000-ton forging press line, heat treatment, machining, shot blasting, etc. The Company also has accredited laboratory for stage wise quality tests. Integrated operations address quality and lead time concerns. From FY 2018, the Company has aimed at increasing its operational efficiency and is going through major technological upgradations. The Company already has two 8000-ton mechanical press line. They are planning to have a 3rd 8000-ton fully robotic press line to be operational by mid of FY 2019-2020. There is a 14000-ton press line already under construction which will enhance the forging capacity from 60,000-MT to 1,00,000-MT. They have purchased 24 acre land parcel for new manufacturing unit and the civil work has already started from April-2018. This is major expansion activity the Company has seen in the review period.

Further, as a part of the future expansion vision of the Company, they are planning to put up 8 dedicated line of crank-shaft with single piece flow. Key machines with high lead time have already been ordered and they are likely to commission at least 3 machine lines by mid of FY-2020. With the expansion plans of the company for manufacturing unit and installed capacity already in motion, it will contribute to a healthy growth in revenue in coming years.

Growing economies as well as urbanization has led regional transport planning and governing authorities to invest substantially on railway infrastructure. Railways are the major source of mass transportation; which are the basic driver of global rail pads markets.

The Indian government has increased its capital expenditure outlays towards the Indian Railways. Its focus areas are medium-term structural reforms as well as infrastructure development such as electrification and expansion of the existing network, improving safety, increasing its fleet of rolling stock, providing for high speed rail and freight corridors and providing better passenger amenities. The government investment has been around INR 1.5 trillion per annum. The Budget estimates government investment in railways to increase by a good 24 per cent to INR 65,837 crore from INR 53,060 crore in 2018-19. Also, the government has set an ambitious investment target of INR 50 trillion between 2018-2030 for which it is also increasing public-private partnership (PPP) projects. The Government of India has decided to create INR 30,000 crore Rail India Development Fund (with assistance from World Bank). This will support commercially viable investment in the railway sector in India over the next seven years.

The Indian Railways have a fleet of more than 2.51 lac wagons, 70,241 coaches and 11,112 locomotives. The traffic carried by the Indian Railways can be split into two segments: passenger and freight. Construction of the Eastern and the Western Dedicated Freight Corridors will lead freight volumes to more than double to 2,165 million tonnes by FY 2020. Increasing carrying capacity, cost effectiveness and improved quality of service will escalate railway?s share of freight movement from 35% to 50% by 2020. These significant growth in rail network will thrust ample demand to multiple locomotive and wagon related products & services.

Metro trains are rail-based mass rapid transit systems that operate on a privileged right-of-way either underground or elevated over street level, separated from all other modes of transport in an urban area. Currently, there are eight operational metro systems in India. As of beginning of 2019, India had 524 km of operational metro lines in the cities of Delhi and NCR, Gurgaon, Kolkata, Chennai, Bengaluru, Jaipur and Mumbai. With a modest beginning with 8 km in 2002, modern metro rail have shown phenomenal growth in the country. There is about 600 km of sanctioned metro lines under construction which will be operational in next five years.There are about 1,000 km of metro line proposals under planning.

There has been a rapid increase in the expansion of urban mass transportation systems across India due to continued support from the Central and State Governments and multi-lateral development agencies.

Metro rail system enables large-scale, rapid and low-cost movement of people while causing very little pollution as compared to conventional modes of transport, however, only 35- 40% in India?s metropolitan cities have a metro rail network. Given rising urbanisation and increasing population levels in India, implementation of metro rail systems will become imperative as mass rapid transit systems are the best way to decongest traffic. The implementation of the 2017 Metro Rail Policy also augurs well for the Company as it manufactures products for metro rail systems as well.

Digitalization is viewed as a route to business model transformation and innovation for building sustainable competitive advantage. Businesses see a need for front-to-back, end-to-end process alignment, which would help them build their digital platforms and their digital operation environments of the future. The global sourcing model continues to grow its importance.

The Company?s digital framework drives outcomes for them across five areas ? Experience, Insight, Innovate, Accelerate and Assure. It crafts the way its customers experience digital solutions, helps their businesses gain insight from data, innovate with them in the world of vertical platforms and digital- first engineering, accelerate their core digitalization, and assure means for them to establish digital trust. Its clients ? large enterprises and government organizations ? are at different points in their digital journey. Infosys is positioning its capabilities to help them navigate their next, across the different dimensions of this journey. Infosys has built, over the years, a formidable position in the digital space ? INR 25,797 crore of the total revenue in fiscal 2019 came from these digital services.
Focus on cloud computing and digitization backed by Government support

Digitalization is viewed as a route to business model transformation and innovation for building sustainable competitive advantage. Businesses see a need for front-to-back, end-to-end process alignment, which would help them build their digital platforms and their digital operation environments of the future. The global sourcing model continues to grow its importance. Cloud computing is a mechanism of sharing of resources, software, and information by different users over the network. It does not require end users to know about the physical location and configuration of the system that delivers these services. This concept is increasingly becoming popular amongst the small and medium enterprises who want to save on the costs of establishing their own IT infrastructure. The group, through its data centers (by having its own networks, servers, storage space) can efficiently provide specialized services like cloud computing, disaster recovery, etc. to increase its revenue.

The Government of India has launched the Digital India program to provide several government services to the people using IT and to integrate the Government departments and the people of India. The adoption of key technologies across sectors spurred by the 'Digital India Initiative' could help boost India's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by US$ 550 billion to US$ 1 trillion by 2025.

India and the US have agreed to jointly explore opportunities for collaboration on implementing India's ambitious INR 1.13 trillion (US$ 16.58 billion) ?Digital India Initiative?. The two sides also agreed to hold the US-India Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Working Group in India later this year.
Long term growth potential in global and domestic healthcare market with expansion of capacities to further boost its scale of operations

The factors that affect the pharmaceutical market size include disease prevalence, drug affordability, consumer attitudes, government policies, technology and some supply-side factors. The global pharmaceuticals market was worth USD 934.8 billion in 2017 and expected to reach USD 1,170 billion in 2021, growing at 5.8%. The factors bolstering the growth include lower drug prices & taxes in the USA, GDP growth of over 6% in China & India, widespread population aging and sedentary lifestyles leading to increased chronic disease prevalence, lowered regulatory barriers for new drugs in the USA, and high urban pollution levels increasing the incidence of conditions like asthma. Also, the entry of consumer health wearables in the global market will facilitate access to accurate, real-world data. Subsequently, the quality of diagnostic services will improve thus leading to increased pharmaceutical consumption.

As a result, healthcare expenditure per capita is set to rise from its 2017 level of USD 1,137 to USD 1,427 by 2021. Most pharmaceutical industry growth now is coming from the increased size of the global aging population, which boosts demand for long-term treatments for chronic diseases, and better access to healthcare in emerging economies. In these markets, the pharmaceutical industry will also benefit from higher income level of consumers. As far as the domestic market is concerned, India?s pharmaceutical market offers good long-term potential, driven by increasing per capita income, rising healthcare awareness, higher incidence of chronic ailments and gradually increasing insurance coverage.

Furthermore, the Group is undertaking capex for expansion of its capacities by setting up another plant at SEZ. The total cost for the same was around INR 96 crore funded through internal funds. The Group has done filing with USFDA, for which the approval is yet to be received and management expects the operations to commence in Q1 FY 2020. Thus, the Group?s wide geographic reach and presence in multiple therapeutic areas along with expansion plans is likely to demonstrate higher market access and topline growth in the long-run.
Increasing scope for offshoring in the LPO industry

The globalÿlegal process outsourcing marketÿsize is projected to reach USD 35.9 billion by 2025, expanding at a CAGR of 31.8% from 2019 to 2025, according to a new report by Grand View Research, Inc. The growth can be chiefly attributed to the emergence of alternative legal service delivery models and virtual law firms.

Electronic discovery (e-discovery) services have grown in prominence, which can be attributed to amendments by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, making Electronically Stored Information (ESI) such as e-mails, e-calendars, and voicemails discoverable on handheld devices in litigation. The development of ESI will reduce the complexity and cost of e-discovery processes and is expected to simplify large-scale complex litigation processes.ÿ The litigation support segment is expected to register a CAGR of more than 34.0% over the forecast period. Majority of the LPO providers are emphasizing on maintaining their locally-registered office in U.S. and setting up back offices in Asia Pacific in order to strengthen their foothold in the global market.

The Company presently has two delivery centers based in Mumbai and Noida with employee strength of 1,265 personnel. On a group level, the Integreon Group has 12 delivery centers across USA, UK, China, Philippines, India and South Africa. The Company has plans to expand its delivery centers by increasing the employee strength in order to cater to the increase in the receipt of outsourced contracts. It invested in an additional office space within the same building in Mumbai to create room for more employees while maintaining the utilisation rate. Expansion of these delivery centers to cater to the demand is likely to benefit the Company going forward in terms of increasing its scale of operations.
Changing trends in the outsourcing industry towards innovation led service offerings

Organizations in today?s time need to embrace emerging technologies in order to grow and gain a competitive advantage. Expertise in every skill and technology cannot be demanded in-house. Hiring more local employees will mean being exposed to a small circle of local talents. Also, these employees will then need training to understand how the business works, hence further increasing development and testing time. But with outsourcing, businesses get access to specialized and skilled workforce all over the world, thus expanding their search. The result is decreasing the skill gaps and exposure to greater talent and technology along with competitive advantage for companies.

Further, technological advancements and innovations in the legal industry are expected to offer new growth avenues in the sector, helping law firms inculcate a transparent relationship with clients. Law firms are deploying Natural Language Processing (NLP) and document automation capabilities to fall in line with the reinvention of the legal industry.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is another factor that has taken the LPO industry to a new level. Software equipped with AI capabilities is garnering utmost importance among lawyers and firms to save their time. Document production and proofreading of documents are efficiently done with the help of automation software. Use of team collaboration software is further streamlining the execution of all the documentation processes. All such technological developments have greatly aided lawyers by decreasing costs and increasing convenience.

As informed, the management is in tune with influx of new technologies in the data processing segment. It continuously invest in new technologies in order to be competitive in the industry and yields from such investment are likely to be visible in the medium term.
Cost competitiveness and government incentives likely to boost up scale of operations

Indian IT-BPM industry has steadily grown surpassing the adverse impact of challenging global environment. It has exhibited significant transformation, both in terms of revenue and services offered. Innovation and customization of products & services to align with changing customer expectation and dynamic operating environment is driving overall industry. Presence of large employee base with technical skills and cost differential against the developed nations has helped India to emerge as a preferred outsourcing destination. Furthermore, Indian IT-BPM industry is a global talent powerhouse and a representative of millennial, showcasing diversity, and leadership in digital skills that too at competitive costs. India has 36-38% share of global employable talent pool for the IT industry. With more than 16,000 companies, and the ability of the Indian companies to blend the requisite of IT, BPM, infrastructure management, analytics, they are increasingly catering to the growing demand. Furthermore, the government initiatives such as tax benefits for new units commencing operations in Special Economic Zones, is expected to provide benefits to the related companies.
Thrust of the Government on power infrastructure could lead to healthy growth prospects

Government of India (GoI) through Ministry of Power launched the initiative of Ultra Mega Power Projects (UMPPs) i.e. 4,000 MW super thermal power projects (both pit head and imported coal based) in November 2005 with the objective to develop large capacity power projects in India. Power Finance Corporation Ltd (PFC) has been appointed as the Nodal Agency to facilitate the development of these projects.ÿ

100% Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) is allowed under the automatic route in the power sector for generation from all sources (except atomic energy), transmission and distribution of electric energy and Power Trading, subject to all the applicable regulations and laws. The government targets capacity addition of around 100 GW under the 13th Five-Year Plan (2017?22). In June 2017, the government announced intentions to set up an asset reconstruction company for handling the stressed assets in power sector. This would also help in the transfer of stressed power generation assets of stalled power projects, which would then be auctioned.

GoI launched two schemes, namely, Deendayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) and Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS) in December 2014 for providing capital subsidy to the States for strengthening of sub-transmission and distribution networks in rural areas and urban areas.

The government has allocated INR 4,843 crore to electrify the rural areas under the Deendayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana in financial year 2017-18.ÿFurther, the Government of India?s focus on poverty alleviation and 100% electrification would help the Company in augmenting its topline.

Moreover, Ujwal Discom Assurance Yojna (UDAY) provides for the financial turnaround and revival of discoms. UDAY seeks to empower loss making discoms to break even in two-three years by helping the Discoms in improving their operational efficiencies (compulsory smart metering, upgradation of transformers, popularizing LED bulbs), reducing the cost of power (increased supply of cheaper domestic coal, liberal coal swaps from inefficient to efficient plants, amongst other benefits).
Thus, the thrust by the Government on power infrastructure would help the Company to augment its topline by tapping these new business opportunities.
Government initiatives on the back increased awareness for wastewater treatment

Due to rising population, increasing urbanization and industrial developments India is a major water consumer. The demand for water hasÿincreased three foldsÿin the past two decades, while the supply remains the same.ÿTo meet the challenges, the Government is taking various initiatives and brought in policies which are essential for the growth of the water treatment industry. Growing industrial sectors together with favorable Government policies like Zero Liquid Discharge (ZLD) are making an increasing number of industries to treat waste water for reuse. ZLD is a treatment process in which the entire waste water is purified and recycled and can help to ensure safety of groundwater. Manufacturing and power plants can meet environmental standards and reduce their reliance on freshwater. India has mandated ZLD systemsÿacross industriesÿlike thermal power plants, iron & steel, textiles, distilleries and pulp & paper. The Indian ZLD market is expected to reachÿ$4 billion by 2020.

Considering that less than 30% of industrial waste water is treated before releaseÿinto the environment, the Supreme Court in India came outÿwith a green orderÿin February 2017. Under this order, all industrial units across the country have to set up effluent treatment plants in working condition within three months. If the polluting industrial units do not fulfil the conditions, they will face immediate closure.ÿHowever,ÿthe outlook for water management companiesÿgot brighter after the order. Companies with innovative technologies for water management will benefit as it is expected to boost their earnings. A lot of investment and innovation is going into this sector and the capital expenditure on water & waste water infrastructure in India may increase byÿ83%ÿby FY 2020.ÿ

The Government has prioritized to treat waste water, one of the landmark projects being the National Mission for Clean Ganga. Discharge of untreated sewage is one of the main causes of pollution of water bodies in the country and the focus of various river clean-up action programmes.

Moreover, recently, the government has created a new Ministry calledÿ?Jal Shakti?ÿin May 2019 after mergingÿMinistries of Water Resources, River Development & Ganga Rejuvenationÿalong withÿDrinking Water and Sanitation. ?Jal Shakti? ministry will encompass issues ranging from providingÿclean drinking water, international and inter-statesÿwater disputes, to theÿNamami Gangeÿproject aimed at cleaning Ganga and its tributaries, and sub-tributaries. This is a major step towards the consolidation of the management of water resources with delivery of drinking water and sanitation ? a much-needed step in the direction of ensuring India?s water security ? as well as a thrust towards the goal of providing safe and adequate piped water supply for all households.
Accordingly, with continual focus of the government towards wastewater treatment, the Company is likely to benefit from increased orders in the domestic market.

While water is a renewable resource, it is at the same time a limited resource. According to aÿreportÿby the United Nations, India is the biggest consumer of groundwater in the world. By contrast, among major countries, groundwater levels in India are going down faster than anywhere else. With increasing water scarcity, the only sources of water are the sea, sewage and industrial waste water, which need to be treated, reused and managed without damaging the environment.ÿ

India?s Waste Water management market is estimated to grow at aÿCAGR of 8-10%ÿduring by 2020. India?s Water & Waste Water Industry will see enormous growth prospects in the coming years. High demand for potable water, Governments initiatives for water reuse and the increasing foreign investmentsÿare the major growth supporting factors for the industry inÿIndia. The National Water Mission of India targets toÿreduce water consumption by 20%ÿin all sectors by 2030. To meet this, it is critical to conserve, recycle and reuse water.
Positive global outlook due to increasing global water stress
The global Water and Wastewater Treatment market is valued at USD 4,950 million in 2018 and is expected to reach USD 6,520 million by the end of 2025, growing at a CAGR of 3.5% during 2019-2025.

The rise in industrial activities and growing contamination have further demanded the treatment of water to make it suitable for end-use purposes. Awareness amongst people towards environmental pollution is also a key driver for water and wastewater treatment market.ÿSome of the prominent trends that the market is witnessing include growing demand for water reuse, depleting freshwater resources and technological advancements in industrial wastewater treatment technology. The Asia Pacific water & wastewater treatment equipment market is projected to grow at the highest CAGR during the forecast period due to the growing demand of potable water in this region. Middle East is estimated to witness steady growth at 4.7% CAGR owing to the increasing population, the rise in the disposable income and the infrastructure availability. The USA is one of the major consumers of wastewater treatment equipment and is expected to enhance the growth over 2019-2025. Hence, due to the aforementioned factors, the Company is likely to benefit from its increased focus in the international markets.
Growth in demand for steel coupled with Government Initiatives provides growth opportunities

India?s finished steel consumption is anticipated to increase to 230 MT by 2030-31 from 90.68 MT in 2017-18 supported by growth in domestic market. Indian steel industry has deep forward and backward linkages with several key segments of the economy, thus the government has formed certain policies for the steel sector. Some of the government initiatives in this sector are as follows:

Metal Scrap Trade Corporation (MSTC) Limited and the Ministry of Steel have jointly launched an e-platform called 'MSTC Metal Mandi' under the 'Digital India' initiative, which will facilitate sale of finished and semi-finished steel products.

The Ministry of Steel is facilitating setting up of an industry driven Steel Research and Technology Mission of India (SRTMI) in association with the public and private sector steel companies to spearhead research and development activities in the iron and steel industry at an initial corpus of INR 200 crore (USD 30 million).
An export duty of 30% has been levied on iron ore (lumps and fines) to ensure supply to domestic steel industry.
The Government of India raised import duty on most steel items twice, each time by 2.5% and imposed measures including anti-dumping and safeguard duties on iron and steel items.

Based on increased capacity addition in anticipation of upcoming demand, and the new steel policy, that has been approved by the Union Cabinet, is expected to boost India's steel production. Huge scope for growth is offered by India?s comparatively low per capita steel consumption and the expected rise in consumption due to increased infrastructure construction and the thriving automobile and railways sectors.

In view of rising imports, the Government had earlier raised import duty on most steel items twice, each time by 2.5% and imposed a gamut of measures including anti-dumping and safeguard duties on a host of applicable iron and steel items. In a further move to curb steel imports, the Indian government banned the production and sale of steel products that do not meet Bureau of Indian Standard (BIS) approval and to check the sale of defective and sub-standard stainless steel products used for making utensils and various kitchen appliances, it issued the Stainless Steel (Quality Control) Order, 2016 for products used in making utensils and kitchen appliances, that will help filter imports of the metal. Again, in February 2016, the Indian Government had imposed the Minimum Import Price (MIP) condition on 173 steel products. The MIP was extended thrice and ceased to be effective in early February 2017. Further, a Steel Price Monitoring Committee has been constituted by the Government with the aim to monitor price rationalization, analyze price fluctuations and advise all concerned regarding any irrational price behavior of steel commodity. These initiatives by the government to curb the steel imports will help the Company improve its business.
Global market dynamics for stainless steel can drive the revenue growth from exports

The global market is largely driven by demand from application segments such as consumer goods, building and construction and heavy industries. Growing infrastructure investments coupled with favorable government policies in emerging economies are likely to fuel demand for stainless steel. Demand for corrosion-resistant material with high tensile strength is projected to positively affect global demand as well.

Growing construction sector in France, Germany and UK is expected to fuel demand for exports while the measures and investment planned in infrastructure within the country is also expected to aid local steel demand. Further, growing demand for consumer products is expected to have a positive impact on market growth. Presence of major manufacturers in this region is also driving the growth of the market in Europe.

USA dominates the North American market. Growth of the construction industry in USA, along with rising application in heavy industries and consumer goods, is expected to have a positive impact on the industry over the coming years.

Asia Pacific is the leading region in terms of manufacturing and consuming stainless steel. Presence of raw materials such as nickel and iron ore is also expected to aid the growth of this regional market. Increasing population, coupled with infrastructure investments, is expected to boost construction and automobile industries in this region, which in turn, is likely to drive the stainless steel industry growth.
Ample opportunity in the stone chips and boulders business with strong scope for infrastructure and real estate development in both India as well as Bangladesh

West Bengal is India?s sixth largest state in terms of economic size. It had a Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP) of USD 158.40 billion in 2017-18. The state?s GSDP grew at a CAGR of 11.88% from 2011-12 to 2017-18. The state has 12 growth centres for medium and large scale industries, set up by the West Bengal Industrial Development Corporation (WBIDC). Major industrial areas of West Bengal are Haldia, Kolkata, Asansol-Durgapur region and Kharagpur. In recent years, the development of infrastructure has been on the forefront in the list of objectives for the state of West Bengal. As of July 2018, West Bengal had 21 SEZs; of which, 7 are operational, 5 are notified, 7 are formally approved and 2 have in-principle approval. Moreover, the State Government has been promoting development of several cities as residential and industrial hubs. Several private investment projects have been identified and are being setup. The residential housing city being setup in Rajarhat and the airport city being developed near Durgapur are a few examples of opportunities in the real estate and infrastructure space within the state. The rapid industrialization and housing development in the state is expected to be a major growth driver for the stone chips and boulder supply industry in the region.

At the same time, Bangladesh is set to be one of the fastest-growing construction markets in Asia. The country's growing infrastructure and urban development needs are gradually being met by rising levels of foreign investment, especially from China. However, the country lacks raw material and logistics as also execution expertise which prompts a huge opportunity for small players in the neighbouring countries.
Commencement of rice mill in January 2019 is likely to augment its scale of operations

The Company has commenced its own rice mill which began operations in January 2019. The capacity utilization of the mill has scaled up only in FY 2020 and the Company expects high utilization leading to notable contribution to total revenue from the segment. Further, the scope for revenue from the segment is expected to further increase once the registration with Food & Supplies Department, Government of West Bengal is complete. After registration, the Company can maintain utilization levels consistently at about 80% of capacity with majority supply to direct customer while the remainder capacity utilization under its Custom Milled Rice scheme. Under this scheme, the State Government will provide paddy to rice mills and will procure the finished rice from the mill. The Government will pay per tonne job work charges for milling of rice and by-products from the milling process can be used/sold by the rice mills. The rice mills business is expected to steadily contribute to the bottom line of the Company in the years to come.

The increasing Government focus on better living and industrial development has led to a boost to the infrastructure and real estate development. Schemes like Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana which promotes housing for all are instrumental in increasing the demand for real estate in the urban as well as in rural India. Further, ?Make in India? is expected to boost infrastructure connectivity thereby directly impacting the demand for stone chips and boulders.

Also, the West Bengal Government?s efforts to develop irrigation through projects like Accelerated Development of Minor Irrigation Projects (ADMIP) is expected to help boost productivity ensuring steady supply of rice paddy. This will reduce dependency on rains and will ensure supply of paddy for maximum capacity utilization of rice mills.

Moreover, continued Government initiatives to support export is expected to further aid the growth in exports for the Company. The same is evident in the benefits availed by the Company due to its 2-star export house status.

Also, these employees will then need training to understand how the business works, hence further increasing development and testing time. Increasing opportunities for the global CNC machines market in the long run

The globalÿCNC marketÿsize is expected to reach USD 100.86 billion by 2025, registering a CAGR of 7.0% from 2019 to 2025. The increasing need for reducing the operating costs, manpower, and errors in the components has led to the growth of automation and CNC machines. Technological advancements are driving the use of CNC machines for developing the most intricate models/components with a definitive finish. This has subsequently led to a rise in the implementation of CNC technology in lathe, milling, laser, grinding, and welding machines. The integration of CNC machines with Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAM) is instrumental in reducing the time required for manufacturing of workpieces and enabling hassle-free production of components.

The commercial demand for advanced compact size CNC machines with automatic tool changers and multi axis machining technology, is on rise. Numerous large manufacturing units and plants are increasingly adopting CNC lathes to perform cutting, drilling, knurling, deformation, facing, and turning operations, among others.

Various milling tools like the Poly Crystalline Diamond (PCD) tools and solid carbide tools are being introduced in the market. These tools offer increased efficiency and versatility while performing operations at the shop floor. The new tools also offer durability, resistance towards high temperatures, and enable better machining with reduction in vibrations, wear, and noise.

Going forward, Milling machines are anticipated to emerge as the fastest growing type segment, expanding at the highest CAGR of 9.7% over the next six years, owing to features such as multi-functionality and reduced time requirements of these machines. Automotive segment is also expected to expand at the CAGR of 9.7% over the next six years, attributed to growing demand to produce components with fine finish in less time.

India stands 12th in production and 8th in the consumption of machine tools in the world as per the 2017 Gardner Business Media survey. The country is set to become a key player in the global machine tools industry and is likely to see substantial high-end machine tool manufacturing with an emphasis on Make in India and manufacturing growth, for which the machine tools sector serves as the mother industry. The government has also introduced the National Policy on Capital Goods 2016 which aims to treble production of capital goods and employment opportunities in the sector further boosting the demand for the sector.

The Indian Machine tool Industry has around 1000 units in the production of machine tools, accessories/attachments, subsystems, and parts. Of these, around 25 in the large-scale sector account for about 70% of the turnover and the rest are in the MSME sector of the industry. ~75% of the Indian machine tool producers are ISO certified. While the large organized players cater to India?s heavy and medium industries, the small-scale sector meets the demand of ancillary and other units. Many machine tool manufacturers have also obtained CE Marking certification, in keeping with the requirements of the European markets.

Wide range of product manufactured could enhance scale of operation

The Company manufactures wide range of cables and has versatile facilities, which can manufacture different types of cable as per the demand. The Company is predominantly an export-oriented unit and is engaged in manufacturing of various sizes & types of cables such as Low Tension Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) & Cross linked Polyethylene (XLPE) Cables, Control Cables and Aerial Bunched Cables. It also manufactures special type of cables like Fire Resistant Low Smoke (FRLS) Sheathing, HR Insulated and Sheathing & Halogen Free Wire and Cable. The promoter has a vast experience in the line of business and a long term relation with the clients. Going forward, wide range of product manufactured would assist in enhancing scale of operation.

The Government has launched projects and policies which promote self-reliance, indigenization, technology upgradation and achieving economies of scale including development of capabilities in the cable manufacturing sector. Initiatives like Bharat Net and NFS have been implemented to ensure nationwide connectivity for all. Flagship projects like Make in India and Smart Cities have been gaining momentum and are driving strong industrial growth. Schemes like Deen Dayal Upadhyay Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) and Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS) have already been implemented for rural and urban areas respectively. Policies like the Electricity Act 2003 which eliminates licensing for electricity generation projects and National Tariff Policy which provides assured electricity to consumers at reasonable and competitive rates have been implemented. Indian Government is confident and has stated that, India has become the world?s fastest growing large economy, and is expected to grow five-fold by 2040, owing to a series of policy measures. This would help the growth in demand for the wire and cable industry.

Further, the Government initiatives to support local manufacturers through ?Preference to Make in India? is expected to further boost revenue visibility for local manufacturers. As per the order, in case the lowest bid for a tender is by a foreign player, only 50% of the tender will be awarded to the player. For the remaining 50% the lowest domestic player will be allowed to match bids with the foreign player. The offer will continue to the next lowest domestic bidder and so on till the entire requirement is fulfilled. This will allow the domestic players to compete on fairer grounds against large foreign players.
The Company would benefit from the healthy growth prospects in the end user industries like power, railways and infrastructure segment.

Power: Despite a generation capacity of more than 330 giga watts (GW), India?s peak load capacity is just about 50% of this capacity highlighting the development in infrastructure required for optimum utilization. Further aggravating this situation is the fact that some of India?s power surplus regions do not have adequate power evacuation infrastructure which could alleviate the recurring supply shortages in other parts of the nation. To solve these issues, the Government is positive in terms of roping in huge investments for developing the transmission and distribution sector in tandem with the power generation segment. The Company is expected to benefit from these investments as it focuses on products catering specifically to long distance power transmission.

Railways: The Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs had approved several projects for expansion of railway network and connectivity across the country. Newer developments are taking place across passenger and freight transport, cross country lines and new railway lines are being deployed with next generation telecom and signaling systems ? across passenger and freight transport, intra-city metro/mono rail. This would propel the demand for the wire and cable industry.

Infrastructure and Real Estate projects: With the introduction of GST, there are signs of revival for long term industrial growth. Real Estate industry is expected to show signs of revival and fall in interest rates would further add on to the growth of affordable housing which would seems to be beneficial for the house wiring sector in the longer term.
These opportunities could help driving scale of operations in medium term.

India and the US have agreed to jointly explore opportunities for collaboration on implementing India's ambitious INR 1.13 trillion (US$ 16.58 billion) ?Digital India Initiative?. The two sides also agreed to hold the US-India Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Working Group in India later this year. ?
Scope to expand in domestic (emerging) and overseas IT market

The group derives a major portion of its revenue from matured geographies like US and Europe (which accounted for around 77% of the topline during FY 2018) and has relatively low presence in emerging markets like Middle East & Africa and Asia-Pacific. However, high economic growth rate of the emerging markets (including the domestic market) has significantly increased the scale of operations of the entities operating within these markets which has resulted in an increase in IT budget of the local organizations to build the next generation IT systems. A significant amount of expenditure proposed to be incurred by the government on IT, to modernize its public distribution systems, and other initiatives like Digital India, 100 smart cities, GST implementation, etc. could serve as another demand driver for the group in the domestic market.

According to NASSCOM estimates, exports of the Indian IT-ITeS industry is expected to reach USD 175 billion by 2020 due to incremental demand expected (despite short term headwinds) from the matured economies like U.S & Europe, owing to local corporations changing the mode of conduct of their operations to remain cost competitive and identify new revenue streams. The domestic market will contribute USD 50 billion revenue by 2020. Therefore, the export and domestic market together are likely to bring in USD 225 billion in revenue with new opportunities emerging across different verticals, such as public sector, manufacturing, defense, utilities, and healthcare, and across different geographies including Brazil, Russia, India, China (BRIC) and Japan. The same would provide an opportunity to the group to leverage its domain competencies and expand its presence in the overseas markets especially emerging geographies like Asia Pacific and Middle East & Africa.

NMACS is the fifth-generation technology stack, consisting of technology forces viz. Networks, Mobility, Analytics, Cloud, Security, Social, and Sensors, which is targeted to build future proof and future ready digital enterprises. These technology forces are often called disruptive technologies owing to them being expected to drastically change the way businesses are done by enterprises, going forward. Building a digital enterprise with real time solutions, predictability, digital & collective intelligence, millennial culture, and high customer engagement would be the need of the hour, and the Company with its domain expertise in the telecom sector, which already has a digital IT & network infrastructure, would be able to increase the revenue from this domain significantly. Currently, about 46% of the revenue is from digital operations, cloud services and data, analytics & AI services.
Launch of 5G is expected to boost the Telecom sector after a downcycle in the industry

Implementation of 5G by mobile service providers would create multiple opportunities for IT service providers not only in the telecom sector, but also bring in deals from user industries viz. automotive, industrial and healthcare sectors. With growing impetus on digitization, the implementation of 5G is expected to be the much-needed boost in infrastructure which will help facilitate digitization on the much bigger scale bringing in a structural shift in industries from hardware to software capital expansion. Given its diverse capabilities, the group is in a strong position to capitalize this opportunity. With implementation of the technology expected by the end of FY 2020, the group?s revenue concentration from the communications segment is expected to increase in the near future.
Addition of products to its portfolio likely to scale up the Group?s operations over the medium term

The Group trades in ferrous and non-ferrous scrap, metallurgical coke, ferro alloys and steel products. It also undertakes manufacturing of structural steel products such as channels, angles and beams. During FY 2018, the Group commenced trading of pig iron considering its increasing demand. Presently, the Group has a portfolio consisting of more than 25 products and has been adding on new products y-o-y basis.
Thus, y-o-y increase in product basket, given the increasing demand, is likely to improve the Group?s business operations through increased top-line and improved profitability levels.
Limited natural resources increasing the demand for recycled metals

Rapidly depleting natural resources and long gestation for discovery of the new ones have called for a thorough recycling of scrap for adequate availability of metal for future generations. Over the next few years the demand for metal is expected to increase due to the expected capital expenditures in various sectors in India.

Over the next 25 years, India will require around US$4.5 trillion for infrastructure development in the country. Investment will be required across all sectors ranging from road, airports, shipping, power, logistics and telecom. Steel consumption for housing construction is also likely to rise due to the ?housing for all? initiative which aims to build around 12 million units in urban areas over next three years.
Economic development / Positive government initiatives in various industries to drive demand for metals

Building & Construction (like Urbanization, Housing for All, PMAY, Rural demand) and Infrastructure projects (like Smart cities, freight corridors, metros, PMKGSY(irrigation), Bharatmala, Sagarmala, etc.) forms more than 50% of the demand of steel in India.

Manufacturing contributes around 16% of the country?s GDP. Over the year, India?s low-cost skilled manpower has attracted a number of manufacturing companies from various industries including petroleum products, machinery and equipment, textiles and leather products. Several companies in these industries have announced expansion plans (including building new manufacturing plants/facilities) to address the growing demand, leading to a higher intake of steel. India?s manufacturing sector could touch US$1 trillion by 2025 increasing the demand for metals in the industry.
Government initiatives to arrest the recent slowdown in the auto sector and support the positive long-term growth prospects

Although the short-term outlook remains a concern, given the slowdown in the automotive sector in the last two quarters, the government of India has taken certain steps to stimulate demand for automobiles. One of the major steps announced included reduction of corporate tax rate from 30% to 22% with the effective tax rate to be 25.17% in Sep 2019.ÿ The government?s move will also help companies to spend more in research and development (R&D) of products and other aspects of the business. Automobile companies exploring opportunities to manufacture in India will have to pay an even lower tax rate of 15%, provided they start their production by 31st March 2023.

To boost research and development activities in India, the minimum alternate tax rate was also reduced from 18.5% to 15% for companies who want to continue availing incentives. These set of major tax reforms are a clear indicator of the government of India?s commitment to improving the business environment to give a definite boost to economic growth. The current reduction of tax rates to globally competitive levels will incentivize OEMs and their vendors to increase localization, which augurs well for the Company and the industry as a whole. Further, given the increasing US-China trade tensions, revision in corporate tax, will attract FDI (foreign direct investment) in Indian manufacturing sector, as the revised tax structure is now in line with other emerging markets.
Expansion of product range and increased capacities on back of South Korean asset acquisition could enhance revenue scale

In FY 2019, the Company acquired the machineries from South Korean company which was disposed off on slump sale basis. The acquired 300 machineries are the special purpose machines which can produce high value-added products like silicon nitrate balls. These balls find application in high technology products like full ceramic bearings, hybrid bearings, aerospace and defence. The product mix is expected to change once the entire machineries become fully operational. Also, the Company would be able to cater to a wider industry base. Moreover, the capacity would increase to 4 to 5 times from the existing level. Increased capacity and production of high value-added products could enhance both scale and margins in the medium to long term.

With the slowdown in world economic growth, the Bearings industry has also suffered a certain impact, but still maintained a relatively optimistic growth. The global ball bearing market size was valued at USD 18.41 billion in FY 2018 and is projected to reach USD 25.73 billion by FY 2026, exhibiting a CAGR of 4.29% during the forecast period (2019-2026). Bearings play an essential role in the machinery and equipment sector. The increasing demand from the various sectors, including machine tools, automotive and evolving advance medical sectors is expected to drive the ball bearing market growth in the near future. Rising demand for the high precision bearing for specific applications is further resulting in the growth of the market. An upsurge in the production of electric motors is the key driving factor for the ball bearing industry. Further, the material advancement such as chrome and plastic based bearings are further contributing to the market potential. The rise in demand for the precision bearing across industries as expected to drive the ball bearing market trend. The chrome steel used in high precision bearing undergoes an additional melting process to produce excellent grain steel. The procedure enhances the bearing in term so hardness, fatigue life, wear resistance and quieter products in comparison to the traditional ones. About 75% of NHB?s revenues is from chrome steel balls. Thus, healthy growth prospects of bearing market would in turn enhance Company?s scale over the medium to long term.

The pharmaceutical industry, at present, is dominated by chemically synthesized APIs for the innovator drugs and chemical based generic APIs for the generic market. However, rising cost of drug development, weak enforcement of patent laws in the under developed markets, stable growth in the demand for drugs and high probability of failure have reduced the pipeline of drugs under development. This has led to an increase in investments towards the development of biotechnology based APIs, both by the global and domestic life science companies, which comprise of recombinant proteins, monoclonal antibodies and vaccines. The trend has now shifted towards Post-translational modification or the chemical modification of these proteins to improve the product stability, obtain a slower or faster action of the product, create new products, increase the biological half-life of protein etc. The generic market has followed the above trends and there has been an increase in investments by the domestic pharma companies towards development of bio-similars (bioequivalent of a biotech based API though not exactly identical), a market which is at present dominated by China. All these developments will further increase the demand for biotech intermediates/ APIs (also called as Knowledge chemicals) serving as a demand driver for the Company.
Increasing demand for speciality chemicals could enhance Company?s scale of revenues

The Indian chemicals sector is a market worth about USD 160 billion, with specialty chemicals representing about 20 per cent of the value. Demand of chemical products is expected to grow at approximately 9% per annum over the next five years (source::www.investindia.gov.in).

The specialty chemicals sector registered double-digit growth over FY13-FY17, supported by subdued oil prices and strong domestic and export demand.ÿFY 2019 is expected to be a strong year for the domestic specialty chemicals sector on anticipation of a continued increase in demand from end-user industries and tight global supply due to stringent environmental norms in China.ÿ

Specialty chemical end-use industries such as textile, automotive, personal care, construction chemicals and agrochemicals, as well as application-driven segments such as surfactants, paints, coatings and colorants, to experience high growth.ÿThe governments focus on affordable housing, agriculture and increased expenditure on infrastructure development will further spur demand for performance-enhancing chemicals. The Company is expected to benefit from the increasing demand for speciality chemicals which could enhance its operation scale.

India is in the midst one of the biggest technological change in the last 15 years. As per NASSCOM, Indian IT vendors would derive about USD 50 billion of their revenues from digital, 23% of the total IT-BPM industry then by 2020. Digitalization is viewed as a route to business model transformation and innovation for building sustainable competitive advantage. Businesses see a need for front-to-back, end-to-end process alignment, which would help them build their digital platforms and their digital operation environments of the future. The higher adoption of digital technologies will enhance its pricing power and will also provide scalability to its business.

According to NASSCOM estimates, the exports revenue of the Indian IT-ITeS industry is expected to reach USD 175 billion by 2020 due to incremental demand expected (despite short term headwinds) from the matured economies like US & Europe, owing to local corporations changing the mode of conduct of their operations to remain cost competitive and identify new revenue streams. The domestic market will contribute USD 50 billion revenue by 2020. Therefore, the export and domestic market together are likely to bring in USD 225 billion in revenue with new opportunities emerging across different verticals, such as public sector, manufacturing, defense, utilities, and healthcare, and across different geographies including Brazil, Russia, India, China (BRIC) and Japan. The same would provide an opportunity to the Company to leverage its domain competencies and expand its presence in the overseas markets especially emerging geographies in Asia Pacific and Middle East & Africa region.

Technology has journeyed from hardware to enterprise software to SMAC (social media, analytics and cloud) and artificial intelligence, while at the same time; it has become an integral part of every industry in an increasingly multi-device connected world. Smart machines, cognitive computing and internet of things are narrowing divide between humans and machines, and creating new applications in a world of cognizant computing where technology will take decisions for humans based on historical data and preferences. Winners in this hyper competitive world are increasingly defined by their ability to go digital i.e., leverage data to the fullest to transform into innovative, responsive, agile, creative and customer focused organization. According to NASSCOM, the nexus of forces (SMAC) will continue to drive change and create new opportunities.

Various services, across complete product lifecycle, ranging from new product development and product advancement to product migration, re-engineering, sustenance and support will be offered by vendors. The services provided will include enterprise transformation services, Independent Testing Services, Enterprise Content Management (ECM) and business intelligence and analytics. Independent Testing Services comprises of testing of new technologies like Social platforms, Mobile, Analytics and Cloud (SMAC).
Opportunities related to business models and military and commercial markets
SDR provides new product and market opportunities, and has the potential of changing the business models in the radio communication industry.

Opportunities in military domain: SDR provides opportunities for having military radio communications equipment which is SW upgradeable and reconfigurable, possibly even field reconfigurable and reconfigurable in space deployment. This represents both benefits for users and a considerable market

opportunity for manufacturers. Since the military domain is characterized by long-lifetime acquisitions, while missions and technical requirements vary at a faster scale, SW upgradability and reconfigurability is very much in demand.

Opportunities in commercial domain: SDR provides an opportunity to switch from conventionally designed cellular base stations to Software Defined Multi-Protocol Multi-Band (MPMB) base stations The reconfiguration possibilities provided by SDR MPMBs accommodate future cellular base station needs, for example:
The trend that new communications standards are put into service in a less mature state than previous standards, implying an increased risk of post-deployment changes needed

The Nextgen DTT Standards and platforms allows broadcasters to open up newer streams of business like interactive services, targeted Geography based advertisements, and emergency alerts through broadband return path.
Favourable growth trends projected in end user Industries

SIL derived majority of its revenue from Pharmaceutical, Chemical and Effluent Treatment Plants, thereby augmenting sales from both glass lined reactors and filter presses and plates. Pharmaceutical and Chemical industry have a positive outlook over the next 5 years as companies continue to invest to increase and upgrade their manufacturing capacities.

The Indian pharmaceutical sector is expected to grow at a CAGR of 15% in the near future till FY 2021, driven by increasing demand in global markets, stable growth in domestic market consumption, low cost manufacturing capability in India and Chinese slowdown in API segment.
India remains an attractive destination for generic R&D and manufacturing of pharmaceutical owing to its strong capabilities across the value chain.
The ?Pharma Vision 2020? by the government?s Department of Pharmaceuticals aims to make India a major hub for end-to-end drug discovery.

The domestic specialty chemical sector is expected to grow by about 10% annually to almost double the market size by FY 2025 (to INR 5864 bn) driven by growth in segments like textile, glass, construction and paints.
Stringent environmental regulations and their enforcement in China, have led to rising labour costs for their companies, thus becoming favourable to Indian players.
India wastewater treatment plants market is projected to grow at a CAGR of over 12% till FY 2021, on account of surging demand for wastewater treatment plants from municipal and industrial sectors.

Stringent government norms issued by Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) to ensure proper management and disposal of sewage is augmenting demand for construction of new sewage treatment plants in the country.

The Government of India through many of its policy reforms has provided a boost for revenue growth. Government of India has allowed 100% foreign direct investment in the Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals sector and the industries remains one of the key focus areas under its ?Make in India? initiatives. Manufacturing hubs have been established to provide the ecosystem for sustainable growth in the industry.

The Government?s focus on affordable housing, agriculture and increased expenditure on infrastructure development will further spur demand for performance-enhancing chemicals. Further, its thrust on pushing infrastructure development, by ensuring increasing funds for core schemes such as ?Smart Cities?, ?Housing for All by 2022?, amongst others, will bolster rapid urbanization and lead to marked improvement in proper waste and water treatment.
Acquisitions and mergers expected to boost Group?s scale of operations

The Group is engaged in manufacturing of APIs and formulations for animal health business to the pharmaceutical companies wherein it provides end to end solutions.
