As a part of its marketing/ strategy, it acquired majority stakes in Karizoo Group, Spain Provet Veterinary Products Limited, Turkey and Interchange Brazil which has helped the Group to expand its reach in European & Latin American markets. It has already acquired majority stake in TopkimIlac Premiks San, Turkey and also acquired animal health division of Lyka Labs Limited in India. Recently, it acquired a German based company Bremer Pharma. With the expanded base of manufacturing facilities (seven in total), the Group expects to drive its revenues in coming years. As apprised by the management, the gestation period for the strategic investment in Vizag in 2014 ended resulting in augmentation of the topline in FY 2019.
USFDA approval of Vizag plant to act as catalyst for robust revenue growth

The Group has recently shifted its entire focus on driving its animal health care business (Alivira). With recent acquisitions, it has changed from API led Group to formulations led Group with 65% of business coming in from formulations. However, the Group in March 2018, received an approval from USFDA for its Vizag plant. This plant manufacturers API for animal health. The Company has wide range of API products, predominantly in Anthelmintics and emerging Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug (NSAID) portfolio. And with largest API filings in the US among all generic companies globally, which puts it in a strong position in the dramatically changing dynamics in the API business. This enable Sequent?s entry into US$ 8 billion the US veterinary healthcare market and being compliant to latest environment, health and safety (EHS) regulations.

From regional perspective, North America is the largest animal healthcare market. This is due to the largest cattle population (both milch and meat cattle), a rising demand for protein rich diet, and rising incidence of animal diseases. Asia-Pacific is the fastest growing market due to factors such as under penetration, rising trend of zoonotics, mandatory government requirement for immunization of animals, and growing trend for keeping companion animals.

Sequent has R&D centre in Vizag and Mumbai, India and Barcelona, Spain. It has 14 products in animal health API and 35 products of formulations under development. According to management, this represents a market opportunity of US$ 500 million +.

Moreover, with already 12 API filings in USA and 10 CEP filings, management expects API business in the short run will be the fastest growing business. It expects to grow anywhere in the region upwards of 20% in the medium-term as it derives benefits of the regulated markets. On the formulation business in the short run will grow anywhere between 12% to 13% on as is basis, which is the organic growth.
Thus, with USFDA approval at Vizag plant and recent filings should boast the revenue of the Group and also increase its margins going ahead.

Animal healthcare market consists of products and services used for animals for the purpose of safe-guarding, preserving, and preventing them from various diseases. It also includes providing necessary veterinary services to enhance their lifespan, quality of life and their yield.

Animal healthcare market is growing rapidly owing to rise in number of veterinary diseases, growing demand for protein rich diet, increase in zoonotic diseases, etc. The global animal healthcare market is expected to reach USD 53 billion by 2025 from USD 32 billion in 2016, by growing at 5.6% CAGR between 2017 to 2025.

The Indian Animal Healthcare market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 8% to reach over USD 1.2 billion by 2024. A major reason for the market growth is country?s extensive animal husbandry practices. Indian livestock population constitute 10% of global livestock population and ranks among the largest producers of cattle, chicken and fish.
Thus, with growing markets for animal healthcare at USA and India, should boost the revenue of the Company.
Sinking groundwater level along with Government initiatives for replacing old agriculture pump-sets

Due to dependence on groundwater for the Indian agricultural sector, despite various government policies, there has been a continuous decrease in water tables thus creating an alarming situation for the agricultural sector. This has posed a major challenge for irrigation for the local agricultural sector thus increasing dependence on the pumps sector. The Government of India through Energy Efficiency Services Limited or EESL (a joint venture of NTPC, Power Finance Corporation, Rural Electrification Corporation and Power Grid Corporation of India, set up under the Union ministry of power; to facilitate the implementation of energy-efficiency projects), the Union Power Ministry has taken up the initiative of accelerating the programme of agriculture demand side management (AgDSM). The ministry has earmarked INR 4,000 million for the project.

Initially, the programme aims to supply nearly 7 million pump sets across Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Rajasthan and Karnataka.ÿ As on May 2018, the Company has bagged an INR 1,500 million order from EESL for implementation of AgDSM program in association with Government of Andhra Pradesh (AP). Government drives for free replacement of agricultural pumps would thereby provide revenue opportunities for the Company. These opportunities ensure clear demand visibility for the Company in the near future.

The Company is engaged in manufacturing and sale of pump-sets with related equipment. It manufactures wide range of pumps submersible pumps and motors, solar pumps, end suction pumps, vertical multistage centrifugal pumps, open well pumps, pressure booster pumps, self-priming pumps, immersible pumps, etc. The Company caters to a diverse customer base which includes agriculture, building services, general water supply, sewage & waste water applications, etc.

The global pump market is estimated to grow at a CAGR of 5% between 2016 and 2020. The steady growth in the global pumps market is attributed to increased investment in water and wastewater recycling plants. The water and wastewater industry is growing due to a rise in population, urbanization, and manufacturing activities.

Industries such as power, pharmaceuticals, and food and beverage are heavily water-reliant and will have a significant impact on the global demand for water. The increase in production of these manufacturing industries makes water conservation and adherence to stringent environmental guidelines paramount. Also, governments of developing countries are investing heavily in the wastewater industry for wastewater treatment, which in turn is benefitting growth of the pump market. Growth in these end user industries would enable the Company to further scale up its operations.
The Government has introduced several schemes which require application of pumps. Some of these initiatives are listed below.

Pradhan Mantri Krishi Sinchai Yojana (PMKSY) ? It was launched on 1st July 2015 with the motto of ?Har Khet Ko Paani? for providing end-to end solutions in irrigation supply chain, viz. water sources, distribution network and farm level applications. PMKSY not only focuses on creating sources for assured irrigation, but also creating protective irrigation by harnessing rain water at micro level through ?Jal Sanchay? and ?Jal Sinchan?. Micro irrigation is to be popularized to ensure ?Per drop-More crop?. PMKSY adopts State level planning and project-wise execution that allows States to draw up their own irrigation development based on District Irrigation Plans and State Irrigation Plans.

KUSUM - The Union Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) has issued operational guidelines for the implementation of Pradhan MantriÿKisan Urja Suraksha evam Utthaan Mahabhiyanÿ(PM Kusum) Scheme on July 22, 2019. The scheme aims to provide energy security along with financial and water security to farmers. It targets to add decentralised solar power capacity of 25,750 megawatt (MW) by 2022. The approved scheme comprises three components:
Setting up of 10,000 MW of decentralised ground / stilt-mounted grid-connected solarÿor other renewable energy-based power plants
Installation of 175 million standalone solar agriculture pumps
Solarisation of 1 million grid-connected solar agriculture pumps.

The Centre will provide financial support of INR 344,220 million. Full-fledged implementation of components A and C is subject to the successful implementation of pilot projects. Under components B and C, central financial assistance of 30% of the benchmark cost or the tender cost (whichever is lower) of the standalone solar agriculture pump will be provided.
The respective state governments will subsidise another 30%, while the remaining 40% will have to be borne by the farmer. ÿ
These plans pose several growth opportunities for the Company in the near future.
Favourable Government policies & initiatives to give a boost to the auto-component industry

Indian automotive industry has deep forward and backward linkages with several key segments of the economy. Likewise, global automobile manufacturers see India as a manufacturing hub for auto components and are rapidly increasing the value of components they source from India due to India's cost competitiveness in terms of labour and raw material and its established manufacturing base.

For instance, the transition to new safety and BS VI norms is expected to increase content per vehicle to support new emission and safety requirements which will offset any likely demand fall faced by domestic auto component makers from OEMs side. Additionally, investment in capacity creation for emission and safety related products, powertrain electrification and localization will push the revenue upward. Further, the gap in regulations between India and developed markets, particularly on emissions but also in terms of safety standards, has been steadily narrowing. This creates several more opportunities for components to be exported to the developed markets.

Also, the ?Make in India? program has propelled many OEMs to set-up manufacturing base in India and include Indian manufacturers as their key partner in their global supply chain. For instance, the Indian automotive aftermarket size, estimated at INR 70,000 crore in FY 2019 is projected to grow at a CAGR of 8.5% for the next few years and register INR 98,000 crore by FY 2023.

Further, the industry anticipates a scrapping policy which would boost auto industry (especially the CV segment) turnover to INR 20 trillion. Under the proposed scrapping policy, people would get an incentive of up to INR 30,000 for discarding small vehicles like cars, while total benefits after taking into account the tax exemptions could be up to INR 1.5 lakh for big vehicles like trucks. This would augment the revenue of the companies operating in the auto component space.

Moreover, as per the ?Automotive Mission Plan 2026? of Ministry of Heavy Industries & Public Enterprises Government of India, India will be a global automotive hub for designing and manufacture of automobiles and auto components. With the advent of various overseas automobile manufacturers setting up their manufacturing units in India, the Company may seek an opportunity to explore new customers.
Collaboration through JVs towards new technologies in the automotive segment

There is rapid change in the automotive industry with a new emerging shared economy, faster changes and disruptions in mobility, and a higher shift towards services. With a shift in customer preferences, there is an increased number of new entrants into the market bringing in disruptive trends ? electrification, autonomous driving and connectivity. The rise in emerging markets, the proliferation of innovative technologies, sustainability policies, and changing consumer preferences are impacting industries globally without exception.ÿLot of these changes have been adopted through collaborations with foreign players. The automotive industry is likely to change more rapidly over the next 6-10 years than it has over the past decade. The industry has been facing a discontinuity in the nature of mobility, and the products and services needed to satisfy the emerging customer preferences.SMIL has recently entered in to a JV with Eberspaecher Exhaust Technology International, Germany to comply with BS-VI norms in the future.
COMPANY RELATED OPPORTUNITY WILL BE UPDATED POST MD
Increasing demand and high opportunities in the export market

Indian packaging industry will see notable growth over 2016-2021, growing at a CAGR of 9.2% as compared to 6.2% during 2011-2016. The growth of the Indian packaging industry will be heavily influenced by changing demographics such as growing urbanization and the rising proportion of middle class consumers. These changes drive the need for new packaging formats, such as different sizes, materials, and strength. The Indianÿpackagingÿindustry constitutes about 4 percent of the globalÿpackagingÿindustry. The per capitaÿpackagingÿconsumption in India is quite low at 4.3 kgs, compared to countries like Germany and Taiwan where it is 42 kgs and 19 kgs respectively. However, organized retail and boom in e-commerce, which offer huge potential for future growth of retailing, is giving a boost to theÿpackagingÿsector. Theÿpackagingÿindustry in India is expected to reach $ 73 billion in 2020 from $ 32 billion in FY 15, according to a report prepared byÿFICCIÿandÿTata Strategic ManagementÿGroup (TSMG) on plastic industry. In the coming years, Indianÿpackagingÿindustry is anticipated to register 18 percent annual growth rate, with the flexibleÿpackagingÿand rigidÿpackagingÿexpected to grow annually at 25 percent and 15 percent, respectively. Thus, the expected growth in the sector can help the Company augment its revenues
Increasing regulatory approvals resulting in higher demand for the Company?s services

The Company is engaged in providing drug development solutions to the global healthcare industry. The Company provides various services which include clinical operations, clinical data management, medical and scientific writing, biostatistics and statistical programming, providing clinical trial supplies and pharmacovigilance services. The manufacturing facilities of pharmaceutical companies need to be regularly monitored and approved by various regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities are becoming more and more vigilant and strict which could result in an increase in demand for the Company?s services.
Expiry of Patents in next 10 years may give a boost to the research industry

About 120 drugs are expected to go off-patent over the next 10 years; with expected worldwide revenue between US$ 80 to 250 billion. It is imperative that these firms have a pipeline of drugs in place by expiry of existing blockbuster drug patents so as to maintain their growth path. To create a healthy drug pipeline, pharmaceutical companies have to increase their R&D expenditure to invest in clinical trials required to develop new drugs. With the overall clinical trial and research study cost in India being 60% lower than those performed in the US and European markets, the country has become a preferred choice for global pharma majors. Hence, this may result into an increase in demand for the Company?s services.
Some of the major initiatives taken by the government to promote IT and ITeS sector in India are as follows:

The government has identified Information Technology as one of 12 champion service sectors for which an action plan is being developed. Also, the government has set up a Rs 5,000 crore (US$ 745.82 million) fund for realising the potential of these champion service sectors.

As a part of Union Budget 2018-19, NITI Aayog is going to set up a national level programme that will enable efforts in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and will help in leveraging AI technology for development works in the country.
In the Interim Budget 2019-20, the Government of India announced plans to launch a national programme on AI and setting up of a National AI portal.
National Policy on Software Products-2019 was passed by the Union Cabinet to develop India as a software product nation.

India is the leading sourcing destination across the world, accounting for approximately 55% market share of the US$ 185-190 billion global services sourcing business in 2017-18. Indian IT & ITeS companies have set up over 1,000 global delivery centres in about 80 countries across the world. India has become the digital capabilities hub of the world with around 75 per cent of global digital talent present in the country. India?s IT & ITeS industry grew to US$ 181 billion in 2018-19. Exports from the industry increased to US$ 137 billion in FY19 while domestic revenues (including hardware) advanced to US$ 44 billion. Revenue from digital segment is expected to comprise 38 per cent of the forecasted US$ 350 billion industry revenue by 2025. India is the topmost offshoring destination for IT companies across the world. Having proven its capabilities in delivering both on-shore and off-shore services to global clients, emerging technologies now offer an entire new gamut of opportunities for top IT firms in India. Export revenue of the industry is expected to grow 7-9 per cent year-on-year to US$ 135-137 billion in FY19. The industry is expected to grow to US$ 350 billion by 2025.

The group derives a major portion of its IT revenue from matured geographies like USA (57% of the total revenue in FY 2019) and has relatively low presence in emerging markets like Middle East & Africa and Asia-Pacific. However, high economic growth rate of the emerging markets (including the domestic market) has significantly increased the scale of operations of the entities operating within these markets which has resulted in an increase in IT budget of the local organizations to build the next generation IT systems. A significant amount of expenditure proposed to be incurred by the government on IT, to modernize its public distribution systems, and other initiatives like Digital India, 100 smart cities, GST implementation, etc. could serve as another demand driver for the group in the domestic market.

Greater use of digital technologies has been seen in recent times in companies across sector. It has become a core part of many operations in order to compete with new emerging competitors and are simultaneously transforming their businesses by leveraging new technologies to create new business models. The need of the hour is seen as agility and flexibility for various CIO?s across organizations. The platform based business models and strategies are the driving force behind many of today?s large organizations. The building blocks for digital and platform companies are Cloud services, API strategy and architecture, mobile development platforms among others. The Group had built its strength in terms of customers, people, technologies, processes, alliances and IP which helps it to garner additional customers looking for solutions on digital transformation. The Group has progressed well with its proprietary model of achieving digital transformation called Platformation? that it announced as seen from increase in number of customers during the review period.
Increase in Engineering and R&D spends leading to increased offshoring to India

Global ER&D spends have witnessed a robust CAGR of 7% since 2009, as companies pursue innovation to re-engineer their products as per customer requirements along with latest technology. With rising digital adoption, the role of ER&D will rise in introducing new products or penetrating deeper into existing geographies. Digitization and user experience have been the central themes of today?s software services. Several traditional OEMs are now re-branding themselves as technology firms. Platform-as-a-service, products-as-a-service and Big Data analytics are the new revenue drivers. Investments are made on labs and design centres to enable creation of innovative solutions, establish strong IoT ecosystems as well as new segments of Cloud computing. India continues to maintain its leadership in the offshore destinations in delivering engineering R&D services with a market share of 22%. The country has become a key contributor in global research and of growth in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, playing host to one-third of top 1,000 R&D spenders globally. Thus, based on these developments the Group will be beneficiary of these increase in spends, thus allowing it to garner more customers.
Enormous growth potential in the organic farming exports

With an increase in lifestyles related illnesses, especially amongst the developed nations, there is a greater inclination towards healthy-eating, and consumption of unprocessed and organic whole foods. In this regard, organic farming is fast emerging as a breakthrough technique, involving cultivation of plants and rearing of animals in natural ways. Employing innovative use of biological materials, this technique precludes synthetic substances and maintains soil fertility and ecological balance, thereby minimizing pollution and wastage. It is reliant upon ecologically balanced agricultural principles like crop rotation, use of green manure, appropriate processing of organic waste, methods of biological pest control and the prudent use of mineral and rock additives, among others. exponential increase in population worldwide, more so in developing nations places high demand of food production. Organic farming show signs of sustainable cultivation and thus is the reliable solution to this need.

The government has played a key role in promoting organic farming by undertaking various schemes and granting number of benefits and subsidies like National Project on Organic Farming, Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojna, etc. The governing associations are creating awareness amongst the producers as well as consumers of benefits from organic cultivation over the conventional cultivation. As informed, currently, of the total organic produce globally, less than 1% is exported from India, thus has enormous growth potential.
Favourable global market scenarios conducive for growth in local as well as overseas markets

The tile industry in India has benefited significantly because of the levy of anti-dumping duty on imports from China. China, the world?s largest manufacturer of ceramic tiles, has a unique advantage; access to cheaper mode of transport (through sea) to southern India. Chinese imports accounted for around 80% followed by Italy, Spain and UAE, to the total imports by India in FY17. The Government of India observed that the ceramic tiles that were exported to India were below normal value and the Indian tile industry has been impacted on account of this dumping from China. Consequently, the Government of India imposed an anti-dumping duty on soluble salt double charge, GVT and PVT, porcelain and vitrified tile from China, for 5 years from March 2016.

This levy of anti-dumping duty on imports from China has been imposed by a large number of countries, to curb the impact of dumping by Chinese manufacturers, regions like, the European Union (EU), Brazil, Taiwan, Chile, Vietnam and Korea imposed anti-dumping duty on the import of ceramic tiles from China. EU, in November 2017, extended the anti-dumping duty imposition for another period of 5 years. This opportunity was tapped by the Indian tile industry which emerged as the fourth largest exporter of ceramic tile in CY17 as compared to eleventh in CY13. The Company?s strategy to increase the export market in the upcoming years with special thrust from its dealers is in the right movement with the industry trend. The Company was also the largest exporter from the Morbi cluster of tile industry in India.
Favourable demographic profile backed by increase in disposable income and Increasing urbanization

India is expected to be the most populous country by 2022, with a majority of the population in the working age group. India is also expected to be one of the fastest growing economies in the next decade. The rising disposable income levels among the working class, increasing trend of nuclear families and increasing demand for aesthetic flooring are expected to augur well for the ICTI.

According to the Indian Census data, 2011, around 31% of the country?s population are urban dwellers rising from the 28% in the 2001 census data. The rapid movement of population from towns/villages to cities for jobs/livelihood along with a growth in income is expected to create more demand for housing as well as discretionary urban products (value-added ceramic tiles). The urbanization rate is envisaged to increase further during the next decade resulting in higher demand for housing units and discretionary products from Tier-II and Tier-III cities. The overall change in the demographic movement is very much conducive for the growth of the domestic growth of the Company; the Company?s business relationship with local infrastructure companies and dealers will play a major part in this.
Revision in tax rates under Goods & Service Tax (GST)

Ceramic tiles were taxed at the highest rate of 28% under GST until October 2017. However, with revision in the GST rates, from 28% to 18% in November 2017, the indirect tax rate is largely in line with the rates prevalent during the earlier tax structure. GST has created a level playing field as a nationwide levy restricting impact of the unorganized sector which comprises 50% of the Indian tiles industry.
Relaxation in norms for the gas sale agreement by Gujarat Gas Limited (GGL)

Morbi is the highest contributor for industrial sales of GGL. The ceramic cluster contributes more than 55% of total industrial sales of GGL and the later has almost 100% market share in the cluster. However, on account of poor implementation of the pollution control norms, gasification plants are still operational and it remains a major source of fuel supply. To increase the penetration of gas, GGL has relaxed norms for gas supply agreements w.e.f. November 01, 2018.
Positive outlook for the infrastructure sector augurs well for the Company

Infrastructure sector in India is expected to reach USD 1 trillion by 2030, it will contribute 13 percent of the country?s Gross domestic product (GDP) by 2025. Increasing share of the infrastructure sector in the GDP would be supported by increasing industrial activity, improving income level and urbanization. Construction is the fourth largest sector in terms of Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows, it stood at USD 38.92 billion from April 2000 to December 2018. Significant increase in infrastructure activity in cities like Indore, Raipur, Ahmedabad, Jaipur and other 2-tier cities has opened new avenues of growth for the sector. Relaxation in the FDI norms for the real estate sector has boosted the real estate sector. Commercial office stock in India is estimated to be around 600 million square feet as of December 2018. New completion of office space is expected to increase by 15 percent and cross 43.6 million square feet by December 2019. Office space leasing in the top eight cities is expected to cross 100 million square feet between 2018-20. Growing impetus in co-working space with change in operating model from sales to a lease and maintenance structure. The increased demand for commercial spaces is driven by rapid growth in services sectors like Information Technology / Information Technology Enabled Services, Banking Financial Services & Insurance and Telecom coupled with rising demand from multinational corporations (MNCs) for office spaces in Tier 2 cities. Further warehousing space in the top eight Indian cities increased 22 percent y-o-y in 2018 to 169 million square feet; further, investments of INR 50,000 crore (US$ 7.76 billion) are expected in India?s warehousing between 2018-20. The overall growth prospect for real estate is expected to augment the revenue of the Company going forward.
Government initiatives to provide thrust for the infrastructure sector.

The government?s thrust on pushing infrastructure development continues by ensuring increasing funds for core schemes such as ?Smart Cities?. It has also brought down (GST rate to 5 percent in the sector. Stock Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has approved Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) which has led to greater transparency. With REITs institutional investors are now looking at Indian real estate with renewed interest for both commercial and industrial infrastructure sectors. In March 2019, Embassy Office Parks India?s first REIT went public. Further, the benefits from the ordinance passed for the amendment of Land Acquisition Bill is reaping benefits for improved development in the industrial corridor. All these initiatives have made the growth prospect in the infrastructure segment positive in the medium and long term.

Increased impetus to develop infrastructure in the country is attracting both domestic and international players. Private sector is emerging as a key player across various infrastructure segments, ranging from roads and communications to power and airports. In order to boost the construction of buildings in the country, the Government of India has decided to come up with a single window clearance facility to accord speedy approval of construction projects. In 2018, India was ranked 44th out of 167 countries in World Bank's Logistics Performance Index (LPI) 2018. India was also ranked second in the 2018 Agility Emerging Markets Logistics Index. India is expected to become the third largest construction market globally by 2022. India has a requirement of investment worth INR 50 trillion (US$ 777.73 billion) in infrastructure by 2022 to have sustainable development in the country. The infrastructure sector has become the biggest focus area of the Government of India. Under Union Budget 2019-20, US$ 63.20 billion was allocated to the sector.

According to Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), Construction Development sector and Infrastructure Activities sector received FDI inflows amounting to US$ 24.90 billion and US$ 24.91 billion, respectively from April 2000 to December 2018. Thus, positive growth prospects of the sector are is expected to benefit the Company in terms of increasing scale.

As informed, the Company has started executing EPC industrial projects on turnkey basis from FY 2018. It has so far executed INR 200 crore of EPC orders in the last two years ending FY 2019. The Company expects the EPC to civil works to be in the equal proportion by FY 2020. Widening of scope of work will place Company in a better position to win new orders which will support the revenue growth in the medium term.
Upcoming product development will help boost the topline of the Company

The Company undertook capital expenditure of INR 25 crores in FY 2019 towards the debottlenecking operations, increase in capacity and a new clean room area. The expenditure was fully funded through the internal accruals.

As informed by the management, the Company is developing newer APIs within steroids segment. Within lateral integration plans, the Company has definite plans to launch sex hormones from new dedicated hormones manufacturing block. The Company believes that the future of steroids, at least in injectables and inhalers, lies in in-process aseptic filtration solution in micronized form. For the same, the Company has carried out single step process of aseptic spray drying while simultaneously working on alternate two step processes.

As informed, it filed 1 DMF in March 2019 and another one will be filed in coming quarter. Formulations plant at USA is expected to start output soon with first batch coming out in Feb 2020. Construction of an injectables plant at Indore is expected to start in Jan 2020. About US 10 Mn will be invested by PE investors.
With these upcoming plans, the Company is expected to increase its topline over the near to medium term.

The pharmaceutical sector was valued at US$ 33 billion in 2017. The country?s pharmaceutical industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 22.4% over 2015?20 to reach US$ 55 billion. India?s pharmaceutical exports stood at US$ 17.27 billion in FY18 and have reached US$ 15.52 billion in FY 2019 (up to January 2019). Pharmaceutical exports include bulk drugs, intermediates, drug formulations, biologicals, ayush & herbal products and surgicals. India?s domestic pharmaceutical market turnover reached Rs 129,015 crore (US$ 18.12 billion) in 2018, growing 9.4% year-on-year (in Rs) from Rs 116,389 crore (US$ 17.87 billion) in 2017. Medicine spending in India is projected to grow 9-12% over the next five years, leading India to become one of the top 10 countries in terms of medicine spending.

Going forward, better growth in domestic sales would also depend on the ability of companies to align their product portfolio towards chronic therapies for diseases such as cardiovascular, anti-diabetes, anti-depressants and anti-cancers that are on the rise. The Indian government has taken many steps to reduce costs and bring down healthcare expenses. Speedy introduction of generic drugs into the market has remained in focus and is expected to benefit the Indian pharmaceutical companies. In addition, the thrust on rural health programs, lifesaving drugs, and preventive vaccines also augurs well for the pharmaceutical companies.

There has been a rise in demand for formulations in the semi-regulated markets of South East Asia & Africa due to a rise in population, increasing health consciousness, increase in lifestyle related diseases, increase in government spending towards health development programs, and improving health infrastructure. The Company can take advantage of this rising demand to boost its top line as well as the bottom line.
Government impetus on the infrastructure and construction segment

The National Steel Policy 2017 and Domestically Manufactured Iron & Steel Products Policy 2017 has led to huge growth in both production and consumption of steel. The per capita consumption has risen from 59 kgs in 2013-14 to 69 kgs in 2017-18.ÿFlagship programmes like 100 Smart Cities Mission, Housing for all Mission, Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation and high-speed bullet trains and metro trains continue to remain contribute in increasing steel demand in our country.

Increasing expenditure by the government in infrastructure projects such as roads, bridges, tunnels, ports, water and gas pipeline is likely to keep the steel demand and production in check. The momentum of government spending to be continued by the new government and steel demand should continue growing at 7-7.5%in FY 2020, highest globally. The Union Budget 2019-20 will give a push to big-ticket infrastructure projects and thereby increase the demand for steel. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a slew of steps in the union budget to scale up the country?s infrastructure, including augmenting 1,25,000 km of rural roads under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) at a cost of INR 80,250 crore and creating a national highways grid. Clear emphasis has been laid on the infrastructure development along with a massive push to every connectivity avenue including industrial corridors, dedicated freight corridors, Bharatmala, Sagarmala, UDAN, and PMGS. The Company is operating at an optimum level of capacity in its melting plant and plans to increase its capacity gradually going ahead to cater increasing domestic SS demand in the country.
Global steel demand to support the Company?s export initiatives

The global stainless steel market size was valued at USD 93.69 billion in 2018 and is expected to witness a CAGR of 5.2% from 2019 to 2025. Rising demand from end-use industries such as automotive, oil and gas, and construction is anticipated to propel the growth. Moreover, increasing investments in R&D for steel manufacturing is projected to contribute to the growth. Stainless steel caters to demand from various application segments such as building and construction, heavy industries, consumer goods, & others. Owing to high resistance to corrosion, stainless steel can be easily fabricated in building structures. Along with aesthetic purpose, it provides strength and support to various building structures. It is used in roofing, structures, fixings, drainage and water systems, handrails, and wall support products. Rising investment in this sector and number of construction activities are creating a high demand for stainless steel products. Moreover, globally the growth is shifting from traditional consumers of stainless steel (consumer goods, architecture, construction, etc.) to now extensive use of stainless steel by auto, railway, transportation, building and construction sector.
The Company?s focus on exports is increasing. It exported roughly INR 67 crore of wire rods in FY 2019 and plans to increase it to over INR 100 crore in FY 2020.

The telecom industry has seen a widespread growth over the last few years with the fact that the world is undergoing a digital revolution by being connected digitally, wherein, video, cloud, big data and IoT are gaining prominence with the incremental access and reach of internet. Machine-to-Machine (M2M) and The Internet of Things (IoT) is the fastest growing area of connectivity with devicesÿfrom cars to vending machines, security systems to health care. A Communications Service Provider (CSP) competing in this space requires an M2M ? IoT platform that provides real-time billing, SIM provisioning and multi-IMSI profile management.ÿ With high transaction rates and critical service delivery requirements CSPs must focus on selecting an M2M ? IoT platform that is scalable, reliable and highly extensible. The Indian Government is planning to develop 100 smart city projects, where IoT would play a vital role in development of those cities.
With the group?s focus on growth in the data service business through product penetration for around 1,000 customers, the scale of operations is likely to improve over the medium term.
Increasing demand from enterprise segment could enhance revenues

On the enterprise front, the growth in business services, including BFSI, IT-BPM, retail, and hospitality, have created the demand for a strong communication infrastructure. The demand for high speed connectivity, data centers, cloud solutions, cyber security services and other related infrastructure have all gone up. The growth in the retail segment is also driven by the Government?s initiative to enable connectivity reach to every parts of the country by virtue of significant reduction in the tariff rates, introduction of affordable mobile phones, growing demand for instant communication, and rising consumption of data playing a vital role in the penetration of data services among EWS. Presently, the group has around 5,000 enterprise customers in its portfolio. The shift in the demographic composition of the country has also changed the data consumption pattern of the country which has thereby led to increase in the overall monthly data usage per smartphone in India and stood at ~9.8GB per user in FY 2019 and it is expected to increase to18GB by 2024. The number of internet subscribers in the country is expected to double by 2021 to 829 million and overall IP traffic is expected to grow 4-fold at a CAGR of 30% by 2021.

The rollout of 5G technologies is expected to create significant business opportunities due to increased data consumption. The group has recently entered into partnership with Syniverse (provides technology and business services for telecommunication companies) to create fully-managed end-to-end IPX network interconnection. The partnership is backed by their network enterprise and platforms that support 5G and IoT, thus creating a comprehensive and reliable foundation for mobility services worldwide. This would help its customers to leverage next generation IoT and mobility services as they would be able to capture, move and manage information seamlessly and securely worldwide. The reliable, high performance and secure IPX networks will connect mobile operators and vertical industries together which would help in driving efficiencies and productivity.
Development of capabilities through mergers & acquisitions and innovation

The Group has acquired over 7 companies in the past three years. In FY 2015, the Company strengthened its competencies with the merger of Mahindra Engineering Services and acquisitions of LCC, Sofgen and BASF IT. MES merger has helped it strengthen its engineering design services portfolio while LCC acquisition has increased the Group?s exposure to network engineering services. Sofgen acquisition was to enhance its core banking systems (build, run, operate) capabilities and BASF IT has its strengths in application and infrastructure business services. The Group has presence in about 90 countries, with low exposure to the Indian IT business due to lower realizations. Besides, acquisition of LCC has given it access to Latin American and North African markets. Further in FY 2016, it acquired Pininfarina SPA, an Italian design Company which will complement the existing engineering capability of the Group with high end styling and engineering services. Further, in FY 2017, it purchased Bio Agency, a digital company in the UK and Target Group, also from the UK, to boost automation in the lending, investment and insurance segments. Its latest purchase was in March 2017-the HCI Group which is expected to strengthen its position in healthcare service provider space and give access to marquee customers and healthcare consultants. The acquisition of CJS Solutions has augured well with contribution in the revenue growth in FY 2018. Further, acquisition of Altiostar is also expected to improve the topline in FY2019. Also, investment in Dynacommerce and K-Vision are expected to obtain additional opportunities in the communications market in the near future.

As informed, Tech Mahindra will identify the ?niche? capabilities that it would offer to clients across various verticals and would develop the same either organically (through retention of profits for innovation) or inorganically (through M&A). The same, going forward, would serve as a demand driver for the Group entity. M&A enables the Group to fill up gaps in its portfolio of competency/services, verticals and client/geography access.

NMACS is the fifth-generation technology stack, consisting of technology forces viz. Networks, Mobility, Analytics, Cloud, Security, Social, and Sensors, which is targeted to build future proof and future ready digital enterprises. These technology forces are often called disruptive technologies owing to them being expected to drastically change the way businesses are done by enterprises, going forward. Building a digital enterprise with real time solutions, predictability, digital & collective intelligence, millennial culture, and high customer engagement would be the need of the hour, and the Group with its domain expertise in the telecom sector, which already has a digital IT & network infrastructure, would be able to increase the revenue from this domain significantly. Currently, about 26% of the revenues is from digital.

According to NASSCOM estimates, the exports revenue of the Indian IT-ITeS industry is expected to reach USD 175 billion by 2020 due to incremental demand expected (despite short term headwinds) from the matured economies like U.S & Europe, owing to local corporations changing the mode of conduct of their operations to remain cost competitive and identify new revenue streams. The domestic market will contribute USD 50 billion revenue by 2020. Therefore, the export and domestic market together are likely to bring in USD 225 billion in revenue with new opportunities emerging across different verticals, such as public sector, manufacturing, defense, utilities, and healthcare, and across different geographies including Brazil, Russia, India, China (BRIC) and Japan. The same would provide an opportunity to Group to leverage its domain expertise competencies and expand its presence in the overseas markets especially emerging geographies in the Asia Pacific and Middle East & Africa.
Expected launch of 5G is expected to boost the Telecom sector after a downcycle in the industry

Implementation of 5G by mobile service providers would create multiple opportunities for IT service providers not only in the telecom sector, but also bring in deals from automotive, industrial and healthcare sectors. With growing impetus on digitization, the implementation of 5G is expected to be the much-needed boost in infrastructure which will help facilitate digitization on the much bigger scale bringing in a structural shift in industries from hardware to software capital expansion. Given its diverse capabilities, the Group is in a strong position to capitalize this opportunity. With implementation of the technology expected by the end of FY 2020, the Group?s revenue concentration from the communications segment is expected to increase in the near future.
Increasing demand for specialty chemicals could enhance Company?s scale of revenues

The Indian chemicals sector is a market worth about USD 160 billion, with specialty chemicals representing ~20%of the value. Demand of chemical products is expected to grow at approximately 9% per annum over the next five years.

The specialty chemicals sector registered double-digit growth over FY 2013-FY 2017, supported by subdued oil prices and strong domestic and export demand. Future years are expected to be a strong for the domestic specialty chemicals sector on anticipation of a continued increase in demand from end-user industries and tight global supply due to stringent environmental norms in China.

Speciality chemical end-use industries such as textile, automotive, personal care, construction chemicals and agrochemicals, as well as application-driven segments such as surfactants, paints, coatings and colorants, to experience high growth. The governments focus on affordable housing, agriculture and increased expenditure on infrastructure development will further spur demand for performance-enhancing chemicals. The Company is expected to benefit from the increasing demand for speciality chemicals which could enhance its scale of operation.

India's chemical sector is expected to double its size at USD 300 billion by 2025, clocking an annual growth rate of 8-10%. The sub-sectors like specialty chemicals and agro-chemicals are growing at a higher pace. Cumulative FDI in the industry from April 2000 to June 2017 stood at USD 13.97 billion and the export of chemicals stood at USD 12.15 billion during the year 2016-17.

Department of Chemicals and Petrochemicals is now focusing all its efforts to achieve the objective of making the Indian chemical industry a USD 300 billion industry by 2025. The industry is also targeting chemical exports of USD 18 billion by 2020. The department has announced that a draft chemical policy was being worked out such that it would aim at increasing the demand for these chemicals in the domestic market and at the same time reduce dependency on the imports. This means that the department will focus on increasing the capacity of the industry to meet the internal needs. The industry is also targeting chemical exports of USD 18 billion by 2020 from USD 12 billion in FY 2017. The government policy of Make in India also substantiates the government policies further with attempts to completely backward integrate the industry thereby trying to reduce the import reliance of the industry.
Strategically located manufacturing units expected to improve operating efficiencies

The Company has shifted its boron manufacturing unit from Ambernath to Dahej which is multi-purpose facility for manufacturing boron products as well as commodity and speciality chemicals. Setting up unit at Dahej, known as a chemical hub with large numbers of small and medium sized players will help the Company in sourcing its raw materials with ease along with catering to the demand of customers based in vicinity. Around 85% of the raw materials which mainly include sulphur, benzene, ethanol, borax and others are sourced domestically and majorly from Gujarat.

Since majority of the suppliers are based in the vicinity of the Dahej unit of DMCC, it is expected to aid in availability of raw materials leading to uninterrupted production and reduction in the logistics costs. Further, as informed, the Company has plans to setup a new sulfuric acid plant, new multipurpose plant for various speciality products, and expansion of benzene sulfonyl chloride capacity. With expansion planned at the Dahej facility, the Company is expected to have certain control over the raw material costs and is expected to improve its operational efficiencies.

The growth in power consumption across the world outpaces the population growth. In FY 2018, the growth in power consumed when compared to previous year stood at ~3.5% when compared to the estimated population growth of ~1.07% during the same year. This growth is a result of technological advancement on the back of increased power consumption seen across the globe. Increasing electrification and industrialization in developing and under developed countries present a huge opportunity for companies like Thermax which present energy solutions and products. Further, globalization has led to increasing cost competitiveness making production efficiency a necessity for manufacturing units. The Group offers various solutions to improve manufacturing processes through increased efficiency. Further, the Group already has presence in more than 86 countries which presents it with a unique opportunity to capitalize on the emerging requirements in these regions.
Increasing emphasis on application of environmental safety measures

The growing awareness with regards to the impact of increasing pollution and exploitation of environmental resources presents an opportunity to environment segment of the group. The group provides environmentally friendly solutions to improve productivity and efficiency to its customers. It currently offers products and services under the air pollution and water & waste management heads. The air pollution control division offers solutions ranging from gas cleaning plants to vent filters, from pulverized coal injection systems to cast house de-dusting systems offering tailor made solutions to meet the customer requirements. Further, the group?s Water & Waste solutions provides end-to-end solutions in water treatment, wastewater treatment, effluent recycle and zero liquid discharge solutions to global customers, consultants and OEMs. The solutions find application in industries, commercial, hospitality, defence establishments and the rural & urban sector. These systems are provided on both turnkey/EPC for large capacities and a standardized product range for smaller capacities allowing the group opportunity to capitalize on both big and small market opportunities.

The per capita consumption of electricity increased from 818 kWh in FY 2011 to 1,122 kWh in FY 2017 on the back of increased industrialization and electrification of rural India. This is expected to grow further with GoI focus on electrification, last mile connectivity, reliability of supply and electrification for transport. In order to realize these objectives, GoI has implemented various schemes like Deendayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojanaÿ(DDUGJY), Pradhan Mantri Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana - Saubhagya, Ujwal DISSCOM Assurance Yojana (UDAY), Integrated Power Development Scheme (IPDS), etc. to ensure power connectivity across the country.

Further, GoI is currently implementing the world?s largest renewable energy expansion programme with plans to achieve 175 GW of power generation through renewable sources till 2022. Further, emphasis is being laid on solar generation at individual level through implementation of programmes like Pradhan MantriÿKisan Urja Suraksha evam Utthaan Mahabhiyanÿ(Kusum) which promotes implementation of solar pumps by farmers. Focus has also increased on other sources of renewable power like wind energy. The emphasis has been on implementation of renewable energy to ensure steady supply at low cost. Implementation of these schemes provides added opportunities for growth as well as backward/forward integration for the group.
Wide industry applications and geographical reach present lucrative opportunities for growth

The group caters to diverse industries including power, steel, cement, FMCG, food processing, tyre, sugar, chemical, pharma, textile, oil & gas, water treatment, paper, construction, etc. offering both products and services to enhance productivity and efficiency. A slowdown in one industry may therefore be countered by the group by focusing on other industries. This reduces the group?s exposure to a single industry. The diverse end industry applications thus allow the group to diversify its industry related risk and seek opportunities presented in these industries. Further, the groups? wide reach to more than 86 countries enables it to capitalize on these opportunities not only in the domestic market but across the world.
Emerging business opportunities in oil and gas sector

Government has enacted various policies such as the Open Acreage Licensing Policy (OALP) and Coal Bed Methane (CBM) policy to encourage investments. The government has allowed 100 per cent FDI in Exploration & Production (E & P) projects/companies; and 49 percent in refining under the automatic route from the earlier approval route. India is expected to attract over US$ 25 billion of investments in Exploration and Production (E&P) by 2022. Gas pipeline infrastructure in the country stood at 16,226 km at the beginning of February 2019. Post NELP (New Exploration Licensing Policy) oil & gas exploration and production sector opened up to private sector, a total of over 250 oil & gas blocks has been auctioned off to private players. This active involvement of private sector along with increasing focus of government to develop domestic production to reduce imports have helped in the growth of all ancillary industries related to oil & gas exploration and production sector. Also, foreign investors will have opportunities to invest in projects worth US$ 300 billion in India, as the country looks to cut reliance on oil imports by 10 per cent by 2022.
Given, the rising energy demand of its economy, tremendous growth in the EPC industry is expected. The group can capitalize on these opportunities which can benefit to improve its overall business.

Make in India, launched in September 2014, by the government of India is an initiative of the government to encourage investment in the manufacturing sector to facilitate best-in-class manufacturing infrastructure in the country.ÿThis has boosted investments across the sector. The government has been continuously focusing on boosting the rural economy, promoting energy efficiency in urea production, maximizing domestic urea output and timely import of urea and other fertiliser. Also the recent Union Budget put more thrust on the wellbeing of farmer and agricultural growth in the country. After two consecutive years of poor rainfall, good monsoon and favourable agro-climatic conditions helped improved the outlook for the fertiliser sector. With the implementation of reforms by the government on the subsidy disbursements front, the government?s continuous rural focus and promise to double farm incomes, deregulation of urea is expected to give a fillip to the sector. The Company is expected to benefit from healthy growth prospects of fertilizer sector from which it derives major revenues.
Focus on overseas market and foray into railway electrification would drive the revenue growth

The Company aims to continue increase its overseas presence and plans to focus on emerging markets like Middle East countries and African countries, which is expected to provide it significant business opportunities going forward. Company is expecting to generate 25-30% revenue from overseas project in the near term.

As informed by the management, all the projects of the Company in African region are backed by World Bank or Export Import Bank funding. With the focus on infrastructure improvement, the overseas markets would provide huge potential for the Company. This will help TLL in driving its top-line and reducing its dependence on domestic market. This is evident in increasing international revenues (increased from 12% in FY 2018 to 22% in FY 2019). Furthermore, the Company plans to expand in railway EPC and widen its scope of railway work with respect o construct railway bridges, stations etc. The Indian Railways? target to electrify all its broad gauge tracks by fiscal year 2022 can open up large opportunities for engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) companies. The national carrier has prepared an action plan to electrify 38,000 route-kilometres in five years, incurring an expenditure of INR 32,591 crores.ÿAn estimated 300,000 MVA of substation capacity addition over the 13th Five Year Plan (2017-2022) represents a huge opportunity for T&D players. This would, going ahead drive the growth of the Company.

Moreover, Ujwal Discom Assurance Yojna (UDAY) provides for the financial turnaround and revival of discoms. UDAY seeks to empower loss making discoms to break even in two-three years by helping the Discoms in improving their operational efficiencies (compulsory smart metering, upgradation of transformers, popularising LED bulbs), reducing the cost of power (increased supply of cheaper domestic coal, liberal coal swaps from inefficient to efficient plants, amongst other benefits).

The government plans to add large generation as well as transmission and distribution (T&D) capacities in view of the long-term paucity of power in the country. Barring the short-term challenges, there is enormous potential for the engineering majors in the power space. The government has foreseen an investment plan of Rs 2.6 lakh crore in transmission sector during the FY17-22, of which estimated Rs 1.3 lakh crore has been allocated for intra-state transmission capacity.

In the past couple of years, the Indian power transmission and distribution (T&D) sector has seen a rise in activities, with the government pushing for programmes for electrifying villages, railway electrification and enhanced public private participation and electricity for all by 2019.
The Company having core business in EPC are now ready to monetise on the same and hence expect better growth prospects in the future.
Favourable global trends coupled with a strong position of India in the global home textile industry

The global home textile market was valued at USD 49 billion (2017) and is expected to increase to USD 57 billion by 2025. India?s home textile industry is expected to expand at a CAGR of 8.3 % during 2014-21 to USD 8.2 billion in 2021 from USD 4.7 billion in 2014. In 2018-19, Indian home textile industry reached USD 4.95 billion. Being a cotton surplus and net cotton exporter nation, India provides the cotton home textile manufacturers an edge over manufacturers in other countries in terms of quick and continuous cotton supply at a much competitive price.

India is in discussion with the European Union for a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) which would reduce the duties, currently, Indian exporters pay 9-10% duty on the home textile products exported to the EU, whereas some of the key competing countries have zero duty access to the market. The above factors may lead to incremental demand for textile products manufactured by the Company thereby improving its topline. However, the global trends shifting towards e-commerce may require steps on part of Indian players to capitalize on the opportunity presented and change the business model as per the need of the hour.
Favourable government initiatives to boost investment in the textile industry

The Government of India through many of its policy reforms has provided a boost for investment growth in the textile industry. The government of India has allowed 100% foreign direct investment and the industries remains one of the key focus areas under its ?Make in India? initiatives. Manufacturing hubs have been established to provide the ecosystem for sustainable growth in the industry. The Government recently replaced 2.2% of Rebate on State Levies (RoSL) with 8.2% of Rebate on State and Central Embedded Taxes and Levies (ROSCTL). This will result in export benefits for the home textile players.

Investment was made to promote modernization and up-gradation of the textile industry by providing credit at reduced rates under the Technology Up-gradation Fund Scheme (TUFS). A subsidy of INR 1,400 crore was released under this scheme in 2017. The scheme has been continuously amended since to suit the need for the hour for the industry where currently it offers capital subsidy for technology upgradation in the sector. Further, under the Union Budget 2019-20, INR 700 crore has been allocated for this scheme.
Expansion in manufacturing facilities and setting up new offices in different regions could propel revenue growth

The Group has set up a manufacturing unit at Jabel Ali, UAE of 10,000 MTPA which has commenced production from March 2019 onwards. Group has submitted its bid to acquire a unit in Vizag which is under NCLT. The unit manufactures low carbon ferro chrome. The plan is to captively consume part of the produce for manufacturing of cored wire at its two manufacturing units which is expected to yield better margins. The expansion in manufacturing activities could enhance revenue growth.

Further, the Group is setting up new subsidiaries as a liaison office in different markets to expand reach. It is in process to set up a new subsidiary in South Africa. The Group anticipates improvement in operational efficiency with lower shipping cost and lower delivery time by setting up a local office near to miner/producer and customers. The Group also practices merchant trading for some of the orders where goods are directly sent from on foreign location (supplier) to another foreign location (customer), without entering Indian shores, thus saving on time and costs. Further, as informed, it has metallurgical testing facility at the warehouses enables it to test and sort the scrap on the site and ship it to the customers with the requisite quality and standards. Further, the Group has applied for REACH registration for its subsidiary in Dusseldorf, Germany which will cater to European clients and the management has sited prospective steel mills in Europe as its customers. Further, penetration in the European market is a part of the Group?s strategy to diversify its geographic reach beyond Middle Eastern countries which currently account for 50-60% of the total revenues.
Hence, strategically located units would enable it to reach out to its prospective customers easily and garner a wide customer base thus providing revenue visibility to the Group.

The offerings of the Group find application largely in steel industry. The Union Government has taken several initiatives in steel sector like setting up research centre for the steel industry. Also, with revival of Indian economy, albeit at slower pace, on the back of positive reform measures undertaken by the government like Make in India initiative to boost domestic manufacturing industry, levy of anti-dumping duties or minimum import prices (MIP) to protect domestic industry from cheap imports, fiscal measures like 100% foreign direct investments (FDI), and tax relief and subsidies would augment domestic production and provides sustainable business opportunities to the Group.

As a facilitator, the Government monitors the steel market conditions and adopts fiscal and other policy measures based on its assessment. Currently, GST of 18% is applicable on steel and there is no export duty on steel items.
Stringent emission regulations shift towards fuel efficient vehicles and emerging markets to be the demand drivers for turbochargers

Today the global automotive players face the challenge to meet the stringent global regulations related to the emissions from automobiles and cater to the demand poised for fuel efficient vehicles. In this situation, turbochargers act as the solution for the problems faced by the automotive players. The role of a turbocharger is to recycle wasted energy from exhaust gas, transforming more of the fuel energy consumed into power. A turbocharged engine, therefore offers improved fuel economy, lesser emissions. The presence of turbochargers in vehicles allows the manufacturer to reduce their engine sizes and therefore emissions while continuing to deliver the power and performance. The migration from BSIII to BS IV is likely to drive the new vehicle sale compliant with upgraded norms and drive the engine and engine component demand. New vehicles sold from 2020 will have to be equipped with engines compliant with the new standards. Consequently, technology upgrade is expected to gain momentum, which will help OEM manufacturers to manufacture BS VI compliant vehicle at reduced cost in comparison to the current scenario of manufacturing BS IV complaint vehicle at huge import cost. Domestic engine manufacturing will drive the demand for engine components and thereby turbochargers.

The global market in terms of value for automotive turbocharger is projected to grow to USD 22.1 Billion by 2020, at a CAGR of 10.21% for the period 2015-2020. The emerging middle class in the high growth regions like India, China and Brazil are set to be accelerating the demand for turbochargers. With a global and domestic presence, the Company is set to benefit from the increasing demand for turbochargers.
Increasing demand of turbocharged petrol vehicle variants could fuel turbocharger demand

Market for turbocharger components in India is predominantly for diesel vehicles. The domestic turbocharger market is facing stagnation in terms of volumes on account of increasing of passenger vehicles for petrol variants. This was due to government?s decision to remove administrated prices for fuel, resulted in narrowing the gap between the prices of diesel and petrol. In the backdrop of changing customer preference towards petrol engines in the Passenger vehicle segment, the domestic turbocharger industry ? which is attuned to the diesel turbocharger ? could face some temporary readjustment pains, especially for supplies to the passenger vehicle industry. Nevertheless, increasing acceptance of turbocharged petrol engines should support demand for the turbocharger industry over the medium term. While the share of diesel vehicles in India is expected to moderate going forward, increasing the share of turbocharged petrol engines as well as superior realization will drive the overall turbocharger market. Turbochargers in petrol vehicles are gaining prominence post enabling the improved fuel efficiency by Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) norms by government of India. The Company can benefit from the increasing demand for turbochargers in petrol vehicles.

As per the ?Automotive Mission Plan 2026? of Ministry of Heavy Industries & Public Enterprises Government of India, India will be a global automotive hub for designing and manufacture of automobiles and auto components. With the advent of various overseas automobile manufacturers setting up their manufacturing units in India, the Company may seek an opportunity to explore new customers and is expected to grow 3.5 to 4 times of the current value of USD 74 billion to USD 300 billion.

Apart from this, the other initiatives launched by the Government include setting up Automotive Skill Development Council (ASDC), support to R&D projects through automotive cess funding, starting of National Automotive R&D Infrastructure Project (NATRIP) for setting up of world class infrastructure for homologation and testing, setting up of the National Automotive Board (NAB) as a repository of auto R&D expertise and an apex coordinating body to address the need of collaborative R&D and synergizing the activities of NATRIP. The automotive sector is expected to generate 65 million jobs. Also, Automotive sector is expected to grow to INR 593,500 crore - INR 732,000 crore by 2026.
Growth in demand for steel and steel products coupled with Government initiatives present growth opportunities for the Company

India?s finished steel consumption is anticipated to increase to 230 MT by 2030-31 from 90.68 MT in 2017-18 supported by growth in the domestic market. Indian steel industry has deep forward and backward linkages with several key segments of the economy, thus the government has formed certain policies for the steel sector. Some of the government initiatives in this sector are as follows:

Metal Scrap Trade Corporation (MSTC) Limited and the Ministry of Steel have jointly launched an e-platform called 'MSTC Metal Mandi' under the 'Digital India' initiative, which will facilitate the sale of finished and semi-finished steel products.

The Ministry of Steel is facilitating setting up of an industry-driven Steel Research and Technology Mission of India (SRTMI) in association with the public and private sector steel companies to spearhead research and development activities in the iron and steel industry at an initial corpus of INR 200 crore (US$ 30 million).
An export duty of 30 percent has been levied on iron ore (lumps and fines) to ensure supply to the domestic steel industry.
Increased capacity addition in anticipation of upcoming demand and the new steel policy that has been approved by the Union Cabinet, is expected to boost India's steel production.

The National Steel Policy 2017 has led to huge growth in both production and consumption of steel. The per capita consumption has risen from 59 kgs in 2013-14 to 69 kgs in 2017-18. Flagship programmes like 100 Smart Cities Mission, Housing for all Mission, Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation and high-speed bullet trains and metro trains continue to remain contribute in increasing steel demand in our country.

Increasing expenditure by the government in infrastructure projects such as roads, bridges, tunnels, ports, water and gas pipeline is likely to keep the steel demand and production in check. The momentum of government spending to be continued by the new government and steel demand should continue growing at 7-7.5%in FY 2020, highest globally. The Union Budget 2019-20 will give a push to big-ticket infrastructure projects and thereby increase the demand for steel. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a slew of steps in the union budget to scale up the country?s infrastructure, including augmenting 1,25,000 km of rural roads under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) at a cost of INR 80,250 crore and creating a national highways grid. Clear emphasis has been laid on the infrastructure development along with a massive push to every connectivity avenue including industrial corridors, dedicated freight corridors, Bharatmala, Sagarmala, UDAN, and PMGS. Thus, Venus group will be benefited by the increasing demand from infrastructure and construction segment.
Global steel demand to support the Company?s export sales
Since, the group derives majority of revenue from export market, global demand will help to increase the revenue of the Company in coming years.

The packaging industry in India is predicted to grow at 18% annually, with flexible packaging growing at 25% and rigid packaging at 15%. Packaging is the fifth largest sector in India?s economy and is one of the highest growth sectors in the country. According to the Packaging Industry Association of India (PIAI), the sector is growing at 22% to 25% per annum. The anticipated growth will be primarily driven by growing population, income levels and changing lifestyles. These changes drive the need for new packaging formats, such as different sizes, materials, and strength. In recent years, India has seen sustainable packaging growth due to the increase of packaged food consumption and awareness, and demand for quality products. Consumer awareness surrounding packaged food, specifically packaged food deliveries, has heightened. Further, organized retail and boom in e-commerce, offers huge potential for future growth and gives a boost to the packaging sector. Thus, the expected growth in the sector can help the Company augment its revenues.
Growing investments in the food processing sector to propel growth in the flexible packaging industry

The growth of the Indian flexible packaging market is because of their increased use at foodservice outlets, along with higher demand for packaged beverages. The Indian flexible packaging market is expected to reach a value of INR ~640.38 Bn by FY 2023, up from its FY 2017 value of INR 375 Bn, expanding at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of ~10% from FY 2018 to FY 2023. Consumers prefer flexible packaging over rigid packaging since they are lighter, easily disposable, and their impact on the environment is significantly less. Being the fourth-largest sector in the Indian economy, the fast moving consumer goods (FMCG) sector represents the largest opportunities for flexible packaging. Sub-segments like food and beverages, and personal care are the major end-users of flexible packaging in India. With the growth of this market, demand for flexible packaging is expected to increase. India, the-fifth largest preferred retail destination in the world, is expected to generate a revenue of INR ~71,986.2 by 2020, increasing at a CAGR of ~17.85% from 2015. The growth of the retail industry will directly lead to the expansion of the flexible packaging market in India.

Further, there has been increasing use of stand-up pouches as one of the key emerging trends in the flexible packaging market in India. Vendors are coming up with new and innovative packaging solutions to withstand the high competition in the flexible packaging market in India. Vendors are taking care to create packaging that is aesthetically appealing as well as tamper-proof to ensure effective supply chain management. The company has an exclusive brand for retail and household segment named ?Zipfresh? which are available in various sizes.

Company in the last two years ending FY 2020 has invested in capacity expansion. It increased its existing capacity by 25% at Vadsar plant and set up a new capacity of 8,000 MTPA at Kolkata. The combined capacity of the two plants will be enhanced by almost 75% ie 12,000 MTPA. As indicated, at full utilization level, Company would be able to achieve around INR 500 crore of revenue and expected to commence production from January 2020 onwards. The added capacities will add to the Company?s revenue and enhance its scale of operations.

Company has invested in a new 50:50 JV with Wilmar International Ltd in PT Flextech Packaging Indonesia. It will set up a 18,000 MTPA plant at Indonesia to cater to the entire demand of Wilmar International Limited. The equity contribution of the Company in the same will be about INR 25-30 crore (of which INR 5 crore has already been invested in fY 2019). The JV is expected to start generating revenues from FY 2021 onwards.

As per the ?Automotive Mission Plan 2026? of Ministry of Heavy Industries & Public Enterprises Government of India, India will be a global automotive hub for designing and manufacture of automobiles and auto components. With the advent of various overseas automobile manufacturers setting up their manufacturing units in India, the Company may seek an opportunity to explore new customers and is expected to grow.

Apart from this, the other initiatives launched by the Government include setting up Automotive Skill Development Council (ASDC), support to R&D projects through automotive cess funding, starting of National Automotive R&D Infrastructure Project (NATRIP) for setting up of world class infrastructure for homologation and testing, setting up of the National Automotive Board (NAB) as a repository of auto R&D expertise and an apex coordinating body to address the need of collaborative R&D and synergizing the activities of NATRIP. The automotive sector is expected to generate 65 million jobs. Also, the Automotive sector is expected to grow to INR 593,500 crore - INR 732,000 crore by 2026. Thus, these benefits augur well for the topline of the Company over the medium term.

During the review period the Company made various acquisitions and investments with a view to diversify its service portfolio and increase its presence in different geographies, The Company acquired Designit, Cellent AG, HPH Holdings Corporation, Appirio and Demisto during FY 2016-FY 2019. Furthermore, it has also entered into an agreement to acquire Viteos Group, a Business Process as a Service (BPaaS) provider for the alternative investment management industry for a purchase consideration of USD 130 million.

As part of a start-up engagement model, the Company has invested in building an ecosystem through a US$ 100 million internal venture capital fund, Wipro Ventures, aimed at investing in cutting edge start-ups in areas such as Digital, Internet of Things (IoT), Big data, Open source, Cyber security and Artificial Intelligence (AI). These investments are expected to bring in more diversity of offerings along with evolving services based on new technological trends. The Company is expected to benefit from these acquisitions in form of access to new innovations, skills and technologies which would help with improvement in the topline and margins over the near to medium term.

The Company derived around 83% of the revenue from USA and Europe and has limited presence in the domestic and other emerging markets. Its revenue from domestic market accounted for around 7.8% of its topline for FY 2019. However, high economic growth rate of the emerging economies (including the domestic market) has caused an increase in the scale of operations of the entities operating within these geographies, resulting in an increase in IT budget of these organizations to build the next generation IT systems. A significant amount of expenditure proposed to be incurred by the Government on IT, to modernize its public distribution systems, could serve as another growth driver for the Company in the domestic market.

According to NASSCOM estimates, the exports revenue of the Indian IT-ITeS industry is expected to reach USD 175 billion by 2020 due to incremental demand expected (despite short term headwinds) from the matured economies like US & Europe, owing to local corporations changing the mode of conduct of their operations to remain cost competitive and identify new revenue streams. The domestic market will contribute USD 50 billion revenue by 2020. Therefore, the export and domestic market together are likely to bring in USD 225 billion in revenue with new opportunities emerging across different verticals, such as public sector, manufacturing, defense, utilities, and healthcare, and across different geographies including Brazil, Russia, India, China (BRIC) and Japan. The same would provide an opportunity to the Company to leverage its domain competencies and expand its presence in the overseas markets, especially in emerging geographies like Asia Pacific and Middle East & Africa.

Digitization is viewed as a route to business model transformation and innovation for building sustainable competitive advantage.
