Businesses see a need for front-to-back, end-to-end process alignment, which would help them build their digital platforms and their digital operation environments of the future. The global sourcing model continues to grow its importance. Cloud computing is a mechanism of sharing of resources, software, and information by different users over the network. It does not require end users to know about the physical location and configuration of the system that delivers these services. This concept is increasingly becoming popular amongst the small and medium enterprises who want to save on the costs of establishing their own IT infrastructure.

Infrastructure Management Services (IMS), being called the ?third wave of outsourcing? after the software services and BPO has been one of the fastest growing segments of the industry. Under these services, the clients even outsource the management of their IT infrastructure which includes monitoring and management of computers, networks, servers etc. These services have become extremely popular following the economic slowdown in the key markets of Europe and US.

Following the slowdown, the clients, in order to cut back on costs, have even started outsourcing the management of their IT infrastructure (hardware and especially the non-core IT infrastructure) along with their software services and business processes. Such management is called ?Remote Infrastructure Management?. Continuous deterioration of the global economic environment resulting in cost cutting measures being adopted by the clients along with trend towards vendor consolidation provides huge opportunities to the Company to increase its revenues from the IMS division.

Implementation of 5G by mobile service providers would create multiple opportunities for IT service providers not only in the telecom sector, but also bring in deals from user industries viz. automotive, industrial and healthcare sectors. With growing impetus on digitization, the implementation of 5G is expected to be the much-needed boost in infrastructure which will help facilitate digitization on the much bigger scale bringing in a structural shift in industries from hardware to software capital expansion. Given its diverse capabilities, the Company is in a strong position to capitalize this opportunity. With implementation of the technology expected by the end of FY 2020, the Company?s revenue concentration from the communications segment is expected to increase in the near future.
Changing trends in the outsourcing industry driven by data analytics wave and digital talent development

Organizations in today?s time need to embrace emerging technologies in order to grow and gain a competitive advantage. Expertise in every skill and technology cannot be demanded in-house. Hiring more employees will mean being exposed to a small circle of local talents and also very high time consumption. Also, these employees will then need training to understand how the business works, hence further increasing development and testing time. But with outsourcing, businesses get access to specialized and skilled workforce all over the world, thus expanding their search. Everything starting from wireframing to development & testing and project management is taken care of by the outsourcing team without any sort of training or guidance. The result is decreasing the skill gaps and exposure to greater talent and technology along with competitive advantage for companies. Further, although technical projects are required, an increasing amount of companies are also looking to outsource innovation too. Moreover, the prevalence of innovative technology like blockchain and artificial intelligence is making it hard to find the talent, as the cost of hiring internal talent that can drive innovation is now higher.

Business process management companies are seeing growth quicken for digital services, as clients increase investment in data analytics to improve customer mining. The BPM industry is still significantly underpenetrated to that extent. Digital technology-led delivery is boosting growth for large BPM firms as more business applications are digitized and processes automated across businesses. Customer demand for analytics has been a key driver (particularly within translation services), led by engineering, bundled with domain specific AI and machine-learning capabilities. WNS group derives nearly 35% of its revenue from digital services.

Also, skilling has been a priority for organisations in the industry to adapt to the digitally transforming operations and the industry now has over 600,000 digitally skilled professionals. Accordingly, WNS continues to progress in its digital transformation journey with an unwavering focus on its talent capabilities ? which the company believes is a key element in its success.

In a nutshell, within the BPM industry, the shift is from ?outsourcing? to ?real value partnering?. WNS has been a part of this transition, from being a Company providing merely cost-reduction propositions to the one that tries to find more revenues for its clients by taking over a process and linking its own earnings to clients? business.ÿThe group seeks to expand relationships with existing clients by cross-selling new services (such as technology-based and analytics offerings), moving up the value chain, and expanding into other lines of business and geographies within each client.
Government?s digital transformation agenda is a critical enabler of industry growth

Government initiatives like Digital India, Smart Cities Mission coupled with higher demand for new technologies to drive growth. Government has been active in promoting digital education by offering platforms such as eBasta and Diksha. Government?s push for a cashless society, improved infrastructure and adoption of digital instruments resulted in strong growth of digital payments. Government announced national program for AI while planning to open 9 COEs to take AI to the masses. In the budget allocation, allocation of INR 3,750 crore is proposed to towards the ?Digital India? program. It launched the National Digital Communication Policy (NDCP) with a target to connect 5 billion people to IoT ecosystem.. Further, with an eye on further empowering the nation's growing digital economy, the Government of India introduced the National Policy on Electronics (NPE) and the National Policy on Software Products (NPSP) in 2019. These policies aim to build a comprehensive digital manufacturing and research and development (R&D) ecosystem, and are intended to complement efforts already underway to improve digital literacy and infrastructure under the "Digital India".

The Indian BPM industry now has more than a 37% share in global sourcing. WNS India is the major delivery center of the Group. Accordingly, WNS group is likely to benefit significantly from the growing impetus of the government towards growth of IT-BPM industry.
Increasing outcome-based deals to become important growth engine for the industry

Business process management companies are steadily deriving more of their incremental revenue from outcome-based deals, the share of which has increased sharply in recent years on the back of new business transformation contracts. With an increasing number of their clients using digital technology-enabled solutions, such asÿchatbots, to interact with their own customers, BPM companies have seen a significant chunk of their revenue proceeds shifting towards business outcomes. BPM companies have traditionally billed their clients based on man-hours spent for a service. Clients have a heightened focus on their customer experience and are making strategic investments in omnichannel engagement, digitization and the customer journey. Outcome-based partnerships are far more customer-centric than contracts based on operational knowledge performance indicators (KPIs) and help BPM companies and their clients better manage complexity and business outcomes.

Companies such asÿWNS,ÿAegisÿandÿHinduja Global Solutionsÿ(HGS) are now engaged in improving business value for their clients using technology platforms. For WNS, traditional and outcome-based projects have an equal share in total revenue.

The group is developing several New Chemical Entities (NCEs) as antibiotic drugs which are at various stages of clinical trials. It has 5 drugs under development and have received QIDP status by FDA. QIDP status is granted to drugs, identified by CDC (Centre for Disease Control, USA), that act against pathogens which have a high degree of unmet need in their treatment. QIDP status provides fast track clinical development and review of the drug application by US FDA for drug approval. The drug is also awarded five-year extension of market exclusivity. QIDP was constituted under Generating Antibiotic Incentives Now (GAIN) Act in 2012 as part of the FDA Safety and Innovation Act to underline the urgency in new antibiotics development.

WCK 4282 (one of the drugs), has been manufactured for cUTI phase 3 study which is scheduled to begin from Q4 of FY 2020. For another drug, WCK 5222, the group has obtained concurrence of EMEA and Chinese Regulator NMPA for abridged phase 3 study protocol and study is expected to begin in Q3 FY 2020. For WCK 4873, the group has obtained India Phase 3 CABP study approval from DCGI and study is scheduled to commence from Q3 FY 2020. For WCK 771/WCK 2349, it has completed India Phase 3 Acute Bacterial Skin and Skin Structure Infection (ABSSSI) study and new drug application is under review by the International New Drug (IND) committee. Also, the group has set-up first manufacturing facility in the Middle East exclusively for NCEs and is waiting for US FDA approval. All these new drugs, once developed and approved, will help in increasing Group?s revenue in coming years.

The global pharmaceutical market is expected to reach USD1.5 trillion by 2023 growing at a 3?6% compound annual growth rate over the next five years (2018-23).ÿThe factors bolstering the growth include, lower drug prices & taxes in the USA, GDP growth of over 6% in China & India, widespread aging population and sedentary lifestyles leading to increased chronic disease prevalence, lowered regulatory barriers for new drugs in the USA, and high urban pollution levels increasing the incidence of conditions like asthma. As a result, the global healthcare expenditures are projected to rise 3.7% annually in real (inflation-adjusted) US dollars through 2023, according toÿGlobal Healthcare. Spending will be driven by increasing access to a myriad of healthcare services in low & middle income countries and population growth, particularly in the cohort 65 years of age and older. In 2023, theÿAsia/Pacific region is projected to become the largest user of healthcare products and services, surpassingÿNorth America.

India?s generic drug producers hold a strong position in the global supply chain and play an integral role in developing the pharmaceutical industry. Drugs worth USD 212 billion are estimated to go off-patent by 2024 which will lead to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for companies. This will push up the demand for low cost generics and in turn will lead to an increase in the demand for the Group?s products in the global market.

The group as on 31st March 2019 has a combined patent pool of 3,132 filings. During FY 2019, the Group filed 95 patents of which 66 were granted. Also, the group has filed 3 new products in UK and has received an approval for 2 new products (ANDAs) in US. Currently for the US business, the Group?s pipeline includes 58 products pending to be approved by US FDA. Pending ANDAs include complex generics and modified release formulations. With the number of dosages going off patent by 2020, the Indian pharmaceutical companies have a good opportunity to file the generics (ANDA?s) which would enable the Group a six-month exclusivity right to market the drugs, giving it a competitive edge over its peers & competitors. The Group?s strength lies in its ability to launch generic version of critical drugs at most competitive prices. It can capitalize on the opportunity to launch the generic versions of those drugs at the earliest and market it through its extensive distribution network in India and overseas markets.

The rising costs and regulatory pressure in developed markets are forcing many global pharmaceutical companies to reduce their internal capacities in research and development (R&D), and manufacturing, and turn to contract manufacturing and research services (CRAMS) and outsourcing of research and clinical trials to developing countries. These strategies help multinational companies reduce costs, increase development capacity, and focus on their core profit makings activities, such as drug discoveries and marketing, rather than on manufacturing. India is fast emerging as a preferred destination for such multinationals seeking efficiencies of cost and time due to low production & R&D costs, talented manpower and large number of national laboratories. Besides, India is the only country in the world with highest number of USFDA approved plants for generic drug manufacturing outside US. The country?s CRAM industry offers a significant cost-quality proposition, with potential savings of about 30-40% compared to western markets such as the USA and Europe. Since the amendment to Patents Act in 2005, many Indian pharmaceutical companies have gradually moved away from generic production to the development of new drugs, exports to regulated markets and cooperative agreements with global pharma companies. With a USD 33 billion opportunity, the pharmaceutical industry in India presents considerable potential for collaborative and outsourced R&D in drug development, biotechnology, chemicals, and manufacturing of medicinal products. India?s CRAMS sector is globally recognized for its high-end research services and is one of the fastest growing segments of the country?s pharmaceutical industry. The Group can capitalize on the aforesaid opportunities to increase its revenue from the contract manufacturing space.

The Company is engaged in the manufacturing of wheel cylinders, master cylinders, other brake parts and turbocharger components. Key raw material required for manufacturing these components are castings, ingots, etc. Prices of these commodities are influenced by demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average 50% of the revenue of the Company. This is also evident from fluctuating gross profit margins during the review period.

As informed by the management, prices are revised quarterly as per London metal exchange quotes and also it has an escalation clause with its supplier. The Company is able to pass on price fluctuation to its customers to an extent, thus, enabling the Company to mitigate the raw material price fluctuation risk.

The Company operates in an intensely competitive environment, facing competition from both organized and unorganized players domestic as well as the international market (mainly from China). Chinese auto manufacturers have leverage over Indian auto component manufacturers in terms of scale of economies, lower power costs, reduced freight, local government concessions and lower transactional costs. Also, it competes with the large unorganized players operating in the market. This leads to pricing pressures from group customers as well as external customers.

The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend, is fairly cyclical. Therefore, short term deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to rising domestic inflation, hike in interest rates, hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production, or a slowdown in the major international markets, could adversely affect the demand for automobiles and consequently products being manufactured by the Company, thereby affecting its topline.

The Company needs to adapt to the changes made in the product designing by the OEMs to meet the progressive, safety, emission and other regulatory norms of their vehicles. Some of the newer vehicles launched in the Indian market (especially by the foreign OEMs) have demonstrated radical changes in the component designing aimed at providing greater comfort and safety feature to customers and meeting changing emission norms. Some of these designs could be disruptive, especially with regards to usage of alternate materials and alternate manufacturing technology, for the existing suppliers and pose a threat to the going concern nature of their business.

In this context, the ability of the Company to remain updated with the evolving specifications for its product viz. bearing house, turbine wheels, and aluminum castings, etc. is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating technological obsolescence risk and ensuring business continuity. This is also very important in terms of the supplies to its group companies and also to remain competitive for new external business opportunities.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the Company are large IT players like PricewaterhouseCoopers Private Limited, UST Global, KPMG, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, HCL Technologies Limited, Deloitte Consulting India Private Limited, Wipro Limited. Also, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low-cost destinations nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Therefore, the ability of the Company to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical. However, Company?s deep domain expertise and proven track record in successfully executing e-governance projects, gives a competitive advantage over the other players.
Ability to manage manpower costs amidst pricing pressure

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. High attrition rate has always remained a major concern in Indian IT industry. It results in loss of skill sets and the cost of recruitment and training. Personnel costs constituted around 41% of the revenue of the Company in FY 2019. As informed by the management, the attrition rate of the Company is around 30%. The ability of the Company to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.
Delays in completion of the project leading to cost overruns

Delays in timely execution of projects owing to pending site preparation, unavailability of key project supplies, disruptions in the project, etc. leads to delay in completion of the project and results in additional cost to be incurred by the Company which might impact the profit margins.

Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Traditional IT services are getting commoditized. Also, the shift from traditional /classic IT projects to projects based on disruptive technologies leads to a lot of churn and investments in costly new resources, trainings. The life cycle of IT products has drastically reduced. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.

The Company provides end-to-end freight forwarding solution. Pricing for the major ports is presently regulated by the Tariff Authority for Major Ports (TAMP), which defines the maximum charges, which a port can levy on its users. As informed by the management, the clearing and forwarding income is directly linked to the freight rates and any variation in the freight rates impacts the revenue of the Company. High competitive intensity may adversely affect pricing / margins of the Company. However, it faces competition with various stevedoring, clearing & forwarding agents.

The Indian Government has been actively pursuing change in recent times leading to quick regulatory changes and modifications. Though most of these initiatives have been implemented to cut down the unnecessary regulatory burdens, constant change requires quick adaptation by the companies operating in the affected industries. This exposes the Company to risks arising from changes in regulatory policy.

Natural disasters, such as earthquake, volcanic activity, windstorm, flooding, and tidal wave, can cause devastating damage to projects. Some ports are naturally endowed with such weather conditions; other ports achieve the same by investing in construction of breakwaters which protect a restricted area against strong tidal/waves/wind conditions. Certain ports are also vulnerable to cyclones and damage caused to the port infrastructure can be enormous in an extreme scenario. Damage to a port can impact the traffic volumes which can further influence the revenue of the companies providing shipping services. Ability of a port to operate in all weather conditions remains critical as handling could otherwise be restricted during monsoon periods.
Consolidation among retailers resulting into weak pricing power for generic drug manufacturers

Drugstores in the United States typically generate revenues by selling prescription drugs, over-the-counter medications, health and beauty products, and general merchandise. However, recently there is a trend of retail pharmacies acquiring medical clinics and pharmacy benefit management (PBM) companies (which process prescriptions for corporations and insurance companies and negotiate prices with drug manufacturers and retailers). The generic pharmaceutical manufacturers from India typically count a major of these players as their customers.

The top three drugstore companies in the United States, by store count, are Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), CVS Health (CVS), and Walmart (WMT) which account for more than 75% of the US pharmacy market share. Due to the recent consolidation trends, there is an increase in bargaining power in these retailers, thus affecting the pricing power of the generic drugs manufacturers in India leading to revenue and profitability decline for Indian generic drug manufacturers. The weak pricing power of the Company has affected the ability of the Company to increase its revenue and profitability. As informed by the management the Company intends to counter the weak pricing of generic drugs in the US market by launch of several new products across various therapeutic segments and focus on new markets like Europe and Africa.

The Company operates in a highly regulated industry and the operations are subject to extensive compliance requirement. The manufacturing facilities of the Company have to be regularly monitored and approved by various regulatory authorities across the globe. Government authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. Regulatory agencies, viz. US FDA, may at any time reassess the manufacturing facilities or the safety and efficacy of the products based on newly developed scientific knowledge or other factors.

Though currently all the facilities of the Company continue to be approved by various regulatory agencies (plant at Paithan and Dahej were approved by FDA in FY 2017, and Guwahati plant was approved by US FDA), any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by US FDA or any other regulatory authorities, on any of the manufacturing facilities in future can significantly affect the revenues of the Company. Such reassessments/prohibitions could result in the amendment or withdrawal of existing approvals to market the products, which in turn could result in a loss of revenue.

Companies have to make continuous efforts to improve their production processes in line with the technological changes as well as increase its scale of operations. A lot of R&D efforts are undertaken to develop products/molecules for which there is a significant amount of cash outflow. As the benefits of research and development activities are uncertain with huge investment involved, in the scenario of unsuccessful attempts, the Company may take a hit on the operating margins. Further, and there is no guarantee whether benefits will accrue on account of such research and development.
Susceptibility to growing regulatory standards to match regulated markets and price controls

Though the Group currently operates only in semi-regulated markets, the increasing awareness amongst the world population has been leading to consistent tightening of regulatory requirements in recent times. Increasingly, many pharmaceutical companies have been subjected to severe actions over regulatory compliance, sometimes as harsh as revoking the contract or banning the product from entering the country of export. Further, the growing backlash from the regulated markets has been leading to further tightening of norms in the semi-regulated countries as well.

India is on a rapid crusade to meet global standards on pharma regulatory framework. Restructuring and revamping are being undertaken in several areas like biosimilars, FDCs, GMP and related areas including ICH, PICs, clinical trials, Schedule Y, Medical Devices and pharmacovigilance. This could further strengthen the regulatory systems in India. At a time when the industry leaders are being adversely impacted by stringent regulations implemented through US FDA inspection audits, the industry needs to take these challenges as opportunities for upgradation and compliance. Co-operation of Indian regulatory bodies like CDSCO (Central Drugs Standard Control Organization) /Office of DCGI with overseas regulators are helping to upgrade Indian quality and regulatory standards. The impact of these changes in the industry on the operations of the Company remain to be seen.

With growing regulatory requirements and large number of products, the liability associated with these products also increases. Further, with increasing pricing pressure on drugs and the encouragement to further streamlining of processes to reduce manufacturing overheads, the focus has shifted to increase production efficiency. Though suitable measure are taken by the Group to ensure adequate testing through measures like laboratory and bioequivalence studies, the large number of products involved increases the risk of exposure to regulatory actions in case of a product or two, where certain unknown variable may realize at a certain point of time in future. Since these products are manufactured through the existing manufacturing facilities of the Group, the situation may also impact manufacture of other products and thereby impact revenue visibility.

The primary raw materials which the Company requires for its manufacturing activities are aluminium, zinc, copper and other metals as also some products which are crude oil derivatives. The prices of these commodities follow the international trends which in the long run are influenced by the global demand and supply factors that are beyond the control of the Company.

Since raw material costs constitute on an average nearly 53% of the total revenues during the review period, any adverse movement in the price of raw materials could have an adverse impact on Company?s margins. However, with few customers, the Company has the bargaining power as the customers chooses its vendors, thus ensuring compensating on any raw material price hike to the Company. Thus, it is able to pass on the raw materials price fluctuations to some extent. However, as informed by the management, the Company based on its strong relationships with customers is able to pass on increase raw material cost with a lag while pricing its products.

The Company sources ~65% of its raw material requirement and earns around 32% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing to an extent to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with limited scope of natural hedge. This exposes profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk which becomes more significant considering the high volatility of the INR in recent times. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though, imports and foreign currency borrowings could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balance exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from both the organized and unorganized sectors. Additionally, entry of new players could intensify the competition further. In India, the Company faces competition from IndFarad Technologies Private Limited, Kerala State Electronics Development Corporation Limited, CTRÿManufacturing Industries Limited and TrishalaÿElectrolytics Private Limited. Internationally, the Company faces competition from a large number of companies like EPCOS, CDE, Hitachi, Rubycon, Chem-con, Kemet and several other companies in Europe, Japan and China. As informed, the Company has focused on providing customized products which carry higher margins. Nevertheless, high competition could restrict the pricing ability of the Company, putting pressure on its margins, especially in a rising prices scenario.

The Company is primarily engaged in manufacturing aluminum electrolytic capacitors and film capacitors for the power electronics sector. The electronics manufacturing industry is characterized by high cost of raw materials along with low product differentiation and requirement of additional investments based on changes in technology. As informed by management the Company manufactures products based on international standards and customer requirements. Thus, if there is a shift in technology in the capacitor industry, the Company might have to entail additional expenditure to emulate the change as per customer requirements, consequently affecting it financial profile. Further, to remain competitive, it will need to invest in product development to meet future demands from the customers.

However, as informed by management, the Company manufactures components for the end product based on customer requirements. The end product has a specific lifecycle which stands between 5- 10 years respectively, thus ensuring the Company a sufficient time period for it to change its operations and technology accordingly.

The Company sources around 40% of its raw material requirement and earns around 58% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing to an extent to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Though, imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Considering its exposure in international market and volatility experienced in foreign exchange market, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism becomes critical for the Company. Further, any adverse movement in currency rates may have a significant impact on the bottom line of the Company. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transaction of INR 6155 thousand in FY 2015, INR 351,800 thousand in FY 2016, INR 280,600 thousand in FY 2018, INR 190,800 thousand in FY 2019 it incurred loss on foreign currency transactions of INR 44,800 thousand FY 2017. Also, as informed by the management the Company hedges a small percentage of net forex earnings. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balance exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

The pharmaceutical sector is highly regulated with government authorities in India and abroad conducting stringent monitoring of manufacturing facilities and formulations. Authorities like US FDA and EU GMP have become more vigilant and stricter with respect to compliance and quality checks. Increasingly, many pharma Companies are withstanding the worst of actions of these authorities, sometimes as harsh as revoking the contract or banning the product from entering the country of export. Moreover, the Department of Pharmaceuticals (DoP), Government of India, has set up National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA), which will ensure price control and stability in the industry for new drug launches (APIs and formulations). Under the mechanism, the Government will keep a floor and ceiling price for new drugs introduced by any pharma Company.

Though manufacturing facilities of the Company are approved by various regulatory authorities including United States Food and Drug Administration (US FDA), European Directorate for Quality of Medicines (EDQM), UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (UK MHRA), Australian Therapeutic Goods Administration (Australian TGA), Brazil ? ANVISA, World Health Organization (WHO), and Therapeutic Product Directorate (TPD) - Canada, any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by them on the manufacturing facilities in future can significantly affect the revenues of the Company. The recent focus of the FDA (Food and Drugs Administration) on the manufacturing processes of the India Pharmaceutical exporters and their ability to meet the stringent norms has caused various firms to receive various Form 483 observations. All manufacturing plants of the Company were audited by US FDA during FY 2019 and cleared without any 483 observations.

The primary raw material for some of the chemicals sold by the Company is crude oil, prices of which are determined by macro factors like global demand for fuel, quantum of production by the OPEC nations, speculative built up of the prices through forwards, political scenario in the Middle East countries, opening and closing inventories, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict which leads to volatility in the prices of crude oil and thereby of the chemicals manufactured from it. Further, since most of the petrochemicals are used in bulk quantities for manufacturing the end products, their costs constitute the major proportion of total direct costs. Therefore, it is very difficult to pass on the change in costs of these chemicals to the customers. Hence any adverse movements in the prices of crude, going forward, could significantly affect the profitability of the Company especially, when it wants to increase the share of polymers (petrochemicals) in its future revenues.
Fragmented nature of industry leading to high degree of competition

The Indian chemical industry is highly fragmented with the presence of large number of unorganized players. The growing opportunities in the domestic market and favourable FDI policies promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. The Company has a wide product portfolio and competes with various companies like Alkyl Amines Chemicals Limited, PI Industries Limited, Anupam Rasayan India Limited, Hikal Limited, Laxmi Organic Industries Ltd and Omkar Speciality Chemicals Ltd amongst others in the respective product categories. Also, the long relationship and healthy business engagement with the principal suppliers ensures regular purchases. However, the Company remains a moderate player in a highly competitive industry with limited bargaining power with the supplier and customers. This could restrict the ability of the Company to scale its volumes and pass on the price hike to its customers (owing to pricing pressures), and could have an effect on its revenues and profitability.
Large-scale imports from low-cost producer countries and competition may put pressure on pricing

Companies dealing in chemical commodities are exposed to the threat of large-scale imports from low-cost producers like China. This risk is further worsened by the structural weaknesses within the domestic commodity chemicals segment such as a fragmented supply base, which leads to lower economies of scale, relatively high capital and interest costs and limited availability of low-cost raw material. Rationalization of import tariffs has, further, worsened the environment. These factors adversely impact the cost competitiveness of the domestic commodity chemicals segment.
Volatility in the prices of key raw materials

The key raw materials required by the Company include metals such as steel, aluminum, nickel alloys and iron compounds. Metal prices are extremely volatile in nature and follow trends in commodity markets like multi commodity exchange (MCX) for price derivations and adjustments. Prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitutes on an average ~42% of the cost of the Company.

This is evident from the financials of the Company. The gross profit margin of the Company depicted an uneven trend during the review period owing to fluctuation in the cost of raw material and finished goods consumed.

The Company majorly caters to end-user industries like general engineering, petroleum, power, chemical and oil & gas industries. These industries have cyclical demand owing to high correlation with economic cycles. Short term deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to rising domestic inflation, constant hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production will adversely affect the demand for services provided by the Company. Apart from the cyclicality of the end-user industries, heavy capital investment and a gestation period of 2-3 years for a new plant also contribute to the cyclicality of steel prices.

As of FY 2019, the Company earned around ~89% of the revenue from exports and while procuring majorly all its raw material requirements from the domestic market (~88%). This exposes the profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk with limited scope of natural hedge. Considering the volatility in exchange rates and limited natural hedge, the ability of the Company to mitigate the risk remains critical as movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Therefore, any adverse movements in dollar rates going ahead will have undesirable ramifications on its margins.
Ability to adapt to technological changes and comply consistently with manufacturing standards

The Company is engaged in manufacturing of valves in European markets which requires various certifications. Therefore, it has to adapt to the technological changes and comply with international standards like standards set by various regulatory agencies for manufacturing valve castings, remains very critical. Preference of the end consumers for more automation of processes and demand for value added services like structural analysis, seismic analysis, thermal analysis, lifecycle tests and Computational Fluid Dynamics analysis will give impetus on development of new products and processes through investment in R&D. Hence, ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with evolving changes in technology and comply with applicable international standards for manufacturing its products is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating technology obsolescence risk. As informed, the Company has a R&D lab to test and develop new products. Further, it gets its processes / products certified by various authorities to ensure that it remains in compliance with requisite standards.

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from a large number of domestic players like Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd (BHEL), Larsen & Toubro (L&T), NSSL Limited, Oswal Valves Private Limited, Forbes Marshall Private Limited. BHEL and L&T together account for a significant share of valve production in India. The industry is also clogged with international players such as Flowserve India Controls Private Limited, Spirax-sarco, Xomox Corporation, Crane Process Flow Technologies. Availability of low cost technically qualified employee base has attracted multinational companies, some of whom have made India their manufacturing hub. Majority of smaller players in the segment are active in manufacturing lower end industrial valves, which requires relatively lower technical skills. High competitive intensity could restrict the pricing flexibility of the Company, thereby adversely affecting the margins in a rising price scenario. As informed, its long association with domestic and international customers and the quality of its products plays a pivotal role in competing with other players.

The Company is exposed to foreign currency rate fluctuation risk as around 86% of the revenue is driven from international markets whereas the entire sourcing is from the domestic market, thus, limiting its natural hedge and thereby exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Any adverse movement in the foreign exchange rates could affect the bottom line which can be witnessed from loss incurred on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2019. Although the Company enters into forward contracts, the entire of the receivables are not hedged. Any unhedged exposure could have a negative impact on the margins and the Company needs to have a proper hedging mechanism.
Threat of substitution of synthetic menthol as increasing capacities may impact natural menthol volumes

With recent commissioning of synthetic menthol capacities by Symrise and BASF and planned capacity addition by BASF in December 2018, the availability of synthetic menthol has increased in the market. With cost of synthetic menthol being lower and the availability from organised large players from where clients also procure other chemicals, synthetic menthol has found acceptance among the erstwhile users of natural menthol. This has led to impact on the demand for natural menthol. While synthetic menthol capacities are expected to increase going forward, rising demand for menthol products is expected to absorb part of the rising capacity thus softening the impact on natural menthol demand.

The domestic prices of commodities that the Company deals in follows the international trends and in long run, these are influenced by the global demand and supply factors beyond the control of the Company. Cost of materials and purchase of traded goods on an average accounted for around 93% of revenue of the Company over the past five years ending FY 2019. Over the past four years, the mentha oil prices have remained volatile with average prices fluctuating between INR 935 per kg to INR 1,549 per kg. Given the high competition, the pricing power of the Company has remained low. This exposes the Company to the risk of volatile raw material prices which can have an impact on the margins going ahead.
Slowing economic growth might impact Company?s revenue scale

After the rapid growth seen in recent years, the Indian economy has slowed down in recent times as the growth rate slumped down to a six-year low of 5% in the April-June 2019 quarter. The slowdown in more pronounced when compared to the rest of the world (which is also experiencing a slowdown) due to the rapid growth rate exhibited by the country in recent years. Further, the July-September quarter is expected to showcase only a slightly better growth rate of 5.3%. The slowing economy has impacted several industries including FMCG, the growth in which dropped to 10% in the April-June 2019 quarter. This was the third consecutive quarter of slowdown in the sector and the Q2 growth numbers follow softening from the third quarter of last year when the sector registered 16.2% growth. FMCG being one of the major industries catered to by the F&F industry, the impact of slowdown on the performance of the F&F industry and thereby on the performance of the Company remains to be seen.

The Indian specialty chemical industry is highly fragmented with the presence of large number of unorganized players. The Company?s competitors are the other players engaged in the aroma chemicals distribution activities. Also, there is a high competitive intensity from Chinese companies in the international market and to compete on the pricing front, many end users are now resorting to Chinese products. High competitive intensity could restrict the ability of the Company to scale its volumes and pass on the price hike to its customers (owing to pricing pressures), thus having an adverse effect on its revenues and profitability.

For the Company, its long relations with the top suppliers and customers, large stocking capacity, pan-India presence and ability to cater to a wide range of volumes as per customer requirement, act as competitive advantages.

The domestic prices of the commodities that the Company deals in follow the international trends and in long run, these are influenced by the global demand and supply factors beyond the control of the Company. On account of trading operations, purchases for resale consumed constituted ~84% of total revenue on an average in the last three years ending FY 2019. The Company majorly sources the products from domestic market. The stringent environmental laws in China has led to shut down of many units effecting the product prices. This might also affect the Company?s purchase cost and could have an impact on its margins. Also, being a trader, the Company has limited bargaining power with the customers. This exposes the Company to the risk of volatile movement in the prices of traded chemicals, which can affect its margins going forward.

The Company is exposed to foreign currency rate fluctuation risk as ~52% of its purchase requirement is met from the international market and ~4% of its revenue is derived from exports limiting its natural hedge and thereby exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Any adverse movement in the foreign exchange rates could affect the top line as well as bottom line which can be witnessed from loss incurred on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2019. Any unhedged exposure could have a negative impact on the margins.
Ability to manage manpower costs and attrition risks along with evolving technology.

The sector Besten operates in including design and detailed engineering services, procurement services, survey and project management are manpower intensive services. Personnel costs coupled with consultancy cost constituted ~38% of the revenue during the review period. The Company has witnessed y-o-y increase in personnel cost throughout the review period on absolute levels. Also, the consultancy charges of Besten have increased y-o-y both on absolute terms and as a percentage of revenue (except in FY 2016) during the review period. Also the industry faces challenges from fast changing development in the designing segment owing to the frequently changing norms and regulation and increased technological upgradations increase the overheads for the Company and may result in cost overruns. Thus, the ability of the Company to continuously evolve its technology remains critical.
High competitive industry coupled with moderate scale of operations

The Company operates in a highly competitive industry marked by competition from large organized players as well from mid & small sized players. Intense competition in the industry puts pressure on the margins of business given the better bargaining power of the customers. Most of the players are having larger size and substantial market position. The topline of the Company in comparison to these players stood at modest levels during the review period. Lower scale and size of the Company can act as a hindrance for bagging bigger projects and will stunt the growth prospects of the Company.

The Company derives a bulk of its revenues from the automobile sector. The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend, is highly cyclical. Therefore, weak economic environment characterized by decline in per-capita income, high domestic inflation, increasing interest rates, weak industrial production, etc. (a scenario witnessed in FY 2013 and in current year), could adversely affect the revenues of the Company. Indian economy is currently witnessing a slowdown. India?s economic growth fell to 5.8 per cent in the January-March period of FY 2019, the lowest in 20 quarters, due to a sharp slowdown in investment andÿmanufacturing growthÿas well as a contraction in agricultural production. Thus, automobile sector too has got impacted from the slowing growth in the economy. Higher cost of vehicles, weak consumer sentiments coupled with liquidity crisis stemming from NBFC defaults are the other factors effecting the auto sales. As informed, management expects the revenues to remain stagnant in the current year.

The Company derives almost 65% of the revenues from the top three customers. Any decline in demand from the top customers can significantly affect the revenues of the Company and in turn, hamper the profitability. Also about 50% of the purchases are from top two suppliers. High dependence on suppliers would increase risk of impact on supplies in case of any adverse events at supplier?s end.
Susceptibility of margins to volatility in raw material prices

The primary raw material, which the Company requires for its manufacturing activities is iron, steel, plastic granulesThe prices of plastic granules are governed by crude oil prices leading to high volatility in their prices. The domestic prices follow the international trends, in the long run, which are influenced by the global demand and supply factors, beyond the control of the Company. Purchases remained in the range of ~60% to ~68% of the total revenues, exhibiting significant fluctuation. Any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials could have an adverse impact on the Company?s margins owing to high competition which limits bargaining power with the customers. Therefore, the ability of the Company to sustain margins in case of adverse movement in raw material prices remain critical.

The Company operates in an industry which is highly fragmented and competitive dominated by large number of organised and unorganised players. Some of the dominant players operating in the industry include Henkel Adhesive Technologies India Private Limited, Dow Chemicals International Private Limited, Bostik India Private Limited, Hubergroup India Private Limited, Uflex India and others. With nascent stage of operations, the Company?s scale of operations has also remained moderate with revenue of around INR 300 crore during FY 2019 which limits the bargaining power with customers and suppliers. As indicated by management, use of latest technology, quality of products and on-time delivery provide it?s a competitive edge against the other players.
Exposure to the risk of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuation

The Company sources ~47% of its raw material requirement through imports whereas exports account for ~15% of the total top-line. Although the Company has a natural hedge to a certain extent, there is a certain amount of unhedged exposure as well. The movements in the exchange rate are influenced by various factors such as demand and supply of foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies and others. Most of these factors are difficult to predict resulting in volatility in the exchange rates, impacting the profitability of the any organization. Further the Company operates on a stock and sale model which builds in a certain time lag between procurement of raw material and sale of finished goods. Albeit the Company undertakes hedging by entering into forward contracts, the fact that there could be a timing difference between the procurement of imported raw materials and orders received from the customers, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. This is reflected in losses incurred on foreign exchange transactions during FY 2017, FY 2018 and FY 2019.
Increasing competitive intensity in key markets coupled with domestic pricing & policy uncertainties

The US generic markets are characterized by buying bulk volumes at lower prices and tend to have price erosion historically. However, this pricing pressure on the USA generic business has intensified consolidation of distribution supply chain (trade partners) and faster ANDA approvals by USFDA especially post implementation of Generic Drug User Fee Act (GDUFA). The key consideration impacting generic prices has been faster ANDA approval leading to higher competitive intensity.ÿFurther, with a large number of applications pending, the pace of approvals is likely to remain high. In addition to GDUFA, USFDA has taken several steps to increase competition in the market for prescription drugs and also facilitate entry of lower-cost alternatives through Drug Competition Action Plan.ÿWhile these initiatives benefit generic players, they are also likely to increase the competition for similar set of molecules. Cadila derives majority of its revenues from the US market, hence,ÿincreasing competition in such markets and research & development cost will likely constrain the margin.

As far as the domestic market is concerned, branded generic drugs account for nearly 80% of the Indian pharmaceutical market by sales making it highly fragmented and competitive. The Group faces headwinds in India from government-mandated price reductions/policy changes coupled with competitive intensity. This will continue to pose a threat to its domestic operations. For instance, the Group?s overall growth for the domestic market was impacted by the temporary disruption in the trade channel due to the implementation of the Goods & Services Tax (GST) during FY 2018. Hence, the Group?s operations are vulnerable to the domestic competitive scenario and change in government policies.

The Group earned over 60% of revenue from exports business, thereby exposing it to currency rate fluctuation risk. Any adverse movements in the foreign exchange rates could have an impact on the margins. As informed, the group proactively uses hedging instruments e.g. forward contracts, options and other derivatives time to time. However, as informed it deals in multiple currencies as it has presence across the globe which makes it unviable to remain hedged at all times, thus exposing it to risk of foreign exchange rate fluctuation.

The Group derived on an average more than 98% of its revenues during the review period from international markets exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, Brexit, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. There could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the group and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Group to the risk of incurring losses on contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. As informed, the Group does not have any hedging mechanism. The Group remains exposed to forex risk which was evident from the fact that it had incurred losses to the extent of INR 3,121 thousand in FY 2018. However, it generated profits in FY 2019 around INR 42,114 thousand.
Ability of the Group to manage manpower cost

The Group being a service company has a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average around 65% to 70% of the revenues of the group during the review period. The Group incurred operating losses due to addition of new employees, revision of salaries, and employee cost spent on tool development. Nonetheless, this has significantly reduced in FY 2019 bringing down the contribution to 56.78% with increased revenue. As informed, attrition rate remains at around 18%. Therefore, increase in personnel costs, due to improvement in the domestic economic environment could, going forward, adversely affect the margins of the group and hence managing the same remains critical.
Protectionist policies of the US government and draft executive order on modification of H1B norms

US administration has tightened visa norms and resorted to other protectionist policies through a draft executive order to overhaul the H1B work-visa programme. The new norms entail modification of the roster of employees, thus requiring more onshore employees (locals to be hired), minimum salaries increased to 135,000 USD (which is indexed for inflation or the average wage for the occupation in the area of employment but with a floor of $90,000), composition of onsite vs offshore for various projects, and specific limits of H1B visas to be offered to companies leading to increase in costs for IT companies and impacting the margins. The bill now heads to the full house for necessary action. Moreover, recently the US administration announced a new policy that makes issuing of H1-B visas difficult for those employed at one or more third party worksites.

The reforms may force Indian IT companies to make changes in their business strategies, including hiring more American workers and raising salaries they pay to employees working on client sites or sub-contract to US IT firms which will reduce operating margins to an extent. Any adverse changes in the law in U.S & other European countries towards outsourcing of work remains critical for the Group.

Information technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Thereafter gradually more and more processes were outsourced. To cut back on costs, the clients may start resorting to ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? wherein they would outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes.

The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead, they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Further, new disruptive technologies like SMAC and innovations by startups which develop niche technology solutions, generate uncertainty regarding predictability of the business models and incremental demand from product differentiations. Therefore, the ability of the group to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical. Cigniti Group, as informed, makes investment in new technologies to consistently upgrade itself. The Group has teamed with leading global software tool vendors to augment its test automation capabilities for aligning with, and meeting, the emerging needs of enterprises.
Stiff competition from unorganized players along with international markets

Marble industry in India is highly fragmented with around 80% being the unorganized players and very few organized players in the industry. As indicated by management, the natural marble industry is India is around INR 2,000 crore while that of artificial marble is around INR 700 crore to INR 800 crore. Few of the players in the industry include Pokarna Limited, Asian Granito, RK Marbles and others, which dominate the industry. Apart from the domestic players, the Company also faces competition from Chinese players because of their lower pricing. Furthermore, competition from low priced ceramic tiles and PVC marble sheet also pose competition to the products of the Company. However, being in the industry for around two decades and industry dominated with few players in marbles segment, the Company enjoys an established market position in the artificial marble industry and is one of the largest importers of natural marble in India.

In FY 2019, the Company sourced around 58% of its raw material requirement and derived around 8% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing financial performance to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with a limited scope of natural hedge. Though imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Company earned profit on foreign exchange transactions of INR 39,836 thousand and INR 13,561 thousand in FY 2017 and FY 2019 respectively, it incurred loss on foreign exchange transactions of INR 168 thousand in FY 2018. As indicated by management, the Company enters into forward contracts to hedge against the volatile currency rates; however, around 60% is hedged while the balance exposure remains open. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

The primary materials required by the Company for manufacturing are rough marble blocks and rough granite blocks, marble lumps, resins, calcium carbonate powder, aggregates and pigments. Prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average 46% of the revenue over the past three years. Therefore, any significant increase in material cost will affect the margins adversely due to its limited ability to pass on the price hike to customers.

Cut and polished diamonds (contributing around 55% of the total raw materials), gold (contributing around 37% of the total raw material) and silver are the major raw material used by the Company. The prices of these are volatile and are susceptible to price movements in other commodities, global demand, global and particularly inflation in the USA, US fiscal deficit, interest rates etc. These factors can impact the cost of procurement of the raw materials which on an average contributed to over 78% of the total revenue.

Moreover, being an export-oriented unit, the revenues and margins are also vulnerable to currency fluctuations. However, the risk is mitigated to a large extent since most of its key raw materials like diamond and gold, although procured locally, are dollar denominated. Further, as informed, the Company has foreign exchange cover of around INR 50 crores and enters into forward contracts to hedge its foreign exchange exposures. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Although the Company has forward cover to hedge against the volatile foreign exchange rates, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes it to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. The Company gained on forex transactions during FY 2017 and FY 2018, whereas, losses were incurred during FY 2019.
Fairly competitive industry structure with large presence of unorganized units in the domestic market

The Company is engaged in manufacturing of diamond studded gold and silver jewellery which is plagued by intense competition with large number of unorganized players. India is one of the largest exporters of gems and jewellery and the industry is considered to play a vital role in the Indian economy as it contributes a major chunk to the total foreign reserves of the country. As per GJEPC, the net exports rose from USD 15.66 billion in FY2004-05 to over USD 30 billion in FY 2018-19, at a CAGR of 5.83 per cent over FY 05- 18. Intense competition may result in pricing pressure and may adversely impact the margins of the Company. Further, the Company?s scale of operations has remained moderate with declining revenue till FY 2018 (from FY 2016) and stagnant revenue during FY 2019. As informed, some of the closest competitors of the Company include Fine Jewellery India Limited, Renaissance Jewels Limited, Sanghavi Exports etc. Further, moderate scale of operations in the fragmented and unorganised sector limits the bargaining power.
Rise in demand for artificial diamond and imitation jewellery along with changing consumer preferences

The lab grown (synthetic) market is one of the growing markets across the globe. The market for synthetic diamonds was valued at USD 16.2 billion in FY 2015 and is expected to reach USD 27.6 billion, registering a compounded annual growth rate of 7.4% by FY 2023. With rising demand for synthetic diamonds and impetus to stone and bagasra jewellery, there is rising threat for real gold and diamond jewellery. Further, changing preferences and spending habits such as growing preference for designer, luxury fashion, and smartphones in urban areas may show a shift in demand from jewellery amongst the youth which may adversely impact the demand for gold and diamond jewellery.

The Group derived around 82% of its total revenue from the international market, thereby leading to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movement in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of foreign currency, domestic inflation, etc. which are hard to predict thereby causing volatility in the exchange rates. Though the Group tries to manage its risk via forwards, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected / hedged by the Group and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses on such contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Engineering service landscape in India comprises of independent service providers as well as captive units of global manufacturing companies. There are close to 800 ? 900 engineering service companies in the country providing a host of services ? both simple and complex ? making the sector highly fragmented. Entry barriers operating in the sector are considerably weak, primarily due to the easy availability of skilled employees and low amount of investment required to set up. Despite the fragmented nature of the business, major companies like KPIT Technologies Limited, Tata Technologies Limited, CMC Limited, Mahindra Engineering, and Quest Global Engineering Private Limited have managed to carve a niche position in the sector. All these companies possess deep domain expertise enabling them to provide end to end solutions to customers in varied industries. In addition to these niche service providers, traditional IT service majors like Infosys, HCL, and Wipro too have managed to build expertise in engineering service domain. Hence, the ability of the Group to maintain its margins amidst competition remains critical. Further, Indian IT sector has threat from emerging outsourcing destinations like Philippines and China. The Philippines has already overtaken India in terms of ?voice? revenues and China, with its cost and infrastructure benefits are turning as favorable destinations. However, as informed, the domain expertise in aerospace and defence sector provides the Group a competitive edge.
High exposure to the aerospace and defense sector

Though, the Group achieved a y-o-y growth in revenue from all its verticals during the review period, the proportion of revenue contributed by the aerospace and defense vertical to the consolidated revenues remained more or less constant between 30-35%. Airline industry is seasonal and cyclical and was hit by the economic slowdown in the past. Therefore, going forward, any deterioration in the economic environment of the key markets of the Group could fairly affect the client?s operations in the aerospace vertical and thereby the revenues of the Group. As informed by the management, the Group foresees aerospace & defense vertical as an attractive area of investment. Increase in budget on security and defense of key nations coupled with increase in civil aircraft deliveries are key drivers for this vertical. The Group has established subsidiary in Israel to cater their defense opportunities. Also, the recent acquisitions of Rangons and Pratt & Whitney GSE division in Singapore was in line with foraying into manufacturing and maintenance & support services of defense and medical equipment, a forward integration to the service & solutions portfolio of the Group. Moreover in FY 2018, the Group acquired B&F Design Inc., a Connecticut based tooling and precision engineering company that focuses on the aerospace and defense industry. Any downturn in the industry can impact the revenue visibility of the Group.

US administration has tightened visa norms and resorted to other protectionist policies through a draft executive order to overhaul the H1B work-visa programme. The new norms entail modification of the roster of employees, thus requiring more onshore employees (locals to be hired), higher minimum salaries, composition of onsite vs offshore for various projects, and specific limits of H1B visas to be offered to companies leading to increase in costs for IT companies and impacting the margins. Moreover, recently the US administration announced a new policy that makes issuing of H1-B visas difficult for those employed at one or more third party worksites. The reforms may force Indian IT companies to make changes in their business strategies, including hiring more American workers and raising salaries they pay to employees working on client sites or sub-contract to US IT firms which will reduce operating margins to an extent. The Group has around 30% of the total employees working on-site. Any adverse changes in the law in U.S & other European countries towards outsourcing of work remains critical for the Group.

Promoter holding in the Company stood low at 22.74% as on 30th June 2019. Low promoter holding has the risk of management losing control in case of a takeover or inability of the management to expedite decision making in the Company.
High contingent liabilities largely in the form of corporate guarantees

The Company carries high off-balance sheet liabilities largely in the form of corporate guarantee. The total bank guarantee given by the Company to its subsidiaries as on 31st March 2019 is INR 10,157,000 thousand (on standalone basis) which is almost 46% of the Company?s standalone tangible networth. Any slowdown in business of the subsidiaries or any other event resulting in invocation of the bank or corporate guarantee, may lead to stress on the cash flows and financial position of the Company.

The Company faces competition from international players from America, Germany, Canada, South Korea, France, Turkey and India. Competition from organized and unorganized players may affect the margins of the Company. However, as informed by the management, exclusivity in pipe manufacturing, plus ability to provide low cost and with quality and one-stop solution for all the work such as designing and engineering, pre-fabrication, pipe fittings provides it a competitive edge over other players. Further, management also remarked, Company has invested in technology where it has installed two in-house robotic arm which offers joint free piping solutions provides competitive edge over others. Also, there are entry barriers in this industry are getting relevant approvals and association with a new client takes approximately 2-3 years. Moreover, the Company operates in a segment which requires major investments and technical qualifications which restricts the entry of new players.

The primary materials required by the Company for manufacturing are carbon steel, SS steel and others, prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average 55% of the revenue during the review period. Therefore, any significant increase in material cost will affect the margins adversely due to its limited ability to pass on the price hike to customers.

In FY 2019, DEE sourced around 70% of its raw material is sourced from international market and earned around 48% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing financial performance to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with a limited scope of natural hedge. Though imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transactions of INR 81,163 thousand and INR 133,573 thousand in FY 2017 and FY 2018 respectively, it incurred loss on foreign exchange transactions of INR 75,425 thousand in FY 2019. As indicated, the Company hedges around 60% of its net receivables by entering into forward contracts. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.
Corporate guarantee and loans extended to group entities which are yet to breakeven

The Company has three subsidiaries which are into manufacturing and fabrication. One of the subsidiary DEE Fabricom India Private Limited was set up only in FY 2019. In order to support the operations of its subsidiaries, the Company has extended loans to these companies to the tune of around INR 33 crore (against INR 18 crore in the preceding year) coupled with additional investments. Further, the Company has extended corporate guarantees to the tune of INR 75 crore. Since these subsidiaries are yet to break even, the operational performance of these companies and any higher than expected support from DEE would remain to be a sensitivity factor.
Profitability susceptible to volatility in prices of raw materials

The Company?s main raw materials comprise of rough diamonds, the supply and prices of which is controlled by large diamond miners in the world. Historically, the diamond market was dominated by De Beers which accounted for nearly 85% of the global diamond supplies. However, following the discovery of new mines in other countries like Russia, Australia and Canada and privatization of De Beers, the diamond prices are largely market driven, impacted by the demand and supply forces.

The other major raw material-gold is also influenced by macro-economic factors across the globe. Given, its limited bargaining power with suppliers, the Company?s competitiveness would depend on its ability to continue to sell diamonds at a premium through relations with suppliers and customers. On the other hand, despite increase in prices of rough diamonds over the past two years, improvement in prices of polished diamonds have resulted in steady margins for the Company. Nevertheless, DDPL?s margins remain susceptible to any adverse fluctuations in the raw material prices and its limited ability to pass on the same to the customers owing to competition.

The Company derives more than 80% of its total revenue from the international market and procures more than 90% of its raw materials also from the international market. As informed, most of its transactions are dollar denominated and it enjoys natural hedge considering most of its purchases and sales are in dollars. Further, it also borrows for working capital in dollars / other foreign currencies. However, as its reporting currency is INR, this exposes the profitability of the Company to fluctuations in exchange rate.
