Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though the Company tries to manage its risk via forward contracts for net open position and it enjoys a natural hedge to a large extent, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. This is reflected in the forex losses incurred by the Company during the review period.
Cyclicality in the diamond industry with weak market sentiments

The demand for diamond and diamond jewellery, being a discretionary spends, is largely cyclical. Diamonds are luxury item and consequently have a highly elastic demand in the market. Similarly, demand for jewellery is closely related to the economic cycles. Therefore, any slowdown in the major international markets like Europe, USA, China could adversely affect the demand (both domestic and export demand) for diamonds and diamond jewellery manufactured by the Company, thereby affecting its revenue. Approximately INR 1.66 trillion worth of cut / worked diamonds were exported from India in FY 2019. During the past five years (FY 2015-19), diamond exports exhibited cyclicality in terms of year-on-year change; dipping in FY 2016, increasing by 13% in FY 2017, and stagnating in FY 2018 before rising again in FY 2019. The industry has seen its ups and downs. During FY 2018, the weak market sentiments in the diamonds industry, resulting from the PNB scam during the last quarter of FY 2018 led to subdued revenue growth. The export of cut and polished diamonds improved only marginally by 0.39% during FY 2019 against the already weak performance of the industry in FY 2018. Further, in the first two months of FY 2020, cut and polished diamond declined by 16.32% to USD 3.52 billion from USD 4.21 billion registered during April to May of FY19 depicting overall gloomy scenario in the industry. Further, with banks tightening their lending to the diamond players, and given the large working capital requirements being funded through external borrowings, might have an impact on the overall business of the companies operating in the industry.

The diamond industry in India is largely unorganized and fragmented. Around 90% of the players operate in the unorganized sector mostly in family-run operations. The Company faces intense competition from several other diamond wholesalers operating in the industry. However, as informed, each player has its own specialized offerings which distinguish the two diamantaires. No two diamonds are the same and can be segregated into nearly 10,000 categories of different sizes, shapes, colors and clarities. Likewise, as informed, the Company specializes in round cut diamonds of sizes 0.30 cents to 5 carats. Also, as the business is largely based on long standing mutual business trust with the customers, the Company has an established customer base (a few of them large retail chains) which places repeat orders with the Company which partly mitigates the risk. Moreover, as informed, due to its long standing presence, the Company is also able to command a premium on its in-house certification diamonds provided to its customers.
Cyclical nature of demand and regulations for automobiles

The Company derives a bulk of its revenues from the automobile sector. The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend, is highly cyclical. Therefore, weak economic environment characterized by decline in per-capita income, high domestic inflation, increasing interest rates, weak industrial production, etc. (a scenario witnessed in FY 2013), could adversely affect the revenues of the Company. Indian economy is currently witnessing a slowdown. India?s economic growth fell to 5.8 per cent in the January-March period of FY 2019, the lowest in 20 quarters, due to a sharp slowdown in investment andÿmanufacturing growthÿas well as a contraction in agricultural production. Thus, automobile sector too has got impacted from the slowing growth in the economy. Higher cost of vehicles, weak consumer sentiments coupled with liquidity crisis stemming from NBFC defaults are the other factors effecting the auto sales. As informed, management too expects its revenue growth to moderate to 8-10% in the current year.

However, with expected implementation of BS VI norms from April 2020, the Company expects its volumes to increase backed by increase in number of electric components assembled in a vehicle under this norm.
Therefore, it can be seen that the demand and changes in regulation in the automobiles industry has impact on DTPL?s performance.

The Company operates in an intense competitive environment facing competition from both organized and unorganized units. Some of its nearest competitors in the organized sector are Motherson Sumi Systems Limited, Minda SAI Limited, etc. High Competitive intensity could restrict the pricing ability of the Company, putting pressure on its margins, especially in a rising prices scenario. The pricing ability of the Company could, further, get eroded from the fact that it derives a significant portion of its revenues from automobile OEMs which are themselves facing intense competition compelling them to cut back the costs of their products to remain profitable. However, the Company is amongst the large players in the wiring harness segment giving it a competitive advantage. It?s a single source supplier of wiring harness for clients like Royal Enfield and is largest supplier of components to Bajaj Auto Limited. Further, ahead of BS VI norms and start of electric vehicle, the Company has observed an uptick in order book from both the existing and prospective clients. It has added TVS group as a customer in FY 2020. TVS group has placed 50% of the wiring harness requirement to DIPL for its new BS VI compliant vehicles.
Adverse movement in the prices of raw materials

The principal raw materials required by the Company to carry on its manufacturing activities are cables (insulated copper wire), terminals (brass/copper made terminals), connectors (made from Nylon PVC), SF Harness, and copper. Cost of raw material constituted on an average around 72% of the revenue during the five year review period and therefore, going forward, any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials could affect the margins of the Company. It has limited ability to pass on the price hike due to high competitive intensity and strong bargaining power of OEMs, which constitute a major portion of the Company?s revenue. Nevertheless, as informed, the Company revisits its contracts on a quarterly basis and is able to pass on the change in raw material costs to its customers.

The ability of the Company to adapt to the changes made in the product designing by the OEMs to meet the progressive, safety, emission and other regulatory norms of their vehicles, remains very critical. Some of the newer vehicles launched in the Indian market (especially by the foreign OEMs) have demonstrated radical changes in the component designing aimed at providing greater comfort and safety feature to customers and meeting changing emission norms. Some of these designs could be disruptive, especially with regards to usage of wireless power transmission in futures. In this context, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the evolving specifications for its product viz. the wiring harness is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating the technological obsolescence risk. However, the mentioned risk is mitigated to a certain extent from the fact that the Company undertakes research & development activities to remain abreast with the recent technology trends.

The Group caters to both the domestic and the international regulated markets of USA and Europe. Hence, the manufacturing facilities of the group have to be in compliance with and certified by regulatory agencies like EUGMP, WHO GMP, USFDA, etc. These authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. Periodically, the US FDA conducts routine audits of all of its approved facilities and accordingly several of the group?s plants were recently inspected by US FDA. Though currently all the facilities of the group continue to be approved by the US FDA, cGMP, any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by US FDA or any other regulatory authorities, on any of the manufacturing facilities in future can significantly affect the revenues of the group.

The Group undertakes contract research for patent / license holders of either recently patented products or for their generic products to be marketed in the regulatory markets and supply of trial products. The future prospects in CRAMS is heavily relying on drugs going off-patent leading to a huge surge in generic product and tremendous opportunities for companies. The IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics points that patents on brands greater than USD 170 Billion are set to expire in developed markets till 2020. However, there is still no clarity on the exact dates as the US biologics patent law situation is still some distance away from being completely in place. There is a high probability that almost every biological patent and bio similar launch could be challenged in courts over the next few years. This could hamper the evolution of bio similar products in some way, going forward. Further, for some of the innovators, the Group is a preferred supplier. There might be fluctuations in order book in case innovator has multiple suppliers.

The pharmaceutical industry is highly fragmented with many domestic and global players. However, as informed, since the group is engaged in manufacturing NCE, which is a niche segment, it faces relatively lower competition. It faces competition from companies such as Albany Molecular Research Inc., Lonza Group, Patheon N.V, Bachem, Syngene International etc. Integrated manufacturing facilities, and strong research and development capabilities, as indicated, provides the group a competitive edge over its peers.

With the expected growth in the industry, players in the generic segment like Parabolic Drugs Limited, Aurobindo Pharma Limited, etc. have also started entering the CRAMS sector. Also, with expiry of some leading patents, some large companies, to keep in pace with biotech companies, are either making collaborations or acquisitions of biotech companies. This could create pricing pressure and negatively impact the Group?s margins.

The group derived nearly 98% of its revenue in FY 2019 from the international market exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Though, procurement of raw materials from overseas market (on an average at approximately 25% of the total purchases during the review period) could serve as a partial natural hedge, any volatility in exchange rates can have a significant impact on the margins of the Group. Movements in the exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates.

Moreover, the fact that there could be a timing difference between the procurement of imported raw materials and orders received from the customers exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. This can also be witnessed from the foreign exchange loss incurred by the Group throughout the review period except FY 2015. As informed by the management, the Group has hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk to the extent of 50% of net open positions. As informed by the management, the Group hedges its foreign exchange through forward contracts.
Uncertainty associated with successful product/process innovation going ahead

The Group spends on process R&D activity every year for executing the development of the molecule (CRS comprises of 65% of the total revenues). The results of research and development activities may not always be favorable and hence, benefits of such activities are uncertain. As informed, success rate of developing molecules is less than 1%. A New Chemical Entity (NCE) needs to go to through various clinical developments and it takes substantial time to successfully develop an NCE. Further, huge investment is made in the biosimilar space and there are challenges associated to continue to generate adequate returns on these investments in view of the uncertainty related to the development and approval process for generic equivalents.
Fragmented nature of industry resulting in a high degree of competition

Indian pharmaceutical sector, though organized, is highly fragmented in nature. Indian pharmaceutical market is characterized by generic formulation manufacturers, API manufacturers, and companies providing Contract Research and Manufacturing services. The industry is organized in nature with generic manufacturers enjoying a dominant position. Despite the stringent regulatory environment which poses an entry barrier, the sector has a large concentration of small and medium-sized manufacturing units. Also, the global pharmaceutical companies are beginning to focus on generic versions of drugs by acquiring leading Indian generic companies which further has increased the competition in the industry.

The industry is highly fragmented with ~10,563 pharma companies operating in the country. As the Company earns around 50% of its revenues from the manufacture of API and it faces strong competition from domestic pharma companies. This could create pricing pressure and negatively impact the Company?s margins.
Stringent regulatory approvals might impact the revenue stream

The Company keeps itself abreast of the various developments relating to the regulatory environment and gears itself in order to comply with such regulatory changes. The manufacturing facilities of the Company have to be regularly monitored and approved by various regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. The Company is in the process of pursuing US FDA approval which is very stringent and other regulatory authorities such as the European and Japanese authorities have also become more stringent.

Further, the Company as informed is the largest manufacturers of products including Trimethobenzamide, Probenecide, Vitamin D3, Lasamide, Fenofibric acid, PTS refined products etc. As informed, orders for Trimethobenzamide and Probenecide increased significantly during the review period (as restrictions are imposed on its production in China and European countries) and the same are manufactured by the Company under stringent compliance with regulations. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain continuously compliant with necessary regulations with necessary investment in its research and development and compliance process remains critical.

The US generic markets are characterized by buying bulk volumes at lower prices and tend to have price erosion historically. However, this pricing pressure on the USA generic business has intensified consolidation of distribution supply chain (trade partners) and faster ANDA approvals by USFDA especially post implementation of Generic Drug User Fee Act (GDUFA). The key consideration impacting generic prices has been faster ANDA approval leading to higher competitive intensity.ÿ The pace of ANDA approvals by USFDA has improved significantly from 440 in 2013 (October-September period) to 651 in 2016, 763 in 2017 and 781 in 2018. The increase was a result of implementation of Generic Drug User Fee Act (GDUFA) in October 2012. Further, with a large number of applications pending, the pace of approvals is likely to remain high. In addition to GDUFA, USFDA has taken several steps to increase competition in the market for prescription drugs and also facilitate entry of lower-cost alternatives through Drug Competition Action Plan.ÿWhile these initiatives benefit generic players, they are also likely to increase the competition for similar set of molecules. DRL derives majority of its revenues from the US market, hence,ÿincreasing competition in such markets and research & development cost will likely constrain the margin.

As far as the domestic market is concerned, branded generic drugs account for nearly 80% of the Indian pharmaceutical market by sales making it highly fragmented and competitive. The Group faces headwinds in India from government-mandated price reductions/policy changes coupled with competitive intensity. This will continue to pose a threat to its domestic operations. For instance, the Group?s overall growth for the domestic market was impacted by the temporary disruption in the trade channel due to the implementation of the Goods & Services Tax (GST) during FY 2018. Hence, the Group?s operations are vulnerable to the domestic comparative scenario and change in government policies.

The Group earned over 80% of revenue from exports business, thereby exposing it to currency rate fluctuation risk. Any adverse movements in the foreign exchange rates could have an impact on the margins. As informed, the group proactively uses hedging instruments e.g. forward contracts, options and other derivatives time to times. However, as informed it deals in multiple currencies as it has presence across the globe which makes it unviable to remain hedged at all times, thus exposing it to risk of foreign exchange rate fluctuation. The Group has reported forex losses in FY 2016 and FY 2017 but registered a profit for FY 2018.
Operations in certain countries susceptible to political and economic instability:

As the Company is increasing its sales in Latin America, Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union, Central Europe, Eastern Europe and South Africa, all of which may be more susceptible to political and economic instability. They need to monitor significant political, legal, regulatory and economic developments in these regions and attempt to mitigate exposure wherever possible. If not mitigated the international operations could be adversely affected by political, legal, regulatory and economic developments, such as changes in capital and exchange controls; expropriation and other restrictive government actions; intellectual property protection and remedy laws; trade regulations; procedures and actions affecting approval, production, pricing and marketing of, reimbursement for and access to our products; and intergovernmental disputes, including embargoes and/or military hostilities.
Also any opposition to free trade agreements and changes in trade policies of countries in which they operate could adversely affect the pricing and demand for their product

The Company derived around 88% of its revenue from international markets in FY 2019. In the absence of natural hedge, these exports leave the Company vulnerable to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though the Company tries to manage its risk via forward contracts, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such forward contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.
Risk of failure to adapt to new technology

If the Company fails to adapt to new technology to meet client needs and preferences, the demand for its services may contract. The Company?s businesses operate in an industry that is subject to rapid technological advances and changing client needs and preferences. Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the customers used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Then gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total IT Outsourcing? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes they earlier used to outsource. The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead, they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Further, owing to automation of processes and new machine learning capabilities, there is trend in IT companies to adopt these technologies and reduce its manpower cost to increase its efficiency in delivery. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology to remain competitive is critical. Any failure to adapt to the new technologies can negatively impact the Company?s business.

Employee cost is the major cost incurred by the Company and constituted on an average ~48% of the revenues of the Company during the review period driven by the manpower intensive business model of the sector. Therefore, increase in personnel costs due to increase in pay scales of the employees, could have an adverse effect on the margins of the Company. Going forward, the Company can also face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs in India and across other geographies due to economic recovery in the global market and/or adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to unemployment in those markets) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff. In the past, there have been uncertainties regarding US Government?s visa policies towards it non-immigrant and temporary visa programs such as the H1-B and L1 visas. Any adverse changes in the visa policy could prove detrimental for the Company leading to pressure on revenues and margins. Therefore, the ability of the Company to manage their personnel cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.

The employee attrition rate in the IT industry is quite high. The companies are not able to convincingly retain their employees for long and thereby suffer huge losses every time they have to train new employees. The cost of hiring a new employee and training that person for the job is again time consuming and expensive. Further, one of the major challenges in industry is to find the right talented workforce to work in the industry.
High competitive intensity of the auto component industry

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from a large number of organized/unorganized players in the domestic market and the international market. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in pricing pressure and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limit the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise to its customers. Since India is a cost-effective hub and is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East and Europe, global auto component players are increasingly adopting a dual-shore manufacturing model, using overseas facilities to manufacture few types of components and Indian facilities to manufacture the others. Therefore, the ability of the Company to sustain in the competitive environment remains crucial.

In FY 2019, the Company sourced around 75% of its raw material requirement and earned around 10% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing to an extent to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with limited scope of natural hedge. This exposes profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk which becomes more significant considering the high volatility of the INR in recent times. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though, imports and foreign currency borrowings could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transaction of INR 1,967 thousand in FY 2019, it incurred loss on foreign currency transactions of INR 2,261 thousand in FY 2017. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balance exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.
Susceptibility to trends and cyclicality of the automotive industry

The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend is highly cyclical. Indian automobile market is facing a tough outlook with sales declining by 18.42% during FY2020 Q1 compared to FY 2019 Q1 because of poor demand. The overall auto market is being impacted by inflation and constant hike in fuel prices along with the finance and liquidity crisis faced by the companies in the auto industry. Increased cost due to the transition from BS-IV norms to BS-VI norms has resulted in a sluggish market for the automotive industry. These unfavorable trends could adversely affect the demand for the Company?s products, thereby impacting the top line.

The pharmaceutical companies are regulated by different national as well as international regulatory authorities like Food & Drugs Administration, World Health Organization, The Central Drug Standards, and Control Organization, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, The National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority, and others. Although the drug has high growth market in India, in its recent guidelines on the Safety and efficacy of non-steroidal, anti-inflammatory drug, Indian Medical Association (IMA) has asked people to desist from using Paracetamol, saying that it cause more harm than good if taken without medical supervision. These authorities have policies and mechanisms to ensure control over the pricing, safety, and efficacy of the drugs. The Company has to keep itself abreast of the various developments relating to the regulatory environment and gears itself in order of the Comply with these regulatory standards. The manufacturing facilities of the Companies are regularly monitored and approved by various regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. Therefore, any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by the regulatory authorities, on any of the manufacturing facilities in the future can significantly affect the revenues of the Company.

In FY 2019, Farmson sourced around 7% of its raw material requirement and earns around 27% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing financial performance to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with a limited scope of natural hedge. Though imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transactions during the review period, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

The Company?s margins are susceptible to higher-than-expected pricing pressure, raw material cost inflation, and uncertainties in economic environment of the importing countries. Hence, gross margin remains vulnerable to fluctuations in raw material prices. Prices of key raw materials, have witnessed significant fluctuation in the past due to lower supply from China following shutdown of many plants (for environmental reasons). Hence, handling fluctuations in key raw material prices will be critical for the Company, given that material cost accounts for significant portion as percentage of total revenue.
Highly competitive coupled with raw material price volatility may put a strain on the margins

The textile industry is highly fragmented with few organized and a large number of unorganized players forming a significant portion of the total market. Also, the high level of fragmentation and low product differentiation has fueled further competition which is putting a strain on the margins of domestic companies. Moreover, foreign multinational companies with advanced technology are also expected to set up large infrastructure for manufacturing textiles in the country, intensifying the competition. High competition limits the pricing ability of the Company, thereby affecting its margins.

Also, as raw material cost constitutes around 50% to 60% of the revenue of the Company, any adverse movement in their prices can significantly affect the profitability of the Company. FY 2019 started with cotton prices of ~INR 39,000 per candy, but with the depreciating rupee, it touched price level of ~INR 48,000 during August 2018. With the season start in the second half of the financial year, cotton prices corrected and reached ~INR 41,000 levels in early-March 2019 but quickly rebounded to ~INR 43,000-levels by end of the March 2019. At present, the prices in August 2019 have reduced by ~26% when compared to August 2018 and are expected to further dim during the year. This indicates extreme volatility in the prices. Further, the Company also uses polyester yarn for its products the prices of which is dependent on crude oil prices which continue to remain volatile. As informed by the management, the inventory is backed by orders and FTL provides quote on the basis of the prevailing prices for every new order placed and hence is able to pass price volatility to its clients to some extent. However, the ability of the Company to maintain its margins amidst a high competitive scenario remains critical.

Majority of the revenues of the Company are derived from export market, whereas imports account for less than 5% of its total procurement indicating limited natural hedge. As such, it is exposed to adverse movements in foreign exchange rates. Further, since movement in exchange rates is determined by various macroeconomic factors beyond the control of the Company, the ability of the Company to hedge its foreign exchange risk remains critical. As informed by the management, the Company adopts a moving strategy to hedge depending on the prevailing forex rates and hence does not hedge its foreign exposure entirely.

However, the lack of a natural hedging mechanism and the absence of a complete hedging policy exposes profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk which becomes more significant considering the high volatility of the INR in recent times.

The Company caters to high end home textile segment. Customers of this business segment are generally fashion conscious. Moreover, leading players have started targeting the online space in their respective export regions and have increased focus on innovation to ensure demand. The Company needs to continuously innovate on products to ensure regularity of orders or may face product obsolescence risk. Any failure on part of the Company to keep abreast with the latest trends in the fashion industry may adversely affect its competitiveness and thereby the revenues.
Shift of business trend with E-commerce and Omni-channel models

E-commerce has been constantly evolving and growing over the past decade. More and more people are opting to shop online, while many new online businesses have penetrated the market. Retail e-commerce sales in the USA are projected to grow at a fast pace in the coming years, going from USD 505 billion in 2018 to over USD 735 billion in 2023. However, online sales still represent only a small share of all retail sales in the USA ? about 9.6% as of the third quarter of 2018.

Most of the big box retailers have been working on having an omni-channel presence with online portal, warehousing, pick and pack, dropship and analytics. Established retailers are realigning and restructuring their business models. They are aiming for significant cost savings from their supply chain. Additionally, the competition from e-commerce firms are resulting in price pressure. Therefore, few large retailers are cutting down on their inventory by moving to weekly orders rather than monthly, thereby passing on the working capital cost to their suppliers. There are frequent promotions at retail and the same is significantly increasing. Hence, industry is seeing build-up in pressure. Given the changing business trends, ability of FTL to continue to maintain established relationship and regular orders from its customers remains critical.

The Company derived its entire revenues from the domestic markets. However, it procured around 20-25% of its total raw materials from overseas, thus, being exposed to foreign exchange rate fluctuations. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Further, absence of any hedging mechanism and the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter). This, coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. The Company incurred loss on forex transactions till FY 2016, however FY 2017 and FY 2018 observed profits on forex transactions. In H1FY19, the Company incurred forex loss of approx. INR 7.43 crores. Depreciating value of the rupee resulted in higher cost of raw materials. As informed, the Company is able to pass on the forex movements but with a time lag.
Seasonality in demand amidst a highly competitive market with continuously evolving technology

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment plagued with seasonality. Apart from domestic competition, it faces stiff competition from Chinese players being a cheaper source for Indian OEM?s. Further, there exists a risk of backward integration from the larger customers of the Company. Continuous product updation and innovation also fuels the competition and limited bargaining power due to large customers results in squeezed margins. Thus, ability of the Company to improve its profitability in a rising competitive environment remains crucial.
Cyclicality in the automotive sector coupled with uncertainty driven by changing norms and market sentiments

The Company earns majority of its revenue through the automotive sector which in turn is dependent on the performance of the automobile sector. The demand for automobiles being a discretionary spend is highly cyclical. Therefore, deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to rising domestic inflation, demonetization, constant hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production, or a slowdown in the major international markets, could adversely affect the demand for automobiles and consequently products being manufactured by the Company, thereby affecting its revenue.

Furthermore, subdued demand coupled with changing emission norms and lack of clarity on electric vehicle (EV) policy has left the industry unsure of its future and has caused decline in future investments in the automotive industry. Further, any slump in demand will affect the performance of the OEMs and translate further to impact the performance of the vendors to these OEMs as well.

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment. The industry is fragmented with large number of organized and unorganized players. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limit the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise fully to its customers who mostly comprise of Tier I and OEM?s. Since India is a cost effective hub and is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East and Europe, global auto component players are increasingly adopting a dual-shore manufacturing model, using overseas facilities to manufacture few types of critical components and Indian facilities to manufacture the others. In addition, Indian manufacturers also face competition from cheaper Chinese substitute products.

The major raw material of the Company comprised of ABS plastics, chemicals and non-ferrous metals. Prices of ABS plastics and chemicals are susceptible to the erratic movement in crude oil prices / global demand & supply dynamics. Further, prices of non-ferrous metals are also a function of international movements and are highly volatile. The ability of the Company to pass on the rise in raw material prices remains critical. As informed, the Company hedges the movements in raw material prices and has quarterly price revision contracts with its customers for seamless passing on of prices.

The Company is engaged in the business of injection moulding and chrome plating for automobile industry. The ability of the Company, to adapt to the changes made in the product designing by the OEMs to meet the progressive, safety and other regulatory norms of their vehicles, remains very critical. Some of the newer vehicles launched in Indian market have demonstrated radical changes which are aimed at providing greater comfort and safety features. These changes could be disruptive with regards to usage of alternate materials or alternate manufacturing technology for the existing suppliers and poses a threat. In this context, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the evolving specification for its products is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating technological obsolescence risk and ensuring business continuity. Obsolescence of technology might affect the Company in terms of reduced revenue and lowered requirement from customers. The ability of the Company to manage these technology risk remains critical for the growth of the Company in the future.ÿ

The GHV group has been referred to in the charge sheet filed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) in the IL&FS investigation. There have been transactions of GHV group companies( GHV Hotel and GHV Hospitality) pertaining to loans being availed and advanced to IL&FS group companies. Any impact emanating from these investigations remains to be seen.

As informed by management, these transactions were examined by the investigating agency for round trapping & they have filed their charge sheet using GHV as a witness & the Group?s name is not mentioned as accused in such reports. However, there is no information in public domain representing the same.
Possible business impact due to ITNL being under SFIO (Serious Fraud Investigation Office) Investigation

IL&FS Transportation Networks Limited (ITNL), a wholly owned subsidiary of IL&FS was a customer of the Company till FY 2018. ITNL was the largest counterparty for GHV in FY 2018 and contributed about 60% of FY 2018 revenue and about 95% of receivables at end of FY 2018. With ITNL and its business dealings being a matter under investigation, ability of the Company to garner revenue from other customers remains critical. Also any impact emanating from these investigations remains to be seen. However, as informed, currently, the Company does not have any contracts or receivables with ITNL.
Risk associated with tender based operations in EPC industry

The Company remains exposed to inherent risks associated with tender based operations in EPC industry including aggressive bidding, interest rate risk, delay in project execution due to external factors and regulatory clearances. These challenges have collectively affected the credit profile of the EPC players in the past as well. In addition to this, it is difficult to predict whether or when a particular project would be awarded since most potential projects involve a lengthy and complex bidding and selection process that may be affected by a number of factors which include changes in market conditions, financing arrangements, government & regulatory approvals, environmental approvals, etc. While service quality, technical capability and work experience, financial strength, safety records as well as reputation & experience are important considerations in decisions, price is a major factor in most bid awards. Furthermore, given the intense competition in the industry, with all the players going for competitive bidding, the chances of securing the order (success rate) is constrained to a certain extent. Thus, improvement in the scale of operations and profitability levels remains critical amidst susceptibility to the tender based business operations.

The Company operates in a highly competitive industry and faces competition from a large number of domestic players. As informed, the Company has different competitors for its projects in different verticals such as Larsen & Toubro Construction Limited, Tata Projects Limited, IOT Infrastructure & Energy Services Limited, J Kumar Infra Projects Limited, Dilip Buildcon Limited, B.G. Shirke Construction Technology Private Limited, ITD Cementation India Limited, etc.

The growing opportunities in the domestic market makes it lucrative for multinational companies to enter the space which further fuels the competitive intensity. Highly competitive intensity could restrict the pricing ability of the Company which in turn could result in bids being submitted at lower prices, thereby adversely affecting the margins in a rising price scenario.
Time and cost overruns in the project coupled with subcontracting risk

The EPC projects of the Company face the risk of time and cost overruns. With inflationary pressures plaguing the domestic economy, time delays could lead to cost escalations. Further, the Company?s profitability is susceptible to price fluctuations in raw materials such as steel, cement, copper, zinc, etc. Prices of these commodities are decided by the interplay of global demand & supply factors, beyond the control of the Company. Change in the cost of raw materials cannot be passed on to the customer in case of fixed price contracts which exposes margins of the Company to these fluctuations in raw material costs. Therefore, the ability to either pass on the price hike by way of an escalation clause or keep itself insulated from any price rise through hedging mechanism remains critical.

Further, the Company subcontracts many of its activities which exposes it to risk associated with subcontracting such as lack of complete control on sub-contracted portion, execution quality of sub contracted portion etc., which may lead to time and cost overruns impacting the execution of the project and profitability derived from it.
Financial transactions with IL&FS which is under Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) investigation

GHV Hospitality (India) Private Limited had availed loan from IL&FS for construction of its hotel. During FY 2018, the Company had also advanced amount of INR 60 crore to ITNL (which is a subsidiary of IL&FS). GHV group has been referred to in theÿcharge sheet filed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) in the IL&FS?s investigation.ÿAny impact emanating from these investigations remains to be seen.

As informed by management, these transactions were examined by the investigating agency for round trapping & they have filed their charge sheet using GHV as a witness & the Group?s name is not mentioned as accused in such reports. ÿHowever, there is no information in public domain representing the same. Given the Company?s stretch liquidity position, repayment of these loans in case any demand arises from IL&FS seems difficult.

The Indian hotel industry is fragmented with a large number of players. The booming industry has attracted many international players like Hilton, Radisson, Marriott, Sheraton, Hyatt, Holiday Inn, Meridian, etc. who are well established in India. The competition is further fueled by new market makers who aggregate global demand and leverage market power to capture revenue and profit from incumbent players. Airbnb, Oyo Rooms and initiatives like CouchSurfing have changed the face of global hospitality. Pricing, location and convenience have converted many traditional hotel users to Airbnb clients which is in-turn is preferred by price conscious young travelers looking for new local experiences. These market makers include hotel and lodging companies (Oyo & Airbnb), media companies (google, trivago), online food delivery services (Swiggy) and online retailers. Larger hotels need to use their inventory in clever ways with the help of intelligent marketing while providing exceptional service at competitive rates.

Major concern for the hotel industry is related to multiple windows of clearances. Hoteliers face regulatory constraint at every step in the process of development of hotels beginning from land acquisition stage to approval by various ministries & association on various matters. A Company requires approximately 100 clearances for setting up an upscale category hotel in India. The clearances have to be taken from multiple government bodies which is tedious and a time-consuming process.
Lack of skilled employees and employee retention challenges

Indian hotels face the continual challenge of shortage of trained employees, especially at the manager and supervisor levels. Major reason for this shortage is absence of organized training and educational institutes for development of skilled employees like in aviation and other service sectors. Only few major Indian players like Taj, Oberoi and ITC have set up their training institutes with a few international brands like IHG, Carlson, etc. Also, hotel and catering management institutes approved by All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE) are less than adequate and much of the talent graduating each year is unsuited for direct employment in the industry due to lack of required skills.
Furthermore, retaining the trained workforce in the hotel industry is a tedious task since the employee attrition levels are high.

The Company operates in the mid to upscale hotel sector in India and the consumer demand is closely linked to the performance of the economy and is sensitive to business and personal discretionary spending levels. Economic growth drives business and leisure travel as well as conferences, banquets and events which impact the success of food and beverage operations.

In addition, the hotel industry and the demand for rooms is also affected by travel advisories, worldwide health concerns, geo-political developments, natural disasters in the region and inflation. Decline in consumer demand due to adverse general economic conditions, risks affecting or reducing travel patterns, lower consumer confidence and adverse political conditions can lower the revenues and profitability of the Company.

The GHV group has been referred to in the charge sheet filed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) in the IL&FS investigation. There have been transactions of GHV group companies (GHV Hotel and GHV Hospitality) pertaining to loans being availed and advanced to IL&FS group companies. Any impact emanating from these investigations remains to be seen.

As informed by management, the transactions were examined by the investigating agency for round trapping & they have filed their charge sheet using GHV as a witness & the Group?s name is not mentioned as accused in such reports. However, there is no information in public domain representing the same.

Indian hotels face the continual challenge of shortage of trained employees, especially at the manager and supervisor levels. Most of the companies are falling short of skilled employees for their hotels. Major reason for this shortage is absence of organized training and educational institutes for development of skilled employees like in aviation and other service sectors. Only few major Indian players like Taj, Oberoi and ITC have set up their training institutes with a few international brands like IHG, Carlson, etc. Also, hotel and catering management institutes approved by All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE) is less than adequate and much of the talent graduating each year is unsuited for direct employment in the industry due to lack of required skills.

Furthermore, retaining the trained workforce in the hotel industry is a tedious task since the employee attrition levels are high. One of the reasons for this is unattractive wage packages. Though the industry has been growing at a fast pace, hotel management graduates opt to join other sectors like aviation and catering services where they are paid higher.

The Company operates in the mid to upscale hotel sector in India and the consumer demand is closely linked to the performance of the economy and is sensitive to business and personal discretionary spending levels. Economic growth drives business and leisure travel as well as conferences, banquets and events which impact the success of our food and beverage operations.

In addition, the hotel industry and the demand for rooms is also affected by travel advisories, worldwide health concerns, geo-political developments, natural disasters in the region and inflation. Declines in consumer demand due to adverse general economic conditions, risks affecting or reducing travel patterns, lower consumer confidence and adverse political conditions can lower the revenues and profitability of the Company.

The Company derived around 90% of its revenue from international market and imported around 10% of its purchase requirements internationally, exposing it to foreign exchange fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies (relative to the USA) such as the BREXIT, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. The Company gained profit on foreign exchange transactions during the review period.

As informed by the management, the Company relies only on natural hedge and does not have any specific policy for hedging. Also, it does not enter into any forward contract or foreign currency loans which can enable the organization in mitigating foreign risk. Considering its exposure in international market and volatility experienced in foreign exchange market, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism becomes critical for the Company. Further, any adverse movement in currency rates may have a significant impact on the bottom line of the Company.
Fragmented nature of industry resulting in high degree of competition

The pharmaceutical industry is highly fragmented with a large number of companies operating in the country. As the Company earns majority of its revenues from the manufacture of formulations, it faces huge competition from domestic pharmaceutical companies. Now, even global pharmaceutical companies are beginning to focus on generic version of drugs by acquiring leading Indian generic companies which is likely to increase the competition in the industry further. This could create pricing pressure and negatively impact the Company?s margins.

Further, Indian pharmaceutical companies face cost disadvantage as compared to China, Korea and Taiwan, which offer low cost manufacturing base. This competition could further drive down prices for the Company?s products, thereby impacting its margins.

The manufacturing facilities of the Company have to be regularly monitored and approved by regulatory authorities. These authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. Though, the manufacturing facilities of the Company are currently approved by various regulatory authorities, any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by any regulatory authorities, going forward, on any of the manufacturing facilities can significantly affect the operations of the Company.

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from a large number of organized and unorganized players in the domestic market and international market. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. As informed, its long association with domestic and international customers and the quality of its products plays a pivotal role in competing with other players.

The primary raw material required by the Company for its manufacturing activities is steel. Its procurement of material grades of steel is done in accordance with specifications/standards provided by customers. The domestic prices of Steel follow international trends which in the long run are influenced by global demand and supply factors that are beyond the control of the Company. Since, raw material costs constituted on an average nearly 55% of its total revenue, any adverse movement in the price of raw materials could have an adverse impact on the Company?s margins unless it passes on the same to its customers owing to limited pricing power.

The ability of the Company, to adapt to the changes made in the product designing by the OEMs to meet the progressive, safety, emission and other regulatory norms of their vehicles, remains very critical. Some of the newer vehicles launched in the Indian market (especially by the foreign OEMs) have demonstrated radical changes in the component designing aimed at providing greater comfort and safety feature to customers and meeting changing emission norms. Some of these designs could be disruptive, especially, with regards to usage of alternate materials and alternate manufacturing technology, for the existing suppliers and pose a threat to the going concern nature of their business. In this context, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the evolving specifications for its products is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating technological obsolescence risk and ensuring business continuity.

For its project division, the Company faces competition from EPC players such as ISGEC Heavy Engineering Limited, Taikisha Engineering India Private Limited, Ram Kripal Singh Construction Private Limited, KEC International Limited,ÿMachine Tools India Limited, Engineering Projects India Limited amongst other large and mid-sized players in the market. Here, the business is entirely tender based and the Company has a success ratio of 50-60%. This segment has a high competitive intensity where the Company is relatively new and hence needs to undertake projects in collaboration with EPC players who have experience in civil work as the Company majorly undertakes the engineering/mechanical aspect of the contracts.

For its engineering division, the Company has strong market share which significantly limits competition in the domestic market. Its strong engineering capabilities, association with railways for over 40 years, and technical collaboration with renowned foreign players gives it a competitive edge. The Company has successfully adopted the technical know-how from foreign player and is able to manufacture products jointly with its foreign partners.

Given the competitive intensity, the ability of the Company to constantly innovate its products to meet the increasing standards and customer requirement will therefore remain crucial for further growth of the Company.
Susceptibility of the Company?s revenue and profitability to tender based contracts and intense competition therein

The contracts bagged by the Company are tender based in nature. As informed, the Company derives over almost entire business of the total revenue from Indian Railways which is entirely tender based. The government contracts are obtained via a process of bidding. Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent unpredictability in tender based business and intense competition amongst other players in bidding for such tenders.

HYT remains exposed to raw material price risks, mainly steel, cement, and other bought out items. The Company generally enters into back-to-back contract for raw material (RM) purchase thereby mitigating some impact of RM volatility. It procures most of its raw material from domestic suppliers. A limited pricing flexibility and a limited bargaining power with suppliers for EPC projects coupled with any adverse movement in raw material costs could directly affect the margins of the Company

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average around 62% of the revenue of the Company. Although marginal, the Company has witnessed y-o-y increase in the employee costs backed by increase in the head count. Going forward the Company can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs especially due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to increasing unemployment in those markets and changes in immigration policies) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff.

The attrition rate of the Company was 18.3% in FY 2019 which increased from 16.4% in FY 2018 which increased from 15% in FY 2017 and 13.6% in FY 2016. With both global & domestic economy slowly recovering from slowdown, there are numerous opportunities now available to the employees which could push up the attrition rate and hamper the execution of projects. Therefore, the ability of the Company to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the Company are Wipro Limited, Tata Consultancy Services, HCL Technologies Limited, Tech Mahindra, Cognizant etc. along with several mid-sized companies. Also, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destinations nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Therefore, the ability of the group to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical.

The Company derived on an average more than 97% of its revenues from international markets exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. While the Company uses foreign exchange forward and option contracts to hedge its exposures, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected / hedged by the Company and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Then gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total IT Outsourcing? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes they earlier used to outsource. The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.

Traditional IT services are getting commoditized. Also, the shift from traditional /classic IT projects to projects based on disruptive technologies leads to a lot of churn and investments in costly new resources, trainings. The life cycle of IT products has drastically reduced to less than 1 year. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.

Political backlash against outsourcing in key market of the group remains a threat. There have been instances, in the recent past, wherein the domestic IT companies have been asked by some states to go for local hiring. An example of the increasing backlash is changes proposed immigration norms announced by US President?s office. One being doubling the minimum salary requirement of H1B visa, which can push the cost of all the IT players. PresidentÿDonald Trump's 'America First' goal could affect the viability of the offshoring model adopted by Indian software companies. Thus, any adverse changes in the law of US or other European countries towards outsourcing of work remain critical.

Further, Indian pharmaceutical companies face cost disadvantages as compared to China, Korea and Taiwan, which offer low-cost manufacturing base. This competition could drive down prices for the Group?s products, thereby impacting its margins. Its major competitors are Sun Pharmaceuticals Industries Limited, Abbott Laboratories India Limited, Cipla Limited, Zydus Cadila Limited, Lupin Limited, etc. Nonetheless, having a market share of around 3.04% along with strong research and development and wide product portfolio catering to various therapeutic segments provides it a competitive edge against the other players.

In FY 2019, the Group sourced around 69% of its revenue from the overseas market. Further Also, the Group has availed foreign currency term loan of INR 35,351,320 thousand and working capital foreign currency loans of INR 52,839,000 thousand, thereby further increasing its forex exposure. Although, the Group enjoys a natural hedge to a certain extent. However, considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Group clocked profit on foreign exchange transactions during the review period, except in FY 2017. Hence, the ability of the Group to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

As informed, the Group has risk management policy in place and based on that Risk Management Committee decides the amount of net exposure to be hedged through forwards or forward derivatives. Hedging is done on net basis, i.e. export receivables are hedged on net basis after considering import and outstanding loan amount, thereby taking full advantage of natural hedge.

The Group spent around 5-6% of total revenue on research and development activity each year which exposes it to high failure risk. The results of research and development activities may not always be favourable and hence, benefits of such activities are uncertain. A New Chemical Entity (NCE) needs to undergo various clinical developments and it takes substantial time to successfully develop a NCE. Further, huge investment is made in the biosimilar space and there are challenges associated in continue to generate adequate returns on these investments in view of the uncertainty related to the development and approval process for generic equivalents. The return generated by the Group has fluctuated ? ROCE (Return on Capital Employed) between 24% to 31%.

The pharmaceutical sector is highly regulated with government authorities in India and abroad conducting stringent monitoring of manufacturing facilities and formulations. Authorities like US FDA and EU GMP have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance and quality checks. Increasingly, many pharma companies are withstanding the worst of actions of these authorities, sometimes as harsh as revoking the contract or banning the product from entering the country of export. Moreover, the Department of Pharmaceuticals (DoP), Government of India, has set up National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA), which will ensure price control and stability in the industry for new drug launches (APIs and formulations). Under the mechanism, the Government will keep a floor and ceiling price for new drugs introduced by any pharma Company.

Being into the pharmaceutical industry with major exposure in international regulated markets, the manufacturing facilities of the Group are regularly monitored and approved by the regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities have become more diligent with respect to the compliance and hence periodic audit is being conducted by US FDA authorities for all its approved facilities. During FY 2018 (July 2017), the US FDA issued 483 observations on the Moraiya plant of the Group on finding quality lapses related to good manufacturing practices. The US regulator had inspected the unit between 26th April and 10th May 2017. The group manufactures 17 biological products from the same plant. The observations made by the FDA include deficient laboratory records, inappropriate controls over computers, insufficient written records of investigations into unexplained discrepancies in batches, lack of proper control processes to validate causes of variability in characteristics of in-process material and drug product, and lack of written procedures to prevent microbiological contamination. As informed by the management, closures were received for all these observations and the Group received Establishment Inspection Report (EIR) during November 2019.

Major industry participants in LPO market include Clutch group, American Discovery, Amstar Litigation Support, Cobra Legal Solutions,ÿInfosys, QuisLex, Cogneesol, CPA Global, UnitedLex Corporation, Pangea3 LLC, Axiom Law, etc. The players are focusing on offering higher-value services such as supporting compliance management. They are expanding their offerings beyond litigation and regulatory investigation support services to contract management to offer varied services to their customers. In addition, these industry participants concentrate on process, people and geographic capability and strategic alliances to gain prominence.

Further, off lately there is an advent of Alternative Legal Service Providers (ALSPs), as a new breed of ?legal? providers with different economic models, structures, expertise, and DNA than traditional law firm partnerships. These ALSP?s include captive and independent legal process outsourcers (LPO?s), managed legal services, staffing companies, and accounting & audit firms. The genesis and evolution of ALSP?s is unmet legal consumer demand for value-driven, efficient, cost-effective, data-reliant, predictive, proactive, interdisciplinary solutions to customer challenges.

With increasing scope of work and presence of large organised players in the industry, the competitive intensity will continue to put pressure on margins in the medium to long term. Therefore, the ability of the Group to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical. However, sticky nature of contracts, partially annuity based business model and industry specific domain expertize reduces competition partially.

India has traditionally been a preferred outsourcing destination owing to its infrastructure and English speaking low cost talent pool for servicing advanced offshore assignments. However, off late, many other countries like Argentina, Mexico, China, Brazil, Philippines, etc. have also emerged as favoured destinations for outsourcing. The labour costs of these countries are similar/ lower than India which could pose a long term threat to India?s status as being a preferred outsourcing destination.

Further, the culture & language of some of these nations (like Philippines) is much similar to the USA and therefore these are now increasingly preferred by US companies. The same could result in some work getting transferred from India to other outsourcing destinations thereby adversely affecting the revenues of the Company. The group would also be required to continuously make investments in these countries to extend its offshore network.
Fairly competitive industry coupled with susceptibility of the Company?s revenue and profitability to tender based contracts and procedural delays resulting in deferral of orders

The Group operates in a fairly competitive environment facing competition from a large number of domestic and international players. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. The domestic competitors include players such as KEC International Limited and Kalpataru Power Transmission Limited etc. Further, as informed by management, it also faces competition from many overseas players. This competitive intensity may adversely affect the Company?s market share as well as may lead to bids being priced at lower rates thereby affecting its top line and profits. The contracts bagged by the Company are tender based in nature. Some of the organized players in the market which have relatively larger scale of operations also operate through tender based business. The government contracts are obtained via a process of bidding. Moreover, the revenues of the Company are vulnerable to deferral of orders. Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent volatility to the tender based business in the industry, as informed, robust designing and testing facilities provide the Company an edge against its competitors.

The Group carries high off balance sheet liabilities largely in the form of bank guarantee. The total bank guarantee given by the Group as on 31st March 2018 is INR 2,784,890 thousand which accounts for significant portion of its tangible networth. Further, other contingent liabilities stood at INR 888,330 thousand in FY 2018. Any slowdown in business or any other event resulting in invocation of the bank or corporate guarantee, may lead substantial stress on the cash flows and financial position of the Company.

The Company derived around 87% of its revenue from exports in FY 2018, thus exposing itself to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk though the same was mitigated by natural hedge. Moreover, the Company expects the revenue to increase from the international market thereby amplifying the risk of loss on foreign exchange transaction. Movements in the exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. The risk is evident from the fact that the Company has incurred foreign exchange loss to the extent of INR 14,797 thousand in FY 2016 and all the three financial years on consolidated levels.

The Company operates in a fairly competitive scenario. It faces competition from domestic players such as Voltas Limited, Indian Valve Private Limited, Triveni Equipments Private Limited as well as international players such as Huber Group, Sismat AS, Ham Baker Group, Biwater Inc., etc. This competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs.

As informed, diversified product base with latest technology and having its own manufacturing process (pattern making, foundry, machining, fabrication, inspection and in-house testing) that can cater to any order size with efficiency provides a competitive advantage edge to the Company over its competitors.

The major raw materials required by the Company for manufacturing are steel, stainless steel, cold roll steel, etc. The domestic prices of these commodities follow the international trends, in long run, which are influenced by the global demand and supply factors, which are beyond the control of the Company. The cost of materials and finished goods consumed constitutes to around 55% as a percentage of revenue on an average basis. Also as informed by the management, the Company is not in a position to pass on the escalation of the prices in its raw materials. This exposes the Company to the risk of volatile movement in the prices of raw materials, which can impact its margins as seen rangebound margins throughout the review period.

The Company operates in capital goods industry which is characterized by changes in government policies, economic conditions, demographic trends, employment & income levels and interest rates, among other factors. These factors, further, negatively affect the demand for and valuation of the projects under development and upcoming projects. The same was evident from stagnant revenue owing to stalling / postponing of projects by the clients following financial constraint faced by them.

Changes in the technology may make the newer products or services better and even cost effective. The Company could lose its market position unless it updates itself according to the new technology. It would require additional capital expenditure for the Company to upgrade itself to new and innovative technologies to have a competitive edge over other players in the industry. As informed by the management, the Company targets to collaborate with customers latest technology or strength in their markets in order to remain abreast to the latest technology which helps in mitigating the risk.

The Company is engaged in the manufacturing of steel and steel allied products. The primary raw material which the Company requires for its manufacturing activities is stainless steel along with other alloys, mild steel and other metals. Prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average 70% of the revenue of the Company.

This is evident from the financials of the Company. The gross profit margin of the Company depicted uneven trend during the review period owing to fluctuation in the cost of raw material and finished goods consumed.

The Company majorly caters to end user industries like chemical, refineries, fertilizers, textile, machinery manufacturers, oil & gas, white goods, machine components, medical, power transmission, wind mill, etc. Majority of these industries have cyclical demand owing high correlation with economic cycles. Short term deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to rising domestic inflation, constant hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production will adversely affect the demand for services provided by the Company as also impact the pricing and profitability of the end-products. Apart from the cyclicality of the end-user industries, heavy capital investment and a gestation of period of 2-3 years for a new plant also contribute to challenges in the industry.

The Company earned ~35% of the revenue from exports and procures ~21% of its raw material from the overseas market. This exposes the profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk with limited scope of natural hedge. Considering the volatility in exchange rates and limited natural hedge, the ability of the Company to mitigate the risk remains critical as movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Any adverse movements in dollar rates going ahead may have undesirable ramifications on the Company?s margins. As informed, Company hedges its forex risk by entering into forward contracts which partially mitigates the risk.
FTA misuse by China could pose a threat for domestic steel manufacturers

Chinese manufacturers are re-routing their products through the markets of other countries that India has Free Trade Agreements with, thus creating a surge in imports.
