Given the scale of the problem, government has attempted several steps such as imposing anti-dumping duties, countervailing duties, quality control and anti-circumvention measures but the problem still persists. New capacities in Indonesia riding on the back of Chinese investments also pose a threat to the domestic market. Thus, rising imports could pose a threat to the domestic steel manufacturers. Nevertheless, with a sharp INR depreciation in the recent months is likely to translate to higher landed cost of steel imports, which in turn would support domestic prices.
High competitive intensity in trading of both agro commodities as well as stone chips and boulders

The Company derives majority of its revenue from trading of agro commodities and stone chips and boulders. Markets for these products are highly competitive and require minimum capital investments leading to presence of large number of unorganized players. Further, while the agro commodities earned the Company ~93% of its revenue in FY 2018, the sector is populated with large organized players which have integrated backward as well as forward allowing them to capitalize on economies of scale. This has in turn led to high price competition in the market. With the current scale of operations of the Company in each of these products, it remains exposed to competition from numerous players.
Rising environmental awareness may hinder the growth in mining of stone chips and boulders as well as mining of sand

Mining of stone from hills and sand from sand ghats has a specific environmental impact which may affect geology as well as flora and fauna in the region. In recent times, various environmental groups have increased to protest against the same and various actions have been taken by the State Governments to limit the mining activities under their jurisdiction. Any such action taken in the vicinity of the Company?s operations may severely impact the supply of stone chips and boulders and thereby impact the turnover of the Company.
High geographical concentration risk with majority exports to Bangladesh

The Company obtains revenue from the domestic as well as export markets with exports contributing to more than 50% of the total revenue on an average. However, more than 90% of this export is made to Bangladesh. Therefore, exposing the Company to geographic concentration risk.

In FY 2018, the Company obtained majority of its revenue from export of rice to Bangladesh. During this period, the import duty on rice was reduced to 2% by the Bangladesh Government. However, subsequently in June 2018, the Government hiked this import duty to 28% which had an adverse effect on the Company?s revenue as well as margins and led to a drastic slowdown in the Company?s rice trade operations. As already seen, adverse regulatory policies from the Bangladesh Government therefore have had a direct impact on the Company?s performance. Therefore, going forward, the ability of the Company to diversify its geographic reach will remain crucial.
Ability to manage manpower costs and attrition risks

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average 65% of the consolidated revenue of the group. Its attrition rate stood at 18% and as informed, the group continuously faces headwind in terms of retaining talent. Therefore, the ability of the group to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical. Going forward the group can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs especially due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets. However, JKT has started hiring from Tier-I institutes and lateral hiring to add quality talent pool. Also, it has increased incentives to employees by giving them opportunities to handle multiple projects. These measures are expected to retain quality talent coupled with increased revenue through the revised incentive model.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the Group are tier III IT companies, etc. along with several mid-size companies who have developed a domain/vertical specific expertise. Also the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destinations nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Therefore, the ability of the group to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical. Setting up of offshore delivery centers in India by some global IT players, pose a challenge to the Group?s efforts to attract and retain talent.

The group derived on an average around87% of its revenue from international markets during the review period exposing it to foreign exchange risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though the group tries to manage its risk via derivatives, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the group and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Then gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total IT Outsourcing? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes they earlier used to outsource. The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network.

Traditional IT services are getting commoditized. Also, the shift from traditional /classic IT projects to projects based on disruptive technologies leads to a lot of churn and investments in costly new resources, trainings, etc. The life cycle of IT products has drastically reduced to less than 1 year. Therefore, the ability of the group to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.
Exposure to risk arising from realization of off-balance sheet liabilities

The Company has large outstanding off-balance sheet liabilities in the form of bank and corporate guarantees provided for self and for its subsidiaries. The Company has outstanding letter of credit and bank guarantees amounting to INR 1,179,270 thousand for self and has outstanding standby letter or credit, bank guarantee and corporate guarantee outstanding amounting to EUR 15,000 thousand provided for its subsidiaries. Besides these it has other off-balance sheet liabilities of INR 113,075 thousand. Realization of any major liability from amongst these may significantly impact the overall liquidity position of the Company.

The Company derives nearly 15-20% of its revenue from exports and also has a subsidiary in France with which it has substantial financial transactions. This exposes the Company to foreign exchange fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Any adverse movement in the foreign exchange rates could affect the top line as well as bottom line which can be witnessed from loss incurred on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2019. Any unhedged exposure could have a negative impact on the margins. However, the Company has foreign currency packing credit and buyers credit arrangements as also has the leisure to manage its foreign currency transactions through subsidiaries to suite its needs. This mitigates its foreign currency risk to a large exchange.
Competitive intensity arising from entry of large international players in the domestic market

While Jyoti is a key player in the domestic market, the expected development in the Indian consumer market and the manufacturer and investment friendly initiatives promoted by the government to attract foreign investment, may lead to entry of global giants in the Indian market. Major players like Amada Co. Ltd., Amera Seiki, Fanuc Corporation, Datron AG, DMG Mori, Dalian Machine Tool Group (DMTG) Corporation, Haas Automation Inc., Okuma Corporation, Shenyang Machine Tool Co. Ltd. (SMTCL), Hurco Companies Inc., Yamazaki Mazak Corporation, among others have established global presence and sufficient resources to wage price wars in the domestic market on their entrance. The Company may face high competition from these players.

With the advent of modern management techniques and break-through presented in the Information Technology space like IoT and AI, it is very apparent that expensive machinery like CNC machines are bound to rapidly change technologically to accommodate more and more efficiency and effectiveness. This will require continuous innovation on the part of manufacturers. The Company?s ability to keep pace with large global manufacturers in this space will remain crucial for its future growth prospects.

The performance of the machine tool sector as also the CNC machine industry is dependent on the global investment cycle. Any slowdown in investment in new projects usually results in a simultaneous slowdown in demand for the product. Given the high uncertainty on global demand due to a number of factors including Brexit and waging trade wars between USA and other countries, GDP growth rates for several advanced and developing countries have seen a slowdown in recent times. Demand for the Company?s products may reduce in such a scenario.

Forging industry is highly fragmented owing to low entry barriers and is concentrated in around the major auto belt clusters in Maharashtra, Punjab, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Haryana, Delhi, Karnataka, Jharkhand, West Bengal and Andhra Pradesh. The Company faces competition from the other forged players located in and around Jalandhar manufacturing the similar product line and catering to OEM?s. In addition, it faces threat from any new entrants. Further, the Company is a Tier I and Tier II supplier to the OEM and has limited pricing flexibility with them. OEM?s themselves are facing stiff competition compelling them to cut back the costs of their products to remain profitable.

As informed, Company?s long standing presence and strong relations with the customers like Honda and TVS group gives it an edge over other peers. Company is also a single source supplier of crankshaft assembly to TVS group at Hosur (has set up dedicated plants for TVS group) gaining a competitive advantage.

The primary raw materials required by the Company for its manufacturing activities are iron and steel. The domestic prices of these commodities follow international trends which in the long run are influenced by global demand and supply factors that are beyond the control of the Company. Since raw material costs constitute on an average nearly 60% of its total revenue, any adverse movement in the price of raw materials could have an adverse impact on the Company?s margins. As informed, any high raw material price increase is compensated by the OEM?s but the selling price revisions are with a lag.

The demand for automobiles being a discretionary spend is highly cyclical. Therefore, deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to rising domestic inflation, demonetization, constant hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production, or a slowdown in the major international markets, could adversely affect the demand for automobiles and consequently products being manufactured by the Company, thereby affecting its revenue. The two wheeler industry is expected to grow at a modest space on back of increasing cost of purchase due to rising raw material prices, hike in insurance premiums, rise in interest rates.
Gradual transition from internal combustion engine to electric vehicle could impact the demand of engine & transmission component

With the gradual transition fromÿinternal combustion engineÿtoÿelectric vehicles, there would be a lesser requirement of some of the engine products which will get replaced by an electric motor. The Company is likely to have the impact, as their current portfolio will be impacted by the electric vehicles. Kay Jay is majorly into two wheelers and the planned target to launch the same on a mass scale by the government in FY 2030 which is far-fetched.

ER&D sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs on an average constituted nearly 63% of the total revenues of the Company in FY 2018. The employee cost of the Company increased during FY 2018 on account of increase in the head-count coupled with annual increments. Nevertheless, employee utilization rate remained comfortable at 77.8% during the same period. Increase in personnel costs could be due increase in pay scales following the improvement in the domestic economic environment, hiring of local staff, temporary retention of client staff, etc. However, the utilization improved to 80.2% in FY 2019 with significant revenue growth.

The attrition rate of the Company remained moderate visa vis other peers in ITES space, however, increased in Q1 FY 2020, stood at 15.8% visa vis 14.8% in Q4 FY 2019. Thus, the ability of the Company to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical. The employee utilization rate (calculated as individual?s total billed hours divided by total available/billable hours) in the three year ended FY 2017, FY 2018 and FY 2019 was 75.1% and 77.8% and 80.20% respectively.

Going forward, the Company can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs primarily due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to increasing unemployment in those markets) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff. Thus the Company?s ability to manage personal cost while increasing scale remains critical.
Reduction in outsourced ER&D or R&D budgets of existing and prospective customers could affect pricing and volume of work

Over the past few years, many corporations have adopted a policy of rationalizing their use of external ER&D service providers and performing R&D functions in-house and this trend may continue going forward. Moreover, from time to time, negative experiences associated with offshore outsourcing, such as theft and misappropriation of sensitive customer data, have been publicized, including reports involving service providers based in India. This may result in the customers deciding to reduce or stop outsourced ER&D that may affect its growth prospects. Further, its current or prospective customers may elect to perform certain services themselves or may be discouraged from transferring services from onshore to offshore service providers including to avoid harmful publicity. Any slowdown or reversal of existing industry trends towards offshore outsourcing would harm the ability to compete effectively with competitors that provide services from within the countries in which the customers operate.

Further the growth of the ER&D industry is linked to the outsourced R&D expenditures and budgets of the customers. Trends in R&D budgets are exposed to general macroeconomic factors and also to demand and production trends in industrial sectors. In the recent past, companies in certain sectors (such as oil and gas) have reduced their R&D budgets due to unfavourable macroeconomic and production trends that have exerted pressure on their margins. This is evident from process industry witnessing a de-growth of 13.5% in FY 2017 and a marginal decline of around 3% in FY 2018 due to drop in oil prices and weak global demand amid concerns over slowing economic growth around the world has affected the capital expenditure spend of energy.

Also, if the Company?s existing or prospective customers decide to use their captive research and development centres for their ER&D services and reduce their budgets for external ER&D service providers, it could lead to a reduction in the volumes of work thereby adversely affecting its business and financial profile. Further, as informed by the management, generally it takes longer time to onboard a new customer as the benefits of outsourcing R&D work which is core to client?s business are more complex to determine and are for longer term. Further, the contract value at the initial stages will be low considering the above apprehensions.

LTTS operates in an intensely competitive industry that experiences rapid technological developments, changes in industry standards and changes in customer requirements. LTTS?s competitors include large ER&D consulting and technology firms globally, divisions of large multinational information technology firms and in-house ER&D departments of large corporations, in addition to numerous smaller local competitors in the various geographic markets in which the Company operates. The ER&D industry is experiencing rapid changes that are affecting the competitive landscape. The Company may face competition as a result of vertical integration owing to consolidation activity among global technology majors, hardware manufacturers, software companies and vendors and service providers.

The Company also faces competition from ER&D firms with operations in other countries and regions, such as China, Vietnam, Ireland, Morocco, Eastern Europe and Latin America, which have competitive cost structures. Further, some of the competitors that provide both IT and ER&D services may be able to provide bundled services that may be cost-effective for its customers. Also the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is also becoming less relevant with the global majors significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destinations nature. This may fuel competition further including competition for skilled technology professionals and pricing pressure from competitors employing an on-site/ offshore business model.

Few of the competitors include Pure play Indian ESO: Cyient Limited, Tata Elxsi Limited, QuEST Global Services Pte. Limited (India Operations); Pure play Global ESO: Altran Group, ALTEN Group, Akka Technologies, Assystem Technologies India Private Limited; and other international, national, regional and local ESO/ER&R/PES firms from a variety of market segments. In addition to the pure play Indian and global ESO players, the Company also faces competition from the ER&D divisions of Indian IT Services firms such as HCL Technologies Limited, Wipro Limited, Tech Mahindra Limited, Tata Consultancy Services Limited and in-house ER&D departments of large corporations. Therefore, the ability of the Company to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical.

However, as informed, LTTS?s domain and technology capabilities (it has 111 owned patents and 288 co-authored patents), scale, multi-vertical presence, specialization, practice maturity, and focus on innovation and IP, combined innovative and complex projects experience, long standing client relationships and past track record retaining highly skilled employees provides the Company with a competitive advantage over other players in the ER&D space.
The Company on an average derives more than 85% of its revenues from international markets exposing it
to foreign exchange risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/
supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies

relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are difficult to predict given the inherent complexities and dependencies involved in their assessment leading to a plausible volatility in exchange rates.

Though the Company actively manages its risk primarily via forward contracts, and around 70% of the revenue is dollar denominated, the fact that there could be a variation - both from a quantum and time perspective, in the cash flows being projected / hedged / actually received by the Company exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, given the relatively volatile exchange rates being witnessed for a while. As indicated on a reasonable estimate basis, a 1% fluctuation in forex has an effect of 0.25-0.30% change in the EBITDA margins.
Fairly competitive market with susceptibility of revenue and profitability to tender based contracts

The Company operates in a fairly competitive environment facing competition from a large number of domestic and international players. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. Competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This competitive intensity may adversely affect the Company?s market share as well as may lead to bids being priced at lower rates thereby affecting its topline and profits.

As informed, the Company is in direct competition with McNally Bharat Engineering Company Limited, Elcon Engineering Company Limited, The Indure Private Limited, Beumer India Private Limited and others for providing end to end solutions to the customers. As informed, weak demand for the products of the Company resulted in bids being quoted at very low rates which adversely affected the margins of the Company during the review period. The Company derives majority of the revenue from infrastructure contractors which bid for various government tenders. Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent volatility to the tender based business in the industry. As indicated, adherence to timelines, and quality provides the Company with a competitive edge over its peers.

The Company has given counter guarantees in respect of guarantees and letter of credit issued by the banks amounting INR 5,149,857 thousand (approximately 2.5 times of the tangible networth of MBPL). The customer?s collect 10% of the project value as retention money which is received only after completion of contract. As informed, there has been no instance of invocation of bank guarantees so far. However, an adverse event of the aforesaid liability being invoked, even in part, would result in a substantial stress on the cash flows and financial position of the Company.
Cost overruns and delays and adverse changes in government policies

In material handling industry, risk of time and cost overruns are transferred to contractors and the onus of executing the project lies with vendors. Since majority of the orders received by the Company are on tender basis; it faces high competition in terms of pricing of products and services.

Additionally, the Company participates in tenders in which there are multiple vendors and thus has higher chances of delays in project execution leading to a significant time lag between the procurement stage and actual completion stage. As informed by the management, since the typical billing schedule comprises of payments after specific milestones any delay in installation and commissioning may increase the instances of cost overruns thus affecting the profitability of the Company. With inflationary pressures plaguing the Indian economy, time delays could lead to cost escalation.

Further, considering the nature of operations of the end customers (i.e. dependence on the policies of the government related to infrastructure development and procedural delays in government projects) and resultant volatility in revenue, it can be observed that operations of the Company is exposed to unpredicted risk of changes in policies of the Government.

The primary raw material required by the Company for manufacturing equipment?s is steel. The domestic prices of these commodities (viz. steel) follow the international trends, which are influenced by the global demand and supply factors, leading to volatility in prices. As informed, since most of the contracts are fixed price and raw material costs constitute on an average nearly 60% of the total revenues, any volatility in the price of raw materials, could have an adverse impact on Company?s margins considering the limited ability to pass on the volatility to its customers. This can be seen in an uneven trend in the profitability of the Company during the review period.

The Company faces intense competition from both small/mid and large size players in the market. Some of the large players in the organized segment include CCI, Finolex Cables Ltd, KEI Industries Ltd and Havells India Ltd amongst others. Also, it faces competition from MNC?s setting up their base in India or Indian companies collaborating with the overseas player to acquire new technologies and expanding customer base. High competition limits the bargaining power with the customers and constantly puts pressure on the margins and revenues of the Company.

The main raw materials required for manufacturing is aluminium, steel and copper. Prices of these commodities are influenced by global demand and supply factors which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material comprised of nearly 88% of the revenues during FY 2018. Also, the Company has limited ability to pass on any increase in raw materials to the customers due to high competition which could adversely impact the margins further.

The Company derives around 60% of its total revenue from the overseas market thus exposing it to foreign exchange risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates.

Thus, ability of the Company to hedge the un-hedged exposure, amidst volatile exchange rates, remains critical. However, as informed by the management the Company covers its foreign currency rate fluctuation risk by entering into forward contracts.

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average around 60% of the revenue of the group during the review period. The industry also witnessed a high attrition rate owing to numerous growth opportunities available in the domestic market. Its employee utilization rate for onsite is high at about 93% to 99%, however the offshore is about 83% to 92%. Therefore, the ability of the group to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical. Going forward the group can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs, especially due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to increasing unemployment in those markets) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff. Presently, around 55% of revenue is derived from onshore contracts with the balance 45% from offshore.

The attrition rate of the group was 20% in FY 2019. With both global & domestic economies slowly recovering from slowdown, there are numerous opportunities now available to the employees which could push up the attrition rate and hamper the execution of projects. Therefore, the ability of the group to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the group are Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Infosys Limited, HCL Technologies Limited, Wipro Limited, Tech Mahindra Limited, Cognizant, etc. along with several mid-size companies who develop a domain/vertical or a service specific expertise. There are about 11 large players and about 120-150 mid-sized companies which account for nearly 80% of the total industry revenue. Also, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destination nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware, but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition.

The risk gets accentuated from the fact that the group derives a significant portion of its revenue (around 60% on an average during the review period) from commoditized services, viz. application development, application maintenance & other services, customer services, etc., which relatively have higher competition. Though, the group is trying to mitigate the impact of competition by entering into specialized service domains, its ability to maintain revenue and profitability, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical.
Susceptible to deterioration in the economic environment of key markets

Around 87% of the group?s revenue was derived from North America and EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa) markets during FY 2018. Although, the economy has recovered mostly, high accumulated debt of USA (resulting in high fiscal deficit) could deteriorate short term economic environment. In such environment, the clients start cutting on discretionary IT spends resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiate the contract value resulting in pressure on margins. Further, the US administration has tightened norms and resorted to other protectionist policies through a draft executive order to overhaul the H1B work-visa programme. The new norms entail modification of the roster of employees, thus requiring more onshore employees (locals to be hired), minimum salaries increased to 130,000 USD, composition of onsite vs offshore for various projects, and specific limits of H1B visas to be offered to companies leading to increase in costs for IT companies and impacting the margins.

The reforms may force Indian IT companies to make changes in their business strategies, including hiring more American workers and raising salaries they pay to employees working on client sites or sub-contract to US IT firms which will reduce operating margins to an extent. Any adverse changes in the law in U.S & other European countries towards outsourcing of work remain critical.

Information technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Thereafter gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes.

The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead, they try to share the resources, applications, software etc. of any service provider over the network. Further, new disruptive technologies like SMAC and innovations by startups which develop niche technology solutions, generate uncertainty regarding predictability of the business models and incremental demand from product differentiations. Therefore, it is imperative for the Group to continuously innovate to ramp up its operations.

The group derives a significant portion of its revenue from overseas market (mainly in USD/Euro) while a substantial portion of its total costs are in INR (owing to a significant portion of employees based out of India), exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. The group has sought to reduce the effect of foreign exchange risk arising from the exposures on our results by purchasing forward foreign exchange contracts. These contracts are entered into in a systematic manner over the lifecycle of the exposure. In Q3-18, the hedge policy was amended to extend the maturity of the hedges from 1 year to 2 years. The outstanding hedges have maturities of upto 24 months. The hedges are taken on a monthly basis and as informed, the group hedges 60% of the total exposure expected to be received over the next twelve months.

Though the group tries to manage its risk via forward contracts (i.e. by entering into hedges following a layered approach), the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the group and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses on such forward contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.
Profitability susceptible to volatility in raw material prices

The Group is engaged in trading of iron ore, steel, coal, ferrous scrap, non-ferrous scrap, etc. Prices of these commodities are influenced by global demand and supply factors which are beyond the control of the Group. Therefore, any adverse movement in prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Group, considering the fact that cost of materials and traded goods account for around 90% of revenues of the Group. Therefore, the Group maintains a minimum inventory holding of around a month and as informed, it enters into back-to-back contracts to shield itself from high volatility in the commodity prices.
High competition may add pressure on the margins of the Group

The market for metal scrap collection and trading is fragmented with a few large players. Majority of the players are regional in nature and of small in size. In the organized sector, MSTC Limited and Ferro Scrap Nigam Limited (FSNL) are two of the notable players. Entry barriers being low, emergence of new regional players may put pressure on the margins of the Group. As informed, the Group has long relations with its customers and provides value added services like testing of composition of the material, cutting oversized material, bundling loose scrap for convenience of the foundries (customers) which partly mitigates risk from new players.
Revenues susceptible to cyclicality in the steel industry

Steel consumption is highly cyclical and generally follows economic sentiment and industrial conditions both worldwide and in regional markets. The steel industry has historically been characterized by excess world supply, which has led to substantial price decreases during periods of economic weakness. The current economic downturn has decreased the demand for steel products and is negatively affecting the profitability and cash flow of the steel producers / traders. Substitute materials are increasingly available for many steel products, which further reduces demand for steel.

In India, scrap imports account for approximately 85% of the total raw material requirement. This exposes recyclers to several risks such as currency fluctuations, volatility in prices of scrap globally, upfront cash payment for settlement of trades (leading to working capital crunch), higher turnaround time etc. Also, with high reliance on imports, any potential upward revision in duty structure (for scrap) may impact recyclers profitability negatively.

The Group has extended significant amount of corporate guarantees for its subsidiaries. The total contingent liability as on 31st March 2019 stood at INR 234 Crores. Amount of guarantees extended are high as compared to its tangible networth of INR 3,004,077 thousand as on 31st March 2019 (about 0.78 times the total net worth size). Hence, crystallization of any of these guarantees could have a significantly adverse impact on financial risk profile of the Group.
Raw material price volatility could affect the profitability metrics

The Company?s primary raw material, chrome steel, is imported from South Korea. Total purchase from South Korea forms about a one third portion of the total raw material requirement. Other raw materials include metals such as stainless steel, brass, and aluminium. Prices of metals are highly volatile in nature and follows trend in commodity markets like London Metal Exchange (LME) for price derivations and adjustments. Currently, the average raw material cost is about 60% of revenue during the review period.

As informed the Company enjoys complete pass through of any fluctuations as the prices are directly negotiated by the customer of NHB (mainly MNCs). Also, as indicated, going forward, the Company will increase its sourcing requirement from Toyota Tsusho India Private Limited (TTIPL) which is a large steel importer. TTIPL being a large player enjoy a better bargaining power with the steel producers which will in turn will help the Company save on cost. Also, the currency risk will be reduced due to billing in domestic currency. The overall saving in cost estimated is roughly 5-7% TTIPL.
Though the prices remain protected, the corrections made are with a lag as prices are reset quarterly by the customers. This in the interim could impact the profitability of the Company.

The Company is exposed to foreign currency rate fluctuation risk as import constitutes 70% of total purchases and exports form 20% of total revenues in FY 2019. The Company mainly caters to economies such as United States of America (USA), United Kingdom (UK), Europe, Italy, China, and South Korea amongst others. These economies are subject to various macro-economic factors such as volatility in exchange rates, inflation/recession, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies, government regulations, trade restrictions etc.

Considering its major exposure to the international market and the current volatility in the foreign exchange market, undertaking proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange currency fluctuation risk becomes critical for the Company.

As informed by the management, the Company enjoys a complete pass through of any fluctuations (including foreign exchange rate increase) as the supplier?s prices are negotiated by the Company?s customers (mostly MNCs). Currently, the Company is booking forward cover for 20% of the total exposure to shield against foreign currency movement. For better management of financial resource, Company has hired an advisory firm Incorp based out of Singapore who advises the Company on raising finance, hedging of forex exposure etc. However, the ability of the Company to manage its exposure in foreign currency through forward covers and pass on the exchange rate price rise to the customer remains critical.

The Company does not have manufacturing facilities of its own and outsources the production to third party manufacturers, which exposes it to sub-contracting risk. The aforesaid business model results in Company having substantial dependence on manufacturers for efficient conduct of its operations and exposes it to sub-contracting risk. The Company also faces the risk of its contractors not being able to scale their capabilities in accordance with the increase in its scale of operations or deficiencies in the quality control methods being followed by the sub-contractors resulting in adverse regulatory action on their manufacturing facilities, thereby, disrupting the consistency in supplies to the Company?s customers. However as informed by management the Company deals in specialized products and has long term agreements with manufacturers for selling and marketing those products in various markets. Further there is strategy of quantities, customers and prices which are discussed with the manufacturing plants for current and future requirements.ÿ The relations with existing manufacturing plants are based on legal documented agreements and contracts are prepared with manufacturing plants to ensure there is no disputes in future. This close relationship with vendors reduces the threat to a certain extent for the Company.

The Company operates in the pharmaceutical industry which is highly regulated and governed by quality norms, patent legislations as well as pricing policies. Though the Company outsources the manufacturing activities, the manufacturers need to ensure compliance of regulatory norms at their facilities. With the focus of the regulatory authorities on the manufacturing processes of the Indian Pharmaceutical exporters and their ability to meet the stringent norms has caused various firms to receive observations. Due to these observations, certain companies have been restrained to export to regulated markets, thus affecting the revenue growth and the profitability of those manufacturers. Thus, the Company indirectly is exposed to regulatory risk.

The Company derives almost entire revenue from exports there by exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Further, it procured around entire portion of traded goods from domestic market thereby limiting any scope of natural hedge. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Considering the volatility in exchange rates and limited natural hedge, the ability of the Company to mitigate the risk remains critical. The Company incurred forex loss in the tune of INR 3,312 thousand during FY 2019.

The primary raw material for some of the chemicals sold by the Company is crude oil, prices of which are determined by macro factors like global demand for fuel, quantum of production by the OPEC nations, speculative built up of the prices through forwards, political scenario in the Middle East countries, opening and closing inventories, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict which leads to volatility in the prices of crude oil and thereby of the chemicals manufactured from it. Therefore, it is very difficult to pass on the change in costs of these chemicals to the customers. Hence, any adverse movements in the prices of crude, going forward, could significantly affect the profitability of the Company especially, when it wants to increase the share of polymers (petrochemicals) in its future revenues.
Moderate scale of operations in the competitive industry

The Indian chemical industry is highly fragmented with the presence of large number of unorganized players. The Company has a wide product portfolio and competes with various companies like Alkyl Amines Chemicals Limited, PI Industries Limited, Anupam Rasayan India Limited, Hikal Limited, Laxmi Organic Industries Limited and Omkar Speciality Chemicals Limited amongst others in the respective product categories. As informed, the Company trades/manufactures in the chemicals that have limited/no availability in the domestic market and the exclusive distributorship of some chemicals give it an edge over others. Also, the long relationship and contracts (normally ranges from 1-3 years) with the principal suppliers ensures regular supplies. However, the Company remains a moderate scale player in a highly competitive industry with limited bargaining power with the supplier and customers. This could restrict the ability of the Company to scale its volumes and pass on the price hike to its customers (owing to pricing pressures), and could have an effect on its revenues and profitability.

About 55% of the total purchases comprise of imports against which the exports are about 27% of total revenues thus providing limited natural hedge. The Company is exposed to foreign currency fluctuation risk to the extent of unhedged amount. Though, the Company has earned profit on forex transactions throughout the review period, any loss arising from adverse fluctuations in foreign currency could impact the margins.

The Company derives a bulk of its revenues from the automobile sector. The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend, is highly cyclical. Therefore, weak economic environment characterized by decline in per-capita income, high domestic inflation, increasing interest rates, weak industrial production, etc. (a scenario witnessed in FY 2013 and in current year), could adversely affect the revenues of the Company. Indian economy is currently witnessing a slowdown. India?s economic growth fell to 5.8 per cent in the January-March period of FY 2019, the lowest in 20 quarters, due to a sharp slowdown in investment andÿmanufacturing growthÿas well as a contraction in agricultural production. Thus, automobile sector too has got impacted from the slowing growth in the economy. Higher cost of vehicles, weak consumer sentiments coupled with liquidity crisis stemming from NBFC defaults are the other factors effecting the auto sales. As informed, management too expects its revenue growth to moderate to 8-10% in FY 2019.

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from a large number of organized/unorganized players in the domestic market and also manufacturers in the international market. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limits the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise to its customers who mostly comprise of the reputed OEM?s.

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average around 71% of the revenue of the Company. In FY 2018, to support the revenue growth and build in capacities for increasing scale of operations and bring in operating efficiencies, Company invested in personals and hired advisors, top executives which raised the salary cost (increased from 65% in FY 2017 to 75% in FY 2018). The attrition rate of the Company is about 14-15% and as indicated, it has added 110+ employees in the current year. This might affect the employee utilization level for the year. Company expects to maintain a gross margin of 23-24% in the near term.

Going forward the Company can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs especially due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to increasing unemployment in those markets) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff (as seen in recent changes made in immigration norms by US President Donald Trump). Thus, the ability of the Company to continue to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.

The Company derived around 72% of its revenue from international markets during the review period with major chunk of expenses being incurred in INR, exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though the Company tries to manage its risk via forward contracts, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such forward contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the customers used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Then gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total IT Outsourcing? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes they earlier used to outsource. The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead, they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Further, owing to automation of processes and new machine learning capabilities, there is trend in IT companies to adopt these technologies and reduce its manpower cost to increase its efficiency in delivery. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology to remain competitive is critical.

If the Company operates in the broadcasting equipment and systems industry. Some of key challenges include utilizing the computational power of the selected hardware platform, keeping the power consumption at a minimum, ease of design process, and cost of tools and equipment. The products also need to be streamlined as per required size, weight, power, software architecture, security, certification and business opportunities. Therefore, if the Company fails to adapt to new technology to meet client needs, preferences and geo specific compliance requirements , the demand for its products and services may contract. The company needs to build on the momentum created by its Nextgen Silicon solutions and products, it has to have a robust Scale up and operations plan and execute to it. The Company?s businesses operate in an industry that is subject to rapid technological advances and changing client needs and preferences. Any failure to adapt to the new technologies can negatively impact the Company?s business. Therefore, the ability of the Company to remain in sync with the continuously evolving technology remains critical. Aligning/partnering with Industry leader will help reduce risk of competition, financial risk and help better manage country specific regulatory requirements.

The Company faces competition from a large number of organized / unorganized players in the domestic market as well as the international market. As informed, Company faces competition from global players like GMM Pfaudler Limited, HLE Engineers Private Limited/ Swiss Glass Coat Equipments Limited, Standard Glass Lining Technology Private Limited and De Dietrich Process Systems under glass lined reactor segment. Similarly, for filter press, it faces competition from Dinshaw Filtration Systems Private Limited, NM Patel & Co. and FLSmidth Private Limited.
Going forward, the growing opportunities in the domestic market could witness the entry of multinational companies, further propelling the competitive intensity.

High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company as the product specifications are governed by the end customer leading to low product differentiation. Though the Company with its unique technology and after sales service poses some competitive advantage, the high competition leads to limited pricing flexibility which restrict the profitability to some extent.

The glass lined equipment segment is marked by significant investment in R&D from participating companies. Glass-lined chemical processing equipment requires a high level of purity as glass prevents the chemicals from corroding the base metal. Unique technological development provides a competitive edge above its competitor. The product is therefore evolving continuously, and market players have to keep up with the latest technical trend to stay competitive. As informed, SIL has tie-up with JP Laboratories Inc. USA which has enabled it to use glass on glass lining which is a unique technique for which JP Laboratories have applied for a patent.
Susceptibility to volatility in prices of raw material

SIL?s major raw material requirement consist of stainless steel and granules, in manufacturing of GLR and filter plates. Cost of raw material constituted on an average 68% of the total revenue during the review period. While steel is a global commodity, the prices of granules are governed by crude oil prices leading to high volatility in their prices. Prices of these raw materials therefore fluctuate daily based on movement in the international markets and in the absence of captive mining sources or long term contract with suppliers, the Company is exposed to the volatility in raw material prices.

Steel prices are expected to rise backed by increased demand and increased coal and ore cost. The prices in local market are at a premium from global par because of increased coal and ore cost. Given that large amount of their raw material requirement is sourced locally, any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials can affect the profitability of the Company and its ability to pass on the increase in raw material cost to its customers remains critical. As informed SIL maintains a stock of 2 to 3 months of raw materials which allows to minimize lead time and mitigate volatility in steel prices to some extent.

The Company procures more than 30% of raw material from its top two suppliers, namely Essar Steel India Limited and Reliance Industries Limited which are large creditworthy players with considerable market pull and bargaining power. This exposes the Company to supplier concentration risk. The risk is however, partially offset by the long-term relationship maintained by the Company with Essar Steel (14 years) and Reliance Industries Limited (19 years).

Primary competitors include animal health medicines companies such as Boehringer Ingelheim Animal Health Inc., Merck Animal Health, Zoetis, Inc.; Elanco, and Bayer Animal Health. In addition, the Group competes with hundreds of other producers of animal health products throughout the world. The level of competition from generic products varies from market to market. For example, the level of generic competition is higher in Europe and certain emerging markets than in the United States. Unlike in the human health market, there is no large, well-capitalized company focused on generic animal health products that exists as a global competitor in the industry.

The Group operates in a regulated industry and the operations are subject to compliance requirement. Regulatory agencies, viz. US FDA, cGMP may at any time reassess the manufacturing facilities or the safety and efficacy of the products based on newly developed scientific knowledge or other factors. Such reassessments could result in the amendment or withdrawal of existing approvals to market the products, which in turn could result in a loss of revenue. As notified by the management, the Group aspires to increase the revenue share from regulated markets going ahead which gives further impetus to regulatory approvals.

Revenues from Turkey declined as forex and new regulations related to judicious use of antibiotics were introduced. New regulations basically have tightened vigilance around anti-microbial use through introduction of E-prescriptions and veterinary pharmaceutical product tracking.

Pump market can broadly be classified into industrial and agriculture segments. The Company?s topline is driven by its presence in agriculture segment. The demand for pumps is driven largely due to replacement and also, a reduction in water level (in years of poor monsoon) leads to an increase in demand for pumps in the following year. Agriculture pump market in India is highly competitive with presence of both organized and unorganized players. Market is currently dominated by cast iron pump makers as these pumps are cheaper than the stainless steel pumps which are generally priced about 20% higher. Owing to the government policy of providing free/highly subsidized power to agriculture consumers, running cost of pumps is not very significant and hence, demand for conventional cast iron pumps in the domestic market is prominent. Therefore, the demand of Stainless Steel pumps in the domestic market is moderate which has prompted a change in focus of the Company to the international market which is evident from the increasing overseas exposure.

The major players in the domestic pumps industry are Kirloskar Brothers Limited, WPIL Limited, Roto Pumps Limited, CRI Pumps Limited and KSB Pumps Limited. As informed, the Company faces competition from Grundfos (Denmark) which is one of the largest pump manufacturer in the world. The competitors of the Company for submersible pumps would be Oswal Pumps Limited and Varuna Pumps. The management informed that its capability to deliver energy efficient products, technology used and brand visibility act as the key competitive edge over its peers.

The major raw materials of the Company are copper and steel. The domestic prices of these commodities (viz. iron ore, steel and copper) follow the international trends, in long run, which are influenced by the global demand and supply factors, beyond the control of the Company. Since raw material costs constitute on an average nearly 56% of the total revenues, any adverse movement in the price of raw materials could have an adverse impact on Company?s margins.

The Company derives its entire revenue from sale of submersible pumps and motors, exposing itself to high product concentration risk. High product concentration risk makes the topline susceptible in the event of decline in demand or increase in competition. Going forward, considering the fact that the competition in the industry would intensify, the Company needs to diversify across products in order to mitigate this risk to an extent.
Susceptibility of revenue and profitability to tender based business operations

The Company derives ~43% of revenue from tender based business from Government. While service quality, technical capability and work experience, financial strength, health and safety records as well as reputation and experience are important considerations in decisions made by authorities providing these concessions, price is a major factor in most bid awards. Furthermore, given the intense competition in the industry, with all the players going for competitive bidding, the chances of securing the orders (success rate) is constrained to a certain extent. Further, there is pressure on pricing which may impact margins. To mitigate the pressure on margins, the Company has been working towards providing complete installation solutions and innovating its offerings to maintain an edge over the competition.

The Indian auto component industry is highly fragmented with more than 10,000 players operating in both the organized and unorganized segment manufacturing diverse products. This indicates that each player (depending on the financial strength) can diversify into various sub-segments within the industry and can increase the competition. Moreover, due to the low capital intensiveness of the industry, the threat of new entrants is high.

High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limits the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise, given the volatility in the prices of raw material (mainly steel) to its customers who mostly comprise of the reputed OEM?s. Since India is a cost-effective hub and is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East and Europe, global auto component players are increasingly adopting a dual-shore manufacturing model, using overseas facilities to manufacture few types of components and Indian facilities to manufacture the others. In addition, Indian manufacturers also face competition from cheaper Chinese substitute products. However, significant cost saving owing to in-house R&D provides the Company with a competitive edge over its peers.
Cyclical nature of automotive industry coupled with rapid changes in the policy framework

The demand for automobiles, being a discretionary spend is highly cyclical. Further, short term deterioration in the domestic economic environment due to NBFC crisis reducing the credit availability, constant hike in fuel prices, weak industrial production, transition to BS VI norms, uncertainty regarding government policies, and high GST rates affects the consumer sentiment. These factors could adversely affect the demand for automobiles and consequently products being manufactured by the Company, thereby affecting its revenue. These factors have resulted in negative short-term outlook for the industry. As a result,the months of April, May, June, and July of 2019 have consistently shown y-o-y decline across all segments. According to SIAM, the industry produced a total 9,724,373 vehicles including Passenger and Commercial Vehicles, Three Wheelers, Two Wheelers and Quadricycle in April-July 2019 as against 10,883,730in April-July 2018, registering a de-growth of 10.65 % over the same period last year.

The ability of the Company, to adapt to the changes made in the product designing by the OEMs to meet the progressive, safety, emission and other regulatory norms of their vehicles, remains very critical. Some of the newer vehicles launched in the Indian market (especially by the foreign OEMs) have demonstrated radical changes in the component designing aimed at providing greater comfort and safety feature to customers and meeting changing emission norms. Some of these designs could be disruptive, especially with regards to usage of alternate materials and alternate manufacturing technology, for the existing suppliers and pose a threat to the going concern nature of their business. In this context, the ability of the Company to remain in synchronization with the evolving specifications for its product is likely to play a crucial role in mitigating technological obsolescence risk and ensuring business continuity.

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment facing competition from both the organized and unorganized players. Some of the major competitors of the Company include (POST md), and others. High competition could restrict the ability of the Company to scale up its revenues and can adversely impact its profitability levels by lowering its bargaining power with the customers and suppliers. Nevertheless, (post MD) mitigates the risk to certain extent.
Risk of adverse movement in raw material prices and foreign exchange fluctuations

The key raw materials required by the Company for manufacturing include (post MD) steel and prices of steel are influenced by global demand and supply factors. Therefore, any adverse movement in price of steel will have an unfavorable impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material cost comprised of nearly 60% of the revenues in the last three years ended 31st March 2018

Exports accounted for around 51% of the total revenue in FY 2018 which exposes it to the risk of currency fluctuation. Given the volatility in the currency rates, it remains critical for the Company to have a proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the risk.

The clinical outsourcing industry is very fragmented, with several clinical service providers offering varying degree of services, skills and capabilities. The players in the service providers market are Clinical Research Organizations (?CROs?) that provide one or more of the services currently offered by the Company. Some of the larger CROs, such as Quintiles Transnational Corporation, Parexel, Covance Inc., Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc., and Icon plc offer services that compete directly with the Company?s services at many levels. Other players include several domestic CROs like Ecron Acunova, Lambda Therapeutic Research Limited, Karmic Lifesciences, GVK Biosciences Private Limited and Veeda Clinical Research Private Limited. High degree of competition could add to pricing pressure of the Company which, in turn, may have an impact on the margins of the Company.
Susceptibility of profitability to fluctuations in forex rates

The Company derives 60% of the revenue from overseas market, exposing it to foreign exchange risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, UK etc. and most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Therefore, any adverse movement in the foreign exchange rates could adversely affect the bottom line of the Company. The Company had incurred forex loss of INR 1,528 thousand in FY 2017 and INR 1,660 thousand FY 2019. However, in FY 2018, it made a profit on forex transactions of around INR 5,385 thousand. As informed, Company undertakes forward contract for its transactions but it is not fully hedged. Therefore, the ability of the Company to undertake a proper hedging mechanism to hedge the exposure thereby mitigating foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk is critical for the Company.

Company is into manpower intensive business. Personnel costs constituted around 45% of the revenue of the Company in FY 2019. Also, the employees need to keep itself updated with the latest laws and regulations applicable in order to provide effective and efficient services. Thus, the ability of the Company to hire, train and retain skilled professionals coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical.

For the Group, international IT services contributed 38% of total revenues and 81% of profits, thereby leading to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Movement in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of foreign currency, domestic inflation, etc. which are hard to predict thereby causing volatility in the exchange rates. Though the Group tries to manage its risk via forwards, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected / hedged by the Group and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses on such contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. Also, since its IT billables are denominated in dollars and its expenses are incurred in rupees, thus the Group has no natural hedge, thus making it vulnerable to forex fluctuations.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Being a mid-size IT services player, the Group competes with different sets of industry players in multiple areas, based on vertical focus, geographical focus and other competitive factors. The traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is also becoming less relevant with global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low-cost destination nature. Therefore, the ability of the group to retain its existing clients and add new clients, in a fairly competitive environment, remains critical.

The Group is subject to risk of rapid changes in technology resulting in shift in preferences of consumers/ corporate. Information technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Thereafter gradually more and more processes were outsourced. To cut back on costs, the clients may start resorting to ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? wherein they would outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes.

The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure along with increasing adoption of SAAS. Instead, they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Further, new disruptive technologies like SMAC and innovations by startups which develop niche technology solutions, generate uncertainty regarding predictability of the business models and incremental demand from product differentiations. Therefore, the ability of the group to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.

The agro-commodity business is inherently subject to extensive regulations and stringent registration guidelines. The Company is required to obtain specific registration from the authorities locally as well as in the country of export. These authorities have policies and mechanism to ensure control over pricing, safety and quality of the products. The Company has to keep itself abreast of the various developments relating to the regulatory environment and gears itself in order of the Comply with these regulatory standards. Non-compliance of these regulations can vary from revocation or suspension of the registration to imposition of fines or confiscation of the goods in such jurisdictions. Further, regulatory agencies, viz. US FDA, may at any time reassess the manufacturing facilities or the safety and efficacy of the products based on newly developed scientific knowledge or other factors. Such reassessments could result in the amendment or withdrawal of existing approvals, which in turn could result in a loss of revenue. Thus maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements remains a key concern for the Company.

The Company derived around 62% of the revenue from exports in FY 2018. However, in FY 2019, revenue contribution from exports declined and was around 26%. As informed, the Company has plans to further penetrate in the export market for the processed soya meal. It procures around 10% of its raw material and traded goods requirement through imports. With an average export of 44% during the review period and imports around 10%, the natural hedge of the Company stands limited. Changes in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. As informed, the Company undertakes hedging of the soya commodity thus partly mitigating the risk. However, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.
Seasonal nature of the agriculture business and its dependence on weather & other allied factors

Around 99% of the Company?s revenue is from sale of agro-commodities which is inherently seasonal in nature. The agriculture business is highly dependent on the monsoon and allied weather conditions. Bad weather can hamper the supplies and the same could increase the working capital requirement of the Company. This uncertainty will require the Company to have a higher amount of inventory, thus reducing the liquidity of the Company. As informed, the Company currently holds inventory of around 10 days. The seasonal nature of supply, will also impact the end product prices thereby affecting the topline as well as the bottom line of the Company. Further, agriculture yield is subject to various factors like varying soil conditions, climatic conditions, rainfall, etc. which makes the performance of the agricultural sector as a whole or the levels of production of a particular crop relatively unpredictable.
Increased cost of production because of mandatory usage of Natural Gas

Tiles and ceramics is a power-intensive industry; the manufacturing process requires natural gas to fire the kiln and after raw materials, electricity and fuel cost is the second largest cost element in the total cost of production. The ceramic tile units in the Morbi cluster use either natural gas or gasification plants (which burn coal to generate gas) or bio waste as a source of gas. Although, usage of natural gas has inherent advantages like no transit wastage, higher fuel efficiency, cleanliness and pollution free, it is still not a preferred option considering severe fluctuation in the gas prices.

Consequently, despite a ban, gasification plants are still operational in Morbi cluster, considering the ease of availability of coal at a lower cost. However, with NGT?s order in March 2019 to discontinue usage of all type of coal gasifiers considering its adverse impact on the environment. All the units will mandatorily have to switch to PNG for their fuel requirements. The switch to PNG as a fuel is expected to increase the cost of production and impact profitability of the entities in the short term.

As informed by the Company it is in the process of complete gasification of its kilns which will increase the cost of production but since the industry suffers as a whole the better pass-on of expenses is anticipated.

The Company derived around 37.26% of its revenue from overseas market, exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. As informed, the imports of raw materials are largely sourced locally thereby negating the possibility of natural hedging. In FY 2018, however the Company acquired some FCRN loans and the Company opines that the foreign exchange fluctuation risk from exports can be largely setoff against the interest movement from these loans. Nevertheless, the Company suffered loss on foreign exchange transaction in FY 2018 and FY 2019.

Further, the lack of a natural hedging mechanism and the absence of a proper hedging policy exposes profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk which becomes more significant considering the high volatility of the INR in recent times.
Highly competitive industry coupled with susceptibility of the Company?s revenue and profitability to tender based contracts

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment facing competition from a large number of civil constructors operating in and around the region. Some of its immediate competitors include Rohan Buildcon Pvt Ltd, Scon, Vascon amongst others in Pune. Besides there is also regional competition wherein the Company executes orders. There are many organized and non-organized players in the industry. Amongst the bigger players, it has competition from Shapoorji Pallonji, L&T etc. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices (as the orders are tender based) and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. The Company has a moderate scale as reflected in its revenue size of INR 459 crores. Moreover, the revenues of the Company are vulnerable to deferral of orders (as evident in stagnant revenue in FY 2018). Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent volatility to the tender based business in the industry. As informed, strong customer relations, proven execution track record helps Company securing repeat orders year on year.

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment facing competition from a large number of civil constructors operating in and around the region. Some of its immediate competitors include Rohan Buildcon Pvt Ltd, Scon, Vascon amongst others in Pune. Besides there is also regional competition wherein the Company executes orders. There are many organized and non-organized players in the industry. Amongst the bigger players, it has competition from Shapoorji Pallonji, L&T etc. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices (as the orders are tender based) and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. The Company has a moderate scale as reflected in its revenue size of INR 321 crores. Moreover, the revenues of the Company are vulnerable to deferral of orders (as evident in stagnant revenue in FY 2018). Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent volatility to the tender based business in the industry. As informed, strong customer relations, proven execution track record helps Company securing repeat orders year on year.

The pharmaceutical companies are regulated by different national as well as international regulatory authorities like Food & Drugs Administration, World Health Organization, The Central Drug Standards and Control Organization, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, The National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority, and others. These authorities have policies and mechanisms to ensure control over the pricing, safety, and efficacy of the drugs. The Company has to keep itself abreast of the various developments relating to the regulatory environment and gears itself in order of the comply with these regulatory standards. The manufacturing facilities of the companies are regularly monitored and approved by various regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities have become more vigilant and strict with respect to compliance. Therefore, any prohibitions or restrictions imposed by the regulatory authorities, on any of the manufacturing facilities in the future can significantly affect the operations of the Company.
