Further, Indian pharmaceutical companies face cost disadvantages as compared to China, Korea and Taiwan, which offer low cost manufacturing base. This competition could drive down prices for the Company?s products, thereby impacting its margins.

In FY 2019, Company sourced a significant portion of its of its raw material requirement and derived around 56% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. Though imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies (relative to the USA) such as the BREXIT, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transactions of INR 310 thousand in FY 2018, it incurred loss on foreign exchange transactions of INR 13,450 thousand and INR 39,760 thousand in FY 2017 and FY 2019 respectively. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical.

Companies in the pharmaceutical industry, have to make continuous efforts to improve their production processes in line with the technological changes as well as increase its scale of operations. A lot of R&D efforts are undertaken to develop products/molecules for which there is a significant amount of cash outflow. As the benefits of research and development activities are uncertain with huge investment involved, in the scenario of unsuccessful attempts, the Company may take a hit on the operating margins. Further, there is no guarantee whether benefits will accrue on account of such research and development. Thus, the Company?s ability to derive benefits from R&D spend thereby sustaining the profit margins remain critical.

The primary raw materials procured by the Company to carry on its manufacturing activities are stainless steel scrap, mild steel scrap, chromium and nickel scrap which are majorly procured indigenously. Cost of raw materials constituted on an average 86% of the total revenue during the review period. Prices of raw materials fluctuate based on daily movement in the international markets and in absence of captive mining sources or long term contract with suppliers, the Company is exposed to volatility in raw material prices. SSL?s sales orders are backed by purchases and thus remain exposed to counterparty risk in case of a sharp fall in prices. In some case where standard grades of stainless steel produced are not backed by orders, its raw material inventories remain partially exposed to price fluctuation risk. Also, some purchases are through imports and thus the Company remains exposed to time lag between orders received from the customers and actual procurement of raw materials. Therefore, going forward any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials can affect the profitability of the Company and its ability to pass on the increase in raw material cost to its customers remains critical.
Susceptible to the cyclicality of the steel industry

Steel is a cyclical industry, strongly correlated to economic cycles, since its key users viz automobiles, construction and consumer durables are heavily dependent on the state of the economy. Apart from the cyclicality of the end-user industries, heavy capital investment and a gestation of period of 2-3 years for a new plant also contribute to the cyclicality of steel prices.

Chinese manufacturers are re-routing their products through the markets of other countries that India has Free Trade Agreements with, thus creating a surge in imports. Given the scale of the problem, government has attempted several steps such as imposing anti-dumping duties, countervailing duties, quality control and anti-circumvention measures but the problem still persists. New capacities in Indonesia riding on the back of Chinese investments also pose a threat to the domestic market. Thus, rising imports could pose a threat to the domestic steel manufacturers. Nevertheless, a sharp INR depreciation in the recent months is likely to translate to higher landed cost of steel imports, which in turn would support domestic prices.

The group operates in a highly competitive environment facing intense competition across all its business segments (it has 8-10 active players across all its business segments) and especially in the wholesale voice services segment owing to lack of last customer ownership. Liberalization of national long distance (NLD)/ international long distance (ILD) licenses in all the key markets (and especially in the domestic market) has enabled the local operators (who were earlier the clients of the group and whom the group, being primarily an infrastructure provider and not a service provider, is dependent for its revenues) to establish direct connectivity with the foreign carriers which, therefore, could adversely affect the revenues of the group, especially in the NLD segment. This is reflected in the y-o-y decline in the NLD and overall voice service segment of the group.

For its network infrastructure or network services, the group is facing competition from domestic players like Reliance Jio, which has expanded the reach of its network infrastructure by acquiring FLAG telecom, and overseas players like Global Cross Holdings Limited, Cable & Wireless plc., AT&T, etc. In the managed/hosted services segment, the group faces competition from companies like Sify Technologies Limited, Reliance Communication Limited in the domestic market and from companies like BT global services, Orange Business Services, etc. in the overseas market.

High competition has led to decline in price of communication services, both voice and data, leading to pressure on margins. The recent economic downturn has, further, increased the tendency of the clients to aggressively pitch for cost cutting. The group also faces the risk of losing its competitive advantage once its competitors scale up their network infrastructure.

In recent times, the domestic telecom industry has faced disruptions underlined by high costs and aggressive pricing by some telecom players. This had created an oligopolistic structure that is now rapidly moving toward a duopoly and eventually can become a monopoly. These structural changes have led to price war and increased consolidation in Indian telecom sector that has created an immense pricing pressure and impacted the group?s revenue and margins over the past three years.

Due to globalization, the need of centralized system has become mandatory for the companies to access the data from all the locations and at any point of time. Cloud system has eliminated the usage of the drives and it has made process easier of accessing the data. It can provide unlimited data storage. Cloud platformsÿsuch asÿOpenStackÿrely on the native ability of their workloads to be relocated to different areas of the physical infrastructure, without noticeably impacting their performance. However, with increasing usage of cloud, cyber security risk is also affecting the telecom players. Further it poses threat as the customers ?opt out? in the belief that going offline would help them secure data resulting in less traffic on the group?s network, which might result in decline in revenue.

Telecommunication services, being vital to the growth and development of a nation, are subject to government regulations throughout the world. As the group has interests in a large number of geographic areas throughout the world, it needs to comply with an extensive range of requirement that are meant to regulate and supervise the licensing, construction and operation of telecommunication networks and services.

For example, in the domestic market, it is the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) that regulates the interconnect charges. In February 2008, Department of Telecom (DoT), Government of India, approved the TRAI?s recommendation that paved way for sharing of active infrastructure amongst telecom operators, primarily affecting the NLD revenues of the group. The New Telecom Policy, proposed to be implemented, provides for clause pertaining to pooling, sharing and trading of spectrum and sharing of active infrastructure even by the IP-1 players which could have an adverse impact on the group.

The Group derived ~76% of its FY 2019 revenue from developed markets of Americas & Europe, exposing it to geographical concentration risk. These markets though have recovered post financial crisis of 2008, high accumulated debt of these nations (resulting in high fiscal deficit) and risk of a euro-zone crisis due to Brexit, which could result in contagion across other euro zone countries, could deteriorate the short-term economic environment. In such an environment, the clients start cutting down discretionary IT spends resulting in cancellation/ modification of contracts and/or renegotiate the contract value resulting in pressure on margins. Existing customers start commanding pricing power by lowering costs and increasing volumes. Further, owing to companies resorting to the strategy of hoarding cash, there may be delays in the decision making by the client (decision cycles getting prolonged) making it very difficult for the IT companies to bag new contracts. IT budgets of large organizations either become stagnant or start declining since the focus shifts on reducing cost by adopting measures like optimizing IT spend and postponing investments. Therefore, the ability of the Group to protect its revenues and margins from short term deterioration in the economic environment of its key markets remains extremely critical.
Protectionist policies of the US government and uncertainty surrounding continued modifications of H1B norms

USA administration has tightened visa norms and resorted to other protectionist policies through a draft executive order to overhaul the H1B work-visa programme. The new norms entail modification of the roster of employees, thus requiring more onshore employees (locals to be hired), minimum salaries increased to 135,000 USD (which is indexed for inflation or the average wage for the occupation in the area of employment but with a floor of USD 90,000), composition of onsite vs offshore for various projects, and specific limits of H1B visas to be offered to companies leading to increase in costs for IT companies and impacting the margins. The bill now heads to the full house for necessary action. Further, the procedures for sanction of these visas has become more stringent over the years allowing only the most skilled and the highest paid beneficiaries to qualify the process. Moreover, recently the USA administration announced a new policy that makes issuing of H1-B visas difficult for those employed at one or more third party worksites.

The reforms may force Indian IT companies to make changes in their business strategies, including hiring more American workers and raising salaries they pay to employees working on client sites or sub-contract to US IT firms which will reduce operating margins to an extent. The Group has ~65% of the total employees working on-site. Any adverse changes in the law in USA & other European countries towards outsourcing of work remains critical for the Group.

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Direct cost of services (personnel costs and subcontracting charges) constituted ~65% of the consolidated revenues of the Group in FY 2019. Therefore, increase in personnel costs, due to improvement in the domestic economic environment, adverse changes in the laws of key markets providing for compulsory hiring of local staff, temporary retention of client staff due to gradual transformation towards total outsourcing, etc., could, going forward, adversely affect the margins of Tech Mahindra.

The attrition rate of the Group increased and stood at ~21% in FY 2019 (as against 18% in FY 2018). With both global & domestic economies slowly recovering from slowdown, there are numerous opportunities for the employees which could push up the attrition rate and hamper the execution of projects. The employee utilization rate remained stable between 80-84%. The management?s focus would be to improve utilization levels and employee connect. Further, there has been a y-o-y increase in revenue from onsite operations during the review period. The management informed that revenue from onsite operations has risen owing to changes in the industry trends, client requirements or requirements of a transformational deal. Direct costs would be marginally higher owing to shift in mix towards onsite operations. Therefore, the ability of the Group to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical. As informed, going forward, the Group expects several big projects for which it may undertake additional hiring. However, the overall utilization rate is expected to remain at a minimum of 80%.

Competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the Group are integrated full service providers like Infosys Technologies Limited, HCL Technologies Limited, Wipro Limited, TCS Limited, Cognizant, etc. along with several mid-size companies who provide a domain/vertical specific expertise. Also, the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low-cost destination nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware, but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. As informed, going forward, the proportion of revenue derived by the Group from the commoditized service lines like Application Development & Maintenance (ADMS), BPO services, etc. is expected to remain fairly high in the short to medium term. Also, as informed, while the Group, going forward, would like to consolidate on its high market share in the telecom vertical, it would have to build market share in other verticals. High competitive intensity leads to intense price wars which could have a direct impact on the margins of the Group.

The Group derived a major portion of its revenue from overseas market (primarily in USD, AUD, GBP or Euro) while incurs a large part of its cost in INR, exposing it to foreign exchange risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though, Tech Mahindra tries to manage the aforesaid foreign exchange risk via derivatives, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by Tech Mahindra and that actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes it to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Tech Mahindra has a board approved hedging policy for past several years. Also, Tech Mahindra has a dedicated Treasury department which seeks advice from expert professionals and banks helping it in hedging decisions.

India has traditionally been a preferred outsourcing destination owing to its competencies and skills in information technology space and English-speaking low-cost talent pool for servicing advanced offshore assignments. However, off late, many other countries like Argentina, Mexico, China, Brazil, Philippines, etc. have also emerged as favored destinations for outsourcing. The labor costs of these countries are similar/ lower to than in India which could pose a long-term threat to India?s status as being a preferred outsourcing destination. Further, the culture & language of some of these nations (like Philippines) is much similar to US and therefore, are now increasingly preferred by US companies. Therefore, the ability of Tech Mahindra to continuously make investments in these countries, to extend its offshore services, remains critical.

Information Technology is continuously evolving both in software and hardware services. Initially the vendors used to have their own IT infrastructure and they used to outsource limited processes to low cost destinations like India to minimize the costs. Then gradually more and more processes were outsourced. But after the financial crisis, the trends changed significantly. To cut back on costs, the clients started resorting to ?Total IT Outsourcing? wherein they started to outsource even the management of their IT infrastructure apart from software services and business processes they earlier used to outsource. The technology has now further advanced to ?cloud computing? wherein the clients (especially the SME enterprises) do not incur expenditure to even have their own IT infrastructure. Instead they try to share the resources, applications, software, etc. of any service provider over the network. Therefore, the ability of the Group to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology remains critical.
Adverse impact of litigations/claims/investigations/non-compliances of regulatory requirements pertaining to the erstwhile Mahindra Satyam Group

The auditors of the Company have qualified their opinion on the consolidated accounts in FY 2018 on account of their inability to ascertain the impact and the consequential effects, if any, thereof which are not quantifiable on a number of items, namely, ongoing investigations and legal proceedings by various regulators / investigating agencies in respect of alleged advances of INR 12,304,000 thousand relating to prior years as claimed by various companies which is presented separately in the Balance Sheet of SCSL under ?Amount Pending Investigation Suspense Account (Net)? and adequacy or otherwise of the provision for taxation pertaining to prior years.

Further, the auditors have drawn attention to the fact that the annual financial statements for the years ended March 31, 2015, March 31, 2014, March 31, 2013 and March 31, 2012 have not been adopted by the members of that subsidiary in their respective annual general meetings in the absence of unanimous consent of both the shareholders in terms of the Articles of Association of the subsidiary company. However, the opinion has not been qualified on these matters.

Going forward, any adverse outcome or settlement of any of the aforesaid investigative/legal proceedings could either disrupt the normal course of operations of the Group or result in a significant outflow of funds, thereby adversely affecting the profitability and cash flow position of Tech Mahindra (a scenario witnessed in FY 2013 when SCSL settled pending litigation with Aberdeen Global which adversely impacted the profitability of the merged entity with its PAT margins declining from 15.68% in FY 2012 to 13.86% in FY 2013).

The management is of the opinion that the issues relating to fraud are untenable in courts and are pending in courts. Even in a worst case, management believes it will have limited impact on the cash flows (financials) of the Group. The cases have been pending for long and the matters being subjudice, the management will not be able to provide more information.

The chemical sector is regulated by many regulations that need to be adhered to in terms of pollution norms. The companies in this sector also need to have the necessary regulatory approvals from time to time to keep the business going. Any change in the Government?s environment policies could have an adverse impact on the production activity of chemical manufacturers at any time.

The Indian chemical industry is highly fragmented and widely dispersed, comprising of both small and large-scale companies, in addition to presence of multinational companies. The Company has a wide product portfolio and competes with various companies like Alkyl Amines Chemicals Limited, PI Industries Limited, Anupam Rasayan India Limited, Laxmi Organic Industries Ltd, Atul Limited and Aarti Industries Limited amongst others in the respective product categories. Although the Company has been in the business for around 10 decades with established relationship with customers and suppliers (which provides it with an edge over other players), its scale has remained at moderate level, resulting in low bargaining power and ability to pass on price hike to its customers (pricing pressures). Further, the chemical industry in India also falls under the automatic route for Foreign Direct Investment which has made competition in local markets stiff.

The Company is engaged in manufacturing of different types of commodity and speciality chemicals. The primary raw material for the chemicals sold by the Company are derivative of crude oil, prices of which are determined by macro factors like global demand for fuel, quantum of production by the OPEC nations, speculative built up of the prices through forwards, political scenario in the Middle East countries, opening and closing inventories, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict which leads to volatility in the prices of crude oil and thereby of the chemicals manufactured from it. Hence, any adverse movements in the prices of crude, going forward, could significantly affect the profitability of the Company.

The Company derives ~33% of its revenue from exports, exposing it to foreign exchange risk. While the Company has a natural hedge to some extent in terms of imports (~16% in FY 2019) there could be timing differences between receipts and payments. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, Brexit, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Further, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Company and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes it to the risk of incurring losses, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. While it achieved profit on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2019, it incurred loss on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2017 and FY 2018. Nevertheless, as indicated, the Company hedges its exposure based on the advice from bankers and external consultant. Going forward, the Company has plans to avail foreign currency long term loan and enter into interest swaps.

The Group remains exposed to inherent risks associated with tender based operations in EPC industry including aggressive bidding, traffic risk, interest rate risk, delay in project execution due to external factors and regulatory clearances. These challenges have collectively affected the credit profile of the EPC players in the past as well. In addition to this, it is difficult to predict whether or when a particular project would be awarded since most potential projects involve a lengthy and complex bidding and selection process that may be affected by a number of factors which include changes in market conditions, financing arrangements, government & regulatory approvals, environmental approvals, etc. Further, competitive bidding may also impact the profitability margins for projects undertaken.

Moreover, the orders received by the Group are typically fixed-price in nature. Therefore, the Group?s ability to manage basic raw material cast within the bid levels remains critical. Also, the ability to ensure procurement/delivery of critical components remains important.
Subcontracting risk coupled with fixed price contracts may lead to time and cost overruns

Thermax undertakes turnkey projects and is likely to face time & cost overrun risk. With inflationary pressures plaguing the domestic economy, time delays could lead to cost escalations. The delays could be due to many external factors which could be unforeseen and beyond the control of the Group. Further, the group sub contracts many of its activities which have led to significant upsurge in sub-contracting cost (10.93% of the total revenue in FY 2019). General risks associated with subcontracting such as lack of complete control on sub-contracted portion, execution quality of sub-contracted portion, etc. may create additional challenges leading to further time and cost overruns impacting the execution of the project and the profitability derived from it.
Slowdown in economy/end user industries impacting order book position and thereby impacting the performance of the group

Being a part of the capital goods and EPC industry, Thermax?s revenue growth is a function of its order inflow, which in turn is sensitive to economic and investment cycles. Adverse economic and political factors may thus lead to slowdown in project execution leading to deferral in execution or even cancellation of orders. Further, the since majority of the annual revenue is generally derived from only a few large projects, slowdown in execution of these projects may directly impact the performance of the Group.

The Group derived 44.13% of its revenue from exports. Further, the Group deals in several currencies including INR, USD, EUR, SEK and JPY. Though most of these transactions are hedged, the Group still remains exposed to certain forex fluctuation risk. Moreover, the group expects a growth in revenue from international market thereby amplifying the foreign exchange transaction risk. Movements in the exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates.
Risk from realization of off-balance sheet contingent liabilities

As mentioned in the annual report FY 2019, the Company/Group has received demand notices/show cause-cum-demand notices from the excise department covering period from June 2000 till June 2017 for INR 13,835,100 thousand (including penalty of INR 3,252,900 thousand and excluding interest not presently quantified) by the Commissioner of Central Excise, Pune. As further mentioned, these demands are of excise duty payable on inclusion of the cost of bought out items in the assessable value of certain products manufactured by the Group, though such duty paid bought out items are directly dispatched by the manufacturers thereof to the ultimate customer, without being received in the Group's factory. Accordingly, the Group has filed an appeal against the said orders and filed replies to the show cause notice cum demand notice. Based on independent legal advice, the Group is confident of the issue being ultimately decided in its favor and accordingly no provision has been considered necessary. However, any liability arising from the issue may impact the liquidity and therefore impact the financial profile of the Group.
Stiff competition in the EPC space due to tender based nature of contracts

EPC sector comprise of large firms capable of executing large infrastructure projects worth billions of rupees to smaller firms who act as subcontractors to large firms. However, the presence of large players executing complete EPC contracts are limited due to the high entry barriers. High initial investments, technical capability to execute large projects and high working capital requirements acts as entry barriers. The Company faces stiff competition from several large players like Larsen and Tourbo Limited, TCIL Limited, thyssenkrupp Industrial Solutions (India) Private Limited [TKISI], Technimont SPA amongst others With respect to engineering services, it faces competition from Engineers India Limited, Jacobs Engineering Group and Thyssenkrupp India Private Limited amongst others. As informed, competetion amonsgt the large MNC players establishing subsidiaries in India is high. High competitive intensity puts a pressure on pricing as the tenders are won based on low bids.
However, the Company has a proven track record and end to end project executional capabilities which help it bag large and complex orders.

Major portions of the EPC contract are outsourced by the Company to various subcontractors. Managing subcontract schedule in order to complete the EPC contract in time will be of utmost importance. If the subcontract scheduling is not adhered to then it may lead to delay and cost overruns.

The Company derives major revenues from oil and gas and fertilizer sector. Considering the downward spiral of crude oil prices which have remained under pressure for more than 2 years, there has been either postponement or cancellation of large oil drilling projects. Thus, the Company can get adversely affected by events in the industry which may result in cancellation or postponement of orders or pressure on prices of the products. This will put strain on topline and bottom-line of the Company. This can be seen from the fluctuating revenues in the last three years ending FY 2019 with fewer orders from oil & gas sector.

The tenure of contracts executed by Toyo-India is within 3-5-year timeframe, which at time is extended to 7-8 years. The project delays are basis the high cyclicality in the hydrocarbon sector, delays in govt sanctions etc. Since majority of the contracts entered into are on lump sum basis, the Company is unable to pass on any material price increase to the customers during the contract period. Also, the time overruns have a huge impact on the manpower billing which remains uncompensated in case of delays. The Company remains highly susceptible to the time and cost overruns in the project which can affect its profitability adversely. Thus, its ability to keep itself insulated against any price rise remains critical.

The Company operates in a fairly competitive environment facing competition from a large number of domestic and international players. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. The domestic competitors include players such as KEC International Limited, Tata Projects Limited, Larsen & Toubro Limited. Kalpataru Power Transmission Limited etc. Further as informed by management, it also faces competition from many overseas players. This competitive intensity may adversely affect the Company?s market share as well as may lead to bids being priced at lower rates thereby affecting its top line and profits. The contracts bagged by the Company are tender based in nature. As informed, the Company derives about 80% of the total revenue from government contracts. Some of the organized players in the market which have relatively larger scale of operations also operate through tender based business. The government contracts are obtained via a process of bidding. Moreover, the revenues of the Company are vulnerable to deferral of orders (as evident from drop in international business in FY 2018 and modest overall revenue growth in FY 2019). Thus, the Company?s operations remain susceptible to the inherent volatility to the tender based business in the industry, as informed, strong experience and customer base, robust designing and testing facilities provide the Company an edge against its competitors.

The Company derived around 22% of its revenue from exports thus exposing itself to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk though the same was mitigated by natural hedge. Moreover, the Company expects the revenue to increase from the international market thereby amplifying the risk of loss on foreign exchange transaction. Movements in the exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand / supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. The risk is evident from the fact that the Company has incurred foreign exchange loss to the extent of INR 60,200 thousand in FY 2017. There was profit on foreign exchange transaction in FY 2018 and FY 2019. As informed, the Company plans to implement risk management policy to provide for hedging mechanism to manage the impact of foreign exchange movements.
Prone to cost and time overrun owing to getting multiple approvals and change in government regulations and policies

As far as EPC projects are concerned, there can be significant delays in getting clearances and other requisite approvals, change in government policies/regulations, shifting of utilities etc leading to cost and time overrun in project execution and completion. For instance, one reason that leads to delays in regulatory approvals is the multiplicity of approvals required from both the Central and the State Governments and the lack of coordination between them leading to standoffs on critical approvals required. This could have an impact on the revenues and margins of the Company.
Susceptibility to bureaucracy as well as political and security conditions in the international region

An organization operating in multiple markets outside its home country is prone to various kinds of risks that can arise due to any number of factors including political, economic, exchange rate or technological influences. Companies have executed projects in n Algeria, Nigeria, Ethiopia, Kenya, Mozambique, Tanzania, Afghanistan, Botswana, Bhutan, Rwanda, Benin & Togo.ÿPolitical risk in international construction projects refers to uncertainty related to political events for e.g. political violence, regime changes, coups, wars, terrorist attacks etc and to arbitrary or discriminatory incidents such as foreign exchange restrictions, unlawful interference, corruption, labour restrictions etc. Such forms of uncertainty can damage or destroy a Company?s assets and prevent it from conducting operations essential to doing business.

The primary raw material for the Company is yarn and cotton. Cotton prices are highly volatile on account of various reasons like government policies, effects of monsoon on domestic production, demand and supply, quantum of production in other countries, etc. A deficit in domestic or global production can result in an abnormal increase in the prices of cotton thereby, hurting the demand and margins. Further, prices of all major commodities are now a function of global demand and supply factors, which are beyond the control of the Company.

Cotton prices have been increasing since August 2016. Stocking of cotton by traders due to demonetization further led to increase in its costs. However, as informed by the management, the Company has an escalation clause in place with some of its customers, whereby it is able to transfer some of the increase in prices of raw materials to the customers. Further, as informed, despite change in government policies regarding MSP, prices of cotton are not expected to increase more than the current prices and hence it do not expects any adverse effect on margins as compared to FY 2018. Trident derived around 57% of its total revenue from the international market whereas procured less than 1% of its raw material requirement from the overseas market, indicating lack of natural hedge, thereby exposing it to foreign exchange currency rate fluctuation risk. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. Considering the same, adverse changes in raw material prices may affect margins of the Company.

Nevertheless, the Company takes appropriate measures and has even written off past mark-to-market losses. As informed, currency risk is now managed by continuous monitoring and limiting of the same in view of applicable margins under relevant product/market segment. 50% of the foreign currency exposure is hedged to mitigate any adverse movement in currency.

The textiles sector is fairly fragmented with unorganized sector forming a significant portion of the total market resulting in cheaper low quality products entering the market. Reduction in trade barriers to facilitate global trade has resulted in increase in the quantity of goods being imported, posing a threat to the domestic players. Since 100% FDI is allowed in textiles sector which adds to the threat, foreign multinational companies with advanced technology are also expected to set up large infrastructures for manufacturing textiles in the country intensifying the competition.

High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company. This coupled with increase in raw material prices could impact the margins of the Company. Major competitors of the Company locally include Vardhaman Textiles Limited, Welspun India Limited, Indo Count Industries, Ballarpur Industries Limited, Tamil Nadu Newsprint and Papers Limited.

The Company?s market share is about 13% in towels segment in USA. Also, the Company has been increasingly focusing on diversifying into more value added textiles products in towels and bed sheets by investing in the research & development of the products and undertaking continuous designing, for which it has designing houses in the USA and India. This helps the Company reduce the impact of competition and thereby improve its margins. Possessing large capacities enables the Company to enjoy economies of scale and provide the flexibility to manufacture a wide range of products from a single facility.
Uncertainty over the trade environment could hurt Group?s revenue growth

The Group majorly caters to steel industry which finds utilization in the construction, infrastructure, oil & gas, power, electronics and engineering industries. The demand of these commodities are directly dependent on the level of demand for the steel, which in turn is linked to economic growth. Majority of these industries have cyclical demand owing high correlation with economic cycles.

In 2019 and 2020, growth is expected to moderate in tandem with a slowing global economy. Chinese steel demand continues to decelerate as the combined effect of economic rebalancing and trade tension is leading to slowing investment and sluggish manufacturing performance.ÿSteel demand in the developed economies is expected to decelerate to 0.7% in 2020, reflecting a deteriorating trade environment. In 2019, the US growth pattern is expected to slow with the waning effect of fiscal stimulus and a monetary policy normalisation. Therefore, both construction and manufacturing growth is expected to moderate. Investment in oil and gas exploration is expected to decelerate as well, while a boost in infrastructure spending is not expected. The EU economies also face the deteriorating trade environment and uncertainty over Brexit. (Source: World Steel Association) Thus, slowing economy could hurt the demand for Group?s products. As indicated, the Group?s revenue is expected to largely remain stagnant in FY 2020 in the wake of a slowing economy.
Susceptibility to the intermittent supply of natural resources

The Group is engaged in trading and marketing of natural resources having limited availability. It has been observed that the government of various nations, from time to time have controlled mining activities to preserve their natural resources or to curb illegal mining practices, thus leading to inconsistency in supply. Moreover, these minerals being critical input for steel manufacturing industry and several downstream industries including infrastructure and construction, automobiles, heavy engineering, white goods, the government, at times to promote the development of the economy bans/ limits export of these resources to meet its internal requirement. Further, procurement of the resources as per the quality and grade requirement of the customer might pose as a challenge. Thus, ability of the Group to secure incessant supply of these materials remains crucial.

About 55-60% of the Group?s total purchases comprised of imports while 72% of revenue was derived from the international markets. Though, imports and foreign currency borrowings could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Group to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis remains critical. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, Brexit etc. With partial scope of natural hedging, subject to appropriate management of timing differences, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk becomes critical for the Group. Any adverse fluctuation in currency rates may affect the bottom-line of the Group.

Ferro alloy segment is fragmented with the presence of both small units and large plants. Some of the leading players in the industry are Indian Metals & Ferro Alloys Ltd, TATA Steel (export oriented), Balasore Alloys, Maithan, Facor Alloys, Rohit Ferro-Tech, Mishra Dhatu Nigam, and Ferro Alloys Corp. Entry barriers being low, emergence of new regional players may put pressure on the margins of the Group. As informed, the Group has long relations with its customers and provides value added services like testing of composition of the material and timely delivery which partly mitigates risk from new entrants.

Currently, the Indian turbocharger manufacturing sector comprises of both Indian companies as well as subsidiaries of international companies. Cummins Turbo Technologies (part of USD 17 Billion Cummins Group) and Honeywell Turbo Technologies (part of Honeywell Group) are two of the major international companies operating in India. High competition owing to technological advancements resulting in new product launches (variants) coupled with the concentrated nature of the industry could restrict the Company?s pricing ability.

The Company?s top three customers contributed around 78% to its revenues in FY 2019, with Ford Motors and Mahindra & Mahindra Limited; each contributing more than 30% to its revenues, with Maruti Suzuki India Limited is exiting from the manufacturing of diesel variant vehicles, contribution from the same although declined but remained around 18% in FY 2019. This indicates significant customer concentration risk. The Company benefits from being a sole supplier of turbocharger to its top customers- Maruti Suzuki India Limited, Mahindra & Mahindra, Ford, Tata Motors and Ashok Leyland.. However, any significant decline in orders from these companies could affect the revenues and profitability of the Company. However as informed, this risk is partially mitigated by the fact that it usually takes 16 to 18 months for an OEM to change its turbocharger supplier (which results in high switching cost to the OEM). As informed, the company has also backed orders for new models from Hyundai Motor India Limited and Volkswagen Group during FY2019 which is expected reduce the concentration risk in the future.

The Company imported around 20% of its total purchase requirements and generates around 15% of its revenues from the international market. While this provides it with a natural hedge to a certain extent, it is exposed to foreign exchange fluctuation risk to a certain degree. Considering the exposure in the international market, limited natural hedge and volatility in foreign exchange market, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk remains critical for the Company. Any adverse movement in currency rates may have a significant impact on the bottom line of the Company. As informed, the Company hedges its currency position through forward contracts.
Electric vehicle market could severely impact the turbocharger industry

Automotive emission regulation is the major factor that is fueling the introduction of cleaner and low-emission vehicles among automakers. Turbocharger is the component that is forcing the car industry to make engines compliant to the stringent emission standards. The emission regulation authorities, who focus on cutting down the CO2 emission, are replacing existing naturally aspirated engines with turbocharged engines. The electric vehicles, which were considered as an impractical alternative to the fossil fuel engines, are witnessing a global demand. The growing electric vehicle industry is a great threat to the fossil fuel-based power generators and the dependent automotive turbochargers market

Widespread adoption of battery powered vehicle could pose a threat to the turbocharger industry. As informed, the Company shall consider diversifying its product base based on the changing market conditions, technology. It foresees that it could take a long time for electric cars to become a disruptive force through mass adoption. So, the Company?s ability to successfully diversify its product line in order to sustain in the market shall remain important.

The Indian valve industry is highly fragmented with around 600 valve manufacturers, of which more than 95 per cent are in the micro, small and medium enterprise (MSME) category. Top 10 players service 40 per cent of the market. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. Further, with a substantial part of future opportunities expected to come from the export market, it has become inevitable for the Indian manufacturers to be at par with their global peers. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. As informed, domestic competitors of the Company include Larsen & Toubro Limited, KSB Pumps Limited and Weir Power & Industrial India. On the international front, the competitors of the Company include Amstrong International, Spirax-Sarco Limited and A.R.I. Flow Control Accessories Limited. As indicated by the management, the Company caters only to tier-I entities and the brand name ?Velan? plays a pivotal role in competing with other players. Further, the ability of the Company to offer its products at a competitive rate gives it an edge over its peers in the overseas market.

The primary materials required by the Company for manufacturing valves includes steel, castings & forgings and metal sheets amongst others. As indicated by the management carbon steel, stainless steel and alloy steel are the primary raw materials used by the Company. Prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average 59% of the revenue during the review period. Therefore, any significant increase in material cost will affect the margins adversely due to its limited ability to pass on the price hike to customers. However, with fixed price multi-year contracts entered with certain of its customers, the price escalation is usually absorbed by the Company leading to a volatile gross profit margins.

In FY 2019, Velan sourced around 26% of its raw material requirement and earned around 62% of its revenue from the overseas market, thereby exposing financial performance to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk with a limited scope of natural hedge. Though imports and exports could serve as a natural hedge, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis and also hedge the balance un-hedged exposure through derivatives remains critical. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, un-hedged exposure could affect the margins adversely and put a strain on the cash flows. Although, the Company clocked profit on foreign exchange transactions in FY 2018 and FY 2019, it incurred a loss on foreign exchange transaction from FY 2015 to FY 2017. Hence, the ability of the Company to maintain the natural hedge on a consistent basis while matching the timings of cash flows along with its ability to hedge the balanced exposure through various mechanisms remains critical. As informed, presently, the Company relies on natural hedging but in the future, it is likely to adopt a hedging mechanism with exposure towards export market is expected to increase going ahead.

The Company is engaged in processing of stainless steel wire/wire rods for Precision Metals (group company) and manufacturing and sale of stainless steel wires and wire rods for other customers. The primary raw material of the Company are iron ore, steel, chromium and Nickel etc. Prices of these commodities are influenced by trends in raw material prices, demand-supply conditions in the market, international price trends, etc. which are beyond the control of the Company. Therefore, any adverse movement in the prices of these commodities could have an adverse impact on the margins of the Company, considering the fact that the raw material consumed constitute on an average ~48% of the cost of the Company. Thus, ability of the Company to pass on the increase in raw material cost to its customers remain critical.

However, now as the Company generates major revenue from Precision Metals in the form of job work charges for processing of stainless steel wire & wire rods and majority of the raw material is purchased in the books of Precision Metals, risk of fluctuation in raw material prices impacting the margins of the Company is mitigated to an extent. Further, as informed by the management, the Company pass on the increase/decrease in raw material prices on monthly basis to its customers as per the agreement.

However, the Company caters to various end user industries like automotive, energy, nuclear, windmill, oil and gas, architecture, water, pumps, defense, welding, pharmaceutical, machine components, conveyor, fencing, vineyard, power generation, boilers, paper industry, petrochemical, pipelines, building & construction and lighting sector amongst others, thus mitigating risk to an extent related to slowdown in any industry.

The Company derives around ~20% of the revenue from international markets, while it procures all its raw material from the domestic market. This exposes the profitability of the Company to currency fluctuation risk. Considering the volatility in exchange rates, the ability of the Company to mitigate the risk remains critical as movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. As informed by the management, it does not hedge its exposure, thus exposing it to foreign exchange fluctuation risk.

The Company operates in a highly competitive environment dominated by large number of organised and unorganised players. The competition in the market is driven by two aspects namely the features and price. Some of the key players operating in the industry include Uflex India Limited, Huhtamaki PPL Limited, Montage Enterprises Private Limited amongst others. Modest scale of operations of the Company limits its bargaining power and restricts its ability to reap benefits of economies of scale. Further, the competition in the industry is also driven by quality and adherence to newly evolving regulations and research and development investments. As indicated by management, threat from competition is mitigated to a certain extent as the Company is specifically into co-extruded films- flexible packaging unlike other players who are also in paper, plastic, laminations and other packaging. Also, with latest technology, quality of products and on-time delivery act as a competitive advantage and provides an edge against the other players. Strong and established relationship with key customers like AWL, Cargill, etc. mitigates competition risk to a certain extent.

In FY 2019, the Company derived around 75% of its revenue and procures about 40-45% of its raw material requirement from international market, exposing it to foreign exchange risk. With partial scope of natural hedging, subject to appropriate management of timing differences, undertaking a proper hedging mechanism to mitigate the foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk becomes critical for the Company. The movements in the exchange rate are influenced by various factors such as demand and supply of foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies and others. Most of these factors are difficult to predict resulting in volatility in the exchange rates, impacting the profitability of the any organization. However, the Company relies on open market for unhedged portion makes it more vulnerable to foreign exchange fluctuation risk. Further there could be a timing difference between the procurement of imported raw materials and orders received from the customers, which exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. The Company has incurred forex losses to the tune of INR 1,265 thousand in FY 2019. Also, as apprised, high volatility in the forex rates has effected the gross margin.

The Company is engaged in the manufacturing of high-strength, multilayer flexible packaging films and provides customised packaging solutions to retail and industrial markets. The key raw materials required for manufacturing include plastic films, polymer granules, plastic resins, chemical solvents, colorants and additives. Prices of key raw materials are directly linked to crude oil, prices of which are determined by macro factors like global demand for fuel, quantum of production by the OPEC nations, speculative built up of the prices through forwards, political scenario in the Middle East countries, opening and closing inventories, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict which leads to volatility in the prices of crude oil and thereby of the petrochemical components synthesized from it. Considering the fact that the cost of material & finished goods consumed depicted an increasing trend & on an average formed 40-45% of the revenue during the review period, any adverse movement in the prices of the raw material could adversely impact the margins of the Company. The same is evident from the declining gross profit margin in FY 2019. As informed, the product pricing is based on per order basis and is reviewed every quarter/ half yearly. This enables the Company to ensure partial transfer of price hike in the raw material prices to the customers.
Stringent rules and recent amendment in plastic wastage management rules might impact the revenue of the Company

India generates 5.6 Mn tonnes of plastic waste each year, of which ~66% is the mixed waste-polybags and pouches which are used inÿfoodÿpackaging. Owing to the serious environmental consequences with regard to the dumping of plastic waste, 20 Indian states have placed blanket bans on the manufacture, use, sale, distribution, and storage of plastic items like one-time-use bags, spoons, PET, and PETE bottles. Some states only permit polythene bags that have thickness in excess of 50 microns. Since plastic is one of the essential materials used in flexible packaging, a ban on its production will be a significant hindrance for the growth of the flexible packaging market in India.

Further, the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has amended the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016 and notified the Plastic Waste Management (Amendment) Rules, 2018 on March 27, 2018. MLP ? All Multi-layered plastics were supposed to be phased out. But these have been given a fresh lease of life by easing the norms concerned. Only MLP that are ?non-recyclable or non-energy recoverable or have no alternate use? are to be phased out. Hence, the Company being the manufacturer of multi-layered plastic packaging becomes vulnerable for the product it manufacturers which are non-recyclable. Thus, onus and responsibility of the Company to manufacture plastic which are recyclable increases, else impact of the same on the revenue (in terms of decline) remains to be seen.
Risk of fluctuation in foreign exchange and raw material prices

The primary raw material procured by the Company to carry on its manufacturing activities is steel. Cost of raw material constituted on an average 75% to 77% of the total revenue during the review period. Prices of raw materials are fluctuating based on daily movement in the international markets and in the absence of captive mining sources or long-term contract with suppliers, the Company is exposed to the volatility in raw material prices. Therefore, going forward, any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials can affect the profitability of the Company and its ability to pass on the increase in raw material cost to its customers remains critical.

Also, the Company imports some of its raw materials leaving it exposed to adverse currency movements. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Moreover, the fact that there could be a timing difference between the procurement of imported raw materials and orders received from the customers exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. This risk is evident from the fact that the Company had incurred loss on foreign exchange during FY 2016 and FY 2017. As informed by the management, the Company does not plan to have any specific hedging mechanism and would be entering into forwards depending on the currency rates movement.

The Company operates in a competitive environment facing competition from a large number of organized/unorganized players in the domestic market and also manufacturers in the international market. The growing opportunities in the domestic market promise the entry of multinational companies in India which will further fuel the competitive intensity. High competitive intensity would restrict the pricing ability of the Company, which in turn would result in bids being submitted at lower prices and thereby adversely affecting the margins of the Company in a scenario of rising costs. This further limits the ability of the Company to pass on the price rise fully to its customers who mostly comprise of the reputed OEM?s. Since India is a cost-effective hub and is geographically closer to key automotive markets like the Middle East and Europe, global auto component players are increasingly adopting a dual-shore manufacturing model, using overseas facilities to manufacture few types of critical components and Indian facilities to manufacture the others. In addition, Indian manufacturers also face competition from cheaper Chinese substitute products. Some of the other players in the industry are Steel Strips Wheels Limited, Enkel Wheels Limited, Minda Kosei and others. However, being in the industry for more than five decades and an established market position, provides WIL a competitive advantage.

IT sector is a manpower intensive business model. Personnel costs constituted on an average around 48% of the revenue of the Company. The Company witnessed a y-o-y increase in personnel costs as a percentage of revenue till FY 2019 which accounted for around 50% of the revenue. The attrition rate of the Company was 17.6% in FY 2019. The ability of the Company to hire and retain talent coupled with its ability to manage their cost via efficient utilization rate remains critical. Going forward, the Company can face margin pressures due to increase in personnel costs, especially due to economic recovery in the domestic market and adverse changes in the laws of its key markets (due to increasing unemployment in those markets) providing for compulsory hiring of local staff (as seen in recent changes made in immigration norms by US President Donald Trump). This has also pushed the increase in onsite employee size which has shot up the overall personnel cost.

The competitive intensity has been quite high in the Indian IT sector. Some of the major competitors of the Company are Infosys Technologies Limited, Tata Consultancy Services, HCL Technologies Limited, Tech Mahindra, Cognizant etc. along with several mid-sized companies. Also the traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destinations nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Therefore, the ability of the Company to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical.

The Company derived around 93% of its total revenue from the international market, exposing it to the risk of foreign exchange currency fluctuation. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to U.S.A, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Though the Company tries to manage its risk via derivatives, the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by it and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the Company to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

Owing to the automation of processes and new machine learning capabilities, there is trend in IT companies to adopt new technologies and reduce manpower cost to increase its efficiency in delivery. Therefore, the ability of the group to remain in synchronization with the continuously evolving technology to remain competitive and price effective is critical. Also, the group runs the risk of uncertainty related to adequate revenue generation from the new products acquired/developed.

The employee attrition rate in the BPO industry in quite high. The companies are not able to convincingly retain their employees for long and thereby suffer huge losses every time they have to train new employees. The cost of hiring a new employee and training that person for the job is again time consuming and expensive. Further, one of the major challenges in BPO recruitment is to find the right talented workforce to work in the industry. During FY 2019, 2018 and 2017, the attrition rate for the Group?s employees who have completed six months of employment remained high at 31%, 29% and 34%, respectively.

The Indian IT-BPM industry is highly fragmented with more than 16,000 players and comprises of large multi-billion dollar companies, small domestic and global MNCs. Some of the major players include Genpact India Private Limited., Tata Consultancy Services BPO, Wipro BPO, Hinduja Global Solutions Limited., EXL Services, Aegis Limited., Convergys, Accenture, Concentrix and Sutherland Global Service amongst others. The traditional cost advantage of Indian companies is also becoming less relevant with the global majors such as Accenture, Cognizant, IBM, etc. significantly growing their base in India to exploit its low cost destinations nature. These companies earlier had a major orientation towards high end consulting and/or hardware, but trends towards ?Total Outsourcing Contracts? have compelled them to develop all round capabilities, to build in extended lock in with the client, further intensifying the competition. Therefore, the ability of the Group to retain its existing clients and add new clients, amidst high competitive environment, remains critical. However, sticky nature of BPM contracts and industry specific domain expertise reduces competition partially.
Emergence of other outsourcing destinations could pose a threat to scope of work in WNS India

Further, the culture & language of some of these nations (like Philippines) is much similar to the USA and therefore these are now increasingly preferred by US companies. The same could result in most of the work getting transferred from India to other outsourcing destinations thereby adversely affecting the revenues of the Company. The group would also be required to continuously make investments in these countries to extend its offshore network so as to avoid loss of work outsourced to these destinations.
Operations across the globe make the Group susceptible to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risks

The Group derives almost all of its revenues from UK, North America (primarily the USA), Australia, and other European markets (denominated in USD or GBP or AUD or Euro) while a significant portion of its payables are in INR (owing to India being the largest delivery center) exposing it to foreign exchange risk. Since over 50% of revenue, non-GAAP, is non-USD denominated, it poses a negative currency risk in a strong dollar environment.

Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, geo-political implosions, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to US, etc. For instance, BREXIT has resulted in a volatile pound sterling; the depreciation of the pound sterling in FY 2019 against the US dollar negatively impacted results of operations in FY 2019 and the appreciation of the pound sterling in FY 2018 against the US dollar positively impacted the results of operations in that year. Such volatility directly impacts WNS Group as approx. 30-40% of its revenues are denominated in pound sterling.

Moreover, the geo-political tensions have risen under Trump (president of the USA) administration with events such as China-US tariff wars which impair global trade and cause movements in global exchange rate. Accordingly, the exchange rates among the Indian rupee, the pound sterling and the US dollar have changed substantially in recent years and may fluctuate substantially in the future. Most of these recent factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates.

The Group has a partial natural hedge in terms of expenditure being incurred in the client?s local currency, and it also tries to manage its risk by entering into derivative contracts for its probable cash flows. However, there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Group and that actually received by them (in a particular quarter/year) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes the group to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile.

The Group derived approx. 27% of its revenues from its top 5 clients and approx. 44% of its revenues from top 10 clients. Given a client base of over 403, this exposes the Group to client concentration risks. The demographics of the customer including the default risk of the industry and country in which the customer operates is heightened due to this concentration risk. However, the concentration has reduced since FY 2018. The contribution of the single largest client declined sharply in FY 2018 and top 5 clients declined y-o-y during the review period and stood at about 6.90% and 27.10% respectively in FY 2019. As informed, the Group has undertaken conscious efforts to reduce concentration risk from top customers, increased number of customers in the USD 1-5 million ticket size (248 in FY 2017 to 278 in FY 2019), and expects to reduce further over the coming years.
Regulatory risk given the increasing scrutiny and stricter controls by regulatory authorities of developed countries

The increasing number of regulatory actions from the US Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) is emerging as a key risk for Indian pharmaceutical companies. Being into the pharmaceutical industry, with major exposure in the international regulated markets, the manufacturing facilities of the group are regularly monitored and approved by the regulatory authorities across the globe. These authorities have become more diligent with respect to the compliance and hence periodic audit is being conducted by the US FDA authorities for all its approved facilities. The Group has received alerts from regulatory authorities like USFDA, UK MHRA for its various facilities. It has received import alert (effectively a ban) for Waluj plant and Chikalthana plant from USFDA in May 2013 & November 2013, GMP alert for Waluj plant from UK MHRA in July 2013 and import alert on Ankleshwar plant in August 2016.

The evolving cGMP regulations have become stringent and the industry is striving unanimously to create world class capabilities to adhere to the mandates. Corrective measures for US FDA clearance are still in process with significant automation, technology upgrades and rollout of best practices at the manufacturing facilities. As indicated, the Group is monitoring the situation closely and is working with best of class consultants for resolution. Risk of regulatory quality compliance shall continue to remain critical.

The industry has been impacted by an unprecedented series of policy changes through the past year. The Government introduced the New Pricing Policy with the notification of the Drugs (Prices Control) Order, 2013 (DPCO 2013) which brought 850 formulations in the National List of Essential Medicines (NLEM) under price control. The National List of Essential Medicines (NLEM) is drawn up to include essential medicines that satisfy the priority health needs of the population.ÿThe NLEM 2015 contains 376 medicines on the basis of which the National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA) has fixed prices of over 800 formulations using the provisions of the DPCO. However, these formulations cover less than 10% of the total pharmaceutical market.ÿ The government is planning to cap the trade margins for highly priced drugs for cancer and rare diseases to bring down their prices in the wake of recent amendments to the DPCO that exempted patented medicines and rare disease drugs from price controls. Higher price controls could interrupt the business and have an adverse impact on the revenue of the group. The impact of the same can be seen in Q4 FY 2019 which affected the Indian market revenues. Hence, the Group?s operations are vulnerable to the domestic comparative scenario and change in government policies.

Wockhardt Group derived nearly 64% of its FY 2019 revenue from the overseas markets, exposing it to foreign exchange rate fluctuation risk. As informed, the Group does not hedge its foreign exchange exposure through derivatives. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to the USA, Brexit etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. Further, the group does not have any hedging mechanism and the fact that there could be a variation in the cash flows being projected/hedged by the Group and those actually received by it (in a particular quarter) coupled with the variation in the timing of receipt of those cash flows, exposes it to the risk of incurring losses on such derivative contracts, especially when the exchange rates are quite volatile. The risk is evident as the Group had incurred losses on forex transaction in all the three years ending FY 2019.
Slowdown in industry could impact the Company?s topline and margins

India?s economic growth fell to 5.8 per cent in the January-March period of FY 2019, the lowest in 20 quarters, due to a sharp slowdown in investment andÿmanufacturing growthÿas well as a contraction in agricultural production. This pulled down theÿgross domestic productÿ(GDP) expansion to 6.8 per cent in FY19, the slowest in the first stint of theÿModi government. Private final consumption expenditure growth fell to 7.2 per cent in the fourth quarter from 8 per cent in the third and 9.7 per cent in the second. The growth stood at a meager 7.3 per cent in the first quarter. Manufacturing activity suffered a slowdown, with growth falling to 3.1 per cent in Q4 compared to 6.4 per cent in the third quarter, 6.9 per cent in the second quarter and 12.1 per cent in Q1.ÿThe economy?s revival will be a key challenge under the new government. The industry slowdown too can impact the Company?s topline and margins as witnessed in a stagnant growth in Q1 of FY 2020 over the previous year. Despite, the capacity expansion, the Company is targeting a 10% revenue growth in FY 2020 in the wake of global slowdown.

The Company derived on an average more than 58% of its revenues from the international markets exposing it to foreign exchange risk. However, it enjoys the advantage of natural hedge (imports stood around 81% of the total purchase) to an extent. Movements in exchange rates are influenced by various macro factors like demand/ supply of the foreign currency, domestic inflation, deterioration in the financial condition of other economies relative to USA and due to events like Brexit, etc. Most of these factors are hard to predict leading to volatility in exchange rates. While the firming up of dollar in current scenario will have a positive sway on the profitability of the Company since majority of export is to the United States of America, any adverse movements in dollar rates going ahead will have undesirable ramifications on its margins. However, the Company has earned a profit on foreign exchange transactions in all the three years which largely supported the net margin.
As informed, the Company has hired Edelweiss Broking Limited to advice on the hedging policy and cushions itself from losses incurred on foreign exchange transactions.

The major raw material required by the Company to produce wide range of specialty and fine chemicals is hydroquinone amongst other 150 to 200 different chemicals and compounds. The Company procures around 81% of its total purchase requirement from international market viz. Japan, China, Singapore and USA. Prices of said materials depend upon the global demand & supply dynamics which are beyond the control of the Company. Cost of raw material constituted on an average about 68% of the total revenue during the review period and therefore, going forward, any adverse movement in the prices of raw materials could affect the margins of the Company, considering its limited flexibility to pass on the price hike owing to fairly competitive industry.

However, as informed by the management, the aforementioned risk is partially offset by its value added services extended to its customer?s viz. providing option to customize order in terms of quantity, formulation or any other related aspect.

The Indian chemical industry is fairly fragmented comprising of both small scale (unorganized) and large scale (organized) companies, in addition to presence of multinational companies. As informed by the management, it faces stiff competition from various companies in both domestic and overseas market from organized as well as unorganized sector. With Indian chemical industry currently contributing only 3% to GDP, it offers huge growth opportunities fueled by rising domestic consumption. This could attract more global corporations to capitalize on the growth story, further increasing the competition. Increasing competitive intensity could restrict the ability of the Company to scale its volumes and pass on the price hike to its customers (owing to pricing pressures), thus adversely affecting its revenue and profitability.

As informed by the management, the Company extends incentives like higher credit lines to its customers in order to remain competitive in the market and increase its ability to expand customer base. However, modest credit lines and high inventory holding period resulted in working capital intensive nature of operations and thereby leveraged capital structure. Also, the price rise of raw materials has to be at times absorbed by the Company due to competition, thereby impacting its profitability.
